Jeff's tip of the day though, nStuff..
Don't try to make your mixing sound great. Just mix it.. Cue it as best as
possible, But get it in on time no matter what.. Eventually you will adapt
yourself to have the dammed beats matched before your cue is up. Just don't
mis your cue nStuff.

Helps the world go around.

Message-Id: <199710011728.KAA15970@netcom23.netcom.com>
To: organic mind <om@dfw.net>
Cc: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: Re: New Aphex vid....and the complications of modern technology 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Tue, 30 Sep 97 17:00:59 MDT."
             <3.0.2.32.19970930170059.00873540@dfw.net> 
Date: Wed, 01 Oct 97 10:28:39 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


> hmm..  the audio came out in such a bad quality (maybe 8 bitz max) and the
> video is choppy..  guess you need a digital line to enjoy this or any
> online video/music.
> 
> i truely wish the chipmakers would engineer some rather ground breaking
> technology, this is more pain than pleasure nowadays.

even the most pathetic 100Mhz pentium (well, just about any pentium is
pathetic by design) can easily play back audio/video w/ relatively good
quality. the problem is that we have the technology but that the 
telecommunications infrastructure is not there -- we could easily all
have T1's going into our houses for like $25.00/month if it weren't for
the greed and stupidity of local telephone companies. we could easily
have satellite or cell-net infrastructure, or even cable-internet...
but every I-provider  is too busy milkiing every last dollar out of the
suckers who need these advanced technologies right now, keeping the
prices high enough that "everybody else" can't afford to get into the
game. at the same time, getting everybody else into the game is exactly
what is needed to lower prices. it's a chicken and egg problem,  while
the fox is guarding the henhouse, and right now, turkeys rule the
roost. :-)

don't worry, though, remember when cell-phones could only be afforded
by the yacht/jet-set? fast personal internet access will be there too
-- in about 5-10 years.

the other side of the problem is the software -- there is absolutely no
reason why the video/audio needs to be "realtime." I really couldn't
give a fuck if the bits streaming off some server are displaying 
themselves on my screen in synchrony. I'd be just as happy to download
a datafile before I go to sleep, and play it the next morning when I 
wake up, caching the data on my local disk drives as it streams in
overnight.

But noooooo, that's just too complicated. 

The only reason for needing "real" video/audio is if you're placing 
bets on sports events (or other stupid wastes of time), or doing
teleconferencing.

People need to snap out of that TV mindset that "live" is somehow
better than "memorex". "As it happens" need be nothing more than the
act of plugging in a Jaz drive ... that's all that is happening 
"back at the station" anyways...

Yes, you can try to make advances in compression, but those will 
always provide degraded media on playback. I don't expect huge 
advances to happen over the kinds of media compression we have
currently. The advances have to happen in our internet connectivity.
28-56Kbaud data streams over analog phone lines is just plain
ass-backwards right now, and that's going to have to change before
things get better.

 =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==>>                    Niels Mayer (mayer@netcom.com)                   <<==
 =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Hello Beautiful, diverse sfravers,
   As you all know, Wednesday just so happens to be the day where City 
Espresso in Santa Clara (408)248-4500) has dj's spin from 8:00pm-10:00, 
while I make your coffee drinks :( It's not that I don't like to do 
that, it's just a lot more fun being on the other side of the counter.  
However, business has been going down the drain on Wed. nights, for what 
reason, I don't know.  We at City E do this to let people of all ages 
come out, drink coffee and socialize.  The use of illegal substances at 
a coffee shop, well, it is pretty stupid and it has been happenning...so 
Please don't bring anything of that genre, just bring your smiles, your 
comuter mug, and your hearts and have a great time.  If anyone in our 
employ, wether working or not sees someone selling, using, throwing, 
jumping on, waving, looking at, drugs etc, etc,  This event will no 
longer happen. So please help spread the word to not do that and also 
please be respectful of the property, use the garbage cans please. We'll 
see you all tonight and I promise to be in a better mood  :P

So everyone come out and have a good time otay?

Yor Friend,
Danny

P.S.
don't forget your...

Slinky

Received: from SONOMA.EDU by SONOMA.EDU (PMDF V5.1-8 #26271)
 id <01IOAMLV9V3Q90O1UC@SONOMA.EDU> for sfraves@hyperreal.org; Wed,
 1 Oct 1997 14:02:03 PDT
Date: Wed, 01 Oct 1997 14:02:03 -0700 (PDT)
From: Doreen <COSTAD@SONOMA.EDU>
Subject: my night last night (petaluma bowling alley)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-id: <01IOAMLVA4QW90O1UC@SONOMA.EDU>
X-VMS-To: SMTP%"sfraves@hyperreal.org"
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

ok, so me and some friends decided to go check out this party at a 
petaluma bowling alley where some dj's were spinning.  my motivation 
was to hear rinse, which was accomplished.

rinse spun a helluva set, i danced my ass off. but check it: security 
were dicks.

1)we first arrived, when to go do something, came back to the car to
get our smokes and whatever, security rolls up and says "just so you
know, you can't hang out at your car...." we're like "we just got
here, we're going IN". ok, sorry mr. officer, we'll get a move on.  i 
handled that very politely and wouldn't have even broughten it up 
again ever but then...

2)i was playing pool and i got caught drinking a sip of beer that
wasn't mine.  i look up, there's mr. officer again asking for my id.
i tel him it's in the car (being underage sucks) so he's all "i saw
you take a drink of that.  you don't have any id, you don't have a
wristband, now you have to LEAVE".  luckily my friend who had
boughten the beer distracted the focus from me, i was able to stay.
thank god too cuz rinse hadn't even come on yet.  ok, i realize that
was my bad, i wasn't sly, i deserved atleast a warning.  but...

3)after dancing with some fellow jungle lovers down near the alleys,
i decided to exchange digits with them.  so we walk up to the lotto
machine thingy cuz there was a pen and some paper.  i proceeded to
tear off some paper, write my # on it, and gave it to my new found
friends.  as i stuffed the folded paper in my pocket, security was
right there again, asking me just what exactly i had rolled up and
put in my pocket.  i said "a phone number".  they say "then do you
mind if we take a look?"  i flaunt the scribbled wrinkled paper in
their face and say "SEE?" gawd, whatdoilooklike?  a criminal(raver)?
so they eyeballed me the rest of the night, waiting for me to 'slip
up' or something...whatever.
just wanted to voice my frustration.
-doreen. "opressed"  :) j/k

From: shindog @ newwavecity.com @ internet
Date: 09/30/97 08:24 PM
Subject: (event 10/4) New Wave City dance party (fwd)

This monthly dance party has been around for five years, and draws a
cool crowd who dig the "old new wave"...

WHAT:  NEW WAVE CITY - Salute Night to the Cure
        Dancing to New Wave music of the late 70^Rs and early 80^Rs
        DJ^Rs Shindog and Skip

WHEN: Saturday, October 4, 9pm-3am

WHERE: King Street Garage, 174 King, San Francisco

        cover charge: $5 til 10pm, $8 after, 21 and over
        Information line: 415/675-LOVE
        Web site:  http://www.newwavecity.com
        (Enter to win free admission on our website!)


SALUTE TO THE CURE - One of the most popular acts of the New Wave City
crowd is the Cure, who get salute treatment at this event with extra
doses of their music throughout the night, including a full half hour of
classic Cure at midnight.  As a special tease for giveaways for the next
event (see below), we will have a box set of the new Cure collection
Galore for a lucky New Waver.  The influence of the Cure and its leader
Robert Smith has been significant ever since their beginnings in the
late seventies, in the textures of their music, their thoughtful, often
gloomy lyrics, and the visual appeal of big, teased jet black hair. 
We^Rll have it all at New Wave City for this night... what could be
better?
----------------COMING SOON--------------------------
WHAT: NEW WAVE CITY - Special Halloween Event
        Dancing to New Wave music of the late 70^Rs and early 80^Rs
        DJ^Rs Shindog and Skip
WHEN: Friday, October 31, 9pm-3am
WHERE: King Street Garage, 174 King, San Francisco

The event will feature an 80's costume contest, salute to Duran Duran
and giveaways for their new release Medazzaland, and giveaways for the
new Cure collection Galore.  More details to be announced.

the studio -  or at least that's what i heard...

Thanks, for the info. I'll check out the URL.I agree with your opinion
regarding criminalization of GHB. As far as other drugs go, you probably
already know this, but others may not, in Holland where marijuana is
legal, their young people smoke it a lot less than young people in
Britain or the U.S., where it's illegal.
	Also, in Switzerland they sell heroin at pharmaceutical prices to
addicts. This results in lower crime rates because they don't become
desparate. It also results in them being healthier because they don't
get AIDS from sharing needles, which means that the tax payer doesn't
have to pay for their medical expenses. One would think that at least
this part of the solution would appeal to Republicans. 
	Of course, just because decriminalization works in those countries
doesn't mean that it will work here, but at least we should be open to
discussions about it. So much drug hysteria...
	On another topic, I went to Ultra on Monday. After being unemployed for
a month I started a new job on Wednesday, so I figured Monday night
would be my last chance to go out. So first, I went to Corazon at the
Elbo Room, where they were playing very good latin music. There was only
about 15 people upstairs though, so since I like big crowds, I went to
VSF after that. I had never been to a club that played strictly drum n'
bass. I must say that it's not my favorite type of music, but since I
can't help moving I was out on the dance floor moving my feet, gyrating
my body, and flailing my arms.
As far as Peshay goes, like I said it's not my favorite type of music,
but the crowd seemed quite appreciative and excited about him.

sent december 27th at four thirty-three pm

      damn you.
      my technique is the best.
      my boss is the best.
      damn you.  i know rdist technique,
      i know sendmail technique,
      and my style is much better.

      my style is the best.

result
> of the rape

Hello,

A friend of mine at the graduate school of Journalism at UC Berkeley is
writing an article about the cancellation of Cyberfest and the relationship
between members of the scene (promoters and participants) and the
"authorities" in the Bay Area.  If you feel inspired, it would help her
greatly to hear your thoughts on the following questions:

*How do you think the authorities/law enforcement agencies percieve the
rave/electronic music scene?

*How is the mainstreaming of electronic music changing the kind of people 
attending raves?

*What percentage of raves in the Bay Area would you estimate get shut down,
and for what reasons (both as perceived by participants and law enforcement
officials- is there a discrepancy?) ?

Please respond to platonik@rosebud.berkeley.edu

Thanks!

> activity, the more unusual the better...

What I do for non-raving fun -

1. Couch potato stuff
 - Read ( Terry Pratchett fantasy humor, popular science, misc )  
 - Watch cable TV ( PBS, Mystery Science Theater 3000, various SF stuff,
   Mr. Bean )
 - Internet ( Web surfing for info and smut. Reading and answering
   email. )
 - Design things with paper, pencil, and calculator that I sometimes 
   don't quite get around to actually building, like subwoofer cabinets.
 - Music - I'd like to listen to more , but I've been hindered recently 
   by moving residences. I just got a used CD ROM last night that has
   a fun little sample mixing program on it - much fun!

2. Really active stuff
 - Gee - raving is pretty much it! I'm not a sportsperson , not even
   hiking.

3. Not so active stuff
 - Doing stuff with my wife ( movies, restaurants, etc. ) 

Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

I was at a party a few months back (party in your pants) that was really
good.. and there was a DJ from Santa Cruz named TOM who spun some really
good stuff that I remember sounding similarly to what you've described.
... kinda fast, break beaty, trancy......   I think a lot of people spin
this kinda stuff... harder housy-trance with breaks. Some poeple refer to
different genres differently..... so it's difficult to track sometimes...


Hope that helps???

Byroni

Go see a movie (liked Contact, if it's still playing, plus it kills extra
time as it is a long flick, only got chessy towards the end, but that's
more than I can say for most movies out there).

Go meet some non ravers... some of them are okay.

Start a religion.

Figure out your financial situation.

Do your laundry.

Clean your room.

Buy some groovy space age bachelor pad furniture.

Write really long responses to old Email on SFRaves.

Get in an arguement with your significant other.

Make up with your SO.

Get an SO.

Masturbate several times in rapid succession until you're in pain.

Sleep.

Watch Gomer Pyle.

Work overtime.

Take a trip on public transportation, even if you do have a car.

Walk.

Bike.

Hike.

Take a psychedelic by yourself.

Read a book.

Learn to sew.

Learn to spin.

Start the great american novel.

Quit smoking.

Invite a friend over for a three course meal, just for being them.

Clean up the house.

Start a garden.

Visit or call a sick friend or relative.

Go to a used record/cd store and by some stuff you've never really 
listened to before (jazz, classical, bluegrass, swing).

Get drunk.

Write poetry.

Get drunk AND write poetry (it worked for Bukowski, it worked for
Morrison).

Start a journal.

Draw.

Paint.

Help throw a party.

Go garage saling (who knows... there might be one of those $5 303's out
there still).

Write music.

Record your ideas onto a tape, and put it somewhere you won't look for a
while.  Ten years from now you'll be glad you did.

Work overtime.

Check other job listings.

Open up your old high school/college textbooks and see how much higher
math you remember.

Pass by a local community center and see what's up on the bulletin boards.

Play pool.

Go to a rally or protest.

Go swimming (will be cold soon).

Work on your car/motorcycle.

Get a haircut.

Make a collage to hang on your wall.

Do something with all those flyers you have.

Wash your car.

Go shopping.  I didn't just say that.

Go for a walk on the beach by yourself in a sportcoat with a T shirt under
it, like Crocket and Tubbs used to on those 2 hour special episodes of
Miami Vice.

Go purchase a sound system (not recommended... this will continue to eat
money).

Miniature golfing.

Bowling.

Batting cage (visualize the boss's head young Luke)

Learn C in 24 hours (yeah right)

Go to Fry's and buy something flaky... try to get it to work... now try to
return it.

Play chicken with your bong.

Look through the classifieds.

Try and find some long lost friends from high school or earlier via the
internet.

Trace your genealogy.

Visit www.word.com/gigo this is one of the greatest wastes of time I have
ever seen.  www.leisuretown.com is pretty up there too.

Do upgrades on your house.

Throw a house party.

Look for some old music, and play it.  Boy, did I ever have fun when I
found Too Fast for Love by Motley Crue in my garage last weekend... I
remembered that stuff being so much faster.  Now, I must find Twisted
Sister's Stay Hungry on vinyl... if only for the sample... what do you
want to do with your life... I want to rock.

Listen to Beatles records backwards, or out of one speaker.  Favorite
finds include "Same as it will ever be, Lucifer..." from SgtPepper's (Brit
import only)... some French Children's song in the background of
"paperback writer"... and the plethora of good stuff in Revolution 9.

Go to Guitar Center, buy a four track, record a really trippy answering
machine message, then return it.

Try to invent a new food.

Pull a condom over your showerhead, hold it on, and slowly turn the water
on.  This just looked so cool, I had to mention it.  Don't ask how we
happened upon this data...

Sew up any ripped clothes you might have.

Weed out any socks with holes, or any underwear you wouldn't want to be
caught in.

Go to a nice restaurant and try somthing new.

Go to a massive or a smaller party, whatever you don't usually do.

Take a guitar to the desert and play crap and sing really loud.

Make up with an old rival.

Be healthy for a day, avoid meat, eat smart just to see if you feel
different.

Dedicate a day to sensory deprivation.  Walk around the house blindfolded
and see how well you do.  Bonus points for using sounds to echo locate
upcoming walls.  Fun activities include pouring water, and urinating while
standing up.  Take a bath in lukewarm water with headphones on (walkman
running on batteries only please) and a blindfold... for added fun drink
some really strong coffee first.  Or combine with the do psychedlics by
yourself theme.

See, I was a latch key kid, and I would get really bored.  After a while, 
I realized I didn't have to be bored.  I now see life through a new pair
of eyes... you can fuck with everything.

Peace,
AndyW

Subject: Re: Who Does BreakTrance ?
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

the combination of break beat and trance seems to be one of the new genres
popping up.  Kind of how this so called speed garage thing has become more
popular.  I think it's just people trying to deny the pull of strait up
JUNGLE!! (that remark is tounge and cheek so be nice) anyways, working here
at the local trance and jungle hub, I think I can leed you towards some
breaktrance...

Psy-Harmonics from Australia were just here and played a party at 115 minna,
I didn't go because after almost puking from breathing in other peoples
sweat at the Richie Hawtin party a couple of weeks ago I couldn't deal, but
they played a lot of their own new music, which Adam here @ Hunab Ku says is
'kind of psychedelic eclectic anything goes, mixing up a variety of
psychedelic styles i.e breakbeat, jungle, and polyrythmic trance'. this
seems to be the new direction many trance labels are going for.

If your looking for vinyl, check out anything on 21-3, and some on Psy
Harmonics, Blue Room and even TIP the Goa originators!

On CD there's a new one called Galaxy Tribe on Magik Eye.  It's more like
atmosheric-psychedelic D&B. (they have them at HouseWares)

Also I've been hearing Cieba's tracks in progress coming out of the studio,
that's some serious breaktrance! that will be released on the next Language
of Light CD due out B4 winter solstice.

I just heard that Space Station Russ (HK, Silver Palm Leaf, & Cieba
collaborating) is going to start a psychedelic eclectic monthly called
Wierd, you'll have to listen to trance but a lot of it will be break style!

hope it helps!
Peace*Lyndsay

(call for press listing for our last CD/12" releases - thanks to all the
writers/reviewers that gave Silent a second listen...)

Vinyl is not dead... Oh yeah... to get sound samples go to our web page :)

Look for more of the San Francisco sound on wax and shiny silver things...

*Solstice-TBA                   SR9717 (360/Silent)      July 30th       12"
Jazzed-up, street tough loungey music which has Gina's vocals in top form
mesmerizing... Expect to hear more from these talented kids...

*VA-Skulpture & Broken Sound    SR9720 (Silent)          Aug 15th        2XCD
The ying and the yang of hip-hop meet as one half brings you the twisted,
sparse and austere face of hip-hop while the other assaults you with the
turntable wizardry of some of the best fucking up said avant-hop...

*VA-Lower Haight High Hitters   UNKNOWN ORIGIN            ????           12"
Take your super-secret project by some pretty high-profile suckers and add
your usual portions of house music creativity and fun... Viola... the
souffle is ready...

Some of the best straight up techno west of Carl Craig, Stacey Pullen, Ian
Pooley, Derrick May, etc. All of whom are dropping it in their sets...


*VA-East Bay Conspiracy EP     SR9713 (Trip'N'Spin)      July 2nd        12"
Featuring the likes of ETI, Jondi & Spesh, Nick Kelly & Cave Dwellers...
A intense contribution to the San Francisco/West Coast House Movement
Deconstruction meets Hardkiss

i guess breaktrance is one of the new labels.. dunno how long people have
been calling it that, but they been spinning it in frisco way back in 92
,kinda a groundbreaking time period.. but in essence.. the best sets are
always heard live and never heard memorex..  that means most of the djs who
spin the tru style seldom ever puts it on recording and saves it for the
dancefloor to keep us off our asses.

organic mind (omzkfc2000)

OOoo, if this isn't flame bait I dunno what is.

Miccaela jumps on the bandwagon:

"Kraftwerk SUCKS!!!  Yeah!"

Just kidding folx.  Jeez.  Stop brandishing those glowstix!

But I like Grandmaster Flash.  Not necessarily because of the music he plays 
(although I was one of those "little G's" @ Planet Rock I guess--sported a 
beanie that night and I danced to his set) but because without him and a 
couple other legendary djs and artists this scene would be nonexistent.  We'd 
all be doing the tootsie roll (old skool!) or line-dancing or something.  Not 
that that's bad.

But everyone is entitled to their own opinion, yes?

xoxo--Miccaela

Too bad you live in SF . . . I'm right there with you!

Things to do in _Sac_ besides rave:
1.  Poetry readings
2.  Clubs (much different than raving, I don't care what you say)
3.  Picnics
4.  Movies
5.  Live music (usually not techno but that's not at all a bad thing)
6.  Arrive unexpectedly at friend's houses and keep them up all night
7.  Read a book
8.  Study
9.  Crash parties
10.  Eat
11.  Learn to dance (ballroom, line dance, salsa, swing)
12.  Get another job
13.  Shop
14.  Work out
15.  Whole lot of other stuff I can't think of

So I know if there's that much to do _here_, the city's gotta be full of stuff 
to do.

----------

gee i'm a little bored installing w95 on my fifth computer today. 
from floppies.  so i thought i'd throw a poser at youse guys.  i'm

i thought i'd give it a rest this weekend so as not to burn out.  so
the question is, what to do?  what do you folx do for fun when you
aren't raving?  i've already seen a drag show or two, been to most of
the museums, watched the hippies in the park, and i'm sicker of bars
than i am of raves.  i know the city has way more to offer, i just
gotta find it.  i'm particularly looking for some sort of friday night

The good stuff is spread throughout the weekend - from tonight thru
Sunday - finishing up with Stompy.  In the weeklies, there's more 
drum n bass than ever, and plenty of new and old events.

Directions for subscribing and unsubscribing are at the bottom, as
usual, as well as directions for submitting event info (basically
send it back to this address...)

                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Thursday, October 2nd - _Hiatus_
   Garth, Jeno, Carlos, Resin (live).
   free giveaways - water pipes, snowboard, dubtribe & mark farina CDs,
   Halloween Ball tix.
   10pm-4am, 21+, $8. VSF, 278 11th St @ Folsom, SF.
   
   Friday, October 3rd - Intervene Productions presents _A Free Beach Party_
   Bloom, Tune, Mes, Abdul, Seanie Boy, Tim.
   510.988.7447 510.553.4250

   J.Sinister of K.O.T. feat Julie McKnight (live), Frankie Bones
   (Brooklyn), Scott Richmond (NYC), Jon Bishop (SD), Hipp-E (Denver),
   Marshal Villarosa (NJ), Pete Avila, Garth, Jeno, Simon, James Reed
   (Dreamer), Joe Lanzon, Pat Allen, Saucee.

   $6. 415.905.8873
   
   Saturday, October 4th - Blasthaus presents Cosmosis
   CoMA 97 festival finale party - futuristic entertainment in
   experimental electronic music
   Reza (live ambient), Aquanaut (The Mist), Solar, Pollywog, Push (Step2k).
   video by Guy Overfelt, light sculptures by Milton Komisar, "Radical
   Beauty" presentation by Nick Philip.
   9pm-3am, $10. 415.789.7690
   
   Saturday, October 4th - Windowpane and Lightseed Productions presents
        _Dragonfly Festival_
   A benefit for Russian River Water Shed and Surf Rider Foundation
   DJ Damian, Vajra, Dovegate, many special guest DJs and live
   performances.
   Presale tix $7 at F-8 (Haight), Backdoor Disk and Tape (Cotati),
   People's Music (Sebastopol), The Last Record Store (Santa Rosa).
   Other attractions and exhibitions, fine organic foods, microbrewed
   beers.
   As a safety precaution, no dogs please!
   10am- $7. Russian River. 707.869.2216

   Rosal, Wunjo, Patrick Dream (Montreal). $5 b4 10pm. opens on Monday,
   Oct.6., every other Monday thereafter.
   8:30pm-3:30am, 21+, $7. 1015 Folsom St, SF.
   
  Tuesday
  
   _Eclectic_ - house, jungle, drum & bass w/DJs Yamu, Siege, Franko,
   Foster, guests. Fresh fruit & condoms to all
   9pm-2am, 21+. Paradise Bar & Grill, 5356 College Ave, Oakland.
   
   _Rhythm_ - house, techno w/DJs Daniel, Stevian, Mark Willson, Mark
   Silva, live congas by Brian, guests. 9pm-2am, 21+, Free. Greg's Bar,
   551 W.Julian/Montgomery, San Jose. 408.286.4388
   
   _Pure_ - house w/DJs Brian Brandon, guests. 9pm-, 18+. The Rage, 1890
   Arden Way, Sacramento. 916.929.0232
   
   Static - Techno, Drum & Bass, Downtempo, Electro w/DJs ReAch, Quantum,
   Brad, Darin Marshall, Sutekh, guests. 10pm-2am, $2. 2925 16th @ S Van
   Ness, SF.
   
   _Get Energy_ - an evening of energetic fusion w/DJs Mark Farina. 21+,
   $5. V/SF, 278 11th St @ Folsom, SF. 415.635.6906
   
   _Influx_ - Mike Bee, Gabe Real, Steven Tune, guests. 10pm-, 21+, $5.
   DNA Lounge, 375 11th St, SF.
   
   Tryptafunk - A Virtual Burning Man every Tuesday night! w/DJs Channel
   23 (live), Abstract, Goldilox, Steve Pagan, more TBA. Ritual fire
   performances, dancers, puppetry.
   8:23pm- $5. 314 11th St, SF. 415.824.9023
   
   _Sedate Grooves_ - downbeat, drum'n'bass, breaks, hip hop and weird
   noises w/DJs David, Erik (Phunkatech), weekly guests. 10pm-2am, 21+,
   $3. the Top, 424 Haight St, SF.
   
   _Move_ - house w/DJs DJ Josh, guests weekly. 9pm-2am, 21+, $5. 1028
   Geary @ Polk, SF.
   
   _Outside_ - techno w/DJs Kevin Kind, Kwashi, weekly guests. All ages,
   $5. , SF 415.340.5607

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 8pm-10pm - "Soundz of Resistance" w/DJ Poohbear.
       Underground electronic music, mainly jungle/drum and bass, dub and
       hard techno along with guest DJs, interviews and not-so-random
       amples of life. KZSC 88.1 (Santa Cruz)
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. The
       best in beats to satiate your inner child. Electronic dance,
       noise, spoken word, world music and more. Also available in
       RealAudio. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 5pm-9pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of jungle, dub,
       breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon and guests -
       Beats, Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford). Also broadcast via
       RealAudio.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
   For a _search_ interface to the calendar, see the Late Train club
   section (http://www.latetrain.com/clubs/).
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.org with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.org with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.org

was at basics back in June.  I used to have her pager number but i can't find it
dammit. Oh well I know she was living in Concord but moved to half moon bay.

happened to her I would greastly appreciate it.

them all summer but to my dismay I have not.  I wish i could remember their 
names but I can't.  But if you have met any of them you would know who I am 
referring to. About 20 kick ass kids who go trek up here from fresno to go to
parties.

sooo if any of ya have some info that would be great

Hi kids!  I just wanted to ask for some opinions.  I just wanted to get you
Sf Ravers to do some thinking.  I thought that this might get all you that
are signed up but never post to add in your thoughts.  (you know who you are
:-)!!)  If you all could post your favorite music and your favorite DJ I
would totally love it!  I think it is so interesting to see the diversity in
people's opinions.  I have my own favorites but I always find it interesting
to hear others.  Just to get you all going I wiil post my favorites  :-)

I LOVE:  Joey Beltram, Danny the Wild Child, and Kid Bippy~*~

I also LOVE:  Micron, Deeks, and Maya 13  ( I also like Macadio although I
haven't heard him spin too many times!!!  I always miss his set some how.)

I am a big fan of Techno and JUNGLE!!!

Thanks to anyone that posts and I'll be listening for your DJ's!!  See you on
the scene!

From: sddpw@sirius.com (Shimako-Dominguez Department of Public Works)
Subject: want to help a good cause?
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

SDDPW is looking for a few happy, helpy people who would like to do a good turn.

We are putting on a benefit for Maitri AIDS Hospice on Sunday, October 19,
1997, in San Francisco and need a few people to help promote the event.

Promoters should be very familiar with the bay area rave/club scene and
associated retail outlets where flyers are usually left/found.

No pay associated with this task, but....
1.  You'll be stacking up loads of karma
2.  Of course, you'll be on the guest list for the party
3.  If you're a good promoter, it can usually get you into any party,
especially when they know you're doing it for a benefit.
4.  It might actually lead to paying jobs for future SDDPW events.

So you know what you are getting into, Maitri is an AIDS hospice in San
Francisco, started by buddhist monks.  Well, they're moving to new digs as
part of a program to be one of the few bay area hospices that accept triple
diagnosis patients (these are people with HIV, addiction issues, and mental
illness).  The move is costing plenty, so we are doing our part to help
raise funds by throwing this benefit.

Because the party is coming up in less than three weeks, we need people
soon.  If interested, please e-mail back to this address, but put "My Tree
House" in the subject.  Or, you may call 415.864.7448 and leave a message
for Rob.

Thanks....

Rob
SDDPW










Shimako-Dominguez Department of Public Works (SDDPW)
http://www.sirius.com/~sddpw
415.864.7448

SDDPW is a cooperative venture in art, commerce and the pursuit of
happiness.

>Q: What do Pink Floyd and Lady Di have in common?
>A: Both had a hit with the  wall.

**************************************

>A herd of buffalo can only move as fast as the slowest buffalo, and
>when  the herd is hunted, it is the slowest and weakest ones at the back
>that are killed  first. This natural selection is good for the herd as a
>whole,
>because the general speed and health of the whole keeps improving by
>the regular culling of the weakest members.
>
>In much the same way, the human brain can operate only as fast as the
>slowest brain cells.  Excessive intake of alcohol, we all know, kills
off
>brain cells, but naturally it attacks the slowest and weakest brain
cells
>first. In this way, regular consumption of beer eliminates the weaker
cells,
>constantly making the brain a faster and more efficient machine.
>
>The results of this in-depth epidemiological study verifies and
>validates  the causal link between all-weekend parties and work
>performance. It also explains why, after a few short years of leaving
>university and getting married, most people cannot keep up with the
>performance of the new graduates. Only those few that stick to the
strict
>regimen of voracious alcoholic consumption can maintain the intellectual
>levels that they achieved during their university years.
>
>So, this is a call to arms.  As our country is losing its technological
>edge we should not shudder in our homes. Get back into the bars!
>Quaff that pint!  Your company and country need you to be at your peak,
>and you shouldn't deny yourself the career that you could have.
>
>Be all that you can be.

Jeff, you are fucking brilliant.

You know that is exactly what I believe?  I figure if there's a higher power, 
whether it be God, Buddha, Allah, or Josh Wink (hey, he could be God), if 
they're the type who will fuck me over because I don't believe in him/her/it 
and detest organized religion in general, whatever then, fuck him/her/it, for 
I have no respect for a god like that.  I don't tolerate _humans_ like that, a 
supreme being has no damn excuse IMHO.

Matter of fact, since I don't believe in god or religion in general, I don't 
believe in heaven, hell, the ten commandments, karma, or anything like that.  
I don't do what I consider bad or immoral things because I want to be a good 
person, not because I'm afraid of going to hell or bad karma or something.  
Doesn't that make me better than a person who does good things just because 
they believe if they don't they'll be punished for it later on?  Do you see 
what I'm saying?  I figure I should be a fuckin VIP in heaven for being nice 
for no reason.

But Jeff,  I just had to tell you that because what you said is something I 
believe very deeply and strongly, and I wanted to give you props.  Right on.

And if I offended anyone who is religious, sorry.  What you believe is not 
wrong (how the hell would I know), I just don't agree with it.

xoxo--Miccaela

I used to believe the same as you do, Miccaela.  I despised the religeons, 
especially those who would condem you for not believing in 'their' God.  At 
best I beleived I was agnostic.  I would ask my family questions like:
If God is all powerfull, he knows all the decesions we will make, or has 
made them for us.  If this is so, why are we 'tested' here on earth? and how 
can we be held responsible for our actions, such as murdering some one, 
raping etc, when it was "God's decision that we do these actions"?  Or how 
can a man command God to excommunicate some one?  I wouldn't think an all 
powerfull being wouldn't  like to be told what to do, and isn't He capable 
of making his own decisions about the fate of a 'soul'?
For bringing these questions up I was called blasphemous etc.  no one i 
could talk to would carry an 'intelligent' discussion about the subject of 
God without resorting to attacking my charactor or using the phrase (my 
favorite) "God works in mysterious ways....."

This summer i took a philosophy intro class at Sam Mateo CC.  it was really 
enlightening.  I wish i could take more.  it really let me explore the 
subject of God, religion, the way we should live (Ten Commandments) and 
metaphysical ideas about reality without all the perversions that religions 
add on to the idea of "God".

Now, I think the Bible is a good 'reference book' of tales and learning 
experiences - perhaps even a documantation of some historical events.  But 
that's it.  people take it too far.  My feeling is that if  God did write 
some of the scriptures (such as creation) he was trying to explain it in 
very simple terms.  Don't forget when this book was 'written', people had a 
hard time even understanding concepts such as air ('how can you be 
surrounded by something you can't even see?).  but that ends my defense to 
the Bible.
i do beleive in an energy (karma, whatever) that surrounds and flows within 
us.  You can call it God, so long as you don't assign It to a religion.  I 
prefer to think of it as a Force (yes like star wars, a little korny but it 
is the closest most recognizable idea to mine besides calling it a GOD).  i 
would love to discuss it more, but i am already writing too much.  let me 
know if you want to being up that topic.
anyway.  i better end this.  i would encourage you to take a phil. class (if 
you already have, i'd like to hear your thoughts on it).  it won't convert 
you to anything, but it will enlighten you to different opinions that have 
been developed over the past 3,000 years-a wealth of knowledge to say the 
least.  and, who knows, maybe you'll find some ideas you like and may even 
unlock some ideas you have lodged deep inside yourself.  self exploration is 
always good, what's a better thing to learn about than yourself?

Thomas
B-)

Jeff, you are fucking brilliant.

You know that is exactly what I believe?  I figure if there's a higher 
power,
whether it be God, Buddha, Allah, or Josh Wink (hey, he could be God), if
they're the type who will fuck me over because I don't believe in him/her/it 

and detest organized religion in general, whatever then, fuck him/her/it, 
for
I have no respect for a god like that.  I don't tolerate _humans_ like that,
a
supreme being has no damn excuse IMHO.

Matter of fact, since I don't believe in god or religion in general, I don't 

believe in heaven, hell, the ten commandments, karma, or anything like that. 

I don't do what I consider bad or immoral things because I want to be a good 

person, not because I'm afraid of going to hell or bad karma or something.
Doesn't that make me better than a person who does good things just because
they believe if they don't they'll be punished for it later on?  Do you see
what I'm saying?  I figure I should be a fuckin VIP in heaven for being nice 

for no reason.

But Jeff,  I just had to tell you that because what you said is something I
believe very deeply and strongly, and I wanted to give you props.  Right on.

And if I offended anyone who is religious, sorry.  What you believe is not
wrong (how the hell would I know), I just don't agree with it.

xoxo--Miccaela

one word yfor ya:

OPRESSION


doreeeeeeeen you shady character ;)

On Wed, 1 Oct 1997, Doreen wrote:

> ok, so me and some friends decided to go check out this party at a 
> petaluma bowling alley where some dj's were spinning.  my motivation 
> was to hear rinse, which was accomplished.
> 
> rinse spun a helluva set, i danced my ass off. but check it: security 
> were dicks.
> 
> 1)we first arrived, when to go do something, came back to the car to
> get our smokes and whatever, security rolls up and says "just so you
> know, you can't hang out at your car...." we're like "we just got
> here, we're going IN". ok, sorry mr. officer, we'll get a move on.  i 
> handled that very politely and wouldn't have even broughten it up 
> again ever but then...
> 
> 2)i was playing pool and i got caught drinking a sip of beer that
> wasn't mine.  i look up, there's mr. officer again asking for my id.
> i tel him it's in the car (being underage sucks) so he's all "i saw
> you take a drink of that.  you don't have any id, you don't have a
> wristband, now you have to LEAVE".  luckily my friend who had
> boughten the beer distracted the focus from me, i was able to stay.
> thank god too cuz rinse hadn't even come on yet.  ok, i realize that
> was my bad, i wasn't sly, i deserved atleast a warning.  but...
> 
> 3)after dancing with some fellow jungle lovers down near the alleys,
> i decided to exchange digits with them.  so we walk up to the lotto
> machine thingy cuz there was a pen and some paper.  i proceeded to
> tear off some paper, write my # on it, and gave it to my new found
> friends.  as i stuffed the folded paper in my pocket, security was
> right there again, asking me just what exactly i had rolled up and
> put in my pocket.  i said "a phone number".  they say "then do you
> mind if we take a look?"  i flaunt the scribbled wrinkled paper in
> their face and say "SEE?" gawd, whatdoilooklike?  a criminal(raver)?
> so they eyeballed me the rest of the night, waiting for me to 'slip
> up' or something...whatever.
> just wanted to voice my frustration.
> -doreen. "opressed"  :) j/k
>

Dilbert's Office Prayer

Grant me the serenity
To accept the things
I cannot change;
The courage to change the things 
I cannot accept;
And the wisdom to hide the bodies 
of those people I had to kill
today because they pissed me off. 
And also,
Help me to be careful
Of the toes I step on today as they 
May be connected to the butt
That I might have to kiss tomorrow.

since _everyone_ on this list has decided to reply to this post, i guess
i have to do the same. not that i mind or anything! ;) actually, this is
a really neat way to get to know each other. sure, it doesn't come close
to actually _talking_ to each other irl, but hey...nothing in this world
is perfect! =)

anyway, here are my favorite djs and acts:

***djs***

robert leiner (sweden, the man behind the project "the source")
david (sweden, the man spins the most amazing 5 hour sets you'll ever
        hear!)
cari lekebusch (sweden, look for him on planet rhythm releases)
frankie bones (i know i'm not alone on this one, just ask mars and
                mystr-e)
josh wink (live, _not_ on tape or cd. he's the bomb when he's playful)
paul oakenfold (the man who brought goa trance to the western world)
commander tom
carl cox
tony de vit
sasha (a few years ago, he's lost it by now...)

and the amazing locals:

micron (dan for president!)
macadio
drc (girl power? *smile*)
uncle noah (so he's not really a local, but i still love him!)
kid bippy ("i wanna kiss myself - dominator dominator" old skool 4ever!)

***acts***

kraftwerk

that should be it. but hey, there are a few other acts that have meant
a lot to me...

depeche mode
yazoo/erasure (vince clarke's projects after he left depeche in 81)
star pilot on channel k (s.p.o.c.k)
page (ask jupiter to play you something by them, he has all my cds)
the orb (if you've seen my tattoo you should know this...)
klf (their comeback show was weird, but still awesome!!!)
howie b (so what if he sold out and started producing u2, he's still a
        god when it comes to making ambient music...)
frank sinatra
emmanuel top (and i'm not just talking about "seven days and one week")
pablo gargano (the man behind basically everything on eve records)
dr dre
a tribe called quest
notorious big
mary j blige
erykah badu

and the list goes on and on...

much love to all of you. i hope to see you all soon! =)

jonas the happy spaceboy.

I have to give peter (boomerang) props for the way that he answered
this question.  I like different dj's for different reasons, some kick
my ass, some take my head and won't give it back for 2 hours, while
others are just fun.  i even like some house dj's.  =P

let's see....

jungle...
re-ach
science
siphon..though i'm not sure what u played at play nice...j/k

originality..
mr. boomerang fidget
andy w.

kicks ass....
li
macadio (minus the big-head, which i'm sure is currently inflating)
ernie deaks
ethan

perfect for the morning
cloud
drenalin

sfraves faves...
vertigo
todd manley (one tall mutha)

and i like the old wicked crew for turning me on to some funky and
trancey house.

and i must also give props to anyone who has EVER gotten the balls or
ovaries to get behind the decks and try to turn people on to their
sound.

on a side note...i love dj's that have their own sound and are
original...keep it coming.

thanks,
micron

ALSO...sorry about my set at the abyss kids....me no was feeling so
good.  =P

it's really cool to see people who can appreciate a truly good dj. often
times i think ravers are somewhat uneducated about djs. i think there are
a lot of djs who can mix (and alot who can't) but just as in art, or
literature, or anything else, there are few masters, and people should
learn to recognize them.

Hey there peeps.  All those great djs being listed, I'm gonna keep my eyes
peeled and ears opened! :)  cool.  Outside of the dance genre, what other
types of music do y'all listen to?  Classical, world, choral, folk, jazz?
What else is good?  I was on a female folk singer kick, ala joni, jewel,
sarah mcgloughlin, loreena mckennit, for a while.  Henrik Gorecki, Satie,
arvo part, are some favorite contemporary classical composers.  

~geo

Date: Fri, 3 Oct 1997 14:48:39 -0700 (PDT)
From: macadio <macadio6@rocketmail.com>
Subject: Mixed up tape reviews**
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


Ok I had the pleasure of getting 2 excellent Mixed tapes from 2
excellent DJ's The First one I got is Ceasers(space children) 3rd
transmission tape. And the Second one is hyrogliphs. By Sutekh I know
Seth I screwed up the Name but Hey I can't spell leave that to
Marketing. Ceasers tape is a blend of Bouncy Tek/house with a very
nice Tekno track played ulta slow that im still trying to get it is DJ
misjah M5 or Off the beat if anyone wants to sell it let me know!!.
Nice mixing kind of got a little housey in one point but for the most
part pretty bumping good Car Music not his usual Prime time sound and
that is good I like "Car Music" A very nice Tek house tape I recommend
it for vital listens.. Now the next tape I pop in is Seth's Tape Let
me tell you this boy is on the Verge he has a diverse style that I can
totally Dig. His tape was way experimental Ambient Tekno if you will.
Not sure how to classify other then experimental. A lot of Intelligent
Tekno in there it had me thinking the whole tape. Excellent mixing it
was very smooth. Now WARING: it is experimental and very downbeat if
you are looking for poundy in your face Tekno tracks I suggest the
First Sutekh Vs. Klank Tape I forgot the name of it but Nice colored
Red tape. That tape is very punchy. His new one is more on the
Intelligent tip Still very Nice good Job's Guys!!! Enuff of my
rambling..

Macadio (Mack-Audio)

---GlttrPrncs@aol.com wrote:

> :-)!!)  If you all could post your favorite music 

just to toss out some unexpected answers:

all time favorites:
stevie wonder: just about anything before the 80's, esp. innervisions,
any song written by antonio carlos jobin,
any song sung by frank sinatra,
chet baker sings/let's get lost soundtrack
john coltrane (especially live stuff from the mid sixties),
Sudanese gamelan degung (a particularly mellow and beautiful style of
javanese gamelan music),
a tribe called quest - people's instinctive travels...
vivaldi - guitar concerto in f minor (largo)
future sound of london: lifeforms (ep and double disk)
gavin(?) hardkiss: three purple neuds in a garden
whatever i happen to be listening to at the moment (right now that's
"let's get it on" by marvin gaye)


> and your favorite DJ

goa gil blew me away more than anyone else i've heard since moving to
sf, but the set and setting (burning man "community dance party")
might have had something to do with it...

and i gotta give props to my favorite north carolina dj's drew and
erik...


-messiah wannabe

I loooooooooooooooooove the 80's pop and new age music..hehee...anything
from men without hats,depeche mode, new order, alphaville<sp?> to peter
gabriel, soft cell, erasure, joy division, earth wind & Fire...I am also a
big fan of suburbian punk such as the Buzzcocks, Clash, Exploted....I also
like Ska very much, Madness, Skankin Pickles, Op Ivy...well....lets just
say I am well rounded and i loveeeee any kind of music...i also looooove
operas( i am going to go see Tosca and Figaro's Wedding this thursday and
next thursday..)  I also am a big fan of an acid jazz/funk group named
Galliano!  Well there is soooo much to list...so i better sign off here..=P

Until about 3:30am, come unity was a pretty low energy party with good but
not great music.  As it got later, Jeno started going OFF, and us remaining
hardcores recieved a flawless mixing of slamming beats until 6am (wasn't it
supposed to end at 4:30?)  Props to Carlos for picking up the energy.
Truly a memorable come unity - the first in a loooong time where I felt a
sense of community :\

-Dan

From: James <james@photon.net>
Subject: Earthdance, TOMORROW!!
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-MIME-Autoconverted: from quoted-printable to 8bit by hyperreal.org id RAA20427
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk



On Saturday October 4th, over 20 countries will unite to create the world's
biggest dance event to raise awareness and funds to support the freedom of
the Tibetan people.
For the first time on such a massive scale EARTHDANCE brings together a
team of international party promoters to create a unified global dancefloor
where we will join as a one world community to dance for peace and earth
transformation.
The climax of the event will be a simultaneous dancefloor link-up where at
a specific moment every DJ in every country will play a specially created
track for world peace at the same time, unifying all dancefloors and all
dancers.
Conceived by Return To The Source producer and Medicine Drum member Chris
Deckker, this groundbreaking event has evolved into a worldwide vision.
Participating countries include: England, Japan, Australia, Israel,
America, Canada, Holland, South Africa, Spain, Switzerland, Mexico, and
more.
A live Webcast is also planned linking at least 5 major capitols via ISDN
links.

Participating in San Francisco, where one of the largest population of
Tibetan refugees reside, Space Children, and Satori Arts^ presents
EARTHDANCE SAN FRANCISCO at the Civic Center Plaza Park in downtown San
Francisco as a free outdoor gathering from 12noon to 6pm.
A special appearance by the internationally respected master musician and
artist -Karma Moffett will open this event with the traditional sounds of
Sacred Tibetan Music to focus the collective intention of the people on
coming together in the name of Human Justice & Freedom for the Tibetan
people.  For the next five hours, DJ's Graeme, Cesar, Dutch, Twerk, and on
four turntables: UFOxJason MousexNoel will bring the best of Techno, House
& Jungle music that will unify the timeless archtypal energies of dance
inherent in all people.
At the closing of the event, Dennis Cusack of the International Committee
of Lawyers for Tibet will speak on the current state of the Tibetan people,
how this affects us all as a global community, and what you can do to help
insure that Peace and Freedom will prevail for the people of Tibet. During
the event, representatives from the Bay Area Friends of Tibet, the
International Committee of Lawyers for Tibet, and the Tibetan Association
of Northern California will be present to offer information on how you can
directly aid the cause of liberating the people of Tibet, and preserving
their culture which has done so much to inspire and enrich the collective
culture of the world.

This entire event will have digital film coverage that will be transmitted
via ISDN by Cyberworld Cafe to London and mixed by Virgin Net,then sent
back out over the internet for all the world to watch.  The complete
footage from every participating country will afterwards be sent to London
to be used in a broadcast documentary.  Also, for those who missed this
year's Earthdance, and the one time opportunity to dance for the freedom of
Tibet, an Earthdance CD will be realeased in January/February 1998,
complete with the music and pictures from the globally unified event that
is bringing the world's attention to bringing freedom to the Tibetan
Nation.

October 4th will be the catalystic date, but the cause of Peace and Freedom
is taking place every moment in life, so as this year comes to its close,
be on the watch for future night events that will provied you the
opportunity to  celebrate in taking part in the global movement of bringing
peace and soverignity to the Tibetan people.

Much Thanks to Photon Net - http://www.photon.net/ - for the ISP that has
made this netcast possible;
and Jane Piper of Next School for making the contacts needed to involve
local Tibetan organizations at this event.

For more details on this and further Space Children events call 415.675.4700
http://www.spacechildren.com

For more information on Return To The Source, visit their website at:
http://www.rtts.com

For more details about Earthdance, and future globally coordinated dance
benefits,visit:
http://www.rtts.com/earthdance.html

Find the cybercast of EARTHDANCE on Virgin Net, at:
http://www.virgin.net

For more information about Karma Moffet, come out to Karma Moffett's
Tibetan Bell Experience, most Wednesdays, Fridays, Saturdays & Sundays @ 8p
($10 donation).
Karma Moffett Gallery, 3895 18th St., SF    415.621.8135

Also visit the only Internet Service Cafe in the Bay Area, Cyberworld Cafe,
at 528 Folsom St.*San Francisco, CA *415.278.9669
http://www.cyberworldsf.com


Peace and Harmony

James at Satori Arts^
james@photon.net

Hello pretty peeps, I came across this article on the usenet about
a techno/rave documentary.  Thought it might raise an interesting 
discussion on the effect of media on the dance culture.   

~~geo

Billboard Magazine, October 4, 1997
Music Video - Programming
CLEOPATRA DOCUMENTS THE ELECTRONICA SCENE ON FILM
By Carrie Bell

LOS ANGELES- in an effort to expose the underground rave scene to a
mainstream audience,Cleopatra Pictures and Entertainment Group is
preparing the first full-length documentary onelectronic music,
featuring appearances by breakout acts like Moby, Aphex Twin, the
Crystal Method, and Sneaker Pimps.

"This culture has been around for at least a decade, but very few people
really know the history and what it's all about," says Cleopatra
president Brian Perera. "We wanted to create a film that took people
there, showed them the inside, and dispelled any false rumors."

The film, tentatively titled ""Better Living Through Circuitry," started
shooting in March at the Winter Music Conference in Miami. Since then,
the crew has filmed in New York, Los Angeles, and San Diego. It also
hopes to work Detroit and London shoots into the $100,000 budget.

Cleopatra expects to have the first cut by December and a finished
product by spring 1998, although it has yet to be determined whether the
project will have a wide theatrical release or go straight to video.

"Several companies have expressed interest in releasing the movie to
theaters, including Trimark, Nonfiction Films, Miramax, and October,"
says producer Brian McNelis. "I think people realize this is a good time
for this film. The music is just starting to change from an underground
urban legend to something they listen to in Des Moines. It's prior to
the burnout stage, and the artists are the most interesting and genuine
at this point." 

Directed by Jonathan Reiss--known for his music video work with Nine
Inch Nails, Black Crowes, and Type O Negative--the film will include
performance footage, location shots with opinions from police and fans,
and interviews with pivotal players like MTV's "Amp" producer Todd
Mueller and Maverick A&R representative/KCRW Los Angeles DJ Jason
Bentley. Other artists involved in the project are Electric Skychurch,
DJ Frankie Bones, Keoki, DJ Spooky, Fluke, and Death In Vegas.

"We tried to incorporate popular, historical, and up-and-coming bands.
This film is narrated by the people who live this lifestyle. Everything
you learn from the film will come from the mouth of an insider," McNelis
says.

 The authenticity of the project is what convinced the Crystal Method to
participate.

 "They are trying to avoid the 'Hard Copy' image of the scene's problems
and expose this energetic and supportive community," says the Crystal
Method's Scott Kirkland. "We're excited to see the final product and
hope it sheds light on people's misconceptions. And we're always
thankful for publicity."

 McNelis says one reason Cleopatra, which owns three record labels
specializing in techno, is involved with the film is that the subject
matter offers a "visual arena" for the fashion, color, technology, and
live experience of electronic music.

 "It is an eye-candy culture. Just look at all the artists who tour with
videos or the efforts that goes into designing CD and poster artwork or
creating the perfect outfit for an all-nighter," McNelis says.

 Retailers agree that electronica can only be helped by the film. "Think
of it as an extended music video. Music films are the next best thing to
being there, and electronic music is tied so heavily to how the music
makes you feel," says Bob Reamer, a music buyer for Borders. "This can
only drive CD sales for the bands involved. Not only do fans of techno
eat up compilations, but electronica-heavy soundtracks like "The Saint"
also sold well."

 Perera says there will more than likely be a companion album, although
his record labels probably won't release it. Both Sony and Warner have
expressed interest.

 "Our main concern right now is getting the film done and out there for
public consumption," Perera says. "We are taking the business part very
slowly because we want to find partners with the same goals, and do what
is best for the bands and people involved."

-- 

                           
                ,.;.             Cleopatra Entertainment

Thought I'd drop in my favorites in for Glitter Princess'  "survey" -
(wouldn't want any of them to feel left out if they happen to be subscribed
to our little list!)

Hands down  - we're talking league of his own so there is no comparison
(anyone who's seen him live - I mean close enough to really watch what he
does - 3 decks, a 909 and an 808 - programming on the fly and mixing average
30 seconds each track -knows what I mean).... alien funky techno
messiah..............JEFF MILLS!!

Following sort of close behind in no particular order : Dave Clarke, Richie
Hawtin, Joey Beltram, Carl Cox on 3 decks doing hard house/techno, Billy
Nasty, Surgeon, Tony De Vit, Darren Pearce, Sven Vath, Josh Wink with a hard
set, Claude Young, Grooverider

locally:  still DJ Dan,  Donald Glaude,  Ethan, Jon Williams, Seanie Boy,
 Doran, David Michael,  even Norman on rare occaisions ...........

Stop here unless you want the editorial comments..........

You probably don't need me to tell you I live and breathe Detroit techno (not
an easy thing to do in SF) - also hard house, hard trance, hard hard jungle,
fast breakbeat,  basically the faster the better (I can only dance to gabber
for about 20 min though) and more than one set of happy hardcore is a little
much for me (its those squeaky voices that get to me). Goa gets old after  4
or 5 hours too. But I listen to Detroit style techno from the minute I wake
up till I'm ready to sleep  - yup  JB 3 is on right now....(Forklift) - .
Sometimes I just leave the CD on repeat all night while I sleep (Jeff Mills
Live from the Liquid Room - Tokyo).   My neighbors must LOVE me!

I think most people who don't like techno haven't had the opportunity to hear
really good techno. It just so very rarely makes it all the way out here, and
when it does the vibe is not there because people aren't familiar with the
music or the style or are expecting something else, or I don't know why..  I
was very fortunate to live in London last year and heard sounds like I've
never heard anywhere before. They say techno is dying there
already.......it'll be too bad if SF missed it altogether. I've still got
mixtapes, but its not the same as on a massive clear sound system with loads
of other people more into it even than you are. Everybody tries to sing along
to these minimal techno noises - no words of course - and it works. 

I'd like to see Jeff Mills vs. Grooverider -we'd have to run for cover !!!

Sorry for the long answer to a short question !  glad you like jb too!

from 12-6 pm, there is a FREE outdoor gethering at the San Francisco Civic
Center Plaza.

It is sponsored by Space Children, Return to the Source, and Mixmag
magazine and is part of a 20-nation unified dance party going on today,
striving to raise consciousness in the youth about the EVILS that have
gone down and are in threat of continuing in Tibet.

GRAEME
CESAR & TWERK
DUTCH
UFO/JASON MOUSE/NOEL on 4 turntables

That is the line-up.  This party, again is free, and for an excellent
cause.  Simply be being there, we will show our solidarity with a
beautiful culture, whose people have been oppressed and abused in
countless unthinkable ways under Chinese occupation.  This event is a
chance to raise our fists as we slip into the music.  Outside, on what
looks like it's going to be a lovely day.  For free.  DO IT.

415.675.4700 for more details.

>  I chipped a big ass hole on one of my top molars with my tounge ring &
> may have  also cracked a tooth or two.  My parents don't know that I
> have my tounge  pierced,(as of tonight I no longer do-I am fed up and

> What believable thing could I say, (I  am NOT telling them that I had
> my tounge pierced & bit my bar!) to the dentist  and my parents that
> could've caused a major CRACK in my TOOTH or Put a small  hole/chip on
> a tooth?

An excuse that has always worked for me is "I was doing grandmaster
flash when his prince-albert cracked my molar". The other one that
usually works on less liberal parents is "I was helping my girlfriend
extract a 2-gauge bar that rusted into her nipple."  If your parents
are really strict and have no sense of humour whatsoever, you can
always say "I was stripping the insulation off a wire in my friend's
engine after his/her car got stuck in the middle of nowhere and we had
to fix it without the aid of tools while we were slowly being encircled
by folks that were trying to capture me a lifetime of slavery in sheik
yerbouti's harem." (The old I did it to escape the ravages of
white-slavery excuse).

Sorry, I'd probably be a little less sardonic if you hadn't called
Grandmaster Flash "trash" and made disparaging comments about all the
"little G's"... Good luck and remember that karma works in mysterious
ways: one moment you can cracker on the ebony, and the next you're
cracking your ivories.

funk? why would I want funk? And I beg your pardon, but rhythm is rhythm, and
you certainly need it at 180 BPM as much if not more than 110.  Fred Astaire
was a skinny tweeky white guy who probably had no booty to speak of. (ask
Ginger)

Anyone can distinguish a person who is simply moving fast and there happens
to be music on around him, and someone who is moving to the music, who has
the music inside, connected with their natural frequency , and it happens to
be fast (or looks that way to everyone else - ever see the Star Trek episode
Blink of an Eye?)

Slow music is soothing, lulling (as in lullabye), it calms you into a state
of .....sleep! Or so tired and relaxed you'd rather be asleep. Dancing is my
cardio vascular -remember I'm still alive vehicle.

We obviously have completely divergent natural frequencies. Do you like
asparagus?
jd

 JD4150171@aol.com writes:
) Why is SF the bastion of slow, groovy, funky, 
>deep,soulful house? Aren't we over it yet? Why do people think slower = 
>mature?

well i have no scientific proof but this is the foolish fish theory
of why some may think that slower =mature

we have fewer brain cells so we think slower therefore our
natural resonant frequency is much slower as we age.

we also have fewer teeth as we age so we chew our food slower.

in general life just  seems to slow down as we age...unless
of coarse you're a foolish fish...

so that's why i believe slower is sometimes associated with 
being more mature

And then there is the saturn return that happens around
the age of 28 but we wont get into astrology today.

I hope this generation decides to change that and uses
the experience of aging to speed things up...will
we be dancing to 400 bpm when were 90 years old?

well enough thinking for today...im off to the civic
center to enjoy that free party in the sun

	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

Subject: a chain letter for friendship
Message-ID: <19971004.195124.9983.0.foolish_fish1@juno.com>
X-Mailer: Juno 1.38
X-Juno-Line-Breaks: 0-90
Date: Sat, 04 Oct 1997 22:28:19 EDT

Precedence: bulk

I know everyone hates chain letters, but I just wanted to share....
-----------------------------------------------------
> Around The Corner:  By Henson Towne
>
> Around the corner I have a friend,
> In this great city that has no end,
> Let the days go by and weeks rush on,
> And before I know it, a year is gone.
> And I never see my old friends face,
> For life is a swift and terrible race,
> He knows I like him just as well,
> As in the days when I rang his bell,
> And he rang mine.
> If, we were younger then,
> And now we are busy, tired men.
> Tired of playing a foolish game,
> Tired of trying to make a name.
> "Tomorrow" I say "I will call on Jim"
> "Just to show that I'm thinking of him."
> But tomorrow comes and tomorrow goes,
> And distance between us grows and grows.
> Around the corner!- yet miles away,
> "Here's a telegram sir-"
> "Jim died today."
> And that's what we get and deserve in the end.
> Around the corner, a vanished friend.
>
> If you love someone, tell them.  Remember always to say what you mean.

>
> Never be afraid to express yourself.  Take this opportunity to tell
> someone what they mean to you.  Seize the day and have no regrets.
> Most importantly, stay close to your friends and family, for they
> have
> helped make you the person that you are today and are what it's all
> about anyway.  Pass this along to your friends. Let it make a
> difference in your day and theirs.  The difference between
> expressing
> love and having regrets which may stay around forever.
> This is a love chain letter.  Within 1 hour you must send it to 10
> other people.  Within five days you will have a miraculous
> occurrence
> in your relationships.  You will find new love or have an old love
> rekindled.  If you do not send it, you will have once again passed
> up
> the opportunity to do something loving and beautiful and continue
> the
> trend that gives you problems in your relationships.
> I'm not going to make silly claims that this same letter has been
> traveling around since before the advent of email and typewriters.
> It
> doesn't contain gruesome stories of what has happened to the people
> who haven't sent it on.  It doesn't need to.
> If you've received this it is because someone cares for you and it
> means there is probably at least someone for whom you care.
> If you're too busy to take the few minutes that it would take right
> now to forward this to ten people, would it be the first time you
> didn't do that little thing that would make a difference in your
> relationships?  I can tell you it certainly won't be the last.  I
> don't have to make up silly stories about people being hit by buses
> or
> crushed by falling disco balls for not sending this letter on.
> You've
> seen the result of this neglect in your own relationships that you
> have allow d to fade, dissolve, and fall into disrepair.
> Take this opportunity to set a new trend.  Take a few minutes to
> send
> this to a few people you care about, just to let them know that
> you're
> thinking of them.  It's even better if they're not the people you
> already correspond with every week.  The more people that you send to,

>
> the better luck you will have.  And the better you'll get and
> reaching out to those you care about.
> Here's the deal:
> Forward this letter to at least 10 different people
> within 1 hour of receiving it.
> Do it, and reap what you sow:
> luck in love,
> people who care for you, and
> that warm glowy feeling that comes from loving others.
> Don't do it, and suffer the consequences of
> being alone, wrapped up in your own affairs, and being too busy to
> do
> the things you actually care about.
> May love litter your life with blessings!

	><{{{">   <"}}}><

		foolish fish

i know i sorta touched it when i did my intro a few weeks ago, yet i have
to comment on some stellar performers i have heard since ive been here
that make my favorits list

Djs: Richie Hawtin (+8), Pixie (Spiraltribe), DJ Silence (Santa
Cruz), Prozac (Disco B), Abe Duque (Tension/SG), Dylan Drazen (Club
Craft), Neil Landstrumm (Scandinavia), Function (Downwards, Relief),
Joelectronik (N.E.W.)

and live acts: Regis+Function (Downwards), Raul (Sheep)

NOTE: Dj Silence :) this kid is AWESOME i was really psyched to hear his
music on top of that mountain he tore it up and people loved it :) go
future galactic in california!!

I also have consolidated my music tastes, because a lot of people ask me
what kind of music i like, and i if say "techno" i get this look of "oh"
"great, did i see you on 20/20?"... or if i say "detroit" and people that
have never heard anyone from detroit hear that... it doesnt help

so... instead of saying "YEAH i really dig techno on a new and
fresh minimal yet sometimes overwhelming tip, but its gotta be engaging
and have the funk, and i dig jungle if its new and groundbreaking and
sounds like something ive never heard or imagined before, and i like
experimental ambient, but it cant have
any of that cheesy garbage in it, and i like house if its deep
and its got wicked soul, and i like reggae in its most blown out mental
form...." ... i just say "I like Future Music"

so!
where is the most wicked underground Future Music presentation tonight??
thanks!
-dsp

(translations: if i say wicked and diesel too much you gotta remember that
im from northern new england ;)

wicked is kind of a boston/salem word... diesel definitely comes from my
farmboy roots.

Subject: NRR *(Breath Life)*
Content-Type: text/plain
Date: Sun, 05 Oct 1997 00:45:13 PDT
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

  I met an unusual person this morning, they said that their name was 
Life.  I was not aware of this Life person but there she was.  Divine, 
broad, and smiling.
  She reached her arm out gently to me in a white, satin gown and said 
in a soft, relaxing voice, "bABy HueY, you must love me for I am not 
immortal, and neither are you.  You need to respect and cherish me.  I 
am your destiny.  
  Breath bAByHueY, breath in the warmth and love that you and I share 
together.  Breath in the friends of whom you love and care about.  
Breath every moment of every beautiful minute in which millions of your 
people are doing the same.  Breath, breath, breath."
  "Ooohh!" I thought, "this is some kind of awakening or something."  
This person kind of scared me in a way that nothing else can. But being 
the curious guy that I am, I listened to her voice some more.
  "bAByHueY, You need to accept who you are and who the people are that 
you love, and love them.  Give them all that you can give them. Give 
them a piece of your heart, a piece of your soul, and a piece of your 
destiny.  Days are days, and forever is forever.  Memories are forever.  
Let's both become one individual and make all the happiest memories that 
we can.  Let's breath together the same air, the same love and the same 
ambitions for I have not known you until today.  And together we can cry 
happily forever, beyond memories.

* I just wanted everyone out there to breath the same air that I am 
breathing. and for someone to rent with me J/k  :P
Tomorrow, when most of you will read this, remember that today is not 
going to be what happened yesterday, it is new, and with all new things, 
we must learn and use to the best of our capabilities.*

bAByHueY

Good Night and sweet dreams with your big, hairy, hangin'

Slinky

  o o0 o0
   0  O  o

Tall Paul wrote:
> 
>  This message i will try to keep short & sweet, yet i feel it very
> important to
> express my deepest concerns for the future of our survival in this scene!
> 
>      Last night i attended "ABYSS" up in the beautiful mountains of Santa
> Rosa. & enjoyed talkin' & hangin' out w/friends & star gazin' under the
> clear skies up there. It was BEAUTIFUL, i saw 12 shooting stars & then
> hiked up a hill later on to greet the most amazing sunrise! Those who know
> me usually find me groovin' in the speakers all night long but last
> night...i just felt like relaxin'.The music was o.k. & there was alot of
> dust in the air from people dancin'. It was good for a free outdoor event
> UNTIL!!! When departing back down the long winding dirt road this morning,
> i came across some very shaken and distraught friends as their car had
> flipped off the side of the cliff and smashed into a large tree!!!   The
> driver was still in shock and i crawled down to help them recover some
> belongings & be there to support them in their dire need of help! They
> luckily, survived without severe injuries and if it weren't for that great
> big tree, they would no longer be here with us!!!
> 
>      Also, after helping them out, i finally made it down to my own ride &
> witnessed that ANOTHER friend's car window had been smashed by a rock that
> was thrown through it!!! WHAT the FUCK is going on!!! In the last month
> alone iv'e lost count with the amount of cars broken into & fights breaking
> out & backpacks being stolen & total kaos @ our events!!!
> 
>      Eventhough, i'd like to wish that we have alot of power to prevent
> these  occurences, we're not invincible to them happening to us. It
> especially
> terrifies me that we could've also experienced a very tragic incident this
> morning that would've resulted in several untimely deaths of our own family
> members!!! Whether YOU even know them or not...they belong to our scene, &
> they're apart of our tribe!!!
> 
>      It is SO important that WE, as a family, bond together & communicate
> to each other & we look out for each other and respect one another! It's
> AWESOME to celebrate our music & gather together to partake in every
> positive aspect of a movement such as ours...The music truly is the
> drug,YET, we obviously need to focus alot more & partake in moderation & in
> a very responsible & mature manner so that we can continue to be strong &
> survive & gain ground in this not so positive world of ours! We can then
> prove to the world that PLUR isn't fantasy, we know it works & we must
> share with others our experiences of how we think,feel,& GROW!!!  Maybe
> then... the world will LISTEN & begin to understand that change is good, it
> comes from within.
> 
>      WE all have a purpose in our scene & in our lives on this planet!
> Reflect, Accept, Know & Understand!!! If we love ourselves, then we can
> love one another, & if we love each other... then PLUR is real!!!
> 
>                             Actions speak LOUDER than words,
>                         peace and love to all who really DO care...
>                                                        tall paul :)

thought maybe we had the wrong place.  But no, for a while the inside was

setup was a model of the Golden Gate Bride, fantastic is all I can say.
