Subject: Re: blue angels & green eggs and ham
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

in light of the recent posts, i'm gonna put in my public two cents here...

i had send foolish fish a personal post when i first read his "joke"
(which, call me obtuse or something, i didn't get as funny in the first
place)....

my viewpoint is that the offensive thing was asking if hookers do dishes
and laundry (or whatever it was) like "regular girlfriends"....

for those who don't know, foolish fish is a very articulate, sensitive,
kind-hearted guy who, in my experience, has never said anything like this
before, and i franky wrote it off to a weird lapse of consciousness (had i
been there in person, i would have thrown cold water on him or something,
know what i mean??)

because the fact is..... there is no such thing as a "regular girlfriend"
job description .... and it annoys the hell out of me when i see the
"elders" in the world, who ought to know better, rehashing the old
"programming" that we've all worked so hard to eliminate from our
society....

i have a 19-year old daughter and the thought that she'd be subjected to
this idiotic subliminal suggestion that she's supposed to do her
boyfriend's laundry and cooking pisses me off big-time!!!  nor do i think
that her boyfriend is supposed to be the driver of the car, or the killer
of the bugs in the house, or the other archaic notions that we have got to
learn to get rid of!!!

and, since i'm posting publicly now, too .... i'll tell you that i also
told foolish fish this morning that, though the blind man and the elephant
story is one that i use and remember often to remind myself that two people
may see different sides of the same thing ..... and that both visions are
fully valid ....  to me, if you're calling yourself the "misunderstood
elephant," you gotta realize it's cuz you stuck your stinky ass out as
someone approached...  that's what "put your best foot forward" means ...
show people the best possible side of yourself...  we aren't perfect, but
we can at least be aware.

what bothers me most is when i hear jokes/statements that put some limited
expecations on entire groups of people ... i.e., "regular girlfriends" do
your laundry... that's crap, and we all know it...  i'm not a prude, and
i'm not easily offended, and i don't care if someing is joking about what
hookers do, but making jokes that potentially make suppositions about all
women is too small-minded for me.

one more thing .... if your idea about whether a joke is offensive or not
depends on who's in the room (i.e., a racist joke about african-americans
is somehow acceptable if there are/aren't blacks in the room?!?!  and i
don't care if the story-teller is black or white) ... then you'd best think
again.  if your "joke" ain't so funny if someone overhears it, then maybe
it ain't so funny.  and if it's truly funny ... and even if it still
contains some racist or sexist humor ... then maybe it *is* really funny,
and we should get up the courage to say so.

So to me, it's not about being "politically correct," it's about respecting
people and not trying to make jokes about those things that others use to
oppress them.  But if it's respectful *and* it's funny ... go for it!

actually, i got an email at work that, to me, is hysterical, and i'll post
that in a minute....

so that's it, love, leslie

well, somebody call me if this actually looks as if it might go
somewhere. we tried to do something of this sort for the
central/southern states - got as far as designing a system for the
thing before someone actually believed me when i said that we'd need
money to publish it....

it's a fantastic thought... i'd love to be involved (still have the
old template that was never used) but putting out a magazine is more
than a full time job... a hell of a lot of work, and the first few
years would be extremely expensive. don't forget who you'd need - a
staff of writers, editors and proofreaders, designers, and if you're
thinking of funding this through advertising, you'd need some really
good ppl people. sales reps. and then come up with a media
kit/proposal, research printers and papers, yadda yadda yadda. anyway,
i probably have the knowledge and skills to do something like this, so
hey! if it takes off, or if ppl are serious about it, write me!

 cheers - e. :)

To me, this is hysterical, I was ROTFLOL!  Out of the mouths of babes (yep,
there's some sexist stuff that hopefully these kids will un-learn as they
grow ... but there's some gems in here!)

----------------------------------
Questions about love, marriage and sex were posed to kids
ages 5 to 10. Their answers below are enlightening:

WHAT IS THE PROPER AGE TO GET MARRIED??
"Eighty-four! Because at that age, you don't have to work
anymore, and you can spend all your time loving each other in
your bedroom."  (Judy, 8)
"Once I'm done with kindergarten, I'm going to find me a
wife!"  (Tom, 5)
WHAT DO MOST PEOPLE DO ON A DATE??
"On the first date, they just tell each other lies, and that
usually gets them interested enough to go for a second date."
(Mike, 10)
WHEN IS IT OKAY TO KISS SOMEONE??
"You should never kiss a girl unless you have enough bucks to
buy her a big ring and her own VCR, 'cause she'll want to
have videos of the wedding."  (Jim, 10)
"Never kiss in front of other people. It's a big embarrassing
thing if anybody sees you. But if nobody sees you, I might be
willing
to tryit with a handsome boy, but just for a few hours."  (Kally, 9)

THE GREAT DEBATE: IS IT BETTER TO BE SINGLE OR MARRIED??
"It's better for girls to be single but not for boys. Boys need
somebody to clean up after them!"  (Lynette, 9)
"It gives me a headache to think about that stuff. I'm just a
kid. I don't need that kind of trouble."  (Kenny, 7)
CONCERNING WHY LOVE HAPPENS BETWEEN TWO PARTICULAR PEOPLE
"No one is sure why it happens, but I heard it has something to
do with how you smell. That's why perfume and deodorant are
so popular."  (Jan, 9)
"I think you're supposed to get shot with an arrow or
something, but the rest of it isn't supposed to be so painful."
(Harlen, 8)
ON WHAT FALLING IN LOVE IS LIKE
"Like an avalanche where you have to run for your life."
(Roger, 9)
"If falling in love is anything like learning how to spell, I
don't want to do it. It takes too long."  (Leo, 7)
ON THE ROLE OF GOOD LOOKS IN LOVE
"If you want to be loved by somebody who isn't already in
your family, it doesn't hurt to be beautiful."  (Jeanne, 8)
"It isn't always just how you look. Look at me. I'm handsome
like anything and I haven't got anybody to marry me yet."
(Gary, 7)
"Beauty is skin deep. But how rich you are can last a long
time."  (Christine, 9)
CONCERNING WHY LOVERS OFTEN HOLD HANDS
"They want to make sure their rings don't fall off because they
paid good money for them."  (Dave, 8)
CONFIDENTIAL OPINIONS ABOUT LOVE
"I'm in favor of love as long as it doesn't happen when 'The
Simpsons' is on television."  (Anita, 6)
"Love will find you, even if you are trying to hide from it. I
have been trying to hide from it since I was five, but the girls
keep finding me."  (Bobby, 8)
"I'm not rushing into being in love. I'm finding fourth grade hard
 enough."  (Regina, 10)
 THE PERSONAL QUALITIES NECESSARY TO BE A GOOD LOVER
"One of you should know how to write a check. Because, even
if you have tons of love, there is still going to be a lot of
bills."  (Ava, 8)
SOME SUREFIRE WAYS TO MAKE A PERSON FALL IN LOVE WITH YOU
"Tell them that you own a whole bunch of candy stores."
(Del, 6)
"Don't do things like have smelly, green sneakers. You might
get attention, but attention ain't the same thing as love."
(Alonzo, 9)
"One way is to take the girl out to eat. Make sure it's
something she likes to eat. French fries usually works for me."
(Bart, 9)

HOW CAN YOU TELL IF TWO ADULTS EATING DINNER AT A RESTAURANT ARE IN LOVE?
"Just see if the man picks up the check. That's how you can tell if
he's in love."  (John, 9)
"Lovers will just be staring at each other and their food will
get cold. Other people care more about the food." (Brad, 8)
"It's love if they order one of those desserts that are on fire.
They like to order those because it's just like how their hearts
are...on fire."  (Christine, 9)
WHAT MOST PEOPLE ARE THINKING WHEN THEY SAY "I LOVE YOU"
"The person is thinking: Yeah, I really do love him. But I
hope he showers at least once a day."  (Michelle, 9)
HOW A PERSON LEARNS TO KISS
"You learn it right on the spot when the gooshy feelings get
the best of you."  (Doug, 7)
"It might help to watch soap operas all day."  (Carin, 9)

WHEN IS IT OKAY TO KISS SOMEONE?
"It's never okay to kiss a boy. They always slobber all over
you...That's why I stopped doing it."  (Jean, 10)
HOW TO MAKE LOVE ENDURE
"Spend most of your time loving instead of going to work."
(Tom, 7)
"Don't forget your wife's name...That will mess up the love."
(Roger, 8)
"Be a good kisser. It might make your wife forget that you
never take out the trash."  (Randy, 8)

---"John S. Lee" <jsl@nexsys.net> wrote:
>
> At 5:43 PM +0000 10/12/97, Faro wrote:
> >Actually, regardless of whether anyone told these people to rise
> >above racisim, or British opression, both of them did do just that
in
> >their own way. Both Martin Luther King Jr. and Gahndi showed how to
> >'rise above' the opression they were facing, and by example they
> >showed what the world would be like if we could all rise above the
> >mistrust and bigotry that is out there.

i guess i don't see them, or any other person who has chosen to stand
up for *human* rights, as having risen above (in the context that
glitter princess was writing) their situation. they fought it. and
that's the only was to instigate change. whether it's violent or non,
standing up for your rights as a person means to fight for your space
in the world. no one will hand it to you. well, maybe if you're a
wealthy wasp male, and even then, not always.

and john wrote:

> I hate the oversimplification of MLK and Ghandi.  I tell you this
much for
> all that non-violent demonstration:  MLK was turning the corner and
began
> to think, right before he was assainated, that non-violence is only
part of
> the solution and it may become necessary at some time to revert to
more,
> active means of protest (read violence).

i brought these ppl up (as well as susan b anthony, who failed to make
it further in this discussion about _sexism_) only because they are
well-known to the masses for their struggles. to me it really doesn't
matter how a person stands up - if they do they are far ahead of so
many in our society. 
> 
> Also Ghandi had serious problems with the place of women in society,
and did little about the plight of females in his country.

yes... well, here we are again. the rights of a man, no matter what
his race, will always be seen as being more important than a woman's.
this was really one of the biggest points i was trying to make - that
this is such a hypocritical scenario. and even the fact that who ever
chose not to include women who have struggled in the remainder of this
discussion only drives that point in further.
 
> These men were not gods, they were just people whos time and ideas
had
> come.  They were not above the predjudices, and the mores of thier
times.

nobody is.  (i'd be pretty wary of anyone who thought (s)he was!)

and just to conclude my participation in this thread - i think that
everything has been said - some of us are more aware of the present
injustices than others (i say, give them time!) my own reaction to
injustice is a passive one - kerry will back me up when i say that i
am no anarchist - i believe in working with, as much as possible, the
current system to  instigate change... although there are certainly
times when this is not possible. having grown up in a household of
liberal democrat media goons, i'm a firm supporter of using our rights
(such as publishing your views to educate others) or even abusing them
as much as possible. i'm probably a lofty idealist who witnessed a
whole lot of violence in my hometown in the early 70's and i'm really
not sure if i believe it was the right way to approach change. okay,
so i'm a whimp. i went to a counter-kkk rally once in phila and when
the cops pulled out their billy clubs i was off, back to the safety of
my own apartment. but we need those who will stand up physically, as
much as we need those who fight in more non-violent ways. it is with
the combination of these methods - violence, education (through
alternative media, through community outreach) that change will be
made. if we don't have anyone who can work within the current system,
i really don't see how much could be accomplished. but that's mho. 

anyway, it's good to see the few people who are aware stand up and try
to educate those who are not. so, in the words of the raver, props to
you, john (and i must say that i'm pleased to see you come around on
this issue), megan, kerry, leslie, and who ever else there was who
stood up on this. hopefully there was at least some growth from this
*discussion* (hello - not an argument!)

cheers - e. :)

battle which any human being can fight, and never stop fighting."    
- e.e. cummings

heya fish! (duane?) gosh, this thread has gone so far from where it
started... i wouldn't feel offended or anything! i just wanted to
reitrerate what kerry wrote here - with a little story. (okay, so i'm
putting off work this morning) i lived in phila in 88, and at that
time i was involved with the brainwashing cult known as n.a.. anyway,
a friend of mine took me to a meeting in germantown - a really
frightening area of phila (first time i saw someone standing on the
street with a sawed off shot-gun)... needless to say, (i'll start with
a discription of myself: small, thin, super-wasp girl with a sheltered
upbringing) i was the only white person in this meeting of about 200
ppl. there were quite a few stares, and quite a few people who felt it
necessary to bash the white race and blame us for just about
everything. to say that i was uncomfortable would be an extreme
understatement. so i shared this with my friend, who responded " now
you know what i feel like all the time." wow. i consider myself pretty
liberal and open minded, but i could have never imagined feeling like
such an unwanted, even hated outsider.  just becasue of the color of
my skin. no one would even give me a chance - because i was white i
was the enemy.  i can't imagine feeling this way all the time.! so in
that vein - i am white, upper-middleclass, educated, liberal, with a
whole lot of advantages. i get pissed because just because i'm
priveledged in some ways, it is almost always over looked that i'm
first a woman who has to deal, everyday, with sexism. i never feel as
uncomfortable as i did that day in germantown, perhaps because i'm
quite used to my situation at age 30. but people don't see sexism in
the same way as they do racism. it's much more covert, you know? and
*so* imbedded in our ways of thinking, acting, dealing. it goes beyond
race - it is far deeper than that, and shows itself in all cultures.
but aside from that, i will never really know what it's like to be a
racial minority, to have racial slurs shouted at me (my favorite
sexist one? "hey baby, i wish that bicycle seat was my face")....  nor
will i ever really understand the all of priveledges that people
assume i have because i'm white. i'm still female. and i think that
was all both megan and kerry were trying to say. a man could never
understand, really, the implications of being female. we are
socialized (or programmed?) from such an early age - this is how we
should be, how we should act, talk, what we should wear, how we should
look, this is what we should do, who we should marry, and it goes on
and on. and we have to do it perfectly, you know. the other thing that
i don't think men can understand is the insecurity and fear that comes
with being female. it's no one's fault, and it's not a bad thing that
you won't understand. but the rate of rapes and abuse is so high, and
at least for me, this is something that's always at the back of my
mind. i learned at a very early age that the world is not such a safe
place for women. but you know, it's just life. and there are benefits
to being female too - wouldn't trade it for the world!

time to get some work done! - e. :)

There was mention in the Chronicle on Saturday that all permits for the 2nd
& Jackson space had been suspended due to noise complaints from Alameda,
across the water from the site. One Alameda woman who was quoted seemed
more concerned with the health & safety of ravers who danced all night,
seeming to think that was a sign of obvious self abuse.

The permit officer mentioned that when he checks up on parties he makes
sure his daughter isn't among the attendees. Apart from that he didn't give
the impression he was opposed to the events, just that the bass being 'real
high' was causing problems.

Joe

John et al.,

> 
> So until we progress as a species, I think jokes should be told only
> by
> those qualified to do so (see above and think of Chris Rock's words).
> 

Would you forsake the truth being spoken or withheld because the speaker was
not "qualified" to do so? How does one define "jokes"?
Sounds like a dangerous position to be in when one has to define "qualified".
Race is a mixed (human) bag by default, and culture is gained by experience,
sooooo.. this leaves one in a quandry when there needs to be someone who
defines the criteria to be approved and then approve those that need to police
the statements made.
I know that you are only illustrating an example (and, it seems to me,
advocating personal responsibility); but chris rock's statement addresses a
valid point successfully, but your point is scary in that it limits discovery
(either through humor or otherwise) of information to certain people who have
been deemed qualified to speak on the matter.

Some religious, scientific, and political examples of those changing the way
people think who were not deemed qualified:

1) Mohammad - The Islamic Faith
2) Malcom X - Political and Spiritual upliftment (and boy, did he realize
mistakes he had made after his pilgrimmage..)
3) Jesus Christ - as if we hadn't heard enough about this guy...
4) Galileo - Told that his views were unnacceptable by the church, yadda,
yadda, yadda...

The bottom line, I guess is this: Jokes are generally based on generalities
(pun semi intended) and therefore very rarely worth the insight they may
bring. It is tempting to categorize them as "editable statements" that are not
worthy to keep and reflect on (whether they are derogatory or not), but there
are times when thoughts or statements that are truly funny (and which reflect
on the human experience in an apparent worthwhile manner) are made by people
who have no background (or obvious authority) are extremely worthwhile to the
human species.

Short of it: Let's be careful about censorship recommendations.

$.02,

rob.
http://www.citizenmag.com

In reference to all the recent parties held in Oakland............

Wouldn't it be nice if the San Francisco underground music scene could 
have parties held in San Francisco? Just a wild, crazy thought.

  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 13 Oct 1997 20:59:02 -0000
Received: from [38.248.198.70] ([38.248.198.70] (may be forged)) by netcommunications.net (10.1/8.7.3) with ESMTP id OAA06402 for <sfraves@qmail.hyperreal.org>; Mon, 13 Oct 1997 14:06:14 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <l03110706b0683475f788@[38.248.198.70]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 13 Oct 1997 14:02:42 -0700
To: sfraves@qmail.hyperreal.org
From: Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net>
Subject: Party Review, Trance Millenium!!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Not having been sparked by a party in a long time, it is my immense
pleasure to actually write a party review (how long has *that* been?)

Trance Millenium at 1015 Folsom last night was really amazing.. the CCC and
Hunab Ku and other assorted folks created a beautiful thing from what can
often feel like a dingy and burnt-out club space.... to walk into that
place and find that it's filled with friends and wonderful people who are
there for the music was so great .... there were only a handful of the
"cocktail-in-hand-who-the-
heck-are-these-people-in-the-psychedelic-clothes?" club crowd there.
mostly it was tried and true goa-heads, trance fans and the familiar party
folks.

The main room was Goa Gil (who, even though i'm not usually a goa-head, had
me under his control for blocks of time when i had to dance like a maniac)
... followed by CEIBA live.

upstairs (where it used to be outside) was an absolutely insane room, fully
psychedelicized by the CCC folks and playing the oddest and most driving
jungle, and what must be what people are calling "breakbeat trance" which I
am now fully hooked on.

Upstairs was Joe Rice and Ethan (and John Carel after I left maybe?) and
comfy chairs and luxury.

It was never crowded (not good for the promoters, but great for the crowd),
always room to dance and breathe, but plenty of wonderful people there
making a powerful viber.

I only wish it weren't a Sunday night, because this was a party I could
have had fun at for many many hours, but I had to leave by 12:45.  Cursed
9-5 job!

I felt myself competely re-energized about what fun it can be to party, no
hassles, all good, so many friends and smiling faces, what a treat!  More,
please!

leslie




From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Oct 13 21:09:30 1997
Return-Path: <sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 10371 invoked by uid 6000); 13 Oct 1997 21:09:28 -0000
Received: (qmail 10351 invoked from network); 13 Oct 1997 21:09:27 -0000
Received: from web2.rocketmail.com (205.180.57.68)
  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 13 Oct 1997 21:09:27 -0000
Message-ID: <19971013211029.13897.rocketmail@web2.rocketmail.com>
Received: from [205.158.204.133] by web2; Mon, 13 Oct 1997 14:10:29 PDT
Date: Mon, 13 Oct 1997 14:10:29 -0700 (PDT)
From: macadio <macadio6@rocketmail.com>
Subject: Stacey pullen Review
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk



Well my Night starts out like any other Party night. I plan on getting
to the party early but you know how ravers are. I needed to make all
these crazy pit stops and stuff. So we end up running on "Raver time"
But we end up at 1015 early enough to catch simon spinning.  He was
playing some good progressive house. Highlight was hearing this house
DJ play Krakpot by Richie hawtin and some other Minimal TeKno tracks.
Then I go to the dub lounge upstairs this DJ was laying down some
funky Dub Sorry I did not get his name :-( Then I walk back to the
main room and I hear this weird tweeky kind of sounds and I instantly
know it is Stacey. He was laying down some Tweeaky Detroit Tekno/Speed
garage/Hardhouse/minimal house Kind of stuff hard to describe but it
was real nice a treat to see him work the 3 decks. He has a very
Unique way of mixing He uses a lot of the EQ and gain controls plus
some other tweaks with the pitch and fader it was nice to see. Then
Super Star DJ Jeno gets on the decks and people like rush to the front
like he is some god. I was suprised cause not as many people crowded
around for Stacey :-(  So Jeno gets on and he must have not slept or
something or was just plain having a bad night cause every mix was off
beat and not buy a little some by a lot, almost of the verge of not
being able to correct it. I know how that goes cause I have had many
of those kind of days. But it is funny how some people Idolize DJ's I
can't wait till they have the surgeon there if ever. He is a treat to
watch if you all ever get a chance you should check him out he has
unique mixing skillzz!!

Peace,
Macadio (Mack-Audio)

> up for *human* rights, as having risen above (in the context that
> glitter princess was writing) their situation. they fought it. and
> that's the only was to instigate change. whether it's violent or non,
> standing up for your rights as a person means to fight for your space
> in the world. no one will hand it to you. well, maybe if you're a
> wealthy wasp male, and even then, not always.

Please keep your racist, sexist, and religiously intolerant comments to
yourself. They have no place here( I hope.) Try rewriting it as " well
maybe if you're wealthy..."

For someone that is bitching about equality you seemingly have a lot
to learn. I can't BELIEVE after your previous comments on inequality and
sexism(most of which I agree with) you would have the audacity to
make a comment like the one above. Fighting racism, sexism, religious
persecution, etc. with more of the same is inexcusable as well as doomed
to failure. It makes you no better than the people you decry. 

While you're busy feeling sorry for yourself and taking everyone to task
for their offensive viewpoints take a good hard look at your own.

					Black Adder

From: Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net>
Subject: green eggs and rotten words
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

one more comment ... (then I may have reached my limit for posting for the
day, yikes!)

John Lee originally said..

....(NOTE:  I know some of you will ask the question, "How come it is okay for
blacks to call each other the "N" word, homosexuals can call thier own
"f*gs", etc.  well Chris Rock said it best "The reason is the same reason
that you can call your child dummy, but it is not ok for someone else to do
it."  Simple.)....


Maybe I'm missing something here  .. but it seems obvious to me that this
is a ironic commentary meant with tongue in cheek, a comment on the irony
of our twisted psyches, and how we excuse our own stupid behavior
sometimes, while condemning others.

Why do I hope this is meant to be ironic???  Because NO PARENT HAS A RIGHT
TO CALL THEIR CHILD A DUMMY.  Period.  I doubt that John actually thinks
it's ok to call his son a dummy, and I hope everyone understands that it is
psychologically damaging and ignorant.  Kids are not there to be the target
of your frustration and insults.  I know that we have been made immune to a
lot of this kind of treatment of children through the media, through tv
that portrays nasty insults as "witty repartee'" but it just isn't funny,
and it isn't right.

This comparison is not at all analogous to why subcultures have their own
"inside" names, words and jokes that aren't really appropriate for
others/outsiders to participate in.  Calling yourself a name is in no way
the same as calling your kid a name.

I guess the true key is whether the derogatory word is meant to put down
and separate the other person, or meant to reaffirm that they are part of
your world, that you consider them your peer, that you stand beside them
against a world that would belittle and mock you all.

Leslie

p.s.  someone took the post about "only those qualified to make jokes" a
little seriously.  i propose that the penalty of taking that joke as if it
were serious should result in a 7-day revocation of your own joke-telling
license.  hand it over.

Hey peoples,

just a quick little post on this one.... I am not sure where all of you are 
going on your weekends but I have only been to one party in oakland in the last
2 months the rest have been in san francisco.  granted these aren't massives
they are underground so often the case is that you don't hear about them till
the day after.

Parties go on in sf all the time just keep your eyes and ears open.

smiles,

herb

This stuff you call humor is fabricated, highly offensive and not even
funny.

I have a 26-year old [friend] and the thought that he'd be subjected to
this idiotic subliminal suggestion that he's supposed to have a lot of bucks
to buy her a ring and a VCR pisses me off big-time!!!

What bothers me most is when I hear jokes/statements that put some limited
expectations on entire groups of people ... i.e., that boys need someone to
"clean up after them." Making jokes that potentially make suppositions about
all [men] is too small minded for me.

Sorry for plagiarizing you Leslie, but I just couldn't have said it any
better myself.

Adam

>To me, this is hysterical, I was ROTFLOL!  Out of the mouths of babes (yep,
>there's some sexist stuff that hopefully these kids will un-learn as they
>grow ... but there's some gems in here!)
>
>----------------------------------
>Questions about love, marriage and sex were posed to kids
>ages 5 to 10. Their answers below are enlightening:
>
>WHAT IS THE PROPER AGE TO GET MARRIED??
>"Eighty-four! Because at that age, you don't have to work
>anymore, and you can spend all your time loving each other in
>your bedroom."  (Judy, 8)
>"Once I'm done with kindergarten, I'm going to find me a
>wife!"  (Tom, 5)
>WHAT DO MOST PEOPLE DO ON A DATE??
>"On the first date, they just tell each other lies, and that
>usually gets them interested enough to go for a second date."
>(Mike, 10)
>WHEN IS IT OKAY TO KISS SOMEONE??
>"You should never kiss a girl unless you have enough bucks to
>buy her a big ring and her own VCR, 'cause she'll want to
>have videos of the wedding."  (Jim, 10)
>"Never kiss in front of other people. It's a big embarrassing
>thing if anybody sees you. But if nobody sees you, I might be
>willing
>to tryit with a handsome boy, but just for a few hours."  (Kally, 9)
>
>THE GREAT DEBATE: IS IT BETTER TO BE SINGLE OR MARRIED??
>"It's better for girls to be single but not for boys. Boys need
>somebody to clean up after them!"  (Lynette, 9)
>"It gives me a headache to think about that stuff. I'm just a
>kid. I don't need that kind of trouble."  (Kenny, 7)
>CONCERNING WHY LOVE HAPPENS BETWEEN TWO PARTICULAR PEOPLE
>"No one is sure why it happens, but I heard it has something to
>do with how you smell. That's why perfume and deodorant are
>so popular."  (Jan, 9)
>"I think you're supposed to get shot with an arrow or
>something, but the rest of it isn't supposed to be so painful."
>(Harlen, 8)
>ON WHAT FALLING IN LOVE IS LIKE
>"Like an avalanche where you have to run for your life."
>(Roger, 9)
>"If falling in love is anything like learning how to spell, I
>don't want to do it. It takes too long."  (Leo, 7)
>ON THE ROLE OF GOOD LOOKS IN LOVE
>"If you want to be loved by somebody who isn't already in
>your family, it doesn't hurt to be beautiful."  (Jeanne, 8)
>"It isn't always just how you look. Look at me. I'm handsome
>like anything and I haven't got anybody to marry me yet."
>(Gary, 7)
>"Beauty is skin deep. But how rich you are can last a long
>time."  (Christine, 9)
>CONCERNING WHY LOVERS OFTEN HOLD HANDS
>"They want to make sure their rings don't fall off because they
>paid good money for them."  (Dave, 8)
>CONFIDENTIAL OPINIONS ABOUT LOVE
>"I'm in favor of love as long as it doesn't happen when 'The
>Simpsons' is on television."  (Anita, 6)
>"Love will find you, even if you are trying to hide from it. I
>have been trying to hide from it since I was five, but the girls
>keep finding me."  (Bobby, 8)
>"I'm not rushing into being in love. I'm finding fourth grade hard
> enough."  (Regina, 10)
> THE PERSONAL QUALITIES NECESSARY TO BE A GOOD LOVER
>"One of you should know how to write a check. Because, even
>if you have tons of love, there is still going to be a lot of
>bills."  (Ava, 8)
>SOME SUREFIRE WAYS TO MAKE A PERSON FALL IN LOVE WITH YOU
>"Tell them that you own a whole bunch of candy stores."
>(Del, 6)
>"Don't do things like have smelly, green sneakers. You might
>get attention, but attention ain't the same thing as love."
>(Alonzo, 9)
>"One way is to take the girl out to eat. Make sure it's
>something she likes to eat. French fries usually works for me."
>(Bart, 9)
>
>HOW CAN YOU TELL IF TWO ADULTS EATING DINNER AT A RESTAURANT ARE IN LOVE?
>"Just see if the man picks up the check. That's how you can tell if
>he's in love."  (John, 9)
>"Lovers will just be staring at each other and their food will
>get cold. Other people care more about the food." (Brad, 8)
>"It's love if they order one of those desserts that are on fire.
>They like to order those because it's just like how their hearts
>are...on fire."  (Christine, 9)
>WHAT MOST PEOPLE ARE THINKING WHEN THEY SAY "I LOVE YOU"
>"The person is thinking: Yeah, I really do love him. But I
>hope he showers at least once a day."  (Michelle, 9)
>HOW A PERSON LEARNS TO KISS
>"You learn it right on the spot when the gooshy feelings get
>the best of you."  (Doug, 7)
>"It might help to watch soap operas all day."  (Carin, 9)
>
>WHEN IS IT OKAY TO KISS SOMEONE?
>"It's never okay to kiss a boy. They always slobber all over
>you...That's why I stopped doing it."  (Jean, 10)
>HOW TO MAKE LOVE ENDURE
>"Spend most of your time loving instead of going to work."
>(Tom, 7)
>"Don't forget your wife's name...That will mess up the love."
>(Roger, 8)
>"Be a good kisser. It might make your wife forget that you
>never take out the trash."  (Randy, 8)
>

Oh boy, ok I'll attempt to clear this up, although I know this is futile
for this list (we've had this conversation before, many , many times).

At 1:18 PM -0700 10/13/97, Robert Pointer wrote:
>John et al.,
>
>>
>> So until we progress as a species, I think jokes should be told only
>> by
>> those qualified to do so (see above and think of Chris Rock's words).
>>
>
>Would you forsake the truth being spoken or withheld because the speaker was
>not "qualified" to do so? How does one define "jokes"?

I don't.  All I was indicating is that there are words within certain
groups that are meant to be used by those groups.  It may be considered by
those in said groups to consider outsiders use of such words as
derrogatory.  It is not only the message, but the messenger.


>Sounds like a dangerous position to be in when one has to define "qualified".
>Race is a mixed (human) bag by default, and culture is gained by experience,
>sooooo.. this leaves one in a quandry when there needs to be someone who
>defines the criteria to be approved and then approve those that need to police
>the statements made.

Nobody is policing anything.  Here's a test, try using a word that one
group has taken to use as a means of self identification or empowerment
within that group that you are not a part of.  Now watch the reaction.

>I know that you are only illustrating an example (and, it seems to me,
>advocating personal responsibility); but chris rock's statement addresses a
>valid point successfully, but your point is scary in that it limits discovery
>(either through humor or otherwise) of information to certain people who have
>been deemed qualified to speak on the matter.

There are those who are qualified to speak of certain issues and things.  I
for one do not think that someone who has not had the black experience can
write about the black experience.  And yes, there are those who are black
who even by the virtue of thier blackness may or may not be qualified, but
someone outside of the group (i.e. not black), would have a difficult time
in effectively communicating a message about and experience they have never
had.

My point and Chris' are the same.  I feel the way he does about the use of
words, exactly.  It is differnt when Chris rock speaks fo the difference
between Blacks and N's.  Put a different face on it, particilarly one from
a Euro ancestry, and you get an entirely different message.  Or I should
qualify that and say that *I* do (as well as many African Americans). One
reason why Chris isn't instantly labelled a racist when he makes such
distinctions, but others may not be so lucky if they are outside the group
being talked about.

However I did like Lenny Bruce and what he had to say, but the fact that he
was of Jewish descent gave him a different kind of credibility.  He is one
of the opressed, and as such he gets the instant qualifier by many who are
opressed to speak using charged words.  Yes, it's insane, but hey, it's
America.

>
>Some religious, scientific, and political examples of those changing the way
>people think who were not deemed qualified:

Huh?  Please clarify.

>
>1) Mohammad - The Islamic Faith
>2) Malcom X - Political and Spiritual upliftment (and boy, did he realize
>mistakes he had made after his pilgrimmage..)
>3) Jesus Christ - as if we hadn't heard enough about this guy...
>4) Galileo - Told that his views were unnacceptable by the church, yadda,
>yadda, yadda...
>
>The bottom line, I guess is this: Jokes are generally based on generalities
>(pun semi intended) and therefore very rarely worth the insight they may
>bring. It is tempting to categorize them as "editable statements" that are not
>worthy to keep and reflect on (whether they are derogatory or not), but there
>are times when thoughts or statements that are truly funny (and which reflect
>on the human experience in an apparent worthwhile manner) are made by people
>who have no background (or obvious authority) are extremely worthwhile to the
>human species.

This may have been true at one time, I would say that the climate has
changed and it is no longer true.  I would cringe at a Jeff Foxworthy (You
know him, the guy who says "You know you're a redneck if..." jokes) started
making jokes about blacks or other minorities.  we are creatures of history
here in this country, and we can never escape that.  The messenger counts.
>
>Short of it: Let's be careful about censorship recommendations.

I didn't say anything about censorship.  You can say whatever you want,
just be prepared for the consequences of your words.  Censorship in this
instance can be a very good thing if not life saving.  think about it.

>
>$.02,
>
>rob.
>http://www.citizenmag.com

Out,
John


"The first casualty of war is truth." - Rudyard Kipling

On a read-read I have to take fuher issue:

At 1:18 PM -0700 10/13/97, Robert Pointer wrote:
>John et al.,
>
>>
>> So until we progress as a species, I think jokes should be told only
>> by
>> those qualified to do so (see above and think of Chris Rock's words).
>>
>
>Would you forsake the truth being spoken or withheld because the speaker was
>not "qualified" to do so?

Er, there has been a big leap in logic here.  When was the decision made
that jokes are indeed true?  And what is the truth?

Would I forsake the truth being spoken?  Nope.  But let's get real, often
times the truth is often twisted for poltiical or self-satisfying purposes.
Statistics are good for this.  Bell curves notwithstanding.

Do I care as to who tells the truth no, but it rarely happens that way.
Does Rush Limbaugh speak the truth?  Does Farrakhan?  Does Bill Clinton?  I
would say that they all have some truth in what they say, but that is a far
cry from saying that what they say is indeed a fact.  Often times they have
protions of fact mixed with tons of spin and hyperbole.  So that's what I
see.  And I still think the messenger is very important.

David Duke had lots of truth, one can only imagine how much of it was
factual (Who were the welfare mothers he always referred to?).

> How does one define "jokes"?

I don't tell them, so I don't define them.

Peace,
John


"The first casualty of war is truth." - Rudyard Kipling

OK, I have been trying to get with what we can expect from Boymerang,
right?  Just like I was trying to figure out what the deal was with the
Trouble on Vinyl posse.

So even if Boymerang flakes at least I have some information yall might be
interested in, my questions on the breaks list answered:


> Boymerang is scheduled to play here on Monday.

> 1) when did he latch onto Metalheadz and is there any cool story
> concerning that?

Actually, I have heard a cool story:  Goldie was at the Blue Note or
somewhere and he heard some Boymerang tune drop and he went bananas.
Called Graham at like 3am and woke him up and was like "man, your tune is
f'in horrible!!" and Graham was like "oh, I'm sorry you don't like it,"
and Goldie's like "nah man, it's terrible, I mean it's terrible!" like
it's the best thing he'd ever heard, you know?  So that was kind of their
introduction, I hear.  Boymerang's been working on an ep for Metalheadz...
it's probably finished by now since it's been rumored to be in the mill
for ages.  And good night, check this out:  last I heard he was scheduled
to put out a remix of Dillinja's "The Angels Fell" on Razor's Edge.  Yo.  

> 3) can I expect him to drop new Metalheadz plates?

Probably...rest assured, although I've not witnessed him live, I
think that whatever he drops is bound to be amazing, metalheadz or no.

Andrew

On Mon, 13 Oct 1997, Kerry Levenberg wrote:

> blkadder@value.net wrote:

> > > in the world. no one will hand it to you. well, maybe if you're a
> > > wealthy wasp male, and even then, not always.
> >
> > Please keep your racist, sexist, and religiously intolerant comments to
> > yourself. They have no place here( I hope.) Try rewriting it as " well
> > maybe if you're wealthy..."
> >
> 
> I am a bit confused.  To what are you refering?  I read you as taking issue
> with the comment that wealthy white males (er, wealthy wasps?) are often in
> an advantagous position.  Am I understanding you correctly?  Please
> clarify...

I am taking issue with the use of a deregatory term. Let me ask you this:

Would it be acceptable for me to run around using the N word? Why is it
then somehow acceptable to use one deregatory term, but not the other? I
have *NEVER* seen that term (WASP) used in anything but a deregatory
fashion, as was done in this case. It is as distasteful to me as the N
word. 

I have *0* problem with the wealthy part. People with money have doors
opened for them. White, black, protestant, jewish, etc. it matters little.
Money is all green(at least in America.)

> "Bitching"?  Is it necessary to belittle all Liz has said with this kind of
> language (and such a loaded term as well, especially given that this thread
> is about sexism...).

I bitch. I am bitching now. I do not mean it in a gender-specific context. 

> > While you're busy feeling sorry for yourself and taking everyone to task
> > for their offensive viewpoints take a good hard look at your own.
> >
> >                                         Black Adder
> 
> "Feeling sorry for [her]self"?  Again, what justifies your belittling of her
> thoughts on the topic sexism, or for that matter, her experiences with
> sexism?  This comment, too, strikes me as way out of line.

I am not belittling her thoughts on sexism. As I stated I agree with most
of them. However, I do feel comments like (paraphrasing): "The rights of
men will always be looked at as more important than those of women" is
untrue, and self-serving whining. The lot of women in the U.S. has greatly
improved from it's inception, and continues to improve. And it needs to
improve some more. So I view the above statement at about this level:

"But weeeere neeeever going to be eeeequal." (sorry, intonation doesn't
travel well via email.)

Further, you won't get any argument from me that, throughout the world,
women are not treated as equals. Far from it in many cases. 
 
> That said, I still don't understand your issue with the above statement.  I
> must not have read it the way you did.  How did you read it?

I hope that clarifies it.

				Black Adder

having perused all the latest posts on this topic, i think there is
definitely enough energy to go ahead and get this started.

and as Gene said,
>one prob though: how is a project this size  going to get organized? I
>think someone (with a lot of free time on their hands) should volunteer to
>be the project coordinator, and we'll go from there.
>

so here it is:  I VOLUNTEER TO COORDINATE THIS PROJECT.  and I also want to
get as much of your input as possible.

basically, here are my thoughts:

1.  We need to meet and plan.  Maya, would you be interested in combining
the movie night with a planning meeting?  Seeing as you've already
publicized it and given directions, it would probably be a good chance to
get a lot of interested people together in the same location.

2.  We need material.  Anyone who wants to get an article or photo or
whatever published can send them to me.

my vital info:

telephoneno.------_(510) 845-2164_--------------

contactname.------_Josh Sorkin_-----------------

digitalmail.------_case@uclink4.berkeley.edu_---

analog_mail.------_Josh Sorkin_-----------------
            ------_2600 Ridge Road_-------------
            ------_Berkeley, CA 94709_----------


if you have any concerns about copyright and other important issues please
straighten them out with me beforehand, like send me a contract in the mail
and i'll send you back a signed carbon copy.  ANYTHING GOES:  PICTURES,
INTERVIEWS, REVIEWS, FICTION, POETRY, TOP TEN LISTS, WHATEVER.

3.  money.  this has got to be funded to run properly.  2 ways i can think
of are advertising and fundraising parties.  i don't think contributors
should be paid, as that's a waste of funds and it should be a labour of
love anyways.  if you think differently please let me know.

4.  staff.  following positions need to be filled.

EDITORS--good spellers with a sense of what works and what doesn't.

LAYOUT--designers with innovative artistic sensibilities.

PROMOTIONS--people who got a taste for the green (money that is) and know
how to get it.

CONTRIBUTORS--anyone with an idea and five minutes to get it down on hard
copy.


5.  Whatever you can think of.
-------------------------------
"i scream so much.  you know what i mean.  this electric stream.  and my
tears in league with the wires and energy and my machine."

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Oct 14 01:22:32 1997

Date: Mon, 13 Oct 1997 18:22:06 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Puddin N' Pie" <gchan@best.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: SFR Project: Discuss magazine
Message-ID: <Pine.BSF.3.96.971013173232.16247I-100000@shell7.ba.best.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

The influx of energy into this idea is great.  A number of people have
mentioned starting up a magazine, which I think is a great idea.  I think
we should open up a discussion on this idea before going too much further,
so that we can get as much creative input as possible. (to paraphrase ben)

I see a need for an archivist to capture the essence of the SF rave scene.
Maybe something like this exists, I dunno.  Regardless, SF Raves is a
large virtual community that is a huge network of information.  The
hyperreal sfraves site saw a big burst of growth, but as of late has
slowed down.  I think we should throw some more energy in this direction,
and create a sfraves webzine.  Perhaps a print based 'zine can come out as
a side product.  A webzine would be easier to produce.  I'm sure we can
find a site to house the 'zine for free.  We have plenty of writers,
artists, poets, trippers, gurus, scientists, coders, dj's, promoters
lurking out in 'net land.  That's what I love about this list, the 
diversity.  Let's start recording the happenings, the raves, the vibes,
all of the energy that's being produced so that posterity can look back
and say, wow so that's what it was like back then; gee we've come a long
way since then.  

So if your interested or have any ideas, dissents, opinions on what we
can/should/have to do speak up.  An aside, I've noticed that compared to
the 60's there doesn't seem to be as much political activism in our
generation.  Why is that?  I'm lazy and selfish.  But I'm trying to change
that, and starting this call for proposals and stuff is my way of taking a
step in the right direction.

So, let's keep the discussion/brainstorming going on the 'zine idea.
Once we get all the interested peeps flushed out we can take it off the
list and keep the rest of you updated.  Where can we get a subgroup
listserv started?

Sunshine on my shoulders,
George

Here's some other ideas I've been thinking of, some of which have been
done before, others fallen by the wayside;

weekly/monthly SF Raves meeting.  Every saturday, Pablo's Sugar Shack at
V/SF has a special sfraves deal going.  How is this doing?  

Ravin' Outreach.  We go to elementary schools and teach kids about
community, dance, and music.  Throw in some "banana's in pajamas" mixed in
with some funky jungle.  Show kids how to let go and boogy, actually let
them show us how to boogy.  I'm not sure how high schools would recieve
this outreach.  Maybe we could throw parties for high school and try our
best to steer them in the right direction.

SFRaves decoration committee.  We start producing various works of art,
visual designs, props and sets for use at parties.  Props and sets
courtesy of SFRaves.  Visuals by SFRaves.  etc.

There's more ideas circulating, but those will stew for now.

You fill up my senses,
George

blkadder@value.net wrote:

> I am taking issue with the use of a deregatory term. Let me ask you this:
>
> Would it be acceptable for me to run around using the N word? Why is it
> then somehow acceptable to use one deregatory term, but not the other? I
> have *NEVER* seen that term (WASP) used in anything but a deregatory
> fashion, as was done in this case. It is as distasteful to me as the N
> word.

Um, the history of the term WASP:  an acronym developed by white people
(statisticians in the 1950's I believe, who were working on census data).  It was
not developed as a term of oppression (and I have never seen it used as such-- I
have only seen it use to specify a set of white people, anglo-saxon protestants,
to be exact).  Not quite the same as the other terms of oppression.  Not to
mention the fact that it specifies one of the most privileged classes in this
country (and if you add "wealthy" to it (wwasps), you are indeed specifying the
most privileged class).

> I have *0* problem with the wealthy part. People with money have doors
> opened for them. White, black, protestant, jewish, etc. it matters little.
> Money is all green(at least in America.)

It sounds as if you mean to say that given a given economic class, opportunities
are equal regardless of race.  This is patently untrue, so maybe you don't mean
this, but it reads as if you do.  Class is a major factor, one of the biggest in
determining opportunity, but not the only factor.

> > "Bitching"?  Is it necessary to belittle all Liz has said with this kind of
> > language (and such a loaded term as well, especially given that this thread
> > is about sexism...).
>
> I bitch. I am bitching now. I do not mean it in a gender-specific context.

OK.  It is impossible to tell where you are coming from in this forum.

> > > While you're busy feeling sorry for yourself and taking everyone to task
> > > for their offensive viewpoints take a good hard look at your own.
> > >
> > >                                         Black Adder
> >
> > "Feeling sorry for [her]self"?  Again, what justifies your belittling of her
> > thoughts on the topic sexism, or for that matter, her experiences with
> > sexism?  This comment, too, strikes me as way out of line.
>
> I am not belittling her thoughts on sexism. As I stated I agree with most
> of them. However, I do feel comments like (paraphrasing): "The rights of
> men will always be looked at as more important than those of women" is
> untrue, and self-serving whining. The lot of women in the U.S. has greatly
> improved from it's inception, and continues to improve. And it needs to
> improve some more. So I view the above statement at about this level:

> "But weeeere neeeever going to be eeeequal." (sorry, intonation doesn't

> travel well via email.)
>

How you can see phrases like "self-serving whining" and "feeling sorry for
[her]self" as doing something other than belittling Liz is a mystery to me.  Maybe
you see such phrases as constructive? Why do you feel you need to be so
inflammatory?

(As John would say:)

At 06:22 PM 10/13/97 -0700, Puddin N' Pie wrote:
>slowed down.  I think we should throw some more energy in this direction,
>and create a sfraves webzine.  Perhaps a print based 'zine can come out as
>a side product.  A webzine would be easier to produce.  I'm sure we can
>find a site to house the 'zine for free.  We have plenty of writers,

While it's true that a webzine is easier to produce and costs less, I think
a free hard copy, paper magazine would have a much wider distribution in
the Bay Area and would reach all people who might not take an Internet site
as seriously as a zine...

plus the instantaneous transmission of information--you don't have to wait
for a magazine to download...

of course, the web site and magazine could mirror each other, producing the
best of both worlds--plus a website can have things like audio and video
samples and a continuously updated, evolving-by-the-second product...

I think at this point the purpose of a virtual discussion at this point
should be to get ideas of what shape we want this zine/site to take.
Things to consider:

--do we want an "in-your-face-new-media-hyper-cyber-trendy" approach like
_Wired_ and _XLR8R_ have taken?  or a more traditional approach like
_Lotus_?  or a stripped-down minimalist approach like _Fix_?  all of the
above?  silly question, maybe, but it's just to get people thinking.

--an objective view of the scene, giving equal weight to both sides of any
issue?  or a positive, "this is our happy family please join us" view?

--focus on just SFRaves, or on PLURry candylicious people around the world?

--more good nutritious text or more yummy eye candy?

oh, and most of all:  No Exclusivity.  This is going to be a production of,
by, and for ALL the people.  Full on communism. :)
-------------------------------
"i scream so much.  you know what i mean.  this electric stream.  and my
tears in league with the wires and energy and my machine."

On Mon, 13 Oct 1997, e.menon wrote:

> oh my *gawd*. all right, just as a black man can joke another black
> man, a woman another woman, a wasp anoter wasp!  

Ahhh, I see. So, if a woman had made the joke foolish fish had, everything
would have been o.k., huh? You wouldn't have any problem with that, right?
oh *gawd* yourself.

Racism is racism, sexism is sexism, whomever the mouthpiece. I simply do
not agree with the idea that it is acceptable for people to spout racial
or sexual epitaphs at one another regardless of their inclusion in that
group. 

And unless I am mistaken, you are not a male, so you are making comments
about a group you are not part of. So how are you any different from the
person you are decrying?

> jesus, buddy - do you not even see that it would be harder for a
> minority male than it would be for a white man of the same economic
> group?  

No, and by your own logic how would you? Are you a member of the male
species? Are you of what is considered to be a traditional minority group?
How could you understand what it is to be a "white male" in todays
political and social climate?

> yes, money brings with it advantages. but it wasn't until recently that
> a black man could play golf at the club with his neighbors. 

Agreed.

> and don't forget that race can affect where you can purchase a house... 

Not the last time I checked. This is your *PERCEPTION*. It is illegal to
discriminate against tenants or buyers on the basis of race, color,
religion, sex, marital status, physical handicaps, national orgin, or any
other statutes applicable to equal opportunities under the Fair Housing
act. I would never be so foolish as to say that this sort of
discrimination does not occur simply because it is illegal. My
*PERCEPTION* is that this occurs in a minority of cases and is not the
norm.

> and there *is* just a little discrepancy in the number of minorities who
> actually get wealthy enough for it to make a difference. ya know?

As doors open, opportunity and sucess follows. The doors have just
recently opened(and continue to do so.) The success is and has been
coming. Changes of this magnitude are not made overnight. Honestly, do you
expect around only 30 years after the beginning of the civil rights
movement there to be a statistically even distribution of wealth in
America? Or anywhere close to it? Most of the wealth in America is *OLD*
money. Passed down and amassed through generations.   

> I can't BELIEVE after your previous comments on inequality and
> > sexism(most of which I agree with) you would have the audacity to
> > make a comment like the one above. 
> 
> well, what _ever_. i've never run into anyone who would get offended
> by being called a wasp. i guess i never thought of it as a bad thing.
> i mean, that's what i am. it's an acronym, not a name. you will note
> that i didn't use the word 'cracker'. what's so terrible about
> white-anglo-saxon-protestant???? got me.... my entire family are wasps.
 
> Fighting racism, sexism, religious
> > persecution, etc. with more of the same is inexcusable as well as
> doomed
> > to failure. 
> 
> i don't see where you saw me doing this. educate *me*....  i just
> don't understand your point.

One of my experience with that term is from a "joke" book that I saw in
high school. You know the kind of joke book, the one with jokes about
people of various colors, blondes, etc. etc.  

The rest of my experiences with the term is seeing it used time and time 
again to refer to people of that group in a derogatory fashion. I have
never, in my experience, heard it used in a positive fashion or even
netural fashion. There has always been a pointed opinion attached to the
usage.  

> > While you're busy feeling sorry for yourself and taking everyone to
> task
> > for their offensive viewpoints take a good hard look at your own.
> 
> i never "took everyone to task", nor did i say anything about feeling
> sorry for myself. i wrote that the whole thing makes me angry, as does
> any sort of human injustice. i also said that there were benefits to
> being a woman, and that i wouldn't trade my life for a man's. i posted
> my opinion with the hopes of showing glitter princess a different
> viewpoint. i don't think i said anything offensive.... 

You took those with a differing opinion than your own with regards to
this subject "to task" in my opinion. 

As far as the "feeling sorry for yourself" comment, it was in response to
your statement to the effect that "the rights of men will always be viewed
as more important than those of women."

As a white male I guess I get to have an unique perspective on things(no, 
I really don't believe that myself, or "white males" are the only people
capable of or do share this perspective, but seeing some of the
attitudes posted here sometimes its hard not to): when I fail at or don't
get something I aspire to, I can only blaim myself. I don't have the
luxury of blaiming others who discriminated against me based on my sex, my
color, or my religion.

If anyone feels the need to flame me, make disparaging remarks, whatever:
as you are busy saying "before you dare make statements about my life as
XXXXX" or "you can't possibly understand until you walk a mile in my
shoes" I ask you to do the same. 

					Black Adder

On Mon, 13 Oct 1997, Kerry Levenberg wrote:

> Um, the history of the term WASP:  an acronym developed by white people
> (statisticians in the 1950's I believe, who were working on census data).  
> It was not developed as a term of oppression (and I have never seen it
> used as such-- I have only seen it use to specify a set of white people,
> anglo-saxon protestants, to be exact).  

This is not the 50's and terms that were acceptable then are not 
automatically acceptable now. I can think of another N word used to refer
to black people that was one step above what they were previously called,
and commonly used in the 50's, but is no more acceptable to me. 

Your experience directly contradicts mine in this regard. I have never
heard thet term WASP used in anything but a derogatory fashion, as it is
was used in the original statement that prompted my response.  

> Not quite the same as the other
> terms of oppression.  Not to mention the fact that it specifies one of
> the most privileged classes in this country (and if you add "wealthy" to
> it (wwasps), you are indeed specifying the most privileged class).

Really, you need to define "terms of oppression" more clearly. What is a
"term of oppresion?" Does this mean at one time a majority subjugated a
minority and used terms to refer to those minorities? Or does a "term of
oppression" simply mean that  a group of people were sterotyped and
referred to in a single context, which is what is what prompted my
response?


> > I have *0* problem with the wealthy part. People with money have doors
> > opened for them. White, black, protestant, jewish, etc. it matters little.
> > Money is all green(at least in America.)
> 
> It sounds as if you mean to say that given a given economic class, 
> opportunities are equal regardless of race.  This is patently untrue, so
> maybe you don't mean this, but it reads as if you do.  Class is a major
> factor, one of the biggest in determining opportunity, but not the only
> factor.

Class is the overriding factor in my opinion. Given enough money, other 
differences are mostly irrelevant. 

> > I bitch. I am bitching now. I do not mean it in a gender-specific context.
> 
> OK.  It is impossible to tell where you are coming from in this forum.

Because you are unable to grasp something does not mean it is impossible.
I haven't stuttered.

> > "But weeeere neeeever going to be eeeequal." (sorry, intonation doesn't
> 
> > travel well via email.)
> >
> 
> How you can see phrases like "self-serving whining" and "feeling sorry for
> [her]self" as doing something other than belittling Liz is a mystery to me.
>  Maybe you see such phrases as constructive? Why do you feel you need to
> be so inflammatory?

That is my take on the situation. I respect your opinion to disagree.
However, I have given specific reasons as to why I think my statements are 
other than simple belittling. Have you offered any reasoning to the
contrary?


> (As John would say:)

A suggestion: learn to speak for yourself. John is quite capable of
speaking for himself, and does so quite well. 


					Black Adder

In all fairness to the group, Leslie sent me an email about my post
about ending this thread of postings.
I don't want people to stop if they think that there is something else
that will help others or the group at large. I was posting a particular
point of view about this subject and it should probably be taken with a
grain of salt (especially by those that are really involved in this
debate).

Leslie made some good comments that I think were very relevant to my
post. So read it for the more detailed explanation of my post and the
points she brings up (which I think are very good).

Alrighty then.

Here's to more chaos and enlightenment (hopefully),

Leslie Ayres wrote:

> rob,
>
> this does sound a little odd to me ... considering that you were not
> just
> participating in this thread ... which, on the scale of intense
> exchanges
> on sfraves is neither completely out of line nor in any way obnoxious
> or
> viscious (in my opinion)... but you were participating with many
> multiple-paragraph posts of your thoughts and opinions.

Yes. This is true. Ah, the beauty of email and the internet. It plays
well with those that want to take time and reason out their thoughts
before they post and it is also a medium that allows for quick passions
that cannot be erased.
It was rash and ill-thought out. For that, I apologize.
I was erasing all these messages off my machine and this thread had
taken like 30 or so posts. Seemed like a dead-horse issue at this point.
Yep, I entered in the conversation late and then realized that I
shouldn't have. I had an offline conversation with John Lee about this
whole issue (which started w/ my first post) and that is when it hit me,
"why isn't everyone else doing the same?"
So, in haste, after erasing tons of messages, I posted w/o regard to my
involvement as well.

>
>
> so suddenly deciding that this is "too many emails" seems a little
> strong
> of a response --- there are many threads -- rave-related and not --
> which
> many people on here find not interesting, and so they just don't read
> them.

Yeah, but after 30 or so of rehashing the same points, ummm, well, I
really don't know where you should draw the line, but, well,  (as my
stance gets weaker and weaker...).... see above....

>
>
> i agree that there are times that we're beating a dead horse (see
> archives
> for leslie's "dead-horse" warning posts!  ;^)

I have. The last time you posted it I saved it. I thought it was very
well written and sage-like. It bespoke of wisdom.

> ... but -to me- this is not
> yet one of them.  particularly since just this morning, john lee
> actually
> admitted publicly that something that i said at least a year ago on a
> similar thread, actually changed his perception of something, and made
> him
> a "better person"...

Didn't know that. If that is what you hope to accomplish with postings
on this list, then, I agree. All the postings are probably worth it.

>
>
> that, to me, is way more cool than another discussion about LTJ Bukem
> or
> blow-pops. and personally much more valuable than another post on the
> merits of Technic 1200s or blue mixers.

Yes, I agree. Changing people for the better is truly worth more than a
discussion on the examples above. I think what it boils down to is this:
The list means particular things to people at specific times. It's like
when  you have a room of 400 people that get together occasionally for
different reasons and suddenly the room becomes dominated by a
discussion that is not relevant to some portion of the room. That
portion of the room will probably speak up and say something like, "Hey,
this topic isn't relevant anymore. Y'all have covered this pretty
thouroughly." etc.This list is really a self governing entity.
In the end, my stance may have been premature, but it was worth posting
if only so those involved would think twice about their next post. If it
is truly relevant (and they feel most passionate about the subject),
well, then be-damned those that are trying to squelch the debate. Hey,
I'm perfectly willing to accept the fate of being ignored.
If the list suddenly is out of touch w/ my wants or needs, then I must
unsub in fairness to the group and myself.

>
>
> being tempted to unsub due to ridiculous threads is an occupational
> hazard
> of sfraves, but if you fight it, you will certainly learn a lot about
> how a
> lot of different people view the world!

This is true. Being part of this list has been great. (sometimes it is
damn addictive and it gets in the way of work... but, oh well. I chalk
it up to research: How the 'Net can be truly collaborative.) Clients of
ours love to hear about how the 'net is addictive. It makes them feel
like they are spending their money wisely....

:)

rob.
http://www.citizenmag.com

p.s. I was talking to Fubari (who hasn't posted in awhile - unsub
victim) of Warmth CD fame, and I was telling him what was going on in
the list. Stuff like this recent rash of listings and I said something
about someone on the list having a 19 year old daughter or something....
he says, "oh, that sounds like Leslie..."
That was so cool. It's so amazing to me when we move beyond text into
the real world of persons and human contact. Makes me feel like there is
hope for this crazy thing called the 'NET.
Anyway, I just thought you'd like to know.
Take care.

On Mon, 13 Oct 1997 12:12:36 -0700 (PDT) "e.menon"
<emdash@rocketmail.com> writes:
>heya fish! (duane?) gosh, this thread has gone so far from where it
>started... i wouldn't feel offended or anything!

nope..it takes more that this to offend me. There
would have to be a deliberate attempt to harm me
for me to be offended and i haven't seen anyone do
that to me.

I was simply pointing out to megan that it is perhaps
a bit unfair to say that men are not capable of understanding 
women or their plight. Being part indian i understand oppression
and abuse...granted its not the same but close.

And i definitely am very much in touch with my past lives as a
woman ...i feel a very strong feminine part of myself and other
women share the feeling with me...yeah i understand sisterhood.

I used to work in a office with women and shared a desk with a women.
every month  i got unbearable cramps to the point of almost passing
out every time the women had their period.

Im somewhat amused at how my making a joke/complaint about
the blue angels (which are mostly men) and their abuse of women
has turned into what it has.

Just for the record i like creative women so i usually do most of the 
domestic work as i feel it much more fun to see her doing artistic
or creative work than wasting her time on  silly stuff like dishes...
plus doing things like the dishes so she has more time
for art is one way i express my love.

	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

ps...i wonder when el nino will quit making the sfrave waters so warm?

own S.F. ravers on T.V., tune in this Wed, Oct. 15th.  It's on channel 9 in
L.A. He wasn't sure which channel that is up here, but hey, we're smart
kids...I'm sure someone can figure it out.  The time is 10:30 am but, again,
that's in L.A. If someone out there is a big Dating Game fan and could post
when it's on, or whether or not it's the same as L.A., that would be great

worry...another Warmth party is in the making.....

all. I hope to see you all at Nebula (DJ Dan and Moda...yummy!!) and, of

Just a few notes:


At 9:56 PM -0700 10/13/97, <blkadder@value.net> wrote:
>On Mon, 13 Oct 1997, e.menon wrote:
<snip>
>
>> and don't forget that race can affect where you can purchase a house...
>
>Not the last time I checked. This is your *PERCEPTION*. It is illegal to
>discriminate against tenants or buyers on the basis of race, color,
>religion, sex, marital status, physical handicaps, national orgin, or any
>other statutes applicable to equal opportunities under the Fair Housing
>act. I would never be so foolish as to say that this sort of
>discrimination does not occur simply because it is illegal. My
>*PERCEPTION* is that this occurs in a minority of cases and is not the
>norm.

Wrong Patrick.  The Clinton Administration just released a study citing
that black applicants are refused for loans far more than any other group.
It's not only the purchase of a house but the aquring of a laon.  Also this
backs up a GAO report citing the same discrimination in loan practices of
major banks to minrotiy housing and businesses.  Race is still a  very real
factor.

The information is there if you know where to look for it.

Out like OJ,
John

	Mon, 13 Oct 1997 22:17:26 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Mon, 13 Oct 1997 22:17:26 -0700 (PDT)
X-Sender: sddpw@pop.sirius.com
Message-Id: <v01520d00b0684b701b71@[205.134.228.181]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: sddpw@sirius.com (Shimako-Dominguez Department of Public Works)
Subject: My Tree House - BSP + explanation

Just wanted to give folks out there a bit of detailed information about an
upcoming benefit

This Sunday, October 19th, a bunch of very good people have gotten together
to put on MY TREE HOUSE.  This is a benefit for Maitri, a hospice in San
Francisco.  It is (to my knowledge) the only hospice in SF that caters to
triple diagnosis patients, that is people with metal illness, drug
addiction, and HIV.  It is a very cool place, started by a buddhist monk in
the 80s, and now they are doubling in size because the demand for a place
like this is still very high.  Except for the bare minimum costs, all the
proceeds from this event are going directly to Maitri.  No administrative
costs, no profit skimming, just lots of people pitching in for a good
cause.

Anyway, it will be at the Sound Factory, 525 Harrison Street @ 1st, in SF.
Sound Factory is normally closed on a Sunday, so the crowd will be the one
we create.  The party is going to be in the red room area, which will keep
the vibe nice and tight.  Starting DJs are going to be Mouse, Ellen
Ferrato, and Arkay, who are the absolute shit when it comes to deep,
progressive house.  Some time after 1:00am, the drum and bass kicks in with
Tom Thump and Derek.  Visuals by Dionysus Dreams and some bomb video in the
lounge area by our secret special suprise last minute sponsor.

So, this will be a tight party for a good cause.  This will not be a
full-on mega event with a 100,000,000 kilowatt sound system, five different
color lasers, and famous DJs from around the world.  We are not trying to
impress and have kept costs to a minimum, so Maitri gets as much money as
possible.  However, if you are looking for some dope beats and don't mind
giving several of your hard earned dollars ($8 - $15 sliding scale) for a
great cause, then I hope you will come on down and check us out.

Further questions may be directed to this address.  Thanks for your time
and interest.


Rob










Shimako-Dominguez Department of Public Works (SDDPW)
http://www.sirius.com/~sddpw
415.864.7448

SDDPW is a cooperative venture in art, commerce and the pursuit of
happiness.

At 07:22 AM 10/14/97 -0700, John S. Lee wrote:
>....The Clinton Administration just released a study citing
>that black applicants are refused for loans far more than any other group.
>It's not only the purchase of a house but the aquring of a laon.  Also this
>backs up a GAO report citing the same discrimination in loan practices of
>major banks to minrotiy housing and businesses.  Race is still a  very real
>factor.

Well, I was hoping to stay out of this one...

I just recently read an article in the SJ Mercury about how, in Oakland, black and latin loan applicants are turned down for loans twice as often as white or asian applicants.  The article went on to decry the racism that the banks are showing, blah, blah...

What factors decide who gets loans?  Says my Girl who worked for years at an Oakland Wells Fargo branch:  Income, collateral, credit history, cosigners, outstanding debts, years of residence at the same location, length of employment at the same job, and age.  Perhaps I left a few out, but one factor they DON'T consider is SKIN COLOR.  I was turned down for a loan at her branch, it never entered my mind that my application was rejected because I was white and the loan officer (all of them) were black.  I had no credit, why pretend it was personal.

The fact that black and latino applications are turned down more often in Oakland has a lot to do with economic factors that effect an entire area, who happen to be mostly black/latino.  Oakland used to be a port town, back when racism was (more) blatant, blue collar jobs were about all minorities could get.  Oakland became a town peopled by folk working hard to escape the economic oppression caused by generations of bigotry.   That was then.  When the heavy industry went away, the jobs went away, Oakland never recovered.  That is now.  If there is anything to be done in this situation, it's the economic/educational factors that need to be addressed, not hurt feelings over rejected loan applications.  Are the banks racist for not handing out loans to applicants who don't meet their guidelines?  

>The information is there if you know where to look for it.

People who find the information often twist it to fit their own agendas.  When ever possible, look at the raw data and draw your own conclusions.  I've seen parts of the Clinton report, to me seemed all about causing minority voter backlash against Republican hopefuls. (Not a bad thing at all)  I'd love to see the GAO report, is there a web site?

Respectfully,

---ChrisP

On Tue, 14 Oct 1997, John S. Lee wrote:

> At 9:56 PM -0700 10/13/97, <blkadder@value.net> wrote:
> >On Mon, 13 Oct 1997, e.menon wrote:
> <snip>
> >
> >> and don't forget that race can affect where you can purchase a house...
> >
> >Not the last time I checked. This is your *PERCEPTION*. It is illegal to
> >discriminate against tenants or buyers on the basis of race, color,
> >religion, sex, marital status, physical handicaps, national orgin, or any
> >other statutes applicable to equal opportunities under the Fair Housing
> >act. I would never be so foolish as to say that this sort of
> >discrimination does not occur simply because it is illegal. My
> >*PERCEPTION* is that this occurs in a minority of cases and is not the
> >norm.
> 
> Wrong Patrick.  The Clinton Administration just released a study citing
> that black applicants are refused for loans far more than any other group.

It is easy to make statements in a vacuum. What is much harder is to site
things in their full context. Why were these folks turned down for loans?

Banks are in the business to make money. AFAIK, they really don't care who
it comes from, as long as you can repay the loan. Why would they? It would
be bad business. 

Black applicants are refused for loans more than any other group. Ok.
As we both agree the majority of wealth in America is held by white men,
and that black people statistically are among the poorest segment of our
society. So, while not having had a chance to look at this report, my
inclination is to draw a different conclusion: Blacks(statistically
speaking) are turned down for loans because they are poor and as such are
not a good credit risk. No mystery there. 

> The information is there if you know where to look for it.

Agreed, but I caution anyone to examine the source and look at *all* the
factors involved. Most people(and governments) have agendas.

And really, I feel the need to reiterate my questions again: How would it
server the banking industry to deny people loans based on the color of
their skin, etc. etc.? From a business perspective it doesn't make any
sense.

A farmer walked into an attorney's office wanting to file for a
divorce.

The attorney asked, "May I help you?"

The farmer said, "Yea, I want to get one of those dayvorce's."

The attorney said, "Well do you have any grounds?"

The farmer said, "Yea, I got about 140 acres."

The attorney said, " No, you don't understand, do you have a case?"

The farmer said, "No, I don't have a Case, but I have a John Deere."

The attorney said, "No you don't understand, I mean do you have a
grudge?"

The farmer said, "Yea I got a grudge, that's where I park my John
Deere."

The attorney said, "No sir, I mean do you have a suit?"

The farmer said, "Yes sir, I got a suit. I wear it to church on
Sundays."

The exasperated attorney said, "Well sir, does your wife beat you up
or anything?"

The farmer said, "No sir, we both get up about 4:30."

Finally, the attorney says, "Okay, let me put it this way. WHY DO YOU
WANT A DIVORCE?"

And the farmer says, "Well, I can never have a meaningful
conversation with her."
