P.s. Musings: The first thing I would do (having a little experience in this
matter already) is make a mission statement that you all could agree on. (To
make it easier, I would imagine that a select few should be empowered to make
decisions on behalf of SFRaves. Why? "How SFRavers does it take to change a
light bulb?" - Should be enough of a reason...)
After the mission statement is agreed upon (Good luck I imagine - i.e. green
eggs people) then there needs to be a line itemed list of what contents would
achieve the mission statement.
>From there you could create sections that address those needs.
Hmmmm, while I'm at it...then you need to decide how and who and what methods
it will take to keep the content relevant.
As far as advertising...yikes. That is a whole can o' worms that y'all don't
really want to open. I suggest this start out as free (web or otherwise) and
be planned around the idea that there is no money and support will be flakey.
At least then then expectations could be met w/o any hurt feelings. I hope
this doesn't sound too discouraging. I think it would be great if it could be
done successfully.

ah, back to work. I've got a mag to run already....

Organization: ANAVA Corporation
X-Mailer: Mozilla 4.03 [en] (Win95; I)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: Christopher Porter <cporter@exploretech.com>
CC: "John S. Lee" <jsl@nexsys.net>, blkadder@value.net,
  "e.menon" <emdash@rocketmail.com>, Faro@usa.net, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: blew angles & grean leggs and BANK LOANS
References: <3.0.16.19971014102553.1327b8ce@exploretech.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

There have been studies done on lending practices which accounted for all factors, so they could test the factor of race, when all other factors are the same.  It the conclusion of these studies, that race is a factor, really a surprise?  This is a national trend.  No doubt some banks are better than others.  Some branches might even show no signs of this problem.

For national data, see:  http://www.ffhsj.com/fairlend/flarch/fl970811.htm
For another study:  http://www.ffhsj.com/fairlend/flarch/fl950714.htm
For some examples, see: http://www.ffhsj.com/fairlend/flarch/fl960509.htm
for another:  http://www.ffhsj.com/fairlend/flarch/fl951020.htm

There is a lot more out there on the web, which you can find with a little looking.

There has been a lot of press over the past few years about bank redlining whole neighborhoods (refusing loans based solely on location, no matter what the other factors are in the loan aplication).  Always poor neighborhoods, true, but not all poor neighborhoods are redlined.   They tend to be poor minority neighborhoods.  Again, in our society, is this really a surprise?

We still have so far to go...

Kerry

Christopher Porter wrote:

> At 07:22 AM 10/14/97 -0700, John S. Lee wrote:
> >....The Clinton Administration just released a study citing
> >that black applicants are refused for loans far more than any other group.
> >It's not only the purchase of a house but the aquring of a laon.  Also this
> >backs up a GAO report citing the same discrimination in loan practices of
> >major banks to minrotiy housing and businesses.  Race is still a  very real
> >factor.
>
> Well, I was hoping to stay out of this one...
>
> I just recently read an article in the SJ Mercury about how, in Oakland, black and latin loan applicants are turned down for loans twice as often as white or asian applicants.  The article went on to decry the racism that the banks are showing, blah, blah...
>
> What factors decide who gets loans?  Says my Girl who worked for years at an Oakland Wells Fargo branch:  Income, collateral, credit history, cosigners, outstanding debts, years of residence at the same location, length of employment at the same job, and age.  Perhaps I left a few out, but one factor they DON'T consider is SKIN COLOR.  I was turned down for a loan at her branch, it never entered my mind that my application was rejected because I was white and the loan officer (all of them) were black.  I had no credit, why pretend it was personal.
>
> The fact that black and latino applications are turned down more often in Oakland has a lot to do with economic factors that effect an entire area, who happen to be mostly black/latino.  Oakland used to be a port town, back when racism was (more) blatant, blue collar jobs were about all minorities could get.  Oakland became a town peopled by folk working hard to escape the economic oppression caused by generations of bigotry.   That was then.  When the heavy industry went away, the jobs went away, Oakland never recovered.  That is now.  If there is anything to be done in this situation, it's the economic/educational factors that need to be addressed, not hurt feelings over rejected loan applications.  Are the banks racist for not handing out loans to applicants who don't meet their guidelines?
>
> >The information is there if you know where to look for it.
>
> People who find the information often twist it to fit their own agendas.  When ever possible, look at the raw data and draw your own conclusions.  I've seen parts of the Clinton report, to me seemed all about causing minority voter backlash against Republican hopefuls. (Not a bad thing at all)  I'd love to see the GAO report, is there a web site?
>
> Respectfully,
>
> ---ChrisP

I understand that we all have strong feelings about these issues - trust
me, I sympathize.

However, there is a time and a place - and this is not the time nor the
place for this discussion any longer.  It began with an off-topic though
humorous post, and has continued from there.

If you MUST continue this discussion, please take it to private email,
soc.women, soc.culture.american, or some other forum.  Most of us are
subscribed to this list to hear about events in the area, not about
personal agendas and opinions regarding the state of racial and gender
equality in our country.

50+ messages on the green eggs thread in less than 24 hours - I've gotten
less OTPs from newgroups in the alt.sex hierarchy.

-Corey

blkadder@value.net wrote:

> <snip>
> And really, I feel the need to reiterate my questions again: How would it
> server the banking industry to deny people loans based on the color of
> their skin, etc. etc.? From a business perspective it doesn't make any
> sense.

  It doesn't make sense form a business perspective.  It does make sense from
the perspective of racism.

Racism in the formalities of the loan processes (more often institutional than
outright redlining based on skin color), racism in loan officers who
approve/deny loans, etc.  A little racism in every step of a complex process,
even though small at each step, could have a huge cumulative impact on the
statistics of the outcome.  Many banks are working hard to eliminate these
impacts, but given the layers of the process, and the chance for racism to have
a small impact at each level, it is a difficult battle.

Peace,
Kerry

From: maruyay@SONOMA.EDU
Subject: bonding
To: sfraves discussion list <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Cc: costa <costa@SONOMA.EDU>

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hi, I just had a great weekend with my roommate and friends, and I came to
some biggest realization of what friendship really means.
I was somehow feeling a weird pressure from my friends and some other
people that I saw and met at some raves; pressure that I'm supposed to be
around them all the time, and hug them, and say, "I love you".  Those are
not the things that I do not wanna do or anything.  I think sharing time
with my friends or people and share some good vibe and hugs are really
cool, BUT not when I'm pressured to do so.  And I realized that it happens
not only at raves but in my life in general.  And since I could not handle
the pressure very well, I just stopped hanging out with most of my friends
and even feel weird about going out to a party any more.
But then, this weekend, my roommate (and friend) and a friend of ours had
somewhat deep conversation about friendship.  And our conclusion was that
"our bond, friendship, and love are there.  It's cool to say, 'I love you'
and share some time with friends, but it is not like, 'you MUST do it'.
As long as you recognize the bond, you and your friends can do whatever
you/they wanna do, and when you get together with your friends, welcome
them, and enjoy the time you are sharing with your friends."  
I'm just glad that I have a few friends who care about me and respect my
individuality.  And I do the same to them, too.
Sorry it's getting too personal, but just wanted to share with you guys
my happiness.  And I also wanted to say,
Thank you very much for being such rad friends
to Doreen and Molly.

yuko

i like the hemp-paper idea, i'm going to look into that...if anybody can
refer me some document about prices and all that i would appreciate it.

as for the web presence, i don't think it should be an either-or thing.  

there's a beauty, strength, and uniqueness to a magazine--a timeless
undeniable truth and a sense of permanence.

there's an equal beauty, strength, and uniqueness to a webzine--a
quicksilver, perpetual-motion creature of the moment.

ideally, the magazine should be used to generate support within the bay
area by giving SFR the respect and power accorded to the printing press,
and the webzine should be used to branch out and provide what the magazine
cannot--sound, hypertext, and frequent updating.

Lose some sleep and say you've tried
Meet frustrations face to face
A point of view creates more waste
So lose some sleep
and say you've tried."

I feel you girl!

You shouldn't have to say those three words all the time. In fact you
should use the verbal expression of love a lot less than then actually
*showing* someone you care. Here's a PERFECT example:

Last Friday after work I came home and was feeling kinda burned out,
bored, etc. So I went over to my neighbors to check my voice mail, and
what do you know?? A *really* genuine friend of mine left me a message
that warmed my soul and made me feel really special. The message was but
15-20 seconds long but meant so much. If you EVER feel the impulse to tell
someone you care, DO IT. Basically what my friend said was that he was
thinking about me, wanted to say hi, and that he hopes I have a great
night... and that he loves me. What's better than that? And it's even
better coming from another guy. Because it just shows me how I've evolved
into an intelligent human being, who is comfortable enough with himself to
accept love from anyone.. no matter what their sex, race, sexual
preferences, breed of animal, etc etc etc. People have put false
definiations of love in their information trays. They think that love is
either a) love you have for relatives or b) love you have for you
girlfriend/boyfriend or sometimes c) love you have for *something* you
really enjoy or admire... lets ad a "d" for humans that we admire, feel
connections to (good connections), are important to us, and that we
care about. This world is lacking love and it's up to our generation to
change that.

These are the things that matter most in life, the connections we make with 
others. Nothing can compare to this. I can honestly say that I've never
had as good of friends as I have now. My friends love me and let me know it 
on a regular basis. I feel as if all this good I do (or at least I think I
do) is coming back to me. Not that I expect it to, but I am a willing 
recipient (sp?).:)  It just makes the world so much warmer when we care
about eachother and except our differences... if only the people in power could
see this. I'm glad I'm 21 and have realized what really matters in life... 
there are people who never realize this. What would life be like??? I feel
sorry for them.

Friends are what life is about. Whether it's a boyfriend, girlfriend, cat,
dog, fish, pet rock, etc. Anything that gives and excepts love is a friend
in my book.

CHAPTER 1 Complete.. :)
I'm sorry for those who don't like long messages, but sometimes I have
something to say. That's the point of this anyway.. right. And besides, if
you don't want a heart felt message (that may be longer than most) you can
skip anything that has byroni written on it. I'm not your average bear...

Byroni

> <snip>
> >
> >> and don't forget that race can affect where you can purchase a house...
> >
> >Not the last time I checked. This is your *PERCEPTION*. It is illegal to
> >discriminate against tenants or buyers on the basis of race, color,
> >religion, sex, marital status, physical handicaps, national orgin, or any
> >other statutes applicable to equal opportunities under the Fair Housing
> >act. I would never be so foolish as to say that this sort of
> >discrimination does not occur simply because it is illegal. My
> >*PERCEPTION* is that this occurs in a minority of cases and is not the
> >norm.
> 
> Wrong Patrick.  The Clinton Administration just released a study citing
> that black applicants are refused for loans far more than any other group.

It is easy to make statements in a vacuum. What is much harder is to site
things in their full context. Why were these folks turned down for loans?

Banks are in the business to make money. AFAIK, they really don't care who
it comes from, as long as you can repay the loan. Why would they? It would
be bad business. 

>Black applicants are refused for loans more than any other group. Ok.
>As we both agree the majority of wealth in America is held by white men,
>and that black people statistically are among the poorest segment of our
>society. So, while not having had a chance to look at this report, my
>inclination is to draw a different conclusion: Blacks(statistically
>speaking) are turned down for loans because they are poor and as such are
>not a good credit risk. No mystery there. 

>>> The information is there if you know where to look for it.

>Agreed, but I caution anyone to examine the source and look at *all* the
>factors involved. Most people(and governments) have agendas.

>And really, I feel the need to reiterate my questions again: How would it
>server the banking industry to deny people loans based on the color of
>their skin, etc. etc.? From a business perspective it doesn't make any
>sense.



Gotta agree with Patrick on this one.  While I won't claim that discrimination 
does not exist, banking is an _intensely_ competitive industry.  The criteria 
for deciding whether or not to make a loan is very formulaic-- you can even 
apply for one over the phone or on the internet (i.e., race is unknown).  If 
there was a large, credit-worthy population of blacks, hispanics, whites, 
aliens, or dogs that was not being served solely because of discrimination, you 
would very quickly see the opening of the Bank of Nathan in metro centers 
around the country.

>>  We never should have given the old hippie a ride.   Doreen had 
>>  already told me and Layne Loomis she'd sport us a piggyback to the 
>>  after-hours party, so the car was full.  But then there was the 
smelly 
>>  old guy who had been hanging around the party all night.  He wasn't 
>>  even a hippie; just some smelly old rambling dood with a backpack.   
But
>>  Doreen was always having trouble with the law too, so I guess she 
empathized 
>>  for the old guy.
>>  
>>  Doreen was all psyched for the after-party, but me and Layne Loomis 
were 
>>  too busy making faces about the smelly guy who was climbing into the 
back 
>>  seat with me.
>>  
>>  Once we were on the bridge, We started axing the guy all kinds of 
questions:
>>  
>>  "So what up, are you a  travelling raver or something?"  Doreen 
said.
>>  "Naw,"  said Smellydood.
>>  "Homeless?"   said Layne Loomis.
>>  "Naw."
>>  "So what brought you to the party last night?"
>>  "I was doing 'research'." he told us.
>>  "Well, why you lugging that nasty old backpack all over God's 
kingdom?"
>>  "I'm heading up to the Unabomber trial in Sacramento."
>>  "Damn, bro.  So what are you carrying in your backpack?  Dope?  
ha-ha!"
>>  "Ain't none of your Got Dam business,"  said Smellydood.
>>  
>>  Then Layne said,  "Shucks, 
>>  Smellydood, we don't care if  you're carrying a stash or running 
from the
>>  law or whatever.  Maybe we can even help you.  But you don't have to 
be 
>>  such a nasty old stinky mean guy."
>>  
>>  "I tolt you, it  ain't none of your Got Dam business."
>>  
>>  And that's when Doreen started flipping out, swerving all over the 
bridge 
>>  and shouting at Smellydood.  We almost got crunched by a busload of 
deadheads 
>>  before she made it to the Treasure Island exit.  Doreen was all 
huffin and puffin 
>>  and fixin to bust an artery, shouting, "Get out of my car, you crazy 
old Unabomber 
>>  backpack-wearing smellydood!"
>>  
>>  We all started slapping at the crazy guy because we were scared he 
might not get 
>>  out of the car,  but he jumped out before we even came to a complete 
stop, and 
>>  Doreen zipped back into traffic like Paul Newman on crack.
>>  
>>  Then once we got to the warehouse in Oakland,  I went to get my 
backpack, 
>>  except Smellydood had grabbed MY backpack and left his!  I was lucky 
cause 
>>  all I had was rave fliers in my pack.  But Smellydood's backpack was 
stuffed to 
>>  the rim, and there was a funnnnny smell coming out of it.  We had to 
use Layne's 
>>  knife to cut the straps off of it.
>>  
>>  Let this be a lesson to all of you--this story could have had a 
scary ending.  Be careful
>>  giving rides to strangers, folks!  Just because they're at a rave 
doesn't mean they're friendly!
>>  
>>  see you out this weekend!
>>  
>>  b))merang

On Tue, 14 Oct 1997, peter sandifer wrote:

> >>  We never should have given the old hippie a ride.   Doreen had 

What ever happened to that Crunchman fellow?  This story reminded me of a
very psychotic journey through the lower mountain ranges of California
looking for a rave in a clearing somewhere after a Dr. Freecloud's party
had been broken up... forest fire burning in the distance, one ex hacker
frying balls in the passenger seat of his car as I drive the gutless
wonder through the dark winding canyons, rave newbie in tow who ends up
freaking out as a result of his homophobia not mixing well with his first
E (Andy, there some _GUYS_ watching you dance dood!  What's up with that
maaaan?), and at the end of the road an _Amazing_ party called Elevation
put on by our lovely cousins from the south... SoCal Raves.

I know that wasn't the intent of the story, but I think I know what was in
that backpack.  They took it right out of the briefcase from "Pulp
Fiction" and put it in the backpack, but what was the old hippy doing with
it?  It's not his to carry either, just ask the man with the bandaid.
Everybody has their own, but some folks don't realize it, and that's the
first step towards losing it.

... or something like that...
AndyW

p.s.	Write me personally if you're bored.  Cause I am right now (I'd
refer to my list of things to do, but most of them would get me in
trouble at work on a day like today).  Anybody have plans for this
weekend?  Heh...

The thing I find most amusing about this thread is that there has been a 
weekly going on down here in SoCal land called "Green Eggs and Ham" and 
it's been one of the best things to happen down here in a long time (eg. 
quality music, great location, great vibes, never gets busted, runs for 
10+ hours etc. etc. etc.).

So on SoCalRaves, you see all these posts with "Green Eggs and Ham" in 
the header and you get excited, and then on SFR you see posts with "Green 
Eggs and Ham" in the header and you just wanna hit the D key...

Received: from get.wired.com (localhost [127.0.0.1]) by wired.com (8.8.6/8.7.3) with ESMTP id TAA02673; Tue, 14 Oct 1997 19:59:30 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <199710150259.TAA02673@wired.com>

             <9710142326.AA1265@notes2.compuserve.com> 
Date: Tue, 14 Oct 1997 19:59:30 -0700
From: Jim Ausman <ausman@wired.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

>> Wrong Patrick.  The Clinton Administration just released a study citing
>> that black applicants are refused for loans far more than any other group.
>
>It is easy to make statements in a vacuum. What is much harder is to site
>things in their full context. Why were these folks turned down for loans?

Let's see, a quick hotbot search turns up:

http://www.areuea.org/evidence.htm

"Agents own prejudices and the prejudices of their customers are shown to be 
be significant in explaining discrimination. Results also indicate that
white home seekers are steered toward more white and affluent neighborhoods." 

http://www.aclufl.org/r-exist.htm

This organization... sends out "testers" when someone complains they were
denied fair housing. When a race discrimination charge is made, the testers
are controlled for made, the testers are controlled for all variables but
race. For example, a black tester will claim the same family status as a white
tester, thereby excluding that as a possible reason for the disparate treatment. 
Sadly, blatant discrimination is frequently uncovered. HOPE has just 
filed lawsuits against the owners of three Dade apartment complexes
where black testers were told either no apartments were available 
or were shown sub-standard units and within hours white testers
were shown apartments in good condition and informed of immediate vacancies. 

At Morningside Apartments in Coral Gables the apartment manager is 
alleged to have said in broken english to a white tester "Black
man, I no rent. You know we all Americans. I decide they mucho problema." 

http://www.hud.gov/cfo/cfoprf44.html

HUD recieved over 10,000 cases of discrimination in housing last year alone.

http://www.lawaid.com/discrim.htm

"Unlawful discrimination in housing occurs in this State regardless of 
both Federal and State fair housing laws that prohibit it. Statistics
have shown that such unlawful practices continue even though there 
have been successful lawsuits that have been filed collecting
substantial damages."

And on and on and on. 

It is difficult to quantify the exact extent of this discrimination, but
it certainly exists. I think you only have to look at the extreme segregation
of our communities on the basis of race to say that the problem is severe.

>Banks are in the business to make money. AFAIK, they really don't care who
>it comes from, as long as you can repay the loan. Why would they? It would
>be bad business. 

Banks are in business to make money, but bankers decide who to offer loans
to on the basis of many factors, personal prejudice (perhaps unrealized)
and upholding "community standards" being some of them.

>>So, while not having had a chance to look at this report, my
>>inclination is to draw a different conclusion: Blacks(statistically
>>speaking) are turned down for loans because they are poor and as such are
>>not a good credit risk. No mystery there. 

Actually, this report indicated that blacks with similar income and
credit history were denied home loans at three times the rate of whites.

>Gotta agree with Patrick on this one.  While I won't claim that discrimination
>does not exist, banking is an _intensely_ competitive industry.  The criteria 
>for deciding whether or not to make a loan is very formulaic-- you can even 
>apply for one over the phone or on the internet (i.e., race is unknown).  If 
>there was a large, credit-worthy population of blacks, hispanics, whites, 
>aliens, or dogs that was not being served solely because of discrimination,
>you would very quickly see the opening of the Bank of Nathan in metro
>centers around the country.

It is possible to apply for a home loan over The Net? If that is true,
I have not been able to find it.

Take it easy,
Jim
------------
"By pressing on the special key, It plays a little melody." -Kraftwerk

I do not like them with my spam.
i do not like them under a wave,
i can not eat them at a rave.
No green eggs and ham for me i say,
I will not roll them in my jay.

Excuse me, I think that these topics are on topic to the list most of the
time.  Usually at the beginning of a discussion.

You can, as I do, use filters and delete the messages of no use.  I have to
do it for the ever increasing "NRR:" posts.

I think that the topics, race, class, gender, poltiics, are all a part of
dance culture.  I do not think that things disappear when you are dancing,
life goes on.  It is natural to see these topics brought up every now and
then.  it is unresolved, and things unresolved, like police brutality,
continue to pop up until they are dealt with.  I do not think raving
provides that much shelter from reality.

I do agree that the post has become way off topic, and should be taken
private.  I also think it should have been NRR, if to be on the list at all.

I think it is healthy to have discussions such as these.  And as compared
to some of the stupid flamewars of past, it is refreshing to see so many
people reallly taking the time to give thought to the various subjects.  It
shows that there's a certain intellectual vitality.  In any case there are
arguments made about some of the "so called" rave posts citing them as not
being rave related.  to each his own I guess.

If people are communicating, isn't that what it's about(raving/ dance
culture/ hanging out)?  Use your filter, your delete key when necessary,
you too are responsible for your mail.  I'll do my part and consider this
post off topic, except for my speech.

Speaking of dancing:

There will be a Wicked this Friday.  Friday btw is the usual evening for a
proper Wicked.  Anyway it's gonna be @ Big Heart City.  That's where I'm
gonna catch a groove wit da crew:  Jeno, Markie, Rob D., and Garth.  Should
be a good one, there hasn't been a Wicked for a while, and I fully expect
to hear some good music and get a groove on.

At 1:35 PM -0700 10/14/97, Corey Alambar wrote:
>I understand that we all have strong feelings about these issues - trust
>me, I sympathize.
>
>However, there is a time and a place - and this is not the time nor the
>place for this discussion any longer.  It began with an off-topic though
>humorous post, and has continued from there.

And easier way would have been to send the message to the offending people
rather than splatter the whole list, making you partly culpable.

>
>If you MUST continue this discussion, please take it to private email,
>soc.women, soc.culture.american, or some other forum.  Most of us are
>subscribed to this list to hear about events in the area, not about
>personal agendas and opinions regarding the state of racial and gender
>equality in our country.

It is not personal agendas, they're called ideas.  And parties can have
very personal agenda driving them.

BTW there is an SF Raves Calendar list that gives you the dates of events,
if that's all you want.  I mean why was there a club called Your Sisters
House is the first place?  Becuase the so called "non-rave" issues are
relevant to dance culture, and have an impact.

>
>50+ messages on the green eggs thread in less than 24 hours - I've gotten
>less OTPs from newgroups in the alt.sex hierarchy.
>
>-Corey
>
>P.S. I wil lnot reply to responses to this message posted in public.

Then one can only wonder why you would post it publicly if you did not wish
to have a public response.

Alrighty guys,

I'm sure most of you grasped the absurdity of the joke that I played w/ the
Green Eggs People, but if you didn't (sigh...)

FYI:

It was a parody of the lamentations that people post to the list about their
convictions and what rights they have about posting their beliefs. In light of
the serious interplay that occurs between members of this list (i.e. Green
eggs), sometimes it is good to have a little wackiness. 
PLUR was never violated.

I, (heh, heh) of course, respect and honor the Green Eggs People.

;)

rob.
http://www.citizenmag.com

Received: from si.UCSC.EDU (randream@si.UCSC.EDU [128.114.129.25])
          by cats.ucsc.edu (8.8.5/8.8.4.cats-athena) with SMTP
	  id OAA26665; Wed, 15 Oct 1997 14:32:16 -0700 (PDT)
Received: by si.UCSC.EDU (8.6.13/4.7) id OAA20082; Wed, 15 Oct 1997 14:31:54 -0700
Date: Wed, 15 Oct 1997 14:31:54 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Ran D. Dreams" <randream@cats.ucsc.edu>
X-Sender: randream@si.UCSC.EDU
To: Is it Trance? <604@party.net>
cc: Know 1 <knowoneness-l@photon.net>,
  nick farwell <nick_farwell@macmail.ucsc.edu>,
  sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: Millenium Trance (review)(long!)
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.971015005106.24598A-100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


Hi all!  ]=}

 In conjunction with the 30th Anniversary of the Summer Of Love (held in 
San Francisco's Golden Gate Park this past Sunday) was the Millenium Trance 
party featuring Goa Gil on the main floor (with Ceiba/Kode IV giving Gil 
a brief break), CCC in one room with various friends spinning, and 
members of the local UG spinning in another room (Ethan Miller and Joe 
Rice of FnF).

 The main floor was *fantastic*!!!!! :) Incredible lighting, great sound, 
places to sit, plenty of fresh cool air, lots of room on the dance floor. 
Goa Gil was playing really tasty, spine-shaking stuff!!

	The lighting;
	  -8 Cyberlites around the upper edges of a rough rectangle.
	  -At *least* 20 to 30 other intelligant lighting units throughout 
	   the room. 
	  -Looked like two lasers, one full colour.
	  -Giant mirror ball, various projection screens.
	  -video projection and high res monitor (Paradise Video)
	  -*very* tasteful light show!! 

	The Sound;
	  -Four giant EAW stacks hanging from the corners of the room. :)
	  -Not sure what kind of bass bins used but they were powerful.
	   I had two *minor* complaints on the sound- There was a 
	   pronounced standing wave effect happening. When this happens 
	   the bass response is very loud near the walls and virtually 
	   non-existant near the center of the room (this is caused by 
	   the physical interaction of the room accoustics and placement 
	   of the bass bins). The other complaint was that the satelitte 
	   speakers kept fluctuating in volume (by a small amount admitedly).  
	   This was most pronounced towards the end of the party.

	Decorations;
	  -A giant mirror ball that lowered to the floor (from the ceiling).
	  -A hexagon lighting truss (around the mirror ball) that raised 
	   and lowered independantly of the mirror ball. On the truss 
	   were 6 intelligant lighting units. The truss could (in 
	   addition to going up and down) tilt while all units were 
	   swiviling their beams around. In addition there was a circular 
	   screen around the mirror ball and hexagon truss. Not only did 
	   this pick up the random (yet prolific) bits of coloured lights 
	   from the laser, mirror ball, intelligant lights, but the 
	   screen could collapse on itself *and* could be raised or 
	   lowered independently of the mirror ball and truss. (whew!)
 	  -At times the air was just filled with brilliant bits of light 
	   EVERYWHERE! A few big purple lite banners in the nearby 
	   sitting areas completed the beautiful setting
 	  -At least 20 to 30 coloured DataFlashes including some in the 
	   truss around the mirror ball.

	The Music;
	  -FANTASTIC!!!!! Gil played (as always) fabulous material!!! I 
	   actually think I heard some *really* older material at times that 
	   sounded like stuff from his earlier days (see my post on 
	   Goa/Psychedelic Trance coming up in a few days)
	   Ceiba/Kode IV gave Gil a short break around midnight (?). They 
	   played less Breakbeat Trance than when I heard them at Burning Man.  
	   Very enjoyable. It was the hardest I have ever danced.

	The Crowd;
	  -Not a whole lot of folks there which made it fine for dancing 
	   but it would have been nice to see more people. The bar crowd 
	   was minimal and some stayed the whole night to lose themselves in  
	   the dance.  :)
 

 The CCC room was likewise fun! A good study in fluro and retro 
psychedelic lighting. The floor was always comfortably packed with lots 
of smiles all around. Had *real* fun dancing to Adams set!!!  :)

 Didn't check out the FnF room too much (I'm such a trance head) but Joe 
Rice was spinning some nicely phunky stuff when I did. The couches and 
footrests really made dancing all night a pleasure.

 I've been (and still am) glowing from this event. I really feel that the 
wonderfully good vibe from the Summer Of love festival really helped. 
Many of the *really* old time psychedelic family from San Fran 
Psychedelic Communitty were there. I think they liked what they 
experienced. Our little party was announced from the stage at the 
festival and was recognised (the trance dance and rave scene) by the old 
timers as the continuation of the psychedelic energies they started way 
back in the late fifties/early sixties.

 Hi to everyone I saw!!!!  :)

hugz,


Ran D. Dreams


				    (Namaste)
                                         /
                                   -=*=-/
                                     ~

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Oct 16 00:48:35 1997
Return-Path: <sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 10866 invoked by uid 6000); 16 Oct 1997 00:48:34 -0000

  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 16 Oct 1997 00:48:32 -0000
Received: from [206.169.229.104] (malay-104.ppp.hooked.net [206.169.229.104])
	by mom.hooked.net (8.8.5/8.8.5) with ESMTP id RAA08808;
	Wed, 15 Oct 1997 17:45:27 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Wed, 15 Oct 1997 17:45:27 -0700 (PDT)
X-Sender: deepfog@mail.hooked.net
Message-Id: <l03020903b06a8f3206b4@[206.169.229.7]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: "Those Silly Ravers..." <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: Deepfog <deepfog@hooked.net>
Subject: a few comments about "bandwidth"
Cc: Mr nStuff <stuff@hooked.net>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hi everyone.

Lately some people have put me on their mailing list for jokes, etc, and I
appreciate that.  I have never really understood the concept of bandwidth
until recently, when I received an email and my eudora thingy was taking
FOREVER to download something.  Well, I Quit Eudora, went into the Apple
Menu Items and selected NCSA Telnet to use Pine to find out what the hell
the problem was and I found out someone had sent me pictures.

I ended up having to delete it because I did not wish to wait to download
it and I am not sure if I can view it anyway.  It made me think about this
bandwidth thing a bit.  It's a good idea to do a few things that can help
reduce it and make it easier for people to download their mail.

1.  Ask them if it's okay to send them pictures first.  Some peoples'
computers don't support that stuff yet (like my ole trusty IIcx) so maybe
it's a good idea to not send something that is over 100 times larger than
the average email, plus when we put it on a mailing list, that is 100 times
times whatever number of people we ares sending it to.

2.  When responding to a thread, try to weed out some of the old part of
the thread.  Most people that are following the thread already know what
has been said, and if someone can't catch on, they can find a web browser
and look through the archives.  Also, on that note, maybe consider how many
people you want to CC...I'm pretty guilty of that myself nStuff (right
jeff?).

3.  This doesn't mean stop sending me mail, or other people.  It's just
something to consider.  Like...do I or do I not recycle this [item]?

There are probably some more, but I don't want to become like th internet
police because there is a fine line between creativity free flowing and
just plain wasing space.

Just like there is a fine line between getting opinions out there and flame
wars.  Lately I have noticed the number of flame wars out there has
increased, and I am not going to tolerate it anymore.  What the hell is
going on out there?  If some of you guys don't cool it out there, im gonna
come over there and smack you one!  Now be good!  I know there are some
proactive people out there, start taking responsibility for your own
actions, it is your own job to make sure you are a positive influence on
this list not just someone who finds fault with everything and everybody.
It's not Brian's job or anyone else to tell you what is expressing opinions
and what is simply being negative and finding fault.  If you want to live
that kind of life in a public forum, move next door to Oprah Windbag's
studio and get free tickets every  day to be part of the studio audience.
In fact, go anywhere in life and you will notice that there are people
everywhere focusing on what is wrong with everything.

Let's instead start once again focusing on what is right with the ravE
community and screw all those people outside of it that are trying to stop
us from bringing house, techno, trance, jungle, drumnbass, and ambient
music to the Bay Area.

I know there are at least one of you out there.  You're just afraid to
speak up because...  -?-

dEEp

The ABC's of Friendship

        A Friend...............

Accepts you as you are
Believes in you
Calls you just to say HI.
Doesn't give up on you
Envisions the whole of you(even the unfinished parts)
Forgives your mistakes
Gives unconditionally
Helps you
Invites you over
Just because
Keeps you close at heart
Loves you for who you are
Makes a difference in your life
Never judges
Offers support
Picks you up
Quiets your fears
Raises your spirits
Says nice things about you
Tells you the truth when you need to hear it
Understands you
Values you
Walks beside you
Xoxoxoxox
Yells when you won't listen
Zaps you back to reality

        May we always be good "buddies"
        May we always be good friends...
        and may our friendship be the kind
        that never ends..........................

So, I taped Spencer on 'The Dating Game'.  It's 100% hilarious!  The 
other two bachelors come off like total dorks and Spencer is Mr. Man! :D  
And whenever the camera is on him, he's smiling, dancing, bopping around, 
etc. etc. etc.!!  

The best part of the whole thing:  SPENCER WINS!!!  This beautiful woman 
totally disses the other two dorks and picks our boy Spencer!  And what 
do they win?  A trip to San Francisco! :D  Though, Spencer told me that 
he didn't actually get to go on a date with the woman.  :/  Ah well, it 
makes for great TV though!

Highlights:

Chuck Wollery:  "He says you have no idea what fun is until you go to one 
of his underground parties -- let's say hello to Spencer!"

Spencer's 'Wizard Love Spell'

Bachelor #3 yelling out football calls

Spencer doing a 360 on his way to meet the lady who picks him

You kids gotta see this!!  I'm sure it's going to be on visuals tapes for 
the next umpteen million years (and I'm already working on the techno 
remix of the whole segment) but you gotta see it!  If any of you venture 
to SoCal, let me know and I'll show it to you!! :)

PLUR

PS:  I miss you bay area folks!  Even with all the green eggs and 
bitching and such, I really miss you kids!

An Irishman walks into a bar in Dublin, orders three pints of Guinness and
sits in the back of the room, drinking a sip out of each one in turn. When
he finishes them, he comes back to the bar and orders three more.
The bartender asks him, "You know, a pint goes flat after I draw it; it
would
taste better if you bought one at a time."
The Irishman replies, "Well, you see, I have two brothers. One is in
America,
the other in Australia, and I'm here in Dublin. When we all left home, we
promised that we'd drink this way to remember the days when we drank
together."
The bartender admits that this is a nice custom, and leaves it there.
The Irishman becomes a regular in the bar, and always drinks the same way:
He orders three pints and drinks them in turn.
One day, he comes in and orders two pints. All the other regulars notice
and fall silent.
When he comes back to the bar for the second round, the bartender says, "I
don't want to intrude on your grief, but I wanted to offer my condolences
on your great loss."
The Irishman looks confused for a moment, then a light dawns in his eye
and he laughs. "Oh, no," he, says, "everyone's fine. I've just quit
drinking."


Peace, Luv, & Hugs
Rebel D Monteer
terrapin@lords.com
http://www.psnw.com/~terrapin
http://wwp.mirabilis.com/1175641 <-- page me here

                         ***UPCOMING RELEASES***
Call Raul/Sang/Matt for a complete list (hey... it's changing like crazy)
(call for press listing for our last CD/12" releases - thanks to all the
writers/reviewers that gave Silent a second listen...)

Vinyl is not dead... Oh yeah... to get sound samples go to our web page :)

Look for more of the San Francisco sound on wax and shiny silver things...

*Solstice-TBA                   SR9717 (360/Silent)      July 30th       12"
Jazzed-up, street tough loungey music which has Gina's vocals in top form
mesmerizing... Expect to hear more from these talented kids...

*VA-Skulpture & Broken Sound    SR9720 (Silent)          Aug 15th        2XCD
The ying and the yang of hip-hop meet as one half brings you the twisted,
sparse and austere face of hip-hop while the other assaults you with the
turntable wizardry of some of the best fucking up said avant-hop...

*VA-Lower Haight High Hitters   UNKNOWN ORIGIN            ????           12"
Take your super-secret project by some pretty high-profile suckers and add
your usual portions of house music creativity and fun... Viola... the
souffle is ready...

                        ***NEW RELEASES***
*Jondi & Spesh                 SR9722 (Trip N' Spin)    out now          12"
Inspired by the Sweet! parties and ' Live at Half moon Bay ' show, this is
the second EP in the collaboration between Trip 'N Spin and Silent.  Floor
rocking trancey house with a left-coast feel.  Remixes by NovaBass.

*VA-Combine EP                 SR9714 (Organised Noise)  out now         12"
Some of the best straight up techno west of Carl Craig, Stacey Pullen, Ian
Pooley, Derrick May, etc. All of whom are dropping it in their sets...

*VA-East Bay Conspiracy EP     SR9713 (Trip'N'Spin)      out now          12"
Featuring the likes of ETI, Jondi & Spesh, Nick Kelly & Cave Dwellers...
A intense contribution to the San Francisco/West Coast House Movement
Deconstruction meets Hardkiss

*Various Artists-Skampler      SR9708 (SKAM)             out now         CD
ONLY PLACE TO GET AUTCHERE'S GESCOM, ET.AL. ON CD
Autechere=Warp (the label)= released by TVT= Gescom=Owners of SKAM

*Epsilon-The Black Hole SR9712 (SoundSphere Recordings) out now          12"
Wicked brit-style dark jungle by the artist that has surprised most
junglist with his debut appearance on several UK playlists... No U-Turn
meets Penny Black

*Mammal-The Big Ten-Four EP    SR9711 (360)              out now
12"
Speaking of wicked... Thomas of Wicked Productions presents us with the
debut release as Mammal... Downtempo funk with raw/intelligent grooves

*Various Artist-Drum Kicks EP  SR9710 (XLR8R Trax)       out now         12"
Hot Sequel to Bad Brakes EP; more of that soothing ;) west coast sound with
a wee bit of attitude for good measure...

*Various Artists-BAD BREAKS EP SR9709(XLR8R Trax)  12"   out now         12"
Mutha Beep-Beep by Professor Smith has charted in the UK; CMJ RPM and Jackpot
Reviews by Deep Dish (favorable) in MixMagUS;
1ST PRESSING SOLD OUT!!!

*Makyo-Rasa Bhava: sr9606
incredibly powerful piece/includes a Bill Laswell remix... referred to this
new sound as Indihop and zen dub... Write-ups in the Wire, Fix, etc.
Reviews as shown plus...

*Various Artist-Land of Baboon (an illclectic brooklyn collection): sr9607
in cover stories by Option and the Wire/ranging from Dub to jungle to
trip-hop to ambient-dub/write-ups (artists and/or release) in the Wire,

Here's one more thing you can do to conserve bandwidth: don't send 500 line
messages such as the one you sent to the SFR mailing list that are not rave
related ... *even* if you mark it NRR. The damage is done once you click on
"send." Whether the subject line has "NRR" is inconsequential.

Hi!  =]

you are so right.  

...but as many people don't even know what bandwidth is, as did not I
6 months ago, wouldn't sfraves be a great place to educate a few
people?  i mean, where else are they going to learn this stuff?  To my
knowledge, there is no bandwidth-education@hyperreal.org.  My company
recently (only very recently) set up a web page and now they have on
their applications their web address.  this stuff is so new.  i think
people deserve to be educated.  i've said it before and i say it now,
this is more than just a rave discussion group, this is a social
thinktank.  I have met some really wonderful people on this list, and
some of them have become very dear friends.  Topics at raves are not
always restricted to rave related stuff, why should it be here?  

I'm not trying to downplay what you have going on here, you have a
good point.  My feeling is that at some point down the road, another
list will pop up that will be only for posting BSp's and/or other
strictly rave related topics.  that way people who don't want all the
100+ messages a day (come on guys, its' gonna grow, and there is
notheing you or i or santa claus can do anything about it) can just
subscribe to that list.  that would be something to be heavily
monitored and a detailed email stating it's strictly for (whatever
subject it is about).  A while back someone started a sfr-legality
mailing list, so i think some more of those would be nice, i am sure
there are.  

so anyway, now i've filled up a whole lane in the information
superhighway, and they are honking in back of me.  Sharif is probably
wailing on the horn right now, so I see a Denny's I'd better pull
off...


-?-   dEEp

going off about whatever. But once you send a message to this list, we all
have to download (yes you can filter, but *after* you download).

then *create* a new list and have at it, don't hijack an existing list.

>always restricted to rave related stuff, why should it be here?

>100+ messages a day (come on guys, its' gonna grow, and there is
>notheing you or i or santa claus can do anything about it) can just
>subscribe to that list.  that would be something to be heavily

>mailing list, so i think some more of those would be nice, i am sure

Right on..  It's all about acceptance.  (No I'm not biased here at all
<sarcasm>  OH NO... )  I love those girls Teresa and Patrice.  I think that
picture of them is so damn cute with the orange courdoroy and rainbow furry
overalls.  Yep.. they're such nice people.  =)
  but on that note... I never know whether to keep encouraging people to
embrace the rave scene  or to say screw it and keep it to ourselves.  Just
gotta try to keep the positive outlook n' everything.  Look at the bright
side.... they don't know what they're missing.  
 FOr months I'd try to convince my friend how much fun raving was and how it
brought people together.  He'd blow me off with the usual, "sure, whatever
tweak."  WE were still friends, tho.  Then about two days ago I got an e-mail
from him.
       "I JUST WENT TO THE GATHERING IN SAN JOSE AND OHMIGOSH I SAW THE
PACIFIERS AND EVERYTHING YOU TOLD ME ABOUT AND I LOVED IT."
This is how the scene should work, and we shouldn't need to make excuses for
other people.  Just my nickel...

[ to sfraves list ] 
Hugh asked ...
> 
> Did anyone go to the Full Moon party last night?
> 
 It was a beautiful night for dancing under the moon. Not a cloud in the
sky, no fog or mist at the beach to speak of. 

 I got to the voicemail site at about 2AM, just before the police did!
In short, the cops gave the Wicked crew 10 minutes to haul the sound 
system off the beach and clear out the people ! 

 The alternate site was spread by word of mouth - a spot on the bay.
Various strings of cars made the trip, so the crowd at the new site
was about 60 to 80 people by 5:30 AM.

 I had been to this site for parties before, and I was reminiscing about
the time we had to move a busted party there about three years ago.
We had been dancing for about an hour when the sprinklers went on!

 Well, history repeated itself! And the crowd last night did the same
thing we did three years ago - gathered the local garbage cans and
covered the sprinkler heads with them. You could dance next to them
and hear the sprinkler jets hitting the sides of the metal cans.

 ( A note for the next bunch that uses this site - do the park maintenance
folks a favor and bring big plastic garbage bags with you to replace
the ones you may have to pull out of the cans in order to use them 
as sprinkler blockers )

 DJs were hot!  Carlos was good to see again - I haven't watched him
in action for over 6 months now. A real mixing genius ! And of
course his enthusiasm is a big big part of a Wicked Full Moon party.
Other DJs were ( I think ) George, Jonas(?), Melanie, and another
Jonas(? - someone correct me please!).

 Good funky house music! Tribal beats and funky breaks and heartbeat
4/4 and spacy acid lines and soulful vocals and samples. 

 Friendly crowd. Not too many "candy ravers", but that fancy-dress
stuff is usually for warm indoor and daytime events, I'd think. 

 The timing of sunrise and moon setting in the bay was just right!
Fat golden sun rising over the Oakland hills and relecting as a 
shimmering column on the water of the bay, as the moon in the west
faded against the lightening sky as it set behind the hills
above Pacifica.

 A first for me last night - Red Bull! It was too dark to see if this
stuff was red or not. Since Carlos gave it to me, I almost feel like
I should keep the can as a souvenir! It did assuage my hunger, and 
maybe it did gently perk me up. I'd like to bring some to the next 
psy trance party I go to . Oh, by the way, it tastes like what I'd
imagine carbonated Gatorade would . Do they still sell Tang - that
powdered orange juice ? Tastes a bit like that too.

 Anyway - last night's full moon was a beautiful little party,
despite the authorities and the park sprinkler system!

Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

the first time i check my email in the morning i down about 200 [about 75
are work related].  and my prog checks every 5 min after that, at
which/each time i recieve approximately 2-5 msgs [more if this list is
jumpin'].  this goes on from about 8 in the morning to 6-7 at night [on
average].

this does not include the 2-3 times i check on the weekends if i'm not
working [i try to stay away if i can/get some sunlight]

as for the morning, i answer/read mails solid from about 8 to 12 minimum,
then get on with the rest of my workday [yes this *is* at work].

i don't feel like i have a problem [denial, 1st syptom] but would be
willing to attend a support group if one starts...  i might meet some real
people. yay!

-SolR

From: Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net>
Subject: To Rave or Not to Rave...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Trice said...

>  but on that note... I never know whether to keep encouraging people to
>embrace the rave scene  or to say screw it and keep it to ourselves.  Just
>gotta try to keep the positive outlook n' everything.  Look at the bright
>side.... they don't know what they're missing.

she was responding to teresa...


>I was in a chat room tonight for fun and posted a pic; the one below, and
>two chics that were in Tennesse-never even been to a rave decided that me
>on the left and my best bud Patrice looked like drag queens and were
>losers because we had fun. My mood is a little shot down now, but only
>for those that choose not to have an open mind.  ( I even tried to still
>be nice to them afterwards, but only recieved more negitivity that we
>were freaks.)


in my experience, i have come to the very strong belief that raving --
whatever it means to you -- is a very personal thing ... and if you belong
there, you know it.  you know when you first "got it" about the driving
bass, the pounding music, the lights, the energy, the throngs of people
dancing.

people always ask me if my daughter raves (they were very curious about
that when i went on the leeza show to talk about the positive sides of
raving), and i say no, she doesn't like it .... she thinks it's too loud,
too crowded, too hot.  inother words, it just isn't her thing (though she
doesn't hate it, she just isn't driven to do it)

to make a controversial analogy, it's sort of like finding religion.  when
you have that epiphany, that "i have finally found it" it isn't really
translatable into words.  and you can't use words to convince others.

it is my policy to *never* try to encourage someone to come to a party with
me, because unless they have that pull to do it on their own, then it's not
really their time yet.  and i hate having to feel responsible for someone
not feeling like they're somewhere that they belong (and besides, then they
want to go home early, and that sucks!)

and -- on the other side of this coin -- remember that there are *LOTS* of
other wonderful things to do that have nothing to do with raving ..... i'm
sure there are people who ride rodeo, or go fly fishing, or (as i
not-so-tactfully said to one of the mothers on the leeza show) play bingo
... these are people who find the happiness and release and feeling of
community in those activities that we find in raving.

Some of those activities are closer to the spirit of raving (like gospel
music, which to me comes sooooo close to the energy and positivy, the
participation and joyouseness that can be found at great parties), and some
are very different (like hunting), but we should remember "to each his or
her own."

bottom line, people don't always understand what the rave/dance community
is about, but they might be mighty cool anyway.  And remember too, that
we're all products of our environment, and to two girls from Tennessee, you
candy ravers probably looked like you were from another planet or
something.  (actually, sometimes you guys look like you're from another
planet to me!  ;^)   which ain't necessarily a negative thing!

but expressing real aspects of who you are is not about approval from other
people, it's about being yourself and being proud of who that is.

love, leslie

i've heard a lot of people complaining about the copious posts to this
newsgroup.  personally, i kind of like the plentiful messages and
topics, its kind of like holding 10 virtual conversations at once. 
but i can see how it could be too much for some people.  so what i'm
wondering is, has anyone out there tried the "digest" version of
sfraves?  isn't that like one or two posts a day of the "best"
messages or something?  i thought about subscribing myself but decided
i liked reading all the many posts better than working anyway (as long
as i'm sitting in front of my computer typing it pretty much looks
like i'm being a productive little drone, heh heh...)  i'd be
interested in reading a "review" of sfraves-digest if anyone's
actually subscribed...

-messiah w

Subject: Cheescake brownies
Message-ID: <19971016.164903.3415.0.foolish_fish1@juno.com>
X-Mailer: Juno 1.38
X-Juno-Line-Breaks: 0-26
From: foolish_fish1@juno.com

Precedence: bulk

Since i wont be coming to the party this friday and i have
recieved a couple of private requests for this and since
these can be wonderful treats to spread around at raves
to make people happy i figured it would be ok to post
this to the whole list. 

A little taste of heaven.

I pkg betty crocker fudge brownie mix( actually any mix will do)
8 oz cream cheese, softened and filled with love.
1/3 cup sugar
1 egg
1/2 tsp vanilla
green stuff ( or blue stuff or red stuff or whatever)

prepare brownie mix as directed on package. Pour into
greased pan.

Beat cream cheese and sugar in electric mixer until smooth 
and full of love. You may chant over them if you like.
Add egg and vanilla, mix well.

pour cream cheese mixture over brownie mix and cut thru 
with knife for a marbled effect

Cover with green stuff if desired and bake at 350 for 35 min
or until c.cheese is slightly browned.

i never get sick and tired of listening to electronica.  i have records 
will play on the down lo strictly b-sides....

walk into room. lights flash.  blue light cool my aural projection.  
familiar and somewhat pleasant odour of fog machine.  pea soup fog 
minded strolling along loops of eternal graciousness. bombastic warm 
bass rubs and the everdreamy nite away..........

mind ache. disneyland feet.  home ward bound. back to the light. back to 
the way it was.  must get rested.

must get dressed and cue up all the b-sides special mix.

quick soft spinal explosion.  makes me wonder how i ever lived without it.
tell me we're all beautiful.

pour clear glass of sunshine, bottled at the rise.

clouds soar like angel breath.  moon winks twice, shimmers and shakes in a
rainspattered puddle.

mad god dancin a merry jig two miles north of the center of the universe.
groove to that piper.

correct, measured, accurate, precision.  with intent to consume.

growling jumping frogs in a chorus across an infinite shard of bayou.
alligator go a-swimmin, swill dat moonshine.

cool like gin and tonic, gentle pale perfumed skin tastes of long-forgotten
phantasms.  o i am melted by those perfect almond eyes and the myuzik keeps
on going.  and going.

and going.
--i am electric wave particle.
and going.
--i am god's little toy.
and going.
--i am a forever dancing serpent twist in the wind.
and going.

and going.

and going.
-------------------------------
"i scream so much.  you know what i mean.  this electric stream.  and my
tears in league with the wires and energy and my machine."

On Thu, 16 Oct 1997 03:26:49 -0000 "Rebel D Monteer" <terrapin@lords.com>
writes:
>An Irishman walks into a bar in Dublin, orders three pints of Guinness 
>and
>sits in the back of the room, drinking a sip out of each one in turn. 
>When
>he finishes them, he comes back to the bar and orders three more.
>The bartender asks him, "You know, a pint goes flat after I draw it; 
>it
>would
>taste better if you bought one at a time."
>The Irishman replies, "Well, you see, I have two brothers. One is in
>America,
>the other in Australia, and I'm here in Dublin. When we all left home, 
>we
>promised that we'd drink this way to remember the days when we drank
>together."
>The bartender admits that this is a nice custom, and leaves it there.
>The Irishman becomes a regular in the bar, and always drinks the same 
>way:
>He orders three pints and drinks them in turn.
>One day, he comes in and orders two pints. All the other regulars 
>notice
>and fall silent.
>When he comes back to the bar for the second round, the bartender 
>says, "I
>don't want to intrude on your grief, but I wanted to offer my 
>condolences
>on your great loss."
>The Irishman looks confused for a moment, then a light dawns in his 
>eye
>and he laughs. "Oh, no," he, says, "everyone's fine. I've just quit
>drinking."
>
>
>Peace, Luv, & Hugs
>Rebel D Monteer
>terrapin@lords.com
>http://www.psnw.com/~terrapin
>http://wwp.mirabilis.com/1175641 <-- page me here
>
>

<sfraves@qmail.hyperreal.org>; Thu, 16 Oct 1997 16:04:26 -0700 (PDT)
>Message-Id: <l03110707b06c47230e6d@[38.248.198.85]>
>In-Reply-To: <971016180529_1178092345@emout03.mail.aol.com>

>To: sfraves@qmail.hyperreal.org
>From: Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net>
>Subject: To Rave or Not to Rave...
>Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
>Precedence: bulk
>
>Trice said...
>
>>  but on that note... I never know whether to keep encouraging people 
to
>>embrace the rave scene  or to say screw it and keep it to ourselves.  
Just
>>gotta try to keep the positive outlook n' everything.  Look at the 
bright
>>side.... they don't know what they're missing.
>
>she was responding to teresa...
>
>
>>I was in a chat room tonight for fun and posted a pic; the one below, 
and
>>two chics that were in Tennesse-never even been to a rave decided that 
me
>>on the left and my best bud Patrice looked like drag queens and were
>>losers because we had fun. My mood is a little shot down now, but only
>>for those that choose not to have an open mind.  ( I even tried to 
still
>>be nice to them afterwards, but only recieved more negitivity that we
>>were freaks.)
>
>
>in my experience, i have come to the very strong belief that raving --
>whatever it means to you -- is a very personal thing ... and if you 
belong
>there, you know it.  you know when you first "got it" about the driving
>bass, the pounding music, the lights, the energy, the throngs of people
>dancing.
>
>people always ask me if my daughter raves (they were very curious about
>that when i went on the leeza show to talk about the positive sides of
>raving), and i say no, she doesn't like it .... she thinks it's too 
loud,
>too crowded, too hot.  inother words, it just isn't her thing (though 
she
>doesn't hate it, she just isn't driven to do it)
>
>to make a controversial analogy, it's sort of like finding religion.  
when
>you have that epiphany, that "i have finally found it" it isn't really
>translatable into words.  and you can't use words to convince others.
>
>it is my policy to *never* try to encourage someone to come to a party 
with
>me, because unless they have that pull to do it on their own, then it's 
not
>really their time yet.  and i hate having to feel responsible for 
someone
>not feeling like they're somewhere that they belong (and besides, then 
they
>want to go home early, and that sucks!)
>
>and -- on the other side of this coin -- remember that there are *LOTS* 
of
>other wonderful things to do that have nothing to do with raving ..... 
i'm
>sure there are people who ride rodeo, or go fly fishing, or (as i
>not-so-tactfully said to one of the mothers on the leeza show) play 
bingo
>... these are people who find the happiness and release and feeling of
>community in those activities that we find in raving.
>
>Some of those activities are closer to the spirit of raving (like 
gospel
>music, which to me comes sooooo close to the energy and positivy, the
>participation and joyouseness that can be found at great parties), and 
some
>are very different (like hunting), but we should remember "to each his 
or
>her own."
>
>bottom line, people don't always understand what the rave/dance 
community
>is about, but they might be mighty cool anyway.  And remember too, that
>we're all products of our environment, and to two girls from Tennessee, 
you
>candy ravers probably looked like you were from another planet or
>something.  (actually, sometimes you guys look like you're from another
>planet to me!  ;^)   which ain't necessarily a negative thing!
>
>but expressing real aspects of who you are is not about approval from 
other
>people, it's about being yourself and being proud of who that is.
>
>love, leslie
>
>
>
>
>
>

from the mayan oracle

Ben

I am Ben,skywalker, time/space traveler,
gentle messenger of the light.

I am the touch of angelic grace.

Once embraced in my robes of light,
a new tone is struck.

Sublime transfiguration becoming in you
 the fruit of divine loves yearning for itself.

I am skywalker who has come to earth,
entering this time and dimensional reality
to initiate vision in this age of masks with few eyes.

I reveal the sweet power in the simplicity of love
as i awaken with my silken touch
the resonance of heaven you have yearned for.

The new harmonic octave has arrived.
The song of the future returning to itself,
now pulsates thru the earth.

Even now its tender promise quickening
within every cell of humanity,
that these heavenly frequencies return
in this time of the great miracle
to draw the shimmering center of humanity
up to embrace the pillars of heaven,
whose beams from the once and future dream,
longing to awaken.

Winged child who walks in wisdom and tenderness,
thou art innocent laughter and flowered heart
open wide in celebratory passion,
for this dream is vitally alive.

And i, the cosmic pied piper,
extend to you now my gentle hand.
Let us take a free fall flight into the unknown.

Abandon your fears.
With unwavering trust, step upon my star-path,
spanning dimensions like a luminous bridge.
Joyfully will we dance awake the dream
on the altar of the present moment,
the platform of sacred delight and glowsticks
joining heaven and earth.

Move in uncharted territory
with protean reference points.
unveiling the one true identity

I am ben
Here to bridge you with a remembered message
from your own heart.
You are a pillar of light on earth,
and heaven is where you stand.

How many of you remember the old Pure Space parties?  I hope I can stop
by for old-times sake ;).  It should be cool.  Our House has a nice little
lineup too, then there's a whole ton of stuff on Friday, including Wicked
and Step2k.  The Party By the People looks good for Saturday, then on
Sunday there's the free Organic in GG Park, and then the huge Global DJ
Mix Awards show on Sunday (check out the lineup).

I'm going to clean up the radio and TV shows soon, so if your show is there,
and you haven't sent me anything about it recently, please drop me a 
message saying it's still on, or give me any updates.

				-Derek

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 8pm-10pm - "Soundz of Resistance" w/DJ Poohbear.
       Underground electronic music, mainly jungle/drum and bass, dub and
       hard techno along with guest DJs, interviews and not-so-random
       amples of life. KZSC 88.1 (Santa Cruz)
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. The
       best in beats to satiate your inner child. Electronic dance,
       noise, spoken word, world music and more. Also available in
       RealAudio. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 5pm-9pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of jungle, dub,
       breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon and guests -
       Beats, Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford). Also broadcast via
       RealAudio.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Saturday night - "House Nation" w/"Anthems Mix", Top 10s from
       guest DJs and "London Connection w/DJ Doubt". 2am-4am, WILD 94.9
       SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.org with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.org with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.org

 Yup,
That's the space it will be held at. As for the vibe, price etc... the music
will speak for itself... we (FTT) put in a lot of effort to choose the right
kind of music to appeal to all our audiences, and we spared no expense to
bring in artists that we feel represent the best in their genre... and
sincerely want to introduce them to our audience...  eg. the
downtempo/chill-out room (ULTRA LOUNGE) with the Ninja crew, Fila Brazillia,
NIghtmares etc... costs us more in talent fees than the other 3 rooms.
Which promoter in their right mind would spend more money on a chill out
room than the main room, unless they were serious about the music, know
what's up with music, and serious about introducing the scene to world class
acts?
Anyway, I'm getting pretty excited about the party and in spite of the
problems other parties have had with the space, we have a few things up out
sleeve that will make the money you spend at our show a memorable
experience!!!

Mohan
Funky Tekno Tribe

- Philip wants:
<< get something strange.. or out of the ordinary >>
I did the best I could for ya man.  It's hard when you consider my mom taped
half of this stuff back when Pay-Per-View was free for us

- Priscilla asked for:
<< how about Peter Pan or The Muppet Movie >>
Well, I couldn't find The Muppets Take Manhattan for some reason.  Maybe my
sibs are borrowing it, but I can bring Peter Pan.  :o)

- Josh Sorkin wants:
<< old Liquid Television episodes (Aeon Flux episodes with no words--yum)...
something from the "Mind's Eye" series... those really old black and white
cartoons>>
Well, I'll be bringing Beyond The Mind's Eye but as for the rest, I don't
have it.  :oP

- Messaih Wannabe
<< "meet the feebles"... >>
Well, unfortunately, I don't have that either.  Not many old cartoons here,
just old cartoon movies.  Here's a list of what I've pulled out so far.

Cartoons:
- Tenchi Muyo Episodes 2-5 (you know this is on every Sunday on Channel 54)
- Robotech episodes.  (Not quite in order but hey, there's a bunch of 'em and
some are actually pretty close.)
- Macross II: The Movie
- Ghost in the Shell (with subtitles. You can turn off the volume and make up
the words.  Or hell, leave the volume up and practice your Japanese.  :o)
- The Fluppy Dogs Movie (I think it's actually the t.v. premiere for the
Fluppy Dogs)
- Rudolph's Shiny New Year
- Care Bears Nutcracker Suite
- Care Bears Movie II
- Pete's Dragon
- Duck Tales: The Movie
- The Camel Boy
- Puff the Magic Dragon
- The Secret of NIMH (very /<ewl if you've never seen it)
- Frosty in Winter Wonderland
- Fern Gully
- Charlotte's Web (I dunno, the end may be too sad for a raver night)
- Alice in Wonderland
- Peter Pan
- Dr. Dolittle (O/<, so it's not a cartoon, but it's still weird kid stuff)

Normal Movies (about three movies per tape):
- Gloria; Mr. Mom; The Toy
- Vice Versa; Willow
- Bright Lights, Big City; Sinbad: The Eye of the Tiger; 7th Voyage of Sinbad
(Hey, someone wanted funky old movies people don't really know)
- The Star Chamber; The Neverending Story; Blackout
- Haunted Honeymoon; Down and Out in Beverly Hills; Labrynth
- Native Son; The Sicilian; Mac and Me (funky alien/ET type movie)
- The Philadelphia Experiment; Oh God, You Devil; Beat Street (Remember way
back when. . .)
- Krull; Lady in Red; Breakin' (. . . breakin had nothing to do with raves?
 Hehehe)
- Drop Dead Fred (Can't get much weirder than that); Butch Cassidy and the
Sundance Kid; Hot Shots
- Against All Odds; Benji (You know, the doggy); Flash Gordon (Woo hoo!!
 Flashback!)
- Legend (a very /<ewl movie.  I taped it off TNTso I tried to edit out the
commercials but kinda fell asleep towards the end and forgot to start taping
agin so I missed a bit of the end)
- Singin in the Rain (Ah the classics. . . ;oP)
- The Princess Bride (anyone who doesn't like this movie cannot be my friend)

Random Funky Shhhhtuff:
- Beyond The Mind's Eye

Any Other Requests?   Hurry before I leave. . .   :o)
You can always call me too.  I'm at 408.526.0606.  I should be at home all
day getting everything ready (and sleeping t' make it through the night O/<,
don't worry about waking me up though)

Hope to hear from everyone really soon.

LuV -N- BiG HuGZ,

I'm never sure how effective these e-mail "calls for action" letters are, 
but this one seemed at least worth effort of hitting the forward 
button.......  I hope this actually does some good.

B-)



HERE IT IS:
American Airlines is a major sponsor to and supporter of groups like GLADD,
the Human Rights Campaign, the Gay and Lesbian Victory Fund, the AIDS Action
Foundation, DIFFA, AmFAR, and scores of community-based groups representing
gays and lesbians. It is also the first airline to adopt a written
non-discrimination policy covering sexual orientation in its employment
practices. In an unusual joint letter released to the media on Friday, March
14th from the Family Research Council, Concerned Women of America, American
Family Association and Coral Ridge Ministries, American Airlines was openly
criticized about their policy. Radical right leader Beverly LaHaye also went
on Christian "talk radio" on Friday to blast American Airlines because
"American's sponsorship of homosexual 'pride' events constitutes an open
endorsement of promiscuous homosexuality." She and the other groups have
written Bob Crandall at American to complain that the airline has  "gone
beyond mere tolerance" of gays and lesbians.  The full article appeares in
Friday's Fort Worth Star-Telegram, and possibly picked up by other
newspapers around the country.
It has come to the attention of the gay and lesbian community that
American Airline's switchboard and e-mails are being bombarded now by
homophobic and hateful callers who have been urged by LaHaye and others to
DEMAND the company terminate its gay-friendly policies.

Please add your name to this petition and forward it to as many people as
you can. To add your name just cut and paste this onto new mail and send it
out!
***if you are the 25th, 50th, 75th, 100th, etc. person to sign this

I think it sucks that some insane people would do something like this(if it
is true). Why doesn't someone ever see the person(s) responsible for this and
beat their ass??  Hearing about stuff like this shows how the scene has
become. I for sure don't want to go to Tribal Massive if I'm going to have to
worry about being stabbed with a needle by some lunatic. It sucks that you
have to think about things like this. I wish the scene was like it used to
be. I can remember being at a party and asking some complete stranger to
watch my bag, and then come back half an hour later and get my bag and not
even have to worry about stuff being stolen!! That is the way it should be.
I've read enough mail from people saying they've gotton their stuff stolen,
and now this needle scare thing. I would really like to see things improve. I
love to dance at parties, but I'm fearful that it will have to change. I
refuse to endanger my life by going to parties and have to worry about
getting HIV/AIDS. NOBODY should have to worry about that at a party!!!
                                 PEACE, <3, and :)   is what it is all
about!!!!!
BECCA

Could we NOT spread this type of info?

Tell the person who told you that you do not believe them, unless they
tell you the source.  These types of rumors SUCK.  Don't you realize this
is screaming fire in a crowded theater?

AIDS/HIV is a serious, life changing and often life ending
illness/condition, and you should tell your sick friends you heard this
from that there is no evidence of this occurring, and that if they know,
they know from the inside and should report it.  If it did happen, the
media would take SUCH a long ride on something like that, that we would
ALL hear about it, over and over and over.

This is another total bullshit myth based on the media/societal paranoia
that HIV positive people have nothing to live for and are mad at the
world.  This is so not the case, I have two friends that have discovered
that they are positive since I have known them, and in my experience, it
brings people to realize how precious life is. 

Because it is.

I mean, if they know enough to know that 5 more people have been chosen,
they either heard it from somebody who KNOWS, or they are making it up.
In either case I am disgusted.

Thank you for dessimating my apetite during my lunch break.  Anybody in
San Jose want a salad?

Please spare me any future paranoid urban myths.
AndyW

yOU KNOW...

 Ooops..  Ok..

You know...
 I really love thoughs tech support calls where the customers sound card
"ain't getting any sound"
 I just got off the phone with this guy.. He calls me up complaining about
his CDROM not playing any audio.. So I go over a few things with him.
.Turns out he had the speakers plugged into the wrong socket. So he plugs
it into the correct socket (speaker out) and all I can here in the back
ground is moaning sounds. Like fake orgasims or something.. I am like..
"Ok.. Looks like we nipped that one in the bud"

 You know.. There will always be a group of people out there ready and
waiting to talk shit about other people. They usually do it to look cool
amongst their pears. Yanno. Because they don't feel they are all that hip
or whatnot.
 But.. You know. If they were to just...Go to a ravE.. You know, these
people you are talking about. They would probably be cooler afterwards..
You think?
 Anyways. I got this bad habbit.. I usually use body lanquage to show
concideration.. Need I say more? Yep.. Most people can not read into body
lanquage as well as myself..  So.. I suppose I should speak up more often.
But...Then you got my friend Wayne.. He is constantly letting you know "Oh,
thats not what I meant to say".. "Don't get me wrong"... Sometimes I just
think he is being, alittle over conciderate..

Welp.
Back to work.
Jeff

no
