>start looking inward.
 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
yup that's where it's at, baby.  There's the DJ called Barry Weaver,
I think he's from Portland; and  I was reading this interview with him 
once--he said some stuff that could easily be seen as shallow and
empty...but which I actually found kind of refreshing.

He said that too many people take raving too seriously; they are looking
for answers and are off on this spiritual quest; and only get frustrated
when find that there are no answers.  He said if people just focus
on having a good time, they'd be a lot happier.

Of course, there's a lot more to it than this...but I do
think that there is a certain wisdom to what he said.  I think a lot
of us (self included)  are in this rush for a spiritual 
quickfix.    

Maybe if we just ease up on the gas and just focus on having a
good time,  the rest (spiritual enlightenmnet) will just occur 
naturally.

I think that in reality, raves aren't really that diffferent from 
the real world, in spite of what a lot of us like to think.
There are cool people, arrogant people, jerks, giggly people, 
solemn people, ex-crackheads (HI!), spiritual types, and people just 
lookin to knock some
boots at the end of the night.

Hopefully though, we are leaning toward some sort of unity.  but
what the hell is going to happen when we get there???

Might be kind of dull.

anybody wanna fight? Mr. Adder?  Mr. Dreams?  Mr Lee?

love you kids.
We rock the house.

At 02:25 PM 10/17/97 -0700, you wrote:
>For those who call tech. support regularly...........
>RTFM Okay????
****
when they get all riled up... you just say in a calm voice...

"You aren't being inconsiderate are you...?"

"what?"

"This free tech support you're getting... for this software... something we
don't distribute... and don't suggest using... you aren't being
unappreciative..."

they generally get docile after that....

or my other fav is... when they are being real jerks....

"Do you mind holding forever?"

they say yes 90% of the time. duh.

tech support is sooo lame, but hey... you can make it fun.

smiles
-SolR

***
hi folx...this is a post i made to midwest raves.  i thought this might
help take the edge off all the seriousness this week...read up and enjoy!

the best, mr s!  all the time mr. w!

***


I dunno...has like wicked ever thrown a party out there?  I guess that's a
stoopid question, cause like Mark Farina comes out here to the city all the
time.

someone mentioned in their post that it should have the music all broken up
into different slots and all that.  I think that is a good idea.  We threw
2 parties called "Warmth" out in SanFran, and that's pretty much what we
did.  Mixed up the music.

Then this kid walked up to me and said he was from another sound crew and
he didn't think it was a good idea to have this dj play after this dj
because the music styles were different.  i told him that was the whole
point.  the party went off, i personally felt i hadn't felth that good
about a party in at least 3 years.

...but you know, there is some value to having a one-room party with 4 dj's
all having at least 2 hour sets, playing good progressive house, techno,
acidhouse, with an ambient room or hallway, and the party ending at 8am,
fruit, coffee, tea served afterward, and getting to hang out in the space
for a few hours after the party instead of getting swept out on the street
like a piece of trash 5 minutes fafter the party ends.

The thing is, who is throwing parties like that any more these days?  I
suspect that since we are having this discussion online, not many.  Even
the party crews I considered to have those qualities I just listed have
seemed to lose some of their edge.

In my eyes, it's not really the music that makes the party.  It's the
people throwing it and attending it.

That I seperate into three distinct areas.

-The promoter(s)
-The promoter's crew
-The partygoers

There might be others but they can be grouped into these categories for
this time being.

The promoter has the most responsiblity to make the party good, because
everyone is looking at him or her.  And if they are treating everyone with
respect or disrespect, it can really affect the crew in a positive or
negative fashion.  That all trickles down on the people attending a party.
Ever been to a rave and sensed wheter the vibe was good or bad?  Look at
what's going on behind the scenes.  Watch what they do.  That will tell you
a lot.

But then responsibility also lies within all of uson how we REACT to our
environment.  That responsibility is individual.  One of the problems in
our country today is that most people are rEACTIVe, or allowing their
environment to control their attitude.  If any of you have lived near the
ocean, that becomes completely apparent, because you will notice that when
it is cloudy out, everyone is inside, and then as soon as the sun comes
out, everyone flocks to the beach.

so if you are reading this, maybe consider that next time you are at a
party.  if it is good or bad in your eyes, you have the power to react to
it in whatever way you want.  im not suggesting that you lie to yourself
and say it is good when you really don't feel that way.  but if it's bad,
you can A/ try to make it better by contributing positive energy to the
party, B/ leave and go home or go to another party that is better or C/
stay and complain all night.

oh, yeah, there are other choices, but i don't feel like listing them.

good night.

(ps, i wanna come spin out there!!!)

drugs may lead nowhere....but at least it is the scenic route

>Is This a Dangerous Precedent?
>
>By Harry Browne
>
>Detroit, Sept. 2: Anti-driving activists cheered
>today when the head of one of the Big Three auto-makers
>admitted publicly that driving automobiles may have
>caused the traffic deaths of thousands of Americans.
>
>For the past decade the auto-makers have steadfastly
>denied any link between driving and auto accidents.
>Leaked documents show that they have suppressed any
>internal studies tending to support such a link.
>
>Other leaked documents indicate that auto-makers
>secretly tampered with the engines in their cars --
>regulating horsepower and fuel content to make the cars
>more powerful.
>
>The documents also support the claim that auto-
>makers intentionally target young people in their
>advertising -- by showing racy automobiles, pretty
>girls, and happy drivers. Anti-driving activists
>maintain that the auto-makers have to recruit 40,000
>new drivers annually to replace those who die from car
>accidents.
>
>Today's admission by the Big Three auto-maker may
>make it easier for state governments to win the many
>suits now in the court system -- suits demanding that
>auto-makers reimburse the states' Medicaid systems for
>money spent treating victims of auto accidents.
>However, supporters of the auto-makers have long
>contended that auto accidents save the states money --
>by reducing the number of people who live long enough
>to receive state-supported health care.
>
>The admission that driving may have caused traffic
>deaths still leaves unresolved the question of whether
>driving is addictive. When accused of trying to hook
>people on driving, auto-makers traditionally produce
>witnesses who claim to have quit driving on their own
>and who insist they lead drive-free lives by using
>public transportation. But anti-driving activists say
>that, at the very least, cars should have strong
>warning labels -- including a Skull & Crossbones, as
>with poisons.
>
>Also unresolved are a number of questions relating
>to the "second-hand driving" issue. Does driving cause
>pedestrians to die in car accidents? And, if so, should
>driving be outlawed completely? Or should it be
>regulated by the BATF as a weapon? Should driving be
>prohibited within 50 feet of federal buildings, as
>President Clinton wants?
>
>Supporters of driving say the root issue is one of
>personal responsibility. They say people make their own
>decisions regarding whether or not to drive -- and they
>have the right to make those decisions for themselves.
>They claim the current anti-driving crusade is a "wedge
>issue" for moralists who really want to control all
>aspects of life. What, they ask, will be the next
>activity to be attacked? Eating fatty foods? Using step
>ladders? Taking showers? Pretty soon, individuals will
>be prohibited from every activity that leads to any
>deaths at all.
>
>In short, once you accept the principle that driving
>is addictive and dangerous, and that drivers can be
>manipulated by the auto-makers, it is only a matter of
>time until the same reasoning is applied -- for example
>-- against smokers and tobacco companies.

Spiral Tribe is a sort of legendary crew from the UK,  a band of merry 
outlaws--
they were in it way back...
apparantly they started getting in trouble with the law; it sounds like
they were being targetted, so they packed up and left England and I 
guess they've been wandering the world
like nomads ever since.

here's the dirt below.  i have no idea about their music or the circus 
acts,
but i'm excited about going.

-Boo Meringue

To: "Those Silly Ravers..." <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: Deepfog <deepfog@hooked.net>
Subject: wicked wAS pretty wikked
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

hi everyone...

well you kno,w i haven't been to w wicked party in quite some time.  like 2
years or something.  I was at this other party last night that was free and
good vibed, but for some reason when leslie mentioned wicked, it seemed to
fit.

i didn't really see anyone there from our online community, but i did see a
lot of people from the non-online community.  one thing i do like about
wicked parties is they are simple.  you know what to expect.  generally
good to great house music, usually one screen with simple psychedelic
visuals, not too many lights.

well i missed rob doten's set (can someone please clarify if Jim Doten
Acura is related to Rob Doten?)  but i gave him  a nice hug just for being
there.

Garth was playing when i got there.  A lot of people have said Garth hasn't
been up to par lately, I heard his music, and though I liked Markie and
Jeno's set for their mixing and music (this time, there have been times
when Garth tripped me the f*** out), Garth laid down some nice quiet but
mind boggleing tribal house mixed with some disco-style house.

I never know how to classify Markie.  I think that's why he's so good.  I
got a brief chance to speak with him after his set and found out he has
been mixing for 13 years.  He said he used to mix what we would call
"modern rock".  But his set kept me dancing and it wove into Jeno's set
very nicely.  They ended up having a very similar sound, though Jeno pulled
off some rEALLY nice mixes, the kind i could never describe in words.
Let's just say the songs overlapped very nicely, breaks and all, to where I
sometimes couldn't even tell what song was what.  That is very rare to
happen to me nowadays, because as a dj myself, I can usually hear the mix
no matter how on beat it is.

So if some of you up and coming dj's want to know where to look for really
good mixing styles no matter wHAT genre you specialize in, I would say look
to Markie and or Jeno.  I'll tell you, if some of you hard trance dj's
learned how to spin like these guys, you'd see me there in front of your
booth more often.

well, nuff said, thanks to leslie for bringing me back to an old familiar
environment.

dEEp

On Thu, 16 Oct 1997 15:52:34 -0700 (PDT) Larry Ching <larryc@netcom.com>
writes:
>[ to sfraves list ] 
>Hugh asked ...
>> 
>> Did anyone go to the Full Moon party last night?
>> 
> It was a beautiful night for dancing under the moon. Not a cloud in 
>the
>sky, no fog or mist at the beach to speak of. 
>
> I got to the voicemail site at about 2AM, just before the police did!
>In short, the cops gave the Wicked crew 10 minutes to haul the sound 
>system off the beach and clear out the people ! 
>
> The alternate site was spread by word of mouth - a spot on the bay.
>Various strings of cars made the trip, so the crowd at the new site
>was about 60 to 80 people by 5:30 AM.
>
> I had been to this site for parties before, and I was reminiscing 
>about
>the time we had to move a busted party there about three years ago.
>We had been dancing for about an hour when the sprinklers went on!
>
> Well, history repeated itself! And the crowd last night did the same
>thing we did three years ago - gathered the local garbage cans and
>covered the sprinkler heads with them. You could dance next to them
>and hear the sprinkler jets hitting the sides of the metal cans.
>
> ( A note for the next bunch that uses this site - do the park 
>maintenance
>folks a favor and bring big plastic garbage bags with you to replace
>the ones you may have to pull out of the cans in order to use them 
>as sprinkler blockers )
>
> DJs were hot!  Carlos was good to see again - I haven't watched him
>in action for over 6 months now. A real mixing genius ! And of
>course his enthusiasm is a big big part of a Wicked Full Moon party.
>Other DJs were ( I think ) George, Jonas(?), Melanie, and another
>Jonas(? - someone correct me please!).
>
> Good funky house music! Tribal beats and funky breaks and heartbeat
>4/4 and spacy acid lines and soulful vocals and samples. 
>
> Friendly crowd. Not too many "candy ravers", but that fancy-dress
>stuff is usually for warm indoor and daytime events, I'd think. 
>
> The timing of sunrise and moon setting in the bay was just right!
>Fat golden sun rising over the Oakland hills and relecting as a 
>shimmering column on the water of the bay, as the moon in the west
>faded against the lightening sky as it set behind the hills
>above Pacifica.
>
> A first for me last night - Red Bull! It was too dark to see if this
>stuff was red or not. Since Carlos gave it to me, I almost feel like
>I should keep the can as a souvenir! It did assuage my hunger, and 
>maybe it did gently perk me up. I'd like to bring some to the next 
>psy trance party I go to . Oh, by the way, it tastes like what I'd
>imagine carbonated Gatorade would . Do they still sell Tang - that
>powdered orange juice ? Tastes a bit like that too.
>
> Anyway - last night's full moon was a beautiful little party,
>despite the authorities and the park sprinkler system!
>
>Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com
> 
>

to maya and friends:  thanks for welcoming me and my group of friends
to your place last night.  we should have stayed longer but we all
needed to dance.  an apology for my friend's spillage, but she is a
helpful person living close by you, so the next time you clean the
house, let me know and she'll come over and help out.

general:  went to step2k, a jungle party which got busted at around
3:40 am.  i'm still trying to get use to jungle and so didn't get to
dance much.  but why judge a party on the music only.  got to meet
some fun and loving people there.  how neat, they had videogame setups
in a couple of rooms. played frogger (ancient atari's videogame) and
there made some friends from distance places.  

because of the lack of dancing, i have to go out again tonite.  spiral
tribe sounds like a good one.  hope it doesn't get busted up again and
hope to see some of U's there.  come and say hi if you wanna risk
being hugged.

hai

I think that I experienced the worst Sunday Morning wake-up call ever today.

9 am, after going to Party By The People, the phone rings. I certainly 
didn't answer it, for no one that I wanted to talk to would call that 
early. Worse yet, when the answerting machine clicks on, it is the 
POLICE. Scared, for nothing, I race to the phone, miss the caller, and 
have to call back. 

I call back, only to find out that some opne threw a rock through the 
window of our Record store, Capricorn Music. Now, there is a new 6 foot 
by 8 foot entrance to the store. On 2 1/2 hours sleep, I get to deal with 
filling this hole. 

Fun way to start the day.

Hope you all had a better morning.

Peace,
ES

At 12:16 PM -0700 10/18/97, Deepfog wrote:
>hi everyone...
>
>well you kno,w i haven't been to w wicked party in quite some time.  like 2
>years or something.  I was at this other party last night that was free and
>good vibed, but for some reason when leslie mentioned wicked, it seemed to
>fit.

It had been about 2 years or so for me too.  Decided I was about due for a
wind-warping, so I headed out for Wicked.  Boy, am I glad I did.

>
>i didn't really see anyone there from our online community, but i did see a
>lot of people from the non-online community.  one thing i do like about
>wicked parties is they are simple.  you know what to expect.  generally
>good to great house music, usually one screen with simple psychedelic
>visuals, not too many lights.

I agree.  Simple grooving.  Music is the main focus.  Everyone dances.

>
>well i missed rob doten's set (can someone please clarify if Jim Doten
>Acura is related to Rob Doten?)  but i gave him  a nice hug just for being
>there.
>
>Garth was playing when i got there.  A lot of people have said Garth hasn't
>been up to par lately, I heard his music, and though I liked Markie and
>Jeno's set for their mixing and music (this time, there have been times
>when Garth tripped me the f*** out), Garth laid down some nice quiet but
>mind boggleing tribal house mixed with some disco-style house.

I missed RD's set, too.  Made it just in time to catch the end of Garth's
set.  He is not ususally one of my fav dj's but I was pleaseantly
surprised.  His set was okay.  I liked it better than many others I've
heard.

>
>I never know how to classify Markie.  I think that's why he's so good.  I
>got a brief chance to speak with him after his set and found out he has
>been mixing for 13 years.  He said he used to mix what we would call
>"modern rock".  But his set kept me dancing and it wove into Jeno's set
>very nicely.  They ended up having a very similar sound, though Jeno pulled
>off some rEALLY nice mixes, the kind i could never describe in words.
>Let's just say the songs overlapped very nicely, breaks and all, to where I
>sometimes couldn't even tell what song was what.  That is very rare to
>happen to me nowadays, because as a dj myself, I can usually hear the mix
>no matter how on beat it is.

Markie, to me, is a *very* good dj, but I don't always like the music he
plays.  His mixing is polished and never boring.  His tunes can get a
little dark for my taste sometimes, but hey, he's Markie and it was a
Wicked.  What do I expect?  Wicked wouldn't be wicked without Markie's
darkness.

I also thought Markie & Jeno had a nice transistion between sets.  Jeno
pulled through for me and played a great set!  He brought me back to the
good ol' days of dancing for hours on end, leaving the dancefloor only to
visit the little girls room.  There was great vibe on the dancefloor.
Everyone was really into the music.  Friendly but not fake.  Positive but
not "PLUR"y.  An all around good time...

>
>So if some of you up and coming dj's want to know where to look for really
>good mixing styles no matter wHAT genre you specialize in, I would say look
>to Markie and or Jeno.  I'll tell you, if some of you hard trance dj's
>learned how to spin like these guys, you'd see me there in front of your
>booth more often.

Now kids, don't let this discourage you...  Asking everyone to get it
together and dj like the wiked boys seems a ltlle unreasonalbe, don't you
think?  Everyone has their own mixing styles and I doubt mant people can
claim the 13 year mixing experience that Markie does.  IMO there are too
many up & coming dj's who model their mixing after Wicked dj's and focus
too much on trying to duplicate their sound, which is, of course, next to
impossible.  Use other dj's as influence, but don't sacrificce your own
fire in hopes of catching someone else's.

>
>well, nuff said, thanks to leslie for bringing me back to an old familiar
>environment.
>
>dEEp

I think we were all due for a Wicked - it had been quite a while.  I am
really glad I went.  The music and dancing and people were all very cool
but I was particularly happy to see Brazilian Eddie.  After all, is a
Wicked complete without Eddie dancing around balancing a water bottle on
his head?  I think not.

Unitl next time,
Megan

Hello Everyone--
well I've never put my .02 in before, but I felt that the party I went 
to last night definitely deserves some recognition.  I just moved here 
from San Diego and in the two months that I have been here, I guess you 
could say, I've had trouble adjusting to the scene.  Finally I took the 
advise of people who have been up here before and I went to a small 
party that sounded, well, interesting.  My friends and I arrived at the 
Spiral Tribe party early due to our fears that another location run 
around may occur as it did last weekend, so there weren't many people 
there.  Slowly the party picked up and the music was great.  I heard 
someone mention the girl who spun early that evening and I have to agree 
she sure knew her stuff, so if you find out who it was do tell!  Along 
with the music, I met some pretty cool kids, who gave me hugs, which I 
had been terminally deprived of.  Anyways, in nut shell I had a 
wonderful time and maybe one of these days I'll meet some of you kids 
too :) 
Come swim with me, beneath the depths of the deep blue sea~~~~~
                                                           Mermaid
**hey Josh where were you??

i have to agree, this was a fun party, but there was too much 
O            P           E         N                 S         P          A
        C        E.  
I like the parties where the dance floor is FULL and sweat is dripping from
the ceiling, and your clothes look like they had just been submerged in a tub

werent many people there. the music was good in the main room. i only visited

outside and they rolled up and told us to go home and that they were breaking

rocked on.

time since i was in good company :)

i have been thinking about something now that ive got my dishes
done for the evening and was wondering if any one had ever
tried this or would be interested in trying it.

I always see these really nice flyers saying that this party is for
some noble spiritual or humanitarian cause yet when you go to the 
party there is nothing remotely connected to this going on.

So i was wondering what it would be like to have a party
for a specific purpose, and ask everyone to be thinking about
solutions for that problem. Perhaps there could be a wall or
a computer where you could post ideas and read others ideas.
Perhaps these ideas could be discussed online and maybe action
groups could come from these discussions.

Just one problem a week....we will be in utopia in no time=)
and then we can all sit around and enjoy our green eggs and
ham in peace. (i wonder what makes green eggs green)

	><{{{">   <"}}}><

		foolish fish

At 04:00 PM 10/16/97 -0700, you wrote:
>so what i'm
>wondering is, has anyone out there tried the "digest" version of
>sfraves?  isn't that like one or two posts a day of the "best"

Nope, it's all the same messages, but sent out in convenient 60 Kilobyte
chunks (i.e. roughly 20-30 messages at a time) rather than as many separate
messages.  I'd guess there's 1-2 digests per day.

Message-ID: <19971020151100.12770.rocketmail@web2.rocketmail.com>
Received: from [204.94.209.1] by web2; Mon, 20 Oct 1997 08:10:59 PDT
Date: Mon, 20 Oct 1997 08:10:59 -0700 (PDT)
From: Layne Loomis <lucke@rocketmail.com>
Subject: Breakfast @ Tiffany's Review
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Got to DNA at about 10:30am. Place was nicely decorated
not very many people there (about 15). They didn't
use the DJ booth but had tables set up on the stage
with some kind of link to the power the sound was
pretty
tinny' but had nice bass. I did not recognize the first
DJ but he had some skills and was throwing down some
nice morning Happy House. They had TV's broadcasting
the games upstairs with big couches, and in the back
there was a nice breakfast set up fresh fruit, bagels,
and a girl making fresh waffles (free of charge) making
the seven bucks to get in, more than worth it. There
were several DJ's trading off Marcellas, and some
others (sorry I did not recognize them) but they had 
several technical problems broken needles etc. which
meant one table running, needless to say I was really
wanting more. 

Right around 1:00 Doc Martin came on, I was dying to
here some good music but it just never happend. I was
dissapointed with his set. It just never quite got
going. I heard he had played a boat party the night
before, maybe he was tired. Not to mentions people
kept flailing into the tables.

The crowd was in good spirits (considering most of
the people I talked to had been up at least all night
if not longer 8). Lots of happy kids.

All in all this could turn out to be the next "Boogie
Buffet" if they can hash out their sound problems.

Layne

In-Reply-To: <971020125137_-626697102@emout17.mail.aol.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.95.971020100442.12619F-100000@ccnet3>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


Is this hypothetical?

If I was in your place i would do **W H A T E V E R** it takes to give him
a better understanding of spirituality. I think this is the KEY to being
comfortable with life, death and everything in between. When you know what
you trully are you know what life trully is. You can increase your
spiritual undestanding in many ways. I can't tell you how differently I
feel now then a year ago. I wish I could have written a journal throughout
this entire journey. Raving has unlocked a part of me that I had been
oblivious to for so long. I knew I always had a better understanding then
most, but the experiences I've had in the last year has increased this
understanding immensely. Once your doors of perception are open you see
things are they trully are. You see what really matters, where you need to
focus your time/attention, and how to do it. I suggest getting some
books on the subject, perhaps joining a Spiritual-related group for
terminally ill people (or people with diseases and illnesses), and
listening to a lot of inspiring music... and going to parties with a lot
of friends. Anything that will move their thoughts away from the darkness
and into the light. We're all going into that light and we don't need to fear
 it. We need to embrass it. Because we are, in essence, a part of that
light. That life force. And besides, what is it worth fearing for? It's
inevidable, so why waste the precious time we have on something we have no
control over?

Going to underground parties would be a great thing. This is where you
feel the most love. Where you will feel that people really do care, and
that we are all are family. He/she is not alone and we are all there for
this person. We care and we will let them know this. Life is a journey,
and it's end is unpredictable. We're given no promises of how long we'll
be here, so we're all in the same situation. Just some of us are given an
idea before others. Yet we can all exit at any time.. any split second.
But if we focus on TODAY and look around for a moment and rethink our
priorities, goals and values. I think if we do this we can make each day a
life in itself. What's so good about living till your 70 anyway? I'm ready
to go whenever I'm requested...  maybe it will be today? maybe tommorrow,
maybe in 10 years, who knows.... but one thing I do know is that I'm loved
and that I will see you all again...

my $2.00 worth. :)

Byroni

> Party?

> Thanks, Neal

 Byroni the Space Cowboy
 "Won't you join me on a cosmic interlude...?"

Hey ravers!!
I went to this nonprophit party on fri night and let me tell you all...
it was the BEST RAVE I have ever been to.
It was on Bryant in the little wharehouse down kinda close to the piers.
The people there were sweet. They had the best Deep Tribal..Deep jungle 
I have ever heard mixed. It was also the first indoor I have been to in 
a long time so it was a nice change from inhaling dust and dirt like at 
4x4, but don't get me wrong 4x4 was awesome to.
 the music was weak until about 1am
up until then it was this really bad sounding trip hop...i like trip 
hop, but not the crap this one dj was spinning. Then Carlos and Tracy(i)
started spinning and it was divine. I just could not stop dancing. I 
went up to Tracx and was like "what is your name" she told me and I said
I'll give you 500 dolllars for a tape if you have it! YOu are the best!
She was really cool. I had no food in my poor raver tummy, but i just 
could not stop dancing to the tribal. It felt like what a rave should be 
like...it was like a rave renaissance. IT WAS SO BEAUTIFUL. There were 
fire dancers that busted out with fire torches and started doing these 
fire dances with each other. Then they swallowed the fire. Two girls got 
up with MiCS and started chanting/moaning with the mix...it was 
indescibable....so deep and so beautiful. BY FAR THE BEST RAVE 

hope all ya all had a good time on fri night too. :)

Matt Breedlove

Well first of all, I'd put an NRR tag on the post. Second, I'd think
about what a sad topic this is for a monday morning.

I think it's an intriguing question, but at the same time, I wonder
why you would want to know such a thing. It's so highly personal, that
I don't see what benefit you would get from reading other people's
opinions.

Personally, I'd hope we live every day like it's our last no matter
what. So if you suddenly had 6 months, why change your habits?? Do
what makes you happy, which is all you should be doing anyways...

-alex

>>So if some of you up and coming dj's want to know where to look for really
>>good mixing styles no matter wHAT genre you specialize in, I would say look
>>to Markie and or Jeno.  I'll tell you, if some of you hard trance dj's
>>learned how to spin like these guys, you'd see me there in front of your
>>booth more often.
>
>Now kids, don't let this discourage you...  Asking everyone to get it
>together and dj like the wiked boys seems a ltlle unreasonalbe, don't you
>think?  Everyone has their own mixing styles and I doubt mant people can
>claim the 13 year mixing experience that Markie does.  IMO there are too
>many up & coming dj's who model their mixing after Wicked dj's and focus
>too much on trying to duplicate their sound, which is, of course, next to
>impossible.  Use other dj's as influence, but don't sacrificce your own
>fire in hopes of catching someone else's.
>

well what i think i am trying to say is if someone wants to know where to
look for good dj styles, look there.  not saying encompass their whole dj
career based upon those people.  my mixing style changed a lot after i
bought a mark farina tape, they are similar to wicked sound but not the
same.  in film classes i took all we did was watch other director's styles;
it was an effort to have us see how others have done to make a platform on
which to get started with.

dj'ing is not as complex as film but i decided years ago to take the same
approach.  i liked garth mostly so i bought a lot of his tapes.  i still
firmly believe they have some good styles of mixing, that smoother type of
transistinoi that i haven't really heard too many hard trance dj's be able
to pull off.  of course there has to be one out there i haven't heard of.

so i was stating a personal preference that if i heard that style mixed
with music i don't normally get into, i would "perk up" like a can of
Sanka.

yes.

decaf.  =]

>Personally, I'd hope we live every day like it's our last no matter
>what. So if you suddenly had 6 months, why change your habits?? Do
>what makes you happy, which is all you should be doing anyways...

i completely agree with you, alex!  
i try my best to live everyday as if it were my last...  

but i do have a job and i do have responsiblities!  and although i'd like
to say that i love my line of work... i have to admit that i'm not quite
there yet.  
i think it takes time to find our niche in society... 
*what am i capable of? 
*what will make me happy?
*how do i get there?
*what occupation is best for me? 
...
yes... i do what makes me happy the minute i get in my car to start my
journey home, after a long day at work... and hopefully someday (soon) i'll
do what makes me happy from the moment the sun pours through the blinds-
til the moment it no longer shines... 
(although if it was a perfect life- i'd be waking up in the afternoon!
:)...  but until then, i do have to make sacrifices in one area of my life
so i have the time and $ to enjoy the other 1/2 of my life...
sooo.... i guess if i was told that i had 6 months to live, there would
definately be changes in my lifestyle!  i would take out a huge loan and
take some time off from work... say... 6 months? 
:)
meg

first...there is a cure for cancer.
The american government is fighting desperately to keep
this info from the people but are not having much success.
Do a web search for dr burzynski. I think his web page is
http//cancermed.com/bri.htm. If that doesnt work let me
know and i will find the correct one.

there ia also a good book called a "cure for all cancers"
which offers another approach that i really cant say
one way or the other weather it works, but it does have some
good info.

Secondly...as some of you know i almost died two years ago
from a fatal disease. I had what some call a near death experience.
while in this other world i saw what happens when we die and where
we go. This place is truly beyond words...incredibly beautiful.
Because i cant describe this in words i often use the metaphor
of the caterpillar and butterfly. We as humans in physical bodies
are just like caterpillars and after we die we become like a 
magnificent butterfly. 
Death is sad in the sense that we are loosing someone very special
but it is also a time of great celebration. the tibetan book of the
dead likens death to one final orgasm...we save the best for last.
Imagine the best orgasm you have ever had, now imagine
that happening on every level of your being, emotional, spiritual,
intellectual, physical,etc simultaneously and thousands of times
more intense... 

That is what happens when we die...its the most wonderful
experience there is and should be anticipated as such.

And what lies on the other side is even better.

if your friend has truely reached the point that death is
certain then there will be a light that he will become 
increasingly aware of...he should allow that light to grow
and it will become a source of strength as he
prepares for this transition

	><{{{">   <"}}}><

		foolish fish

At 12:42 PM 10/20/97 -0700, you wrote:
>
>I payed 520+120+50(tax) for my equipement.  Has *anyone* actually purchased
>a 449 turntable from Thomas Trouble? 
>
>I think getting a 100 dollar price break for buying something that
>has had only home use for 3 months is a very fair deal...  obviously
>the price of new 1200's has dropped, so offers will be accepted.
>
Thomas is currently out of stock (at least last Thursday he was), but I
took his add in XLR8 over to Good Guys and they beat the price by 10%
(their standard policy on anything)  $449 less 10% is $404.10 plus tax is
$437.  The policy actually says that the item must be in stock at the
competitors (which it isn't) but the guy I went to in Emerryville didn't
bother to call over to check.  Your luck may vary on this part.  The going
rate at Guitar center is $479 which is the same price as pro sound  stage
and lighting (www.pssl.com).
New 1200's also have a two year warranty.

I don't mean to make your job of selling your stuff any harder, but as
someone who just went through the whole process of getting set up I know
that there are a lot of people saying a lot of different numbers out there.
 I just want people to be aware of what's out there.  Nothing worse than
spending a lot of cash on something and then realizing you paid too much.
It pays to shop around.   Besides, that leaves you more money for the most
important (and expensive) part ... the music.

FYI, T&J factory is always out of stock. However, just that ad in
XLR8R has prolly brought prices down all over the bay area...And that
rocks. 1200's were always overpriced in the bay area, and I sure there
are people besides me who remember when 1200's were rumored to be
going out of production and the price jumped from $400 to $500. And
gee, suddenly everyone had walls of them again...

At 12:55 PM 10/20/97 -0400, Ventrfar@aol.com wrote:
>A friend has been diagnosed with cancer and told he has 6 months left to
>live. He has been told that for the next few months he will feel fine. What
>would you do with those months.? He is a raver (or former raver). Would you

it all depends on what his opinion is about the spirit.  as Nachiketa notes
in the Katha Upanishad, the only really important question that humans
should ask of God is "does the soul live after death, or not?"  if the
answer is yes, then it really doesn't matter what he does in this lifetime
and he should go on with life as he has lived it, continuing down whatever
path he has chosen, as that will be the most fulfilling.

but if he believes that upon death the soul is annihilated along with the
body,  i suggest that he explode with activity, spend and donate money,
make love to beautiful people, take lots of fascinating substances...

in short, live a life of gratifying the senses if they are all you have and
will soon disappear.
----------------------------
and if tomorrow ever comes:
"We'll know how small we really are.
 We'll be amazed we've come this far.
 We'll rip the blinders from our eyes and truly see."

> >a 449 turntable from Thomas Trouble? 
> >
> >I think getting a 100 dollar price break for buying something that
> >has had only home use for 3 months is a very fair deal...  obviously
> >the price of new 1200's has dropped, so offers will be accepted.
> >
> Thomas is currently out of stock (at least last Thursday he was), but I
> took his add in XLR8 over to Good Guys and they beat the price by 10%
> (their standard policy on anything)  $449 less 10% is $404.10 plus tax is
> $437.  The policy actually says that the item must be in stock at the
> competitors (which it isn't) but the guy I went to in Emerryville didn't
> bother to call over to check.  Your luck may vary on this part.  The going
> rate at Guitar center is $479 which is the same price as pro sound  stage
> and lighting (www.pssl.com).
> New 1200's also have a two year warranty.
> 
> I don't mean to make your job of selling your stuff any harder, but as
> someone who just went through the whole process of getting set up I know
> that there are a lot of people saying a lot of different numbers out there.
>  I just want people to be aware of what's out there.  Nothing worse than
> spending a lot of cash on something and then realizing you paid too much.
> It pays to shop around.   Besides, that leaves you more money for the most
> important (and expensive) part ... the music.
>

On the hard trance/techno DJs that can't mix like Jeno thread... 

Keep in mind a lot of techno seems like it requires a slide rule and taped
up glasses just to figure out where the count starts... it's harder to
mix, but much more rewarding (IMHO), due to the amazing variety of tones,
heavy amount of experimentation on the part of the artists, and slightly
more avante garde approach to mixing (less obvious *please mix here*
points like those found on many trance, breakbeat and house records).
Plus there's a lot of it out there... [flames to me please if you're not a
techno believer thankyou]

So yeah, Jeno is smooth, but so is the music he spins.  If you spun techno
records the same way, you'd risk a boring set without that "house pulse"
to push the crowd through the night (that amazing quality about house
music that makes it just grooooooove for days).

I agree, a lot of the local/list DJs aren't at the "supahtight-beatmatch
and long transition like Jeno"  point (that andyw guy included), but it
doesn't mean they won't eventually, or that a lot of them don't hit that
point regularly, just not with the same consistency. We gotta keep
challenging each other, and raise our standards for ourselves and each
other as we accumulate experience and vinyl (so in a way thanks for the
post deepfog).

I'm still trying to figure out why amazing DJs who are creative and
innovative and technically _ON_ often seem overshadowed by DJs with
records that are often less than fresh and mixing that leaves something to
be desired (like, go back to beatmatching 101, do not pass go, do not
collect $200 kid...).  I guess it's talent /= success... 

I only know one thing for sure:
Diversity in an open scene means the music means whatever it means to
anybody who shows up I guess.

Er?,
Andy

*byroni* wrote:

> I think that's a fantasmic idea and would do whatever I could to help. I
> think that parties are drawing more and more away from the *community*
> aspect and more into the *MONEY* aspect. We need to keep it real as Vlad
> always says. Which is 10000% TRUE.

Hay Byroni :) I am very honored that you quoted me.  That's very special.
Thanks.  :)

    BTW, I tend to agree with you on this, in the last few years I have seen
an increase of "$$ Return Motivation" for throwing events on the up-rise,
and the "Collective Goodness" of event production taking a secondary role.
This seems to be more apparent with the younger promotional crews than with
the old-schoolers, but it has definitely been more evident this last year
more than ever.   In our society we cannot factor money of  any business
situation, but it does not necessarily need to be such a prevailing factor
and motivater for organizing a rave.  I've learned early on that there is a
strong and direct correlation between the way a promoter prioritizes the
reasons for producing an event... and how the event will be perceived by the
people, and play a big role in the vibe of the event.
    We live in a financially driven society, and there are NO purists in our
community... but there are a lot of people with PURE intentions.  And as the
say "the Cream always rises..." and "Shit will always stink!"

Keep it Real

Yours in PLUR  ...   Vlad (aka Ray Vonie)

foolish_fish1@juno.com wrote:

> I always see these really nice flyers saying that this party is for
> some noble spiritual or humanitarian cause yet when you go to the
> party there is nothing remotely connected to this going on.

I would be curious as to what you think people would want to see at a
party for a nobel cause...???

> So i was wondering what it would be like to have a party
> for a specific purpose, and ask everyone to be thinking about
> solutions for that problem.

This is a great idea.  I would like to see more people get involved in
organizing events like this.  It takes it one step further than just a
cash donation.  Its a wonderful idea.  I think that at the next FGE
event we will have a suggestion box setup for people to give input and
recommendations for solutions as well as the overall $$ donation.  It
will add a new level of involvement and interaction between the rave
community and the organization that will benefit from the rave.  It's a
very powerful idea.

BTW in case your wondering the next FGE event is called :  the SPIRIT of
Giving : A Thanksgiving PLURity Vibe-Fest.  It is a benefit for the Bay
Area Homeless Alliance.  So start thinking of your suggestions and ideas
to help with the homeless situation in the bay area.  It is still a
major issue, and it looks like its going to be a very wet and cold
winter.

Keep it Real

Vlad, aka Ray Vonie

If *I* had 6 months to live, I would:
- work at my job for like a month and then quit so I'd have more time to 
do important stuff
- spend as much time as possible outdoors, and in the ocean
- tell everyone I know how much I love them
- spend as much time as possible with my parents and other relations
- party my ass off (plenty of drugs, booze, sex, etc.)
- write as much music as I could
- spend at least an hour a day in deep meditation so I could keep it all 
together and not freak out
- take time to talk to as many holy people from as many beliefs as I 
possibly could

and I wouldn't cut my hair or shave.  I would want to go out tanned and 
hairy if nothing else!

:)

Subject: spiral tribe & its haunting thoughts
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

hello beautiful people,

my apologies for the wide distribution but i need help to understand
an event that i experienced saturday nite at spiral tribe, especially
from those who had been there and seen a chinese (asian for sure) girl.

so yeah there she was sitting along the wall with two guardians.  she
was uniquely tiny and young so decided to come over for a closer look.
 seeing me walking over, she developed a ghostly frighten look and
slowly shied her head toward the wall, with body squelching, arms
hugging chest, and knees bent. i have never seen anything like it
before so stayed at a distance and talked to one of the guardians.  it
was so unusual that i forgot some of my manners and hounded the
guardian with this circle of questions: "what's wrong with your
friend? why is she so petrified? is she alright? how old is she? why
is she being like that?"  the guardian kept dodging the subject and
finally asked me to leave. so cool but i hope that little girl is
alright and is in good hands.

i'm very haunted by the thoughts of that event.  could someone care to
try to explain?  

side notes: the promoters of spiral tribe are a cool bunch.  i had the
pleasure of talking to some of them personally and they gave new
meaning to PLUR.  

thanks&hugs,
hai



Sent by Yahoo! Mail - http://mail.yahoo.com

At 12:55 PM -0400 10/20/97, Ventrfar@aol.com wrote:
>A friend has been diagnosed with cancer and told he has 6 months left to
>live. He has been told that for the next few months he will feel fine. What
>would you do with those months.? He is a raver (or former raver). Would you

>Party?

I think it is interesting that people even try to speculate how they would
react to their own death and how their would spend the rest of their life.
Personally, I cannot even fathom how I would react or what I would do.
First, I would probably cry.  But then again, I tend to be somewhat of an
over-emotional crybaby sometimes. :-(  After that, I don't really know.  I
doubt I would spend too much of my time partying, though.  I'm not in too
much of a party head-space right now.
Whatever I did, I  would make sure to tell everyone everything I've ever
wanted to say to them.  Yeah, yeah... I know we're supposed to live each
day as if it were our last and all that crap but let's face it, who the
hell really does that?  Not me, that's for sure.  I've got lots of thoughts
in my head that never make it out of my mouth.  Sad reality but at least
I'm honest about it, right?
Megan

ps - sorry for the ho-hum attitude.  It's just been one of those days...

Subject: Weekend review...or how I slept for 2 days.
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Friday night, went to Abstract Soul.  Heard Mark E. Quark, ran into Corey,
saw Loren, the place was packed, the music was good, the beer was cold, and
it was a good party! It's good to see plenty of folks out on a friday,
getting ready for the crackerjack hour.  Booze and weed can be good primers.

Anyway said goodbye to the bulk of my friends and headed over to Wicked.
Got settlted into a booth, saw alot of people out I normally don't see
these days.  Danced my ass off with my lady, with my neighbor (hey Astral
Matrix).  There were alot of people in that place but it wasn;t too
crowded, plenty of room to dance, and you could almost carry on a
conversation.  I heard the last part of Garth's set, and although I didn't
like the tunes, he was solid, then Markie took it over and banged the
f***ing drum.  The shit was stompin'! Next the Jeno got on and tore it up!
I was so good to hear the boys out, if for nothing but a gurantee of good
music at their party.  Jeno really did it and it was good to hear him
again.  Damn that boy smiles alot these days!  Good vibe, cool party!  Like
we used to do it!

Security was very cool, and I enjoyed that spot more than I thought (I
remeber in the day when the DJ was way at the top, it was such a
disconnected space).  Anyway they remodeled and the place was cool.  They
wre cool with in/outs if you didn't clown 'em (that meant if you said you
were going to come back you did, quickly (it amazes me people don't do
in/outs at clubs, f'ing restrictions).

Wicked was on, Abstract was on, time to go to bed for a couple of days...

That's that,
John


"The first casualty of war is truth." - Rudyard Kipling

Subject: [NRR]  Why did the chicken cross the road?
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Just got this from a friend...had anybody heard this one yet?

Why did the chicken cross the road?

MOSES:  And God came down from the Heavens, and He said unto the
Chicken, "Thous shalt cross the road."  And the chicken crossed the
road, and there was much rejoicing.

FOX MULDER:  You saw it cross the road with your own eyes.  How many
more chickens have to cross the road before you believe it?

RICHARD M. NIXON:  The chicken did not cross the road.  I repeat, the
chicken did NOT cross the road.

JERRY SEINFELD:  Why does anyone cross a road?  I mean, why doesn't
anyone ever think to ask, "What the heck was this chicken doing
walking around all over the place, anyway?"

FREUD:  The fact that you are at all concerned that the chicken
crossed the road reveals your underlying sexual insecurity.

BILL GATES:  I have just released the new Chicken Office 2000, which
will not only cross roads, but will lay eggs, file your important
documents, and balance your chequebook.

OLIVER STONE:  The question is not, "Why did the chicken cross the
road?"  Rather, it is, "Who was crossing the road at the same time,
whom we overlooked in our haste to observe the chicken crossing?"

DARWIN:  Chickens, over great periods of time, have been naturally
selected in such a way that they are now genetically dispositioned to
cross roads.

LOUIS FARRAKHAN:  The road, you will see, represents the black man.
The chicken 'crossed' the black man in order to trample him and keep
him down.

MARTIN LUTHER KING, JR.:  I envision a world where all chickens will
be free to cross roads without having their motives called into
question.

GRANDPA:  In my day, we didn't ask why the chicken crossed the road.
Someone told us that the chicken had crossed the road, and that was
good enough for us.

MACHIAVELLI:  The point is that the chicken crossed the road. Who
cares why?  The end of crossing the road justifies whatever motive
there was.

EINSTEIN:  Whether the chicken crossed the road or the road moved
beneath the chicken depends upon your frame of reference.

BUDDHA:  Asking this question denies your own chicken nature.

RALPH WALDO EMERSON:  The chicken did not cross the road; it
transcended it.

ERNEST HEMINGWAY:  To die.  In the rain.

COLONEL SANDERS:  I missed one?

Personally, I think I would go and say goodbye to all of my dearest 
friends and family and go on a walk-a-bout sorta thing, just by myself.  
I'm thinking of the movie 7 Years in Tibet-Walk around, learn more about 
yourself and  other cultures, and how and why people live.  And when it 
was my time, I would pass away, only I would know, and my soul would be 
in existence for eternity.  Every person I that I have had in my life 
would hold on to a piece of my soul and never let that die.  Then it is 
on to the next life as a dog that gets hit by semi truck.  ;0 ouch!



   "Wisdom enriches the soul, not just the mind. It is different from 
mere intelligence, information, and cleverness, which dwell only in the 
mind.  Wisdom goes deeper than that.  When the brain, and it's 
multituinous facts and pieces of information, ceases to exist, the soul 
will endure.  The ageless wisdom of the soul will survive."
                 -from The Power Of The Witch(Wiccan Phillosophy)
                       By Laurie Cabot


P.S.  And while I am on my last trek with the Dali Lama I'll be sure to 
introduce him to Western cult magik called a "slinky"

i got, like, light.
	in my pocket and all throughout my body.
big unspeakable flashbulb goin' off inside.
silver flying fish
come leaping outta my still waters.
perhaps it's ALL in my mind.
but now it's in your mind.  and your mind.
calm virus spreads from these words, now you've got
infinite golden radiance.
everyone's turning golden.

take me now in your hot embrace.
welcome me into your shaking arms.
let me kiss you
--o just once--
and leave the print of wine and rose petals on your heart.
listen to it beat.
beat.
beat.
beat.
and hearing that you know
what kind ov MYSTERY you got brewin,
just waiting to be drunk.
-------------------------------
"i scream so much.  you know what i mean.  this electric stream.  and my
tears in league with the wires and energy and my machine."

Howdy folx;

One of you knows me (Hey Siphon!) The rest don't.  I'm not a raver.
Been to one rave, Siphon spun it for us on a camping trip this summer -
What a trip!
(and I DO mean -trip-!)  Since July, I've been lurking here and
reading.  One of these nights I'll makE it out to a rave, but not yet.
;)

no longer has a mixer to use, and I was just thinking about Christmas
around the corner..  Where would I go to buy a mixer, if I wanted to?
I'm interested in the possibility, at least.

Thanks for any help you could provide!

In a message dated 97-10-07 17:06:32 EDT, you write:
<Why do people think slower = mature>
<< #1    because this is the style of  music from the  disco glory years 
 when alot of people first found the rave (91-92-93)   these people are
 mature now>> 

I thought disco was from the 70's?
 
 <<#2   because more places that are 21+ play this kind of music.   when is
 the last time you saw or heard of a 21+ night of all breakbeat and
 trance?  parties that play predominantly breakbeat and techno often have
 a younger crowd.>>
 
 All the time, just not in SF!!. LA, NY, especially England - some of the
biggest clubs are 3 floors, 8 hours of techno, jungle and trance - nothing
under 180 BPM (except the chill room) and the average age at most techno
clubs is 25-30. Its the house clubs that attract the kids (18-20) except in
the North where happy hardcore is popular with the younger crowds. Over there
techno (real Detroit or German techno,  not Chem Bros/Underworld
 "electronica" techno) is what is considered more mature.

<<#3   most people who are older and still going out are not on speed that
 much so a slower deeeper groove feels right>>

  That doesn't make much sense to me- if you're not on speed you would need
fast                                        music to keep going, slow music
would slow you down.But if you've got good music you don't need drugs . Are
you saying young people dance fast and are on speed and older people dance
slow and aren't on speed? 

<< #4  soul and funk isn't something that you "get over" anyway. (if you
 truly feel it in the first place)>>

I agree but the point is there should be some variety.
 
 #5  alot of this type of music comes from either chicago or england.     
 chicago is the originator of house music( late 70's) and england was
 really  heavy into house music in the eighties before everyone started
 talking about "electronica".  so this type of music has history and
 sophistication.   i guess you could call it mature as an art form.
 
 #5.a   san frandisco has a bunch of dj's from england and at least one
 from chicago so these people have experienced house music that many of us
 have never known if we have only been paying attention to dance music for
 the last 5 years or so.   
 
 so if alot dj's in sf aren't playing the latest progressive hits from
 mixmag, 
 or trying in vain to mix two dat tapes full of goa,  these might be some
 of the reasons  ( in my opinion of course)
 
 HOUSE MUSIC WILL NEVER DIE
 peace
 gabe >>

The other reasons sound like what you are saying is we are 10 years behind
the times! I agree!  What is wrong with hearing some new music? Don't be
afraid of the future or trying something new! It all goes back to people's
need to cling to the familiar and the past. Retro and classic rock stations
are the most popular.....10 years from now all the clubs will be playing
happy hardcore!

IMHO....jd (thanks for the food for thought)

Yup, I went.  The security wasn't very friendly though.  The EAR sound was
ok, but there was a lot of the room where the sound wasn't very good.  The
visuals weren't the best either.  All together there was probably about 400+
people there.

The one thing that I didn't like at all was the competition between Sac and
SF dancers.  All fuckin night long there was this huge circle of Sac and SF
dancers goin' at it.  When nobody was dancing in it, my friends just went
in and started dancing because it was a waste of room.  My friends aren't
the greatest dancers either, and when they started dancing, people were
looking at them like they were crazy for going in the circle.  Anyways,
nobody was going to say anything to my 2 friends because they are both
about 5'11 250lb
guys.  But the competition was just crazy.  There was no vibe at all.  

As far as location, it has been the same wherehouse over and over again.
The one off of wherehouse ct.  One big room and an outside area.    

DJ's: Donald Glaude- o.k. but could have done better
      
      Tony- pretty good through the middle of his set, the begining of his
           set he played too much "tribal" house for me though.
      
      Dreamer- he was ok but a lot of the same 'ol shit

      Carlos- He pretty much tore shit up.  I like the way he drops in
beats	              by "scratching" them in, if you know what I mean.  He's
cool
              because he really gets into the music.  He had double booked
              that night, so he couldn't stay long.  He played at "Love" as
              well.

      Spun- I have no idea what or when he played.
    
      Paul Gordon- I don't know when he played either.    
     
The only bummer for me was the bunk E that I got, and not to mention I got 2
of them for me and a friend.  Oh well.
Overall the party was a 5 out of 10.

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Oct 21 20:35:33 1997

  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 21 Oct 1997 20:35:31 -0000
Message-ID: <19971021202947.11833.rocketmail@web1.rocketmail.com>
Received: from [205.158.204.133] by web1; Tue, 21 Oct 1997 13:29:47 PDT
Date: Tue, 21 Oct 1997 13:29:47 -0700 (PDT)
From: macadio <macadio6@rocketmail.com>
Subject: L8 Trance Reviews)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


Well my weekend started off good. I get off a hard
days work.Ready to go to the party. This was a
underground Trance/Tekno/DnB party if you will, So we
get ready and head out. We get to the location and it
is nicely decorated plenty of nice black lights and
banners all over the place. Not much on the way of
lights but it was a small UG and Free so it fit in
nicely. I wanted to see Li and AndyW play but as I
was walking in the door Li was getting off and my Boy
Science was getting on. Now im not ver knowledable in
the way of jungle stylies but Science was playing
some good fast paced stuff. He was also doing some
Turntable Trickery he was cutting and back queing and
stuff. It was nice not to packed or too empty there
was about 200 people it was a Viberation party BTW. I
was waiting for the Intimadator to go on I had heard
him at a CFC party before and he rocked my world. He
gets on and he did not go off as hard as I would have
liked him too. He was good but I expected to much. I
hate when I and other people do that as well. Then my
boy Siphon was up. He was playing more Trancey breaky
kind of DnB I think it is called tech step? Correct
me if im wrong. So im lounging upstairs chit chatting
and being sillie then I hear Bam,Bam,Bam from
downstairs and I am like Shit who is playing that
poundy Tekno so I walk downstairs and low and behold
it is My man Micron ripping shit up. Now you have to
understand one thing:

Micron= Trance
Macadio= Tekno

So when I hear him playing stuff I would be scared to
play it blew my mind. Heheh Hi Dan He was slicing and
dicing nice set. He does this one trick with this
rekkid called "Getdown" if you have not heard it yet
I am sure he will do it again somtime this is a must
to hear and watch. Very nice party!!.

Then Saturday we head out to this Real underground
trance party in a nice fresh new space it had nice
visuals sound and laser. Joe Rice and MR.E were
laying down the phatest tracks. I had never heard Joe
in a complete set and he was playing some nice hard
house. and MR.E played some nice Cyber. The crowd was
nice but a lot older then I had expected it was more
like a older PSY/Hippie party. But the hosts were
very nice and I had a decent time.  That was my
weekend in a nutshell See ya all soon.

Macad!0 (Mack-Audio)

Ermine,

Nice name. 

You can get a good priced mixer at the Trance and Jungle factory for about
$228. Get a 3 line Numark. Perfect to start with...... or youc an spend
$600 and get a rockin Rain (sp?).... the T&J factory is run by a cool guy
named Thomas.... "Hey mate".. :)  call 411 if you're in the 510 and ask
for the Trance and Jungle Factory in Berkeley.. if you're out of the 510
.. dial 15105551212 and ask the same pregunta (question).

Peace, love, and frame relay.

Byroni

Break Dancer,

I feel you man. I haven't remembered a dream in ages and what do you
know?... 2 days ago I have a dream that me and my ex are back together and
that she loves me once more. This is more than a dream, this is a fantasy
that i lived for nearly 4 years. Then it shattered on my birthday last
year. :( It's been a very depressing year for me.... I'm so happy that
I've met all of you and received the love you all radiate through
cyberspace and at the great parties we attend. The rave scene helped save
me and renew my pride and belief in myself.... this is such a beautiful
thing. Penicilin for the soul.

Byroni

ps. speaking of long boring babbling... you're probably refering to my
posts... :) oh well....

sounds like were in very similar situations..
 last year i broke up with my girl after we went out for like 2 years...
it sooo broke my heart and i still feel "the pangs and arrows of 
outrageous fortune." 
i hardly ever remeber my dreams...... why when i do does it have to be 
of her??
i miss her and want to call her, but my pride wont let me...so i dont 
i need to find someone else, someone just as special, who is right for 
me.. thats what ive been saying for the past year, but it hasnt 
happened...oh well.. maybe when iday, probably when i least expect 
it..someone beautiful will cross my path and we'll know were right for 
each other.. i hope :)   gotta think positively ya know...
well thats all for now....
Peace
Philip

Hi all!  ]=}

 Went to  a completly UG party Saturday that was soooo much fun!! (Hi to 
Macadio-thought that was you but wasn't sure so I didn't say Hi!) Party 
was way fun with incredible vibe and kind mature folks everywhere (YEA!!)
Hi to everyone I saw.

 One reason for the specialness (other than a nice reminder from the 
promoters to be thankful for all that we have accomplished for ourselves 
this year-this IS the harvest season ;), was that this was a "coming-out" 
party for me and my new love.

 Amy Starkey and I have been seeing each other for about a month now (and 
a wonderful month it has been!  :) and we felt secure enought to make this 
party our ""official" announcement that we are a couple.

 We are soooo in love that both of us are kinda blown away! I"M SOOOO 
HAPPPYYY!!  I have *never* had a realtionship with anyone before like 
this before. It feels so right and perfect and to know that the feeling 
is felt by Amy also makes my knees all rubbery.   :)

 I would like to thank *everyone* (even those I have been at odds with!) 
involved in the scene here. Amy and I met through SFraves and later at a 
FnF party. (I think I'm gonna cry) Who knows what roll everyone had to 
play in order for Amy and I to finally get together.

 Remember folks; just about anything is possible.


			I LOVE YOU AMY!!!



and all the rest of youse folks as well!  :)

hugz,


 Ran D. Dreams

Precedence: bulk

yeah! my niffty computer is hooked up again, so i can write my 
mini~reviews ;)

Sat. nite...i scored a pass to the <<Global DJ Mix Awards>> private 
boat party!  It took true talent to dance on a rockin' boat!  The 
awards were presented there...

**Doc Martin** got "Best Technical Trick DJ" and he proved it later 
when he played a record UPSIDE DOWN, yes the famous trick that my eyes 
have been waiting to see, so the record was suspendend OFF the pad, 
balanced by my goodness, was it a pencil?? and he placed the needle 
UNDERNEATH the record, thus playing it BACKWARDS, of course everyone 
went BALLISTIC!!! He just had a baby, so now there is a little Baby 
Doc Martin ;)
*Little Louie Vega* played and *Marques Wyatt*, a little too 
Houseymousey for me, but they are still great.  The Boat Party was 
groovy, an amazing light show was projected on the wall of Alcatraz!
Organic presented by FTT in GG Park was a nice treat, DJ DAN and 
Hector provided their best! the sound system was awesome! But due to 
kicking up all the dust, my new adidas are history, oh well.

***HOWIE B*** the only event i actually payed for all weekend and $5 
was nothing to get to hear him at <<ULTRA>>  he totally challenged 
your body, you were in the groove and NoPe, sampling, sampling, how 
many samples does it take to almost drive you insane?? He's amazing 
and so adorable, but i was hoping to see his G~friend, my favorite 
nymph *BJORK* but no sign of her, unless she went unnoticed which she 
gets away with all the time!

Well that my "Mini Review" until <<TRIBAL MASSIVE>> and <<JAMIROQUAI>>
XOXO
~ELENA~

Man, I was listening to a very old tape of a very old compilation that is
still in stores.  It's called XL Recordings "The American Chapter".  Holy
Shit.  It's got the good ones like T-99 (Anastasia; speaking of which,
has anybody seen their album "Children of Chaos" on vinyl?  Or have it on
vinyl?), also Cubic 22, Johnny L, old skewl Prodigy, etc.  It's from 1992
and has some really kewl shit on it.

I strongly recommend it if you wanna get nostalgic back to a magical
period in the rave scene.

L8

dErEk

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Oct 21 23:31:15 1997
Return-Path: <sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 8692 invoked by uid 6000); 21 Oct 1997 23:31:14 -0000
Received: (qmail 8681 invoked from network); 21 Oct 1997 23:31:13 -0000
Received: from web2.rocketmail.com (205.180.57.68)
  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 21 Oct 1997 23:31:13 -0000
Message-ID: <19971021233222.14780.rocketmail@web2.rocketmail.com>
Received: from [205.180.227.143] by web2; Tue, 21 Oct 1997 16:32:22 PDT
Date: Tue, 21 Oct 1997 16:32:22 -0700 (PDT)
From: Messiah Wannabe <messiahw@rocketmail.com>
Subject: NRR: spam spam
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk



my co-worker wrote these poems while working on a spam filter for our
email server.  i know this has abosolutely nothing to do with raving,
but i felt that electronically replicating these poems in the virtual
mailboxes of hundreds of people who didn't ask for them was a fitting
tribute to his zen craftiness - i laughed, i cried, i attained
enlightenment.  

messiah wannabe


>
> 
> > S p a m  H a i k u s:
> > 
> > 1.
> > Blue can of steel
> > What promise do you hold?
> > Salt flesh so ripe
> > 
> > 2.
> > Can of metal, slick
> > Soft center, so cool, moistening
> > I yearn for your salt
> > 
> > 3.
> > Twist, pull the sharp lid
> > Jerks and cuts me deeply but
> > Spam, aah, my poultice
> > 
> > 4.
> > Silent, former pig
> > One communal awareness
> > Myriad pink bricks
> > 
> > 5.
> > Clad in metal, proud
> > No mere salt-curing for you
> > You are not bacon
> > 
> > 6
> > And who dares mock Spam?
> > You? you? you are not worthy
> > Of one rich pink fleck
> > 
> > 7.
> > Like some spongy rock
> > A granite, my piece of Spam
> > In sunlight on my plate
> > 
> > 8.
> > Little slab of meat
> > In a wash of clear jelly
> > Now I heat the pan
> > 
> > 9.
> > Oh tin of pink meat
> > I ponder what you may be:
> > Snout or ear or feet?
> > 
> > 10.
> > In the cool morning
> > I fry up a slab of Spam
> > A dog barks next door
> > 
> > 11.
> > Pink tender morsel
> > Glistening with salty gel
> > What the hell is it?
> > 
> > 12.
> > Ears, snouts and innards
> > A homogeneous mass
> > Pass another slice
> > 
> > 13.
> > Old man seeks doctor
> >  "I eat Spam daily", he says.
> > Angioplasty
> > 
> > 14.
> > Highly unnatural
> > The tortured shape of this "food"
> > A small pink coffin
> > 
> > 15.
> > Pink beefy temptress
> > I can no longer remain
> > Vegetarian
> >

	Hak (sj)

Spin Cycle is every Tuesday in Monterey.  7pm - 10pm.  FREE!

Directions....

Highway 1 to the Main CSUMB campus exit
Take a left at the second stop sign, onto 2nd Avenue
Take a right at 3rd Street (next to the campus gym)

Take a left into the parking lot next to the campus police dept.

The Black Box Cabaret is at the far end of the parking lot, next to the
Administration building and nearest to the intersection of 3rd Street/4th
Avenue.

hang out.  Upcoming dj's are...

From: George Chan <gchan@best.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: SFR Movie Night/Tsunami
Message-ID: <Pine.BSF.3.96.971021171909.14946A-100000@shell7.ba.best.com>

Hugs to Maya for bringing us all together.  Maya lost her 'net access so
she isn't getting to hear all of our positive comments.  I'm happy to say
that I left Maya's feeling warm and grounded. I like meeting new peeps.
As of late, I've chosen to live a hermit's lifestyle; sorting my life out,
healing, finding my path, learning to love myself.  Raves have been a
great place for me to sort things out and learn things about myself.  It 
was SO nice to just sit down and share stories.  i'd love to host a little
party, but unfortunately my living arrangements are not conducive.
 
Afterwards, I got stumped at the step2k mappoint, so I cruised over to
1015 for a little DJ mix awards.  DJ Dan spun a tune with a
Joni Mitchell sample in it, "don't it always seem to go, that you don't
know what you've got till its gone."  I heard this and went totally nuts!
Bouncing around slapping people on the behind, hugging strangers, grinning
all the while.  Who, what, where!?  I must have this tune.  And if that
weren't enough, the next song he mixes in has Stevie samples in it.
Samples and beats.  I love it.  

On saturday, Tsunami at the Trocadero went off.  All sorts of layered
trance music pounding away and people bouncing and flailing to the beats.
Upstairs, there was a dj mixing up some really groovy trance, some had
breakbeats in it, others some house flavor, very diverse.  I forget her
name, something like beth johnson?  I liked it a lot. The big day-glo
murals and batiks covered the whole club.  Every wall had a gorgeous work
of art on it, enhanced by yer fav' wavy gravy substance.  

That's all fer now, everyone have a good week.  

Regards,
George

Hi all!  ]=}


 Me and some pals are calling some of this new stuff "Goa Breaks". A good 
example (IMO of course) is "Buffo" from Ceiba's upcoming release "The 
Language Of Light 2" (ETA is estimated at this fall). Although on the 
promo hand bill all tracks are labled as "psychedelic tracks".   ;)

 Heard this track for the first time at Burning Man '97. As Ceiba/Kode IV 
were burning up the dance floor with this track, Rob Rayle (who himself 
played an excellent live/CD--DJ set the night before) leaned over and 
remarked how nice it was that Adam was playing the new track he and Adam had 
worked on (composing/creating that is).

hugz,

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: SFR Movie Night/Tsunami
Author:  George Chan <gchan@best.com> at Internet
Date:    10/21/97 6:04 PM


Hugs to Maya for bringing us all together.  Maya lost her 'net access so 
she isn't getting to hear all of our positive comments.  I'm happy to say 
that I left Maya's feeling warm and grounded. I like meeting new peeps.
As of late, I've chosen to live a hermit's lifestyle; sorting my life out, 
healing, finding my path, learning to love myself.  Raves have been a 
great place for me to sort things out and learn things about myself.  It 
was SO nice to just sit down and share stories.  i'd love to host a little 
party, but unfortunately my living arrangements are not conducive.
     
Afterwards, I got stumped at the step2k mappoint, so I cruised over to 
1015 for a little DJ mix awards.  DJ Dan spun a tune with a
Joni Mitchell sample in it, "don't it always seem to go, that you don't 
know what you've got till its gone."  I heard this and went totally nuts! 
Bouncing around slapping people on the behind, hugging strangers, grinning 
all the while.  Who, what, where!?  I must have this tune.  And if that 
weren't enough, the next song he mixes in has Stevie samples in it. 
Samples and beats.  I love it.  
     
On saturday, Tsunami at the Trocadero went off.  All sorts of layered 
trance music pounding away and people bouncing and flailing to the beats. 
Upstairs, there was a dj mixing up some really groovy trance, some had 
breakbeats in it, others some house flavor, very diverse.  I forget her 
name, something like beth johnson?  I liked it a lot. The big day-glo 
murals and batiks covered the whole club.  Every wall had a gorgeous work 
of art on it, enhanced by yer fav' wavy gravy substance.  
     
That's all fer now, everyone have a good week.  
     
Regards,
George
     
--IMA.Boundary.104584778

   Dreams are pathways into an individual's soul, they are used, seen, 
and heard by all, but not too many people can decide what they actually 
can be used for.  If only people could actually feel, and make their 
dreams a part of their reality.  This whole world would be way more 
random.  Just when you thought I was going to say something really 
intelligent...nope  :)
Dreams are wonderful and without them, we would not be talking about 
this right now.
Last night, I actually had a magnificent dream of a little, cute family 
of
Slinkys during the Christmas time, openning presents, and getting all 
o  wrapped up with eachother, but then it became a huge mess, they     
 o  were all tangled up, and then a beautiful jumbo jet crashed into  
  o o0 o0 their little cute Slinky home, then they came to live with

under the age of 99)

Freud on Seuss
    
A book review by Josh LeBeau (copied from the Koala, UCSD's humour 
newspaper, which has no copyright notices in it anywhere) 

_The Cat in the Hat_ by Dr.Seuss, 61 pages.  Beginner Books, $3.95

     The Cat in the Hat is a hard-hitting novel of prose and poetry in
     which the author re-examines the dynamic rhyming schemes and bold
     imagery of some of his earlier works, most notably _Green Eggs and
     Ham_, _If I Ran the Zoo_, and _Why Can't I Shower With Mommy?_  In
     this novel, Theodore Geisel, writing under the pseudonym Dr.
     Seuss, pays homage to the great Dr. Sigmund Freud in a nightmarish
     fantasy of a renegade feline helping two young children understand
     their own frustrated sexuality.  The story opens with two
     youngsters, a brother and a sister, abandoned by their mother,
     staring mournfully through the window of their single-family
     dwelling.  In the foreground, a large tree/phallic symbol dances
     wildly in the wind, taunting the children and encouraging them to
     succumb to the sexual yearnings they undoubtedly feel for each
     other.  Even to the most unlearned reader, the blatant references
     to the incestuous relationship the two share set the tone for
     Seuss' probing examination of the satisfaction of primitive needs.
     The Cat proceeds to charm the wary youths into engaging in what he
     so innocently refers to as "tricks."  At this point, the fish, an
     obvious Christ figure who represents the prevailing Christian
     morality, attempts to warn the children, and thus, in effect,
     warns all of humanity of the dangers associated with the
     unleashing of the primal urges.  In response to this, the cat
     proceeds to balance the aquatic naysayer on the end of his
     umbrella, essentially saying, "Down with morality; down with God!"
     After poohpoohing the righteous rantings of the waterlogged Christ
     figure, the Cat begins to juggle several icons of Western culture,
     most notably two books, representing the Old and New Testaments,
     and a saucer of lactal fluid, an ironic reference to maternal loss
     the two children experienced when their mother abandoned them "for
     the afternoon."  Our heroic Id adds to this bold gesture a rake
     and a toy man, and thus completes the Oedipal triangle.  Later in
     the novel, Seuss introduces the proverbial Pandora's box, a large
     red crate out of which the Id releases Thing One, or Freud's
     concept of Ego, the division of the psyche that serves as the
     conscious mediator between the person and reality, and Thing Two,
     the Superego which functions to reward and punish through a system
     of moral attitudes, conscience, and guilt.  Referring to this box,
     the Cat says, "Now look at this trick.  Take a look!"  In this,
     Dr. Seuss uses the children as a brilliant metaphor for the
     reader, and asks the reader to re-examine his own inner self.  The
     children, unable to control the Id, Ego, and Superego allow these
     creatures to run free and mess up the house, or more symbolically,
     control their lives.  This rampage continues until the fish, or
     Christ symbol, warns that the mother is returning to reinstate the
     Oedipal triangle that existed before her abandonment of the
     children.  At this point, Seuss introduces a many-armed cleaning
     device which represents the psychoanalytic couch, which proceeds
     to put the two youngsters' lives back in order.  With powerful
     simplicity, clarity, and drama, Seuss reduces Freud's concepts on
     the dynamics of the human psyche to an easily understood gesture.
     Dr. Seuss' poetry and choice of words is equally impressive and
     serves as a splendid counterpart to his bold symbolism.  In all,
     his writing style is quick and fluid, making _The Cat in the Hat_
     impossible to put down.  While this novel is 61 pages in length,
     and one can read it in five minutes or less, it is not until after
     multiple readings that the genius of this modern day master
     becomes apparent.
