hey all you lightweights
whats up with the 16 year old ravers who think they are such the shit that
dont dance? i thought it was illegal at raves here not to dance all night
without stopping ;) 

it is where i come from you get thrown out of raves if you sit down for
too long

spiraltribe has a lot of terrific music that people all over the world
unite with and dance their hearts out to, dazncing to sounds unavaliable
anywhere in t he blown up prodigy infested world of techno today.  how
come the kids here just
stand there and brush their hair back and look at each other?  or is it
the norm when the music isnt recycled same ol same ol music... 

these people drove a f'n long way to present their music to the "most open
minded city in the United States" i guess the most openminded
representatives werent representing at the most recent free techno
gathering in sf.

sorry for the funny tone of this message, im just confused a little with
what the new
minds into "raving" ie: sitting around combing their hair and not dancing
their hearts out are thinking

... when i was getting into raving, a little bird told me the true
hardcore ravers were in it to dance themselves to a new level, not to sit
back and complain that the "music is not doing it for them" when the music
was different, translate that into a new movement in dance, rather than
gawk and sit...

oh well i think im caught in an evil non creative non open minded vortex
where raving is more about being "cool" nowadays... heheheh too many
yuppie children, not enough baby busters ;)

anyway, for all you creative minds musicians, artists zippie
representatives of the most radical city in the United States of America,
definitely definitely check out the free spiraltribe 3 day festival on
halloween weekend every one of their three day festivals is truly
unforgettable

-dsp

Ok... so I plan to go to this party/weekly in sac, cause its close to 
Davis...  I get shitty ass directions and it ends up taking me 1 hour to 
get there.. oh well. it was only $5..
 the music is all good.. it was house, if thats what you call it...
i just call it music...
its all music..
so i got in the break circle for a bit... but the music wasnt loud 
enough there so i moved to the dancefloor wherer it was a little 
louder...
the vibe wwas pretty cool.. my favorite part was when i closed my eyes, 
ignored everyone around and danceed my heart out.till they turned off 
the music at 2:00!!!!  early.. but its a club...
so it took me 15 mins to get back home.. and here i write my review..
I had fun.. but Next time I would like to go with someone..
Its cool going to parties by yourself, but one tends to get a little 
lonely... :( with no one to talk to. so next time your at a party and ya 
see someone chillin.. go up to them and say high.... :)
later peoples
peace
Philip

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Oct 22 10:52:22 1997

From: JD4150171 <JD4150171@aol.com>
Message-ID: <dff111a.344dda72@aol.com>
Date: Wed, 22 Oct 1997 06:50:50 EDT
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: NO TV review
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit
Organization: AOL (http://www.aol.com)
X-Mailer: Inet_Mail_Out (IMOv10)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

I'll preface this review by warning that I am not completely unbiased, as I am
friends with the people involved, but regardless, NO TV is a nice change of
pace, a unique environment, and a perfect wind down for Monday. 
The front room of 1015 was set up a space for local artist to create/show
their work - the main room was transformed to a living room/lounge setting,
with all the big comfy couches brought onto the floor in a semi circle and the
disco ball lowered as sort of a centerpiece. Many chairs and stools to sit,
candles, candy, fruit and veggies, and mellow music to start out.. then Freaky
Chakra played live and anyone who's seen him before knows - he rocks! Very
original music of differing paces and beats. Then Henrik finished up with some
classic danceable house music. It was a great mellow lowkey  vibe -
If anyone remembers the Gardening Club it reminded me a lot of that. (Not just
because its on a Monday!) In 2 weeks Mark Farina will be playing -
unfortunately it is 21+........        jd   :)

Kinda rave related.

This is a topic that I'm VERY interested in.

I had an out of body experience at LOVE AFFAIR.... it was beautiful. But I
didn't give in to it and it lasted but of a moment. I want to do it again.
My mom has had multiple out of body experiences and both her and my
grandma see spirits and are comfortable with it. Sometimes (a lot of the
time) I feel presences.... and have been afraid to face this reality...
but now I'm getting comfortable with it and am ready to face them... like
they're wanting to contact me and communicate or something. I swear there
are spirits everywhere and definately within my apartment... and I feel
like if I wanted to I could see them and feel their presence even more.

I've heard of people who are able to leave their bodies and meet others on
plains of existences... I've also heard/know people who are into lucid
dreaming. This all really intreges me and I would love for you guys to
share your ideas, thoughts, experiences with me and others... if you just
wanna e-mail me privately that is coool. But I would definately appreciate
some feedback. Plus any books, videos, movies, etc.. web pages that tell
about reaching the other side....

I talked to my friend last night about spirituality and our existence...
and about how drugs and spirituality sometimes go hand in hand for people.
I talked about Future Sound of London and how deep they are and how I feel
they have a good understanding of things.. and in turn are a path for us 
to pass through some spiritual gate to a deeper understanding..... and he
said it was too spacey for him and that he doesn't think about spirituality o
r even feel it's a part of his life.... Hmm.... talk to me!...

 Byroni the **Spacey** Cowboy?? :)
 "Won't you join me on a cosmic interlude...?"

first, the day that you're supposed to bring a "date" to a party is the day
I stop going.

second, the thought that to choose that "date," you should ask imbecilic
meaningless superficial questions is horrifying.

it's bad enough this is even on tv (sorry, spencer, i know it's a way to
get seen in hollywood, and appreciate that you have to take that
opportunity)

evolved???

i dunno, a "dating game" where the contestants don't even know what
each other looks like, and get chosen on their ability to write,
sounds fairly pc.  progressive, even.  i think a computer-based
virtual dating contest would be an evolutionary step forward, not
backwards.  and while i think it's great that you don't have to bring
a date to a rave, or hook up while there, that doesn't mean it's wrong
to do so.

-messiah wannabe

At 01:01 PM 10/22/97 -0700, you wrote:
>i dunno, a "dating game" where the contestants don't even know what

on that note...
a friend told me about this site: www.sfbaymatchmaker.com
and i'm embarrassed to admit this to a whole list of people!  BUT...  i
went there to check it out last friday... and i have to admit it was FUN!
you really don't have to participate, it was just fun reading about
different people- they have bios, essay questions to fill out, and some
people even have pictures to look at! the questionnaire is really good-
helps describe people very well in my opinion (age, location, music taste,
cat/dog person, likes/dislikes, etc...) and it's not just to find the love
of your life... you can use it just to meet people (opposite OR same sex)
that have similar tastes or that live near you!
i wouldn't recommend it to find the person of your dreams... i'm sure that
their are some (possibly many) weirdos visiting the site... i suggest caution,
but if you've got an hour or two to spare... check it out for fun!

do i sound like a spokes person or what???

at least this sort of site might give y'all some ideas to start out our own
little "raving ravers rendezvous" game!

On Wed, 22 Oct 1997, Megan Hug wrote:

> i wouldn't recommend it to find the person of your dreams... i'm sure that
> their are some (possibly many) weirdos visiting the site... i suggest caution,
> but if you've got an hour or two to spare... check it out for fun!
> 

Might I bold so bold as to ask "What is wrong with weirdos?"

Once a weirdo looked over Paris and said, "we need a tower that does
nothing but stand there"

Once another wierdo wrote a song about the first weirdo.  Sorry about the
Pixies reference...

Once a whole bunch of weirdos decided that we could do better than beer
busts, and threw a party in a warehouse and had their friends spin
records.  They spun music made by weirdos.  Weirdos showed up.  Soon, they
started to dress weird, the music got even weirder.  Soon, weird hell was
breaking loose.  Platform shoes, glitter, bass bins for 200 yards to
either side of the DJ, mixing in Led Zeppelin when people got to used to
house, jumping, bumping and grinding, taking *stuff*, sharing ideas,
touring the world, using glowsticks as landing beacons, UFOism, and being
nice and talking to strangers for a change. 

Then some other weirdos thought they could contact even more weirdos by
setting up a server so weirdos wouldn't keep making the same mistakes
with drugs, could find out about weirdo events, and even find out info on
how to make weird music.

Before this was the "next big thing", people thought it was pretty weird,
and I think that is a big part of it's beauty.  Keep it weird.

I just opened up my fortune cookie, and it says "You have a remarkable
power which you are not using" with happy faces to either side.

I think this is the fortune cookies way of saying I should quit my job and
become something I'm currently not...

Bye bye.
&EUU

It's like E.T. said.... be good.

you, then things will fall into place.. as everyone seems to believe

damn.. icant beleive what a thread i started, but its a posistve vibe

Philip

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

just to clarify what my intention was .....

i have no judgments at all about dating services, answering personals,
whatever people want to do to widen the circle of people they meet...  as a
matter of fact, it was through a personals ad years ago that I was first
introduced into the world of underground raving ...

and i encourage people to visit those personals sites, call those phone
lines, whatever, if they're interested.... and if there are cool ravers
participating there, that's great (and cool non-ravers are great too).

my objection was to the specific suggestion that we use this list --
sfraves, which is a group of 450+ diverse people -- and create our own
imitation version of "singled out" which i consider to be an idiotic show
that makes a mockery of any sort of true interpersonal relationships.

we have in the past had a couple of stabs at "raving personals" ... and, as
far as these kinds of introductions go in encouraging face-to-face meetings
with your online pals, who just may become your real-life friends, i'm with
that.

But "singled out" is crap, promoting shallow values and treating people
like disposable herds of merchandise.  it's like a tv-version of a kegger
or something.  i wouldn't be surprised if they've had wet t-shirt contests
on it.

I'd be much more encouraged to hear us want to emulate "politically
incorrect" or another show that has some brainpower and courage behind it.

leslie

>on that note...
>a friend told me about this site: www.sfbaymatchmaker.com
>and i'm embarrassed to admit this to a whole list of people!  BUT...  i
>went there to check it out last friday... and i have to admit it was FUN!
>you really don't have to participate, it was just fun reading about
>different people- they have bios, essay questions to fill out, and some
>people even have pictures to look at! the questionnaire is really good-
>helps describe people very well in my opinion (age, location, music taste,
>cat/dog person, likes/dislikes, etc...) and it's not just to find the love
>of your life... you can use it just to meet people (opposite OR same sex)
>that have similar tastes or that live near you!
>i wouldn't recommend it to find the person of your dreams... i'm sure that
>their are some (possibly many) weirdos visiting the site... i suggest caution,
>but if you've got an hour or two to spare... check it out for fun!
>
>do i sound like a spokes person or what???
>
>at least this sort of site might give y'all some ideas to start out our own
>little "raving ravers rendezvous" game!

look pal,

maybe YOU have to hook up at a rave to feel good about yourself. 
personally, i went to plenty of raves when i was married, with and
without my wife, and had a blast every time.  this summer i went to a
lot of raves, but my girlfriend wasn't into it, so i went with friends
instead.  and had a blast, every time.  now i love a nice sexy vibe at
a rave, and have no problem with hooking up at parties, but one of the
things i like about the rave scene is it's not the only reason people
are there.  people dance in their own space if they want to, talk to
friends, hug strangers they aren't neccesarily making moves on, talk
about interplanetary intellegence or whatever.  i think it makes a
nice change from, say, a friday night club scene where people have one
thing, and one thing only, on their minds.  i like being around people
who aren't one dimentional...

by the way, i got to say sometimes i think i detect a bit of a mean
streak in some of your posts, Jeff.  be careful, that sort of thing
tends to bounce back at you - i've never had any girl at a rave tell
me "don't come back till you got a girlfriend", or anything remotely
like that...

-messiah wannabe

Subject: spiral tribe!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Date: Wed, 22 Oct 1997 15:23:31 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4ME+ PL32 (25)]

well i haven't seen many actual reviews of spiral tribe, so even though it
was way back at last weekend, i figured i'd give mine anyway.

i got there early, about 11, since i was already in the city and my gf 
dropped me off...  there were about ten people there at the time, most of
them were in spiral tribe :)  oh well, i had a full tummy and had to digest
some before i was gonna attempt dancing anyway.  after an hour or so, more
people started showing up...i had met these swiss kids earlier in the day
and tried to talk them into going, so i looked for them, but didn's see em.
i was surprised at how few people i knew there...there were a few other 
things going on that night, but it was interesting that there was this whole
party full of people i'd never seen before :)  i like seeing attractors
at work.  

now, about the music...  i heard some of the loudest pounding jungle i have
ever heard that night..it just felt like someone had turned something up
to 11 when it was only supposed to go to 10 :)  the bass lines would get
heavier and heavier and then start screeching and squealing...it tore me
apart!  i have to mention that i was so-so on jungle before this night, but
spiral tribe made me a believer!  the other nice thing is that they would
keep alternating between trance and jungle, short sets, only about 45 min
of each.  that really kept you on yer toes, although the crowd seemed to 
thin a little each time the jungle came back.  i wandered outside for a 
smoke a few times and met some of the spiral tribe folks, they were all
very friendly and had some great stories :)  so the cops showed up at about
3:30 and told everyone to leave, which most people did, although i hear
that back room kept a little flame going all morning.  

all in all i had an astounding night, met a lot of cool people, and 
danced me silly head off =D

cheers,
 datura

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Oct 22 22:24:40 1997

To: *byroni* <byroni@ccnet.com>

well it's a real slow day at work so i might as well put my 2 cents
in...  i've never had an out of body experience, but i've had some
experiences along similar lines...

my ex-wife and i did hallucinogenics together quite a few times, and
often we both felt like we had had some sort of telepathic contact
with each other.  someone at party was telling me there were fairly
legitimate scientists doing research on ketamine's ability to increase
ESP etc.  well one time we were doing ketamine with some people,
complete strangers, really.  we all took quite a bit.  and once again
melissa and i were, well, connecting.  anyway, the next morning (uh,
noonish anyway) as we all stumbled out of our rooms and started
talking about the night before, this one guy pipes up and says, "hey
it was the weirdest thing last night!  i was just sitting there
listening to you and your wife talking.  but then i realized, you
weren't actually speaking!".  the funny thing was, at least part of
the time, we were talking about him...

another experience along those lines - for weeks this winter i had
been getting this really strong feeling that i should call my
grandmother in florida, who i hadn't talked to too recently.  "what if
she died and i hadn't called her in a while when it happened?"  this
thought kept popping into my head over and over, so one friday night i
decided to go with the feeling and call her.  and while she was
answering the phone, she fell down and hit her head.  i didn't know
exactly what was going on, so i called the front desk of the
retirement home where she was staying.  they called an ambulance, but
said they thought she would probably be ok once she got to the
hospital.  i wasn't so sure, so i asked if i could talk to her while
they waited for the ambulance.  she wasn't completely coherant when
she got on the phone, but she was concious and seemed to understand
what i was saying, so i told her how much i loved her, and admired her
for bringing up my mom so well after grandfather died, and everything
else i could think of that i wanted to tell her.  then the ambulance
came.  after we hung up, i went out just walking through downtown
portland, feeling this really strong connection to her.  then suddenly
it was gone.  she died at the hospital that night.  at the funeral, a
friend of hers from the home told our family that she had recently
found out she had cancer again, and basically over the last few weeks
had made peace with the idea that it was time to let this world go...

um, i think i'm rambling at this point.  hope you guys don't think i'm
a complete flaked-out acid casualty or anything.  i'd love to hear
about any similar experiences people have had...

-mw

>I was wondering what BREAKBEAT music is desbribed as by all a yall. =A0FAST=
=20
>or S L O W, what is it like etc. =A0DO you think that its good to dance to=
=20
>or is it mellow, =A0someone said that it is slower than TRANCE?

breakbeat is a rythmic style, where "breaks" are sped up and looped
together. the old happy hardcore (ex: prodigy's experience album and the
like) falls under the broad category of breakbeat, as would today's drum
and bass/jungle. something like "breakbeat trance" is, as you would expect,
is trance with some breakbeat influence.=20

technically, breakbeat would usually be faster than trance since the tempo
is usually greater, but the music might feel slower because your ear might
be focusing on the half-speed bassline rather than the drum line..

as for the danceability of breakbeat, it varies depending on the person.
some people prefer 4 beat, some people prefer breakbeat...

Okay, so my story isn't as deep and meaningful as everyone else's, but it's
pretty intereseting nonetheless. . . :)

I had a dream about a friend of mine that lives in SF, and she got lost in
the city.  We searched everywhere for her, but coulnd't find her.  I walk
up to a car and guess who is sitting in the front seat?  Marilyn Manson.
He says hello and gives me body jewelry (they were nice niobium rings,
too... Marilyn has gooood taste)I ask him if he has seen my friend, but he
says that he hasn't . . . And then I wake up.
Here's the deal, though.  I was on Haight Street on saturday doing some
shopping and talking about this friend that I had the dream about.  Guess
who walks by as I am talking about her--  Yes....It was Marilyn Manson and
his peeps.  Does that qualify as a psychic encounter or does Dionne Warwick
still have have the one up on me???

Just a thought.

HUGZ
jessica






>From: Messiah Wannabe <messiahw@rocketmail.com>
>
>
>
>
>well it's a real slow day at work so i might as well put my 2 cents
>in...  i've never had an out of body experience, but i've had some
>experiences along similar lines...
>
>my ex-wife and i did hallucinogenics together quite a few times, and
>often we both felt like we had had some sort of telepathic contact
>with each other.  someone at party was telling me there were fairly
>legitimate scientists doing research on ketamine's ability to increase
>ESP etc.  well one time we were doing ketamine with some people,
>complete strangers, really.  we all took quite a bit.  and once again
>melissa and i were, well, connecting.  anyway, the next morning (uh,
>noonish anyway) as we all stumbled out of our rooms and started
>talking about the night before, this one guy pipes up and says, "hey
>it was the weirdest thing last night!  i was just sitting there
>listening to you and your wife talking.  but then i realized, you
>weren't actually speaking!".  the funny thing was, at least part of
>the time, we were talking about him...
>
>another experience along those lines - for weeks this winter i had
>been getting this really strong feeling that i should call my
>grandmother in florida, who i hadn't talked to too recently.  "what if
>she died and i hadn't called her in a while when it happened?"  this
>thought kept popping into my head over and over, so one friday night i
>decided to go with the feeling and call her.  and while she was
>answering the phone, she fell down and hit her head.  i didn't know
>exactly what was going on, so i called the front desk of the
>retirement home where she was staying.  they called an ambulance, but
>said they thought she would probably be ok once she got to the
>hospital.  i wasn't so sure, so i asked if i could talk to her while
>they waited for the ambulance.  she wasn't completely coherant when
>she got on the phone, but she was concious and seemed to understand
>what i was saying, so i told her how much i loved her, and admired her
>for bringing up my mom so well after grandfather died, and everything
>else i could think of that i wanted to tell her.  then the ambulance
>came.  after we hung up, i went out just walking through downtown
>portland, feeling this really strong connection to her.  then suddenly
>it was gone.  she died at the hospital that night.  at the funeral, a
>friend of hers from the home told our family that she had recently
>found out she had cancer again, and basically over the last few weeks
>had made peace with the idea that it was time to let this world go...
>
>um, i think i'm rambling at this point.  hope you guys don't think i'm
>a complete flaked-out acid casualty or anything.  i'd love to hear
>about any similar experiences people have had...
>
>-mw
>

hello there again peoples,

Okay so I think i am sending this out to prevent anyone from having the
shitty afternoon I have had.  

Mainly this pertains to netadmins whoare using sendmail 8.8.X

If you or someone else hasn't updated your source binary or modified the
sendmail.cf file recently you might want to consider doing that.
please check out www.sendmail.org and check out the part of limiting 
your host as a relay host.

I know this is rave related and all that but getting 1000 emails an hour
and responding to lots of pissed off people isn't my idea of a fun
afternoon. 

just doing my bit of preventative maintenance for the net.

smile = )

herb

yeah, it was cool, although the dj after gabber girl didn't really do
it for me.  usually static is like 4 or so dj's tag teaming, generally
they play this hard-ass dark techstep stuff.  i liked the hardcore
tho, it was fucked up and weird, but surprisingly pretty at times (in
an empty sort of a way).  although i think maybe it would be better
for sticking in your mercedes tape deck while cruisin' at 250km/hr
down the autobahn than for dancing.  wait, mecedes?  gabber is
hollendaise, right?  or hollandic, or something.  hollandese? 
netherlandish?  what the hell do the drive in holland, anyway, and
where (not the autobahn, i don't think).  i gotta find out, i just
discovered my roommate's got a gabber comp...

On Mon, 20 Oct 1997 19:25:21 -0400 (EDT) JD4150171@aol.com writes:
>In a message dated 97-10-07 17:06:32 EDT, you write:
><Why do people think slower = mature>
><< #1    because this is the style of  music from the  disco glory 
>years 
> when alot of people first found the rave (91-92-93)   these people 
>are
> mature now>> 
>
>I thought disco was from the 70's?
> 
disco is from the 70's thats true.  (but so is the earliest house)   i
was just using a phrase that i say for the time when i and alot of people
i know first started going out.   this is when we first DISCOvered the
GLORY of being out at night, all night, getting high and listening to
house music with other people who were discovering it too.    The
dub-house-disco sound was bigger then too it seemed. Hits like two fat
guitars and rockers to rockers are songs that always bring me back to
that time. 


> <<#2   because more places that are 21+ play this kind of music.   
>when is
> the last time you saw or heard of a 21+ night of all breakbeat and
> trance?  parties that play predominantly breakbeat and techno often 
>have
> a younger crowd.>>
> 
> All the time, just not in SF!!. LA, NY, especially England - some of 
>the
>biggest clubs are 3 floors, 8 hours of techno, jungle and trance - 
>nothing
>under 180 BPM (except the chill room) and the average age at most 
>techno
>clubs is 25-30. Its the house clubs that attract the kids (18-20) 
>except in
>the North where happy hardcore is popular with the younger crowds. 
>Over there
>techno (real Detroit or German techno,  not Chem Bros/Underworld
> "electronica" techno) is what is considered more mature.

but why would people in SF care about what people in NY, England and
especially LA are doing?   I don't think we need to be like LA.   One of
the most mature things my mother ever said to me was "if all your friends
are going to jump of a bridge are you going to do that too?" 

><<#3   most people who are older and still going out are not on speed 
>that
> much so a slower deeeper groove feels right>>
>
>  That doesn't make much sense to me- if you're not on speed you would 
>need
>fast                                        music to keep going, slow 
>music
>would slow you down.But if you've got good music you don't need drugs 
>. Are
>you saying young people dance fast and are on speed and older people 
>dance
>slow and aren't on speed? 

i don't understand your logic.   if you are shaking your ass to the beat
and it is going 180 beats per minute you shake your ass 60 times more
than someone dancing to a 120 bpm house track.    that is one third more
energy to expend.   if i am not high on speed or acid it becomes hard for
me to keep up after a couple of hours.   when i am dancing to house i can
drink a couple of beers smoke some herb and groove and still be able to
keep up with the music.

when i go out to a trance party (beilieve it or not i have been to a few)
  almost everyone is dosed.  it is hard to not be high and still
participate when the music is that fast.  

but if i am out at wicked or come-unity or stompy i could chill and dance
and not have to wait a couple days to come down so that i can participate
in the "real world" again.

i was not trying to say that if you are under 21 you are on speed, but
the older you get the harder it becomes to go out and do speed or take
dose every weekend. 

>
><< #4  soul and funk isn't something that you "get over" anyway. (if 
>you
> truly feel it in the first place)>>
>
>I agree but the point is there should be some variety.
> 
> #5  alot of this type of music comes from either chicago or england.  
>   
> chicago is the originator of house music( late 70's) and england was
> really  heavy into house music in the eighties before everyone 
>started
> talking about "electronica".  so this type of music has history and
> sophistication.   i guess you could call it mature as an art form.
> 
> #5.a   san frandisco has a bunch of dj's from england and at least 
>one
> from chicago so these people have experienced house music that many 
>of us
> have never known if we have only been paying attention to dance music 
>for
> the last 5 years or so.   
> 
> so if alot dj's in sf aren't playing the latest progressive hits from
> mixmag, 
> or trying in vain to mix two dat tapes full of goa,  these might be 
>some
> of the reasons  ( in my opinion of course)
> 
> HOUSE MUSIC WILL NEVER DIE
> peace
> gabe >>
>
>The other reasons sound like what you are saying is we are 10 years 
>behind
>the times! I agree!  What is wrong with hearing some new music? Don't 
>be
>afraid of the future or trying something new! It all goes back to 
>people's
>need to cling to the familiar and the past. Retro and classic rock 
>stations
>are the most popular.....10 years from now all the clubs will be 
>playing
>happy hardcore!
>
>IMHO....jd (thanks for the food for thought)
>
i am not saying we are behind the times at all.   I am saying that we
here in SF don't need the rest of the world to tell us what to listen to.
 Underground music in many cases is becoming mainstream.    electronica
is just another word for pop music.  it is the alternative rock of the
late 90's.  mixmag is a commercial magazine.   Sure there is radio house
music.  but you don't hear that stuff when you go to a good club.   

besides we are not listening to the same old songs over and over like a
retro rock station.    house music has been evolving for almost 20 years
now.   people are making all kinds of crazy styles of house music.   we
just like the whole "easy to dance to 120 bpm" tempo.   my reason #5 was
just trying to say that certain people who dj around here have had the
experience of  hearing the power of house music in an environment where
it really took off and are trying to share it with us in the bay area.  i
was just trying to relate the history and culture of house as an art
form.   i mean why stop playing jazz just because grunge rock comes
along.  you don't just drop one art form because another comes along that
is making more money for some music executive.   

as far as trying something new.   there are ample opportunities all the
time to hear other music than house.   SF is very diverse musically.  
people aren't afraid of playing trance or techno or jungle.   there are
all kinds of parties here.    But there is a large group that are really
into the house vibe, for many of the reasons i pointed out earlier. if
more people really preferred techno, trance, and jungle over house music
they would play less house music.  


peace
gabe

On Wed, 22 Oct 1997 ravalum@pacbell.net wrote:

> I was wondering what BREAKBEAT music is desbribed as by all a yall.  FAST 
> or S L O W, what is it like etc.  DO you think that its good to dance to 
> or is it mellow,  someone said that it is slower than TRANCE?
> 
> TERESA
> 
Turn up your CD player.  That Chemical Brothers CD you hear? That's
probably breakbeat.  Firestarter by Prodigy, that's breakbeat.

Not the Boom Boom Boom Boom Boom Boom Boom Boom Boom Boom...

but the Boom ka! BoomBoom ka! Boom ka! BoomBoom ka! Boom...

Thank you,
Andy

p.s. Breakbeat should be a little slower or the same speed as trance, but
music with breakbeat riddims go all the way up to jungle and british
hardcore...  and that's fast stuff... woohaaa... extra spicy... most
really slow stuff (like rap, lotsa that trip hop chemical stuff) has what
would be considered a breakbeat beat, but we don't usually call it that.
So does a lot of surf music too... in fact, it might all be breakbeat if I
sit and think about it long enough...

p.p.s.	Can be fun to dance to, assuming your shopping cart doesn't get in
the way (inside joke to myself, last time I heard the Chem Bros I was
shopping really late, and the stockpeople were buggin out to it).

At 04:05 PM 10/22/97 -0700, George Chan wrote:
>Has anyone offered to give C.A. a proper induction into the SF
>rave scene?  When you more e*perienced ravers take neophytes
>out to their first rave, what do you do?  

it really depends on the party...you can't really do anything about it if a
person gives raving a try for their first time and it's a bad vibe or what
not...i suppose sharing some smokable substance with them helps--although
most of my non-raving friends are straightedge...encourage them to meet new
people, let them wander around on their own and see what it's all about, if
they're self-conscious about dancing don't chide them for not doing so...if
you think they'll be o.k. with it, give them an ExpEriEncE; for better or
for worse, _that's_ what converted me.

and don't forget that some people are just never gonna be into it...it's
like any type of entertainment, you either groove on it or you don't...
-------------------------------
"i scream so much.  you know what i mean.  this electric stream.  and my
tears in league with the wires and energy and my machine."

> is present in my mind...I'd have it no other way.
> Breedlove

else is more important then ask about that.

Winter is the time of solstice but it is also the time for Rebirth(not
the Mac version).  Winter is about change and gives people a chance to
look inwards and possible change that which needs changing.  Remember
that what we feel on the inside is what we project to other on the
outside.  Its kinda a double-edged sword, in some ways it can drive away
that which we desire but on the other hand it can also attract what we
may not need(in the long run).  So enjoy your freedom and look towars
the positive things like(even though its hard as Hell to think of
anything else).
  My first post on Sf Raves.... Fate out.....

though there might be a presence about.   Fate

AndyW wrote:
> 
> On Wed, 22 Oct 1997 ravalum@pacbell.net wrote:
> 
> > I was wondering what BREAKBEAT music is desbribed as by all a yall.  FAST
> > or S L O W, what is it like etc.  DO you think that its good to dance to
> > or is it mellow,  someone said that it is slower than TRANCE?
> >
> > TERESA
> >
> Turn up your CD player.  That Chemical Brothers CD you hear? That's
> probably breakbeat.  Firestarter by Prodigy, that's breakbeat.
> 
> Not the Boom Boom Boom Boom Boom Boom Boom Boom Boom Boom...
> 
> but the Boom ka! BoomBoom ka! Boom ka! BoomBoom ka! Boom...
> 
> Thank you,
> Andy
> 
> p.s. Breakbeat should be a little slower or the same speed as trance, but
> music with breakbeat riddims go all the way up to jungle and british
> hardcore...  and that's fast stuff... woohaaa... extra spicy... most
> really slow stuff (like rap, lotsa that trip hop chemical stuff) has what
> would be considered a breakbeat beat, but we don't usually call it that.
> So does a lot of surf music too... in fact, it might all be breakbeat if I
> sit and think about it long enough...
> 
> p.p.s.  Can be fun to dance to, assuming your shopping cart doesn't get in
> the way (inside joke to myself, last time I heard the Chem Bros I was
> shopping really late, and the stockpeople were buggin out to it).

Actually its all spionning of into new and different tangents of music. 
When I was in Germany(93-95)  Techno in germany was 180-200 Bpm, muck
different than British Techno which was more like 130-150 Bpm.  So many
styles these days its hard to keep up with whats Trance and whats
Ambient.  One thing is for sure, Happy Hardcore is one style that is
very pronounced and is easy to tell from the rest.

My Susan B., Fate

Subject: Re: DESCRIBE Breakbeat PLEASE!
To: ravalum@pacbell.net

In-Reply-To: <344E7E3D.64F1@pacbell.net>

Precedence: bulk



ahem

:D

Back in the day, techno music was dominated by the now ever-so-familiar 
quarter-note "4-on-the-floor" drum beat (boom boom boom boom).  One day, 
some guy was listening to a salsa or marengue rekkid and thought, "Hey, 
if I replace every either measure of this boring-ass drum beat with this 
fresh salsa beat, it will really break up the monotany of this music!" 
and thus "the Breakbeat" was born.

A little while later, some folks thought, "Hey, why not use those groove 
Afro-Cuban and Latin beats to drive the entire track!" and the subgenre 
was named "Breakbeat"

More or less that's how it happened.

Also, this style of beat programming became popular with the rap crowd in 
the early 80's and became a mainstay of breakdancers.  Thusly, breakbeat 
music and breakdancing go hand-in-hand.


"You know if it wasn't for Grandmaster Flash inventing scratching and 
bringing the records back to catch just the break to um elongate it then 
you woulda never had b-boys 'cuz there woulda never been a break."

More or less that's how it happened


Breakbeat ranges in tempo from really slow downtempo stuff (like 60bpm) 
up to as fast as you can get it (Breakcore for example).  In general, you 
find breakbeat at around 100-120 bpm.  I pitch up most of my breaks, as I 
like to hear them somewhere between the 125-135bpm range.  

Personally, I find breakbeat to be the most 'danceable' of all techno 
music.  Where trance or house seem to get into my head and get me on a 
mind trip, breakbeat goes straight to the old booty and gets me movin'.

Another khakamaymee idea of mine.  Foolish fish posted a while back ago
about trying to bring the rave community together to help solve problems.
This is along those lines. 

Picture one of these scenarios;  You are at a massive, you feel 
lost, you're friends are missing, you feel a bad trip coming on, you're
dehydrated...whatever.  Hey what's that over there?  Candles, beanbags,
incense burning, a sign that says please come in.  It's the SFR karma zone
where you can find solace, infosheets, hugs, fruit, promotional stuff for 
local djs, good vibes, etc.  We are there helping others and promoting
healthy raving and healthy lifestyles.  It's a win-win situation!  I know
I've had a lot of cracked out ideas, but I think this one is really good.

What do the promoters on the list think of this idea?  Is it something
worth pursuing, something you would support at your ug/massive?  I'm not
really in the promotion loop so any insights would be great.

*GEOrGEOrGEOrGE.... and so on...

needle with nothing in it . Go fill it up and poke your arm I'm sure it
cant
do any harm. So what if it desroys your vein, it's already destroyed
your
brain. Become addicted? No way! No how! Sorry pal it's too late now.
You've
taken it a step too far got off your feet and in your car. Drove all the
way
to nowheresville. Just to snort a line or pop a pill. What'll it be just
one
more fix? Just one more time to get your kicks? Just one more needle to
be
shared, just one less life to be spared. Stay awake, just five more
days.
Wait, you'll see, it really pays! Pays for what your life I guess. Does
it
relieve or cause more stress? There is nothing wrong with getting high I
love it lots I can not lie. But everyday at what extent? Weekends
come-your
money's spent. No food, no sleep, no energy, can't you enjoy your
ectasy?
Can't move, can't dance, you feel like shit! Don't you ever get sick of
it?
Smoke the budda all week long, keep other drugs where they belong. When
it's
party time, let it loose. Swallow, snort,or smoke the juice. It's not
easy, I
understand,and I don't like to reprimand. But you have to realize what
you're
doing. It's not only yourselfs your screwing.Those of us that stand up
tall
don't like to sit and watch you fall. But we can't tell you what to do,
it's
your life, it's up to you! So,if you choose to waste away, and get
cracked up
every single day-then so be it! My hands are tied! But I will never lose
my
pride. Enjoy yourselves, it's good I'M sure. I just hope your soul stays
pure. Don't damage it with wasted time, please accept the meaning of
this
rhyme. We can benfit from the drugs we use, just think about it and
don't
abuse. 
 STAR QUEEN "97"

(what's going on? i just don't seem to be able to get this message thru to
sfraves. if anybody got this 3 times, i apologize.)

hello all you lovely sfravers

i see you're all still around. hi byroni, dErEk, liz, foolish fish, beth...
who else's name did i see amongst the 1600 messages that i just downloaded
after 4 weeks of involuntary abstinence. i tried unsubscribing twice. don't
know why it didn't work but at least i'm not missing anything :)
rubilicious, you still around? anybody seen julie hayes (*fairy princess*)?
could someone please ask her to email us? hi doughboy, hi ari, hi jelo...
ed leech, where are you? please come back to england. we need someone to
hang out with. people are horrid here. they don't understand. they haven't
been touched by the californian philosophy of life...;)

well, we live in manchester, uk, now and finally got the phone connected.
it's a cool city although we'd rather be in san francisco :) ppl are so
much nicer there. we miss you all so much. coming back to england was such
a come-down. i hope this is not going to deter you from coming to visit us.
we'll do our best to find some entertainment for you groovers.

btw: to all those who constantly winge that the underground is going
mainstream and techno is gonna die and stuff like that i can only say that
it's just damn hard to find, especially in a new place...but we're getting
closer. found some wonderful fast and hard trance and spacey techno last
week. after 2 months w/o raving we were so ripe for it. but there's just so
much meat-market handbag house clubs around it's disgusting. oh and this
disco revival sends us running as far as we can every time. someone was
telling us about a place that stays open until 9 in the morning (clubs shut
around 2). his words were: 'no idea what they do that long'. and that the
police is trying to shut it down. yeah, that's what we're looking for, we
said. didn't even have to ask what kind of music they're playing.

well, that's all for now. have a wicked halloween.

iris + ben
"...the only difference between computers and drugs is that one is too
large to swallow."  (Terence McKenna)

Precedence: bulk

Hi george and others who may be fairly new on this list....

we have the makings of a group called Karma Patrol, which is pretty much
what you describe.... Karma Patrol has done several parties ... but then
when things started slowing down a few months ago (due to lack of sites,
lack of energy, etc.) we haven't done much formally...  (though, in one
sense, we're all on Karma Patrol all the time)

We had a crew who were committed to sobriety at any party where they
worked, we had a "safe spot" corner that was only available for people who
Karma Patrol though should be there to be looked after... we walked the
party, checked on people, spread smiles and good thoughts, and in the
process, found people who might need a little attention..

if you think this is a great idea, then you should be part of it... foolish
fish has been karma patrol, and many of the people on this list (and not on
this list) have chosen to do it...

one of the limitations is that every party needs a committed organizer of
it, who can "recruit" and "manage" the team of people who want to
participate ... and make sure that the safe spot is a workable one ....

Some parties, like Harmony, have always had either a formal or informal
karma patrol.... i encourage each of you to talk to the promoters of
parties you're involved in to try to get a Karma Patrol presence...

love, Leslie


>Another khakamaymee idea of mine.  Foolish fish posted a while back ago
>about trying to bring the rave community together to help solve problems.
>This is along those lines.
>
>Picture one of these scenarios;  You are at a massive, you feel
>lost, you're friends are missing, you feel a bad trip coming on, you're
>dehydrated...whatever.  Hey what's that over there?  Candles, beanbags,
>incense burning, a sign that says please come in.  It's the SFR karma zone
>where you can find solace, infosheets, hugs, fruit, promotional stuff for
>local djs, good vibes, etc.  We are there helping others and promoting
>healthy raving and healthy lifestyles.  It's a win-win situation!  I know
>I've had a lot of cracked out ideas, but I think this one is really good.
>
>What do the promoters on the list think of this idea?  Is it something
>worth pursuing, something you would support at your ug/massive?  I'm not
>really in the promotion loop so any insights would be great.
>
>*GEOrGEOrGEOrGE.... and so on...

"my $0.02 on this great idea"

by 

jdw


i think this idea is great because it is a really good idea. i would
like it if there was a place at places that i go where i could know that
people i know would also go. people could use a place like this one that
is a great idea as a place to share things and ideas and other things. i
think it is hard to make a great idea like this great idea happen
without great effort and determination and planning and other things.
but it is still a great idea and i could help sometimes because i like
it.  

the end

Yeah, "Love comes quickly, whatever you do you can't stop falling..".. one
of my favorite songs... definately my favorite Pet Shop Boys song...
yeah, I'm not worrying about it. If it was meant to be it will happen.

All I know is that I haven't been remembering my dreams lately. Maybe
because I day dream so much that my dream juices are all drained out...
haha. Just kidding.

I hope we all find that special someone. But an intersting point was
brought to my attention. Our collective consciousness works in a way that
doesn't allow us to meet people that we can really CONNECT to very often.
Something about the rhythim of our lives and the energy in the universe.

Byroni

Thanks for sharing that. That's so touching.

As for communication without talking. It happens to me all the time when
I'm tripping. I feel myself flowing in and out of other people's energy
and consciousness. We have convesations and express feelings, ideas,
witout even talking. Then we realize it and laugh and say something like,
"Oh my God.... Trippy". Derek Fieldsoe and I did this the night of Big Top
at Mc Donalds.... we were in a comic strip dressed up as Droogs and we
were communicating. It's so much fun. It happens when you don't think abou
tit and just *exist* without any really deep thought or concentration.
Where your spirit has more attention than your limited universe called
life on Earth.

I come to understandings and learn things about people just from day to
day life. I know I have ESP and have inherited a 6th sense from my mom's
side of the family. But when I'm *DiVERgEnt* I am even more in touch with
this. It's nice. I can read people pretty well and thank myself for this
ability. It saves me a lot of time getting to know people that end up
being worthless, cold, people who have no benefit to mankind and care
little about others...

I'm so glad we brought this up. Because we are all aware of this second
existence that we've been open to. But no one talks about it!... or if
they do it's only to close friends. Which is understandable. At first I
was hesitent to say anything (Wait.. Byroni hesitent to babble and talk
about things, regardless of anything...??) but these feelings and the
importance of these experiences are becoming more and more important to
me. So I want to share them with you and hear your ideas. At a rave I
always feel much more comfortable... because I feel like more people are
on the same level....    

Also.. my cat has to know what's going on... He always knows things. Like
when I'm about go come home, when I'm going to wake up in the morning,
when I'm sad, lonely, etc. It's nice. I love watching my at when I'm
divergent.... examing his sleekness, his dexerity, charisma... he's so
cozmic looking... furry, BEAUTIFUL eyes, nice fur... totally open to any
affection.. weather it's another cat (male or female), a cubbord door, my
foot, himself, etc. They are definately in touch with themselves. :) But
at the same time I wonder... their intelligence isn't as great as ours in
OUR EYES, but maybe that's because they're living on a different path...
but are just as socially aware and spiritually adept.???

Byroni

On Wed, 22 Oct 1997, Messiah Wannabe wrote:

> 
> 
> 
> well it's a real slow day at work so i might as well put my 2 cents
> in...  i've never had an out of body experience, but i've had some
> experiences along similar lines...
> 
> my ex-wife and i did hallucinogenics together quite a few times, and
> often we both felt like we had had some sort of telepathic contact
> with each other.  someone at party was telling me there were fairly
> legitimate scientists doing research on ketamine's ability to increase
> ESP etc.  well one time we were doing ketamine with some people,
> complete strangers, really.  we all took quite a bit.  and once again
> melissa and i were, well, connecting.  anyway, the next morning (uh,
> noonish anyway) as we all stumbled out of our rooms and started
> talking about the night before, this one guy pipes up and says, "hey
> it was the weirdest thing last night!  i was just sitting there
> listening to you and your wife talking.  but then i realized, you
> weren't actually speaking!".  the funny thing was, at least part of
> the time, we were talking about him...
> 
> another experience along those lines - for weeks this winter i had
> been getting this really strong feeling that i should call my
> grandmother in florida, who i hadn't talked to too recently.  "what if
> she died and i hadn't called her in a while when it happened?"  this
> thought kept popping into my head over and over, so one friday night i
> decided to go with the feeling and call her.  and while she was
> answering the phone, she fell down and hit her head.  i didn't know
> exactly what was going on, so i called the front desk of the
> retirement home where she was staying.  they called an ambulance, but
> said they thought she would probably be ok once she got to the
> hospital.  i wasn't so sure, so i asked if i could talk to her while
> they waited for the ambulance.  she wasn't completely coherant when
> she got on the phone, but she was concious and seemed to understand
> what i was saying, so i told her how much i loved her, and admired her
> for bringing up my mom so well after grandfather died, and everything
> else i could think of that i wanted to tell her.  then the ambulance
> came.  after we hung up, i went out just walking through downtown
> portland, feeling this really strong connection to her.  then suddenly
> it was gone.  she died at the hospital that night.  at the funeral, a
> friend of hers from the home told our family that she had recently
> found out she had cancer again, and basically over the last few weeks
> had made peace with the idea that it was time to let this world go...
> 
> um, i think i'm rambling at this point.  hope you guys don't think i'm
> a complete flaked-out acid casualty or anything.  i'd love to hear
> about any similar experiences people have had...
> 
> -mw
> 
> 
>

> the

> > but now I'm getting comfortable with it and am ready to face them...
> like
> > they're wanting to contact me and communicate or something. I swear
> there
> > are spirits everywhere and definately within my apartment... and I
> feel
> > like if I wanted to I could see them and feel their presence even
> more.
> > 
> > I've heard of people who are able to leave their bodies and meet
> others on
> > plains of existences... I've also heard/know people who are into lucid
> > dreaming. This all really intreges me and I would love for you guys to
> > share your ideas, thoughts, experiences with me and others... if you
> just
> > wanna e-mail me privately that is coool. But I would definately

> tell
> > about reaching the other side....

> > said it was too spacey for him and that he doesn't think about

FSOL is the best group to get DEEEEEP with. I don't know if any of you
guys remember this.. but there was a time about 8 or so months ago where I
was at work (after Captain Crunch got busted) with some friends I MET THAT
NIGHT... and I was to say the least... tripped out. I was hoping that I
could listen to something while the others and I chatted and got deep. So
I remembered that I had ISDN!... nice.....   FSOL has helped bring to me
placed I never imagined. This stuff is engineered for trippers..... Jack
Tripper... :)

"I killed a man.. a man who looked like me"..

FSOL is to music as David Lynch is to movies.

Byroni

now here's where the irony of this whole "singles" thing really gets to me...

you want to have a "singles" party (yeah, as if 80% of the rave community
is single anyway??) ....

but i guess you'll just have to have a separate event if you want to meet
Brian, because Brian is married to Laura, who's also a cool person ... but
of course, they can't come to the "super-cool singles" event, because
they're under the category of "super-cool married people"....

see the problem here, folks?  the reason having a "singles-only" event
feels awkward is because it's basically contrived and unnatural...

How about just keep on keeping on having small non-dance oriented
get-togethers where all the sfravers are invited, and the ones who have the
time, interest, etc. will come together ....  have that dinner, byroni, but
invite all the people who'd like to come together and meet each other...

and who knows, maybe once you meet the married Brian, he'll introduce you
to someone who's single and will turn out the be the love of your life...

funny how life works that way...

love, leslie

Hi byroni-

Bad analogy. A lot of vegans don't like going to a macdonalds b/c the
smell makes them sick. Imagine, then having a monthly veganism meeting
in a macdonalds...some would think it was ok and go, others would
freak out b/c their theories on eating are so totally opposed to what
the fast food chain is all about. Some might say let's just call that
meeting off.

Ultimately, you're right. I don't have to go, and I won't go. 

Probably one of the top things I always liked about raves, from the
very first one I went to was the total freedom from conventional
social interaction. Whether I danced with my friends, or by myself, or
with a girl or with a guy..it just didn't matter. 

Sure, I've met plenty of cool girls at parties, gotten together with
one or two..but even so, there was somthing magical in the spontanaity.

So I'm sorry if you think it strange that I consider raves above a
some sort of formal or planned dating ritual, but I know there's lots
of others out there who feel the same way as I do. This scene is what
you make of it, and of course there's room for all our opinions, but I
guess there's some new ideas that I'll never get used to.

-take care-

alex

Ok Ok.. just a little humor to lighten this awful day.. =D

The Perfect Story
=================

There was a perfect man who met a perfect woman.  After a perfect courtship, 
they had a perfect wedding.  Their life together was, of course, perfect. 

One snowy, stormy christmas eve this perfect couple was driving along a 
winding road when they notice someone at the roadside in distress.  Being the 
perfect couple, they stopped to help.

There stood Santa Claus with a huge bundle of toys.  Not wanting to disappoint
any children on the eve of christmas, the perfect couple loaded Santa and his 
toys into their vehicle.  Soon they were driving along delivering the toys.  
Unfortunately, the driving conditions deteriorated and the perfect couple and 
Santa Claus had an accident

Only one of them survived the accident.  Who was the survivor?
(scroll down for the answer)

















The perfect woman.  Everyone know there is no Santa claus and no such thing as
a perfect man.   

**A males response:  So, if there is no perfect man and no Santa Claus, the 
perfect woman must have been driving.... explains why there was a car 
accident.....

=D
lUUNATiK
lUUNATiK
=D

AndyW wrote:
> Turn up your CD player.  That Chemical Brothers CD you hear? That's
> probably breakbeat.  Firestarter by Prodigy, that's breakbeat.
>
> Not the Boom Boom Boom Boom Boom Boom Boom Boom Boom Boom...
>
> but the Boom ka! BoomBoom ka! Boom ka! BoomBoom ka! Boom...
>

Hmmm. I don't know if I agree w/ that. By that definition, I guess
Tack>>Head, Gary Clail, Keith Leblanc (DJ SPike), Fats Comet, Mark
Stewart and that whole "industrial/big beats" crowd that accreted
around Adrian Sherwood's production values are "breakbeat" too. But we
all know that's not quite right. What I do know is that these "big
beat" sounds  (which began around 1986) have not been given proper
respect for being one of the progenitors of the techno/rave/house/dub
movement of today.

I've heard this style of music, as well as some of the Chemical
Brothers stuff described as "big beat" w/ a tip of the hat to the
big-beat masters of yore. (actually, i'd rather listen to Tackhead or
Keith LeBlanc). I don't know where the Prodigy fits into this, other
then the fact that I don't like anything the Prodigy did after their
first releases way back in the day.

For more on "big beat" (not breakbeat), check the "The Power Inc --
vols 1, 2, 3" compilations from Alfa in Japan (anybody got copies i can
borrow?? I have some of the original releases, but it would be nice to
have them all on a few CDs).

PS: for breakbeat, an easy to find CD compilation is DJ John Kelley
"Funky Desert Breaks" on Moonshine. It's ok, but it's nothing to phone
ET about.

>if you arent going to do anything to contribute, dont take up space?!?!?!

>DO your own thing, yes :) but if "not doing anything" is "your own thing"
>go sit on the haight all night and do your own thing

there is no law (or even an unwritten rule) against being a member of the
audience rather than a performer...it's sometimes preferable...

like when everything is just SO pretty and SO real and INTENSE that you
can't even move, and just kind of sit there watching everything happen...

gotta understand this--a rave is a place where anybody can go and be
themselves while listening to the big bass thump.  and if being themselves
is standing around and "being cool" well then that's the way it goes and
there's nothing wrong with that.
-------------------------------
"i scream so much.  you know what i mean.  this electric stream.  and my
tears in league with the wires and energy and my machine."

hey all you glowing blinking led kidz out there, i have a question. 
where can i find some of those multicolored glowstring tubes - not the
standard-issue glowsticks, mind you, but the rainbow hued
string-things that you can wear as a neckace.  or a bracelet.  or a
halo.  and while were at it, if anyone wants to share sources for
glowing blinking things, feel free.  i'll start the ball rolling with
one suggestion - radio shack.  they don't have glowsticks, but i've
seen some pretty interesting and unique blink-gear there.  and they
have "psycho lights", which you can't wear at a rave, but will turn
your bedroom into one, for like $12 - HIGHly recomended...

- messiah wannabe

George Chan wrote:

> What do the promoters on the list think of this idea?  Is it something
> worth pursuing, something you would support at your ug/massive?

Well, it initially sounds like it would be a good idea.  From a promotional
perspective, I feel that it is the responsibility of promoters to provide such
attractions for the ravers, if there is a reflected desire for it.   Many
events do not have chill rooms, and could benefit from this type of 'tent'.
But at events that do have a produced chill area... having a second chill out
spot produced by an external entity/organization may actually imply a
'clickyness' and could backfire on the entire concept of itself.  The last
thing we need is any associated segregation.  of course I understand that that
may not at all be the case, and that this is only a reflection of diversity of
our community, but many people may see it as a 'click' and not come over to
the 'tent' because its not their scene.  These are issues that would have to
be addressed.

An alternative to this idea would be an SFR Promotional table, to spread the
word about SFR and try to inform NEW people about this online community.
Incorporate into this table a few bean bags, and a rotation of people on the
list to always be at the table, and one main organizer, and you may have what
you are looking for.  And that would be accepted at any event, and could be
setup inside the chill room, or with the vendors.  This way it does not imply
any form of grouping, but more of an outreach and informative purpose.

Personally, I think that ANY group/member effort made by SFR compromises its
purpose., not extends it..  This list serves as a medium of discussion, were
anyone can discuss anything about raving that they want.   To organize events
and produce attractions... I feel takes away from the very foundation, and
nature of the purpose of this list.   If this list is open for anyone, at
anytime... then a group/member produced activity is a contradiction of its own
agenda, and may seem to some people a bit hypocritical.  Maybe Im just
reaching to far, or getting a bit analytical here, but its just my take on the
subject. :)Keep Ir Real

Vlad aka Ray Vonie


> Another khakamaymee idea of mine.  Foolish fish posted a while back ago
> about trying to bring the rave community together to help solve problems.
> This is along those lines.
>
> Picture one of these scenarios;  You are at a massive, you feel
> lost, you're friends are missing, you feel a bad trip coming on, you're
> dehydrated...whatever.  Hey what's that over there?  Candles, beanbags,
> incense burning, a sign that says please come in.  It's the SFR karma zone
> where you can find solace, infosheets, hugs, fruit, promotional stuff for
> local djs, good vibes, etc.  We are there helping others and promoting
> healthy raving and healthy lifestyles.  It's a win-win situation!  I know
> I've had a lot of cracked out ideas, but I think this one is really good.
>
>
>
> *GEOrGEOrGEOrGE.... and so on...

Break Dancer wrote:

> this IS a very touchy subject.. in some sense i think they have a right
> to do that, but in another sense, it just adds to the useless " i'm
> gonna sue you" mentality.. they got shut down, they should elave it at
> that...unless they plan on throwing a big free party, or donating the
> won money, instead of putting it in their already fat pockets if ya know
> what i mean...

       Actually CWP is standing up for everyone in the entire dance
community by filing this suite.  Don't get distracted by the $4.5 mill, its
just a statement.   If there will be any settlement it will be a small
percentage of the initial complaint... that's the way our fucked up system
works.  You have to ask for 100 times more than what you want in order to
get what you expect.      But all that aside....  CWP is making a stand on
behalf of the entire community.... They are saying that youth culture should
not be discriminated against, and they are trying to set a president to make
sure something like this NEVER happens again to ANY promoter.  Not just in
this area, but anywhere in this country.  Don't forget, it was CWP that
opened up the city of Oakland for permits after they fought long and hard
for 2 years with the city council to allow after-hours event to happen in
Oakland... And Now they are still leading the fight to eliminate
discrimination and unfair treatment of OUR Youth Culture.
    So before anyone starts to put them down, just remember that they are
not just doing this to recoup a $300,000 loss, but to make a point that We
are not to be Fucked around with, cause We fight back, and are Not
pushovers.  This is the main issue in this suite... not the Money...
remember money is just a tool... it has no REAL intrinsic value, and is not
the end product.  Unless your a drug dealer, lawyer, politician, or a used
car salesman.

Keep It Real

Vlad

To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: FYI -- latest pioneer CD DJ decks -- CDJ-700S
Date: Thu, 23 Oct 97 12:17:08 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


Looks like another generation of DJ CD decks is going to be hitting the
market one of these days.

See ... http://www.cddj.com/pioneer/prodj.htm for a picture ...

Also, a web search turned up
http://www.glenn-miller.com/wwwboard/forum1/messages/410.html , which
says:

--------------------

Posted by Todd Barber on September 10, 1997 at 00:40:18:

I spoke with a rep from Pioneer yesterday regarding the CDJ-700. If any
of you are thinking about getting one of these here is the info I
recieved.

There are five new features in the 700 over the 500II's. First there is
the anti-skip mech. which is the same technology used in Pioneers car
stereo line. The rep told me that they gave a demo of the unit at a
convention in Alantic city where they turned the cd player upside dow
and shook it and it did not skip. Next there is a loop tuning feature
where you can set the loop points and on the fly adjust the length of
the loop making it longer or shorter. Third the pitch adjustment has
been bumped up from +/- 10% to +/- 16%. Fouth is the size which is less
than half the size. Finally the jog wheel represnts the same number of
frames from o to 360 degrees as a turntable does.

There is a system that is offered called the 700S, which includes 2
CDJ-700's, the DJM-300, and a custom case. Pioneer is working on a case
design for two CDJ-700's and one DJM-500.

The 300 mixer features -26db on the eq section and a feature that
allows you to hear both input in your headphones where one side of the
headphones is one source and the other is the other source when used
with Pioneers new headphones. There are some big disadvantages of the
300 series mixer though, inputs and effects.

Also the 700's should be shipping to stores in a couple of weeks. 

--------------------

I can't find it to Re: to, but I saw a thread harshing youngin's up against
the wall tossing hair... somthing about walkmans?  and how this was wrong..
or not good.. or something...

I wanted to throw in my two cents.. not exactly as a rebuttal or anything,
but as a simple statement.

It's all about dancing for me, but I still chill on the sidelines when it
gets too intense, or i just get too hot... need water... check in on
friends......

i have a few friends that just *don't* dance.  they love being there, but
just don't find it in themselves to get out there and shake it.  one of my
friends usually goes home with a numb wrist and hand from just kind of
moving his right hand to the music.  that is his way of dancing.  he has a
blast, and i can't imagine anyone telling him he is not doing the right
thing by enjoying himself as a wallflower.  the music pumping in your ears,
people dancing around... that is an Experience all in it'self.  the
lights... the pretty lights.... visuals from the beyond.  a bit of
brain-bend to put it all in perspective...

how can enjoying yourself, no matter how, be wrong?

peace
-SolR

Date: Thu, 23 Oct 1997 17:47:37 -0700 (PDT)
From: Raen <stevedb@best.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: Breakbeat
In-Reply-To: <19971023222115.3315.qmail@hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.SGI.3.95.971023160011.11344B-100000@shellx.best.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Breakbeat is simply syncopation in the basic rhythm track - why is this a
big deal? - most pre -"electronica" (for lack of a better term) was and
often still is built on having the kick drum on 1 & 3 and the snare on 2 &
4 - this has a long history in pop music going back at least as far as 50's
R&B - when I say "built on" this literally the way the music is created in
the studio by musicians doing R&B and Funk, first you lay in the drums then
the rest of the rhythm (bass, guitar, keyboard, etc.), then any
instrumental breaks or solos or backing vocals (usually with a scratch
vocal line), then the final vocals and any other overdubs (there are a
bazillion exceptions to this ordering - this is music after all) .....

Since there's alot of other stuff going on the drums of were kept simple,
except at the turnarounds (at the 4th or 8th or 16th, etc. bar) when there
would be a space and the music would need a little push to go on to the
next verse or chorus or whatever - and the drum would play a little
sycopated phrase - a little "break" in the repetition of the basic rhythm
pattern of the song (some drum machines, like the Alesis actually organize
their preset patterns that way - a basic pattern and a break) ..... 

So Hip Hop DJs back in the 80's or so liked these little "breaks" and found
them sometimes more interesting and useful than the rest of the song, and
would construct mixes or entire new tracks based on looping or repeating
these patterns - either with two copies of a record on two turntables or
using a sampler .....

The other "4-on-the-floor" sort of rhythmic structure comes from 70's
disco where every beat has an accent (personally I believe it was that way
so white people could figure out how to dance to it) ..... so electronic
musicians picked up on this process of using the break's beat pattern, to
create a "Dance Track" (as opposed to a more guitar oriented pop song) -
only they started with their own original syncopated pattern - their own
break beat .....

What tends to happen is that because the basic rhythm
track is strongly syncopated the other parts tend to fall on top of, and in
alignment with the basic track - if you listen to Chemical Brothers
especially "Dig Your ...",  you'll notice that the bass line
riff comes in (usually some sort of Rock oriented sample in their case)
then the drum track comes in playing almost the same rhythm pattern with
maybe a couple of notes added or subtracted - or vice versa the rhythm will
be chugging along and a synth line will come in using the same or nearly
the same rhythm but with changes of pitch in the line .....

So Breakbeat can be in any tempo or style of Dance music and seems to me to
be a style or process of creating - personally  I think "4-on-the-floor"
(with 909 kick on every beat) has its place - but it's BORING if that's all
that's going on - pleaze, pleaze, pleaze DJs - no more 128 repetitions of
4-on-the-floor kick drum thank you very much.

Boy this ended up longer than I thought, probably more than you ever wanted
to know about the subject - Well, anyway, that's the end of tonight's
lecture on "Breakbeat Style in Late 90's Electronic Dance Music"

Or WHATEVER,
raen

Hi fellow music makers around the bay,

I find this conversation in general extremely interesting.  I would hope
that more of this type of discussion occurs, in addition to the usual
"when/where/how was" the party talk.  I hope this isn't as off topic
as some of the other posts are... this seems rave related.

Tim

>From: 	Raen
>Subject: 	Re: Breakbeat
>
>Breakbeat is simply syncopation in the basic rhythm track - why is this a
>big deal? - most pre -"electronica" (for lack of a better term) was and
>often still is built on having the kick drum on 1 & 3 and the snare on 2 &
>4 - this has a long history in pop music going back at least as far as 50's
>R&B - when I say "built on" this literally the way the music is created in
>the studio by musicians doing R&B and Funk, first you lay in the drums then
>the rest of the rhythm (bass, guitar, keyboard, etc.), then any
>instrumental breaks or solos or backing vocals (usually with a scratch
>vocal line), then the final vocals and any other overdubs (there are a
>bazillion exceptions to this ordering - this is music after all) .....

[The rest was snipped]...

 I think that a singles party could potentially be fun but it could also turn
out to be really ackward.....what if only males show up...or vise versa? If I
was to go to a singles party....these thoughts would run through my head.....

1) what if no one likes me?
2) what if someone I'm not attracted to hits on me? 
3) what if someone I think I might be attracted to isn't attracted to me?
4) is everyone going to expect to hook up with someone?
5) I would feel really bad seeing people getting together with someone and
then myself not finding anyone
6) Can I talk to anyone without them thinking I'm hitting on them?

 I have more thoughts but I'm sure I sound strange already....I'm not trying
to be negative about the whole thing....because I do think it "could" be fun,
but I think it would turn out to be an ackward situation....I think everyone
who is single should all just get together and play...."spin the bottle" or
"7 minutes in heaven" he he he....I hope this post doesn't make anyone
mad....or think i am a shallow person.....because I AM SINGLE TOO!!!!!!!   =)
 *MushyB! hubba hubba

At 2:48 PM -0800 11/23/98, Ray Vonie wrote:
>Break Dancer wrote:
>
>> this IS a very touchy subject.. in some sense i think they have a right
>> to do that, but in another sense, it just adds to the useless " i'm
>> gonna sue you" mentality.. they got shut down, they should elave it at
>> that...unless they plan on throwing a big free party, or donating the
>> won money, instead of putting it in their already fat pockets if ya know
>> what i mean...
>
>       Actually CWP is standing up for everyone in the entire dance
>community by filing this suite.

No they are not.  If I read correctly this is not "The Rave Community vs
The City of Alameda"  it's Coolworld, a for profit company vs the City of
Alameda.  They do not speak for me, nor anyone else I know.  They do
however speak for themselves.  Something they have always done.  Quite well
in fact.

>Don't get distracted by the $4.5 mill, its
>just a statement.

No it's just money, TAXPAYER money.  Distracted?  How can you do that if
you just follow the money.  For Collworld the whole object is money,
nothing to be distracted by, that is what they are about.  They are a for
profit company, dressed up in ravewear for marketing, and they sell a
product.  No, I'm afraid the money is much more than a statement, it is a
reason.  Their entire reson for existence.

>   If there will be any settlement it will be a small
>percentage of the initial complaint... that's the way our fucked up system
>works.

No, that is the way our legal system works.  It is not so fucked up that I
would *dare* throw it out and try to do something *better* (I think the
founders were great thinkers, far better than the scum who have invaded
that space over the past couple of centuries...slavery notwithstanding,
they did a good job).

To me, there is no better system of jurisprudence.

>  You have to ask for 100 times more than what you want in order to
>get what you expect.

Judging by teh Coolworld foldouts, you have to multiply your original
number by 10 fold.

>     But all that aside....  CWP is making a stand on
>behalf of the entire community....

No they are not, they ar representing themselves.  And I am not so sure I
want them to win.  I never elected them, attended any of thier parties
(that is a lie, I went to one and left some 30 minutes later.  I got in on
guest as did my crew, and we bailed.  The party and vibe left plenty to be
desired.  I never attended another event.  That was 1994.

> They are saying that youth culture should
>not be discriminated against, and they are trying to set a president to make
>sure something like this NEVER happens again to ANY promoter.

Nope, just to them.  I think they should have bene wiser than to even try
to do a partin in a military installation.  How dumb.  Anyway they are
making sure this never happens to them, and in the course of this ditch
effort, they will scare anyone they approach in the future.  I think that
if they win they will have a heck of a time finding other municipalities to
give them permits.  On the other hand, who cares.  If they pocket 4.5, or
2.1, they won;t have to throw another party again, and will probably go
away or break up and do smaller things that will eventually become
large...oh the drama.

>  Not just in
>this area, but anywhere in this country.  Don't forget, it was CWP that
>opened up the city of Oakland for permits after they fought long and hard
>for 2 years with the city council to allow after-hours event to happen in
>Oakland... And Now they are still leading the fight to eliminate
>discrimination and unfair treatment of OUR Youth Culture.

No, that is not true.  There were vents in Oakland before Coolworld that
went on all hours...Flohouse anyone?  Anyway untrue.  Also as for fighting
for *OUR Youth Culture*, I do not consider it such.  I consider it dance
culture, since many of the players, movers, and shakers, are far removed
from being youth.  Just ask some of them (30 something so and so's ;) ).
They are fighting against discrimination against them.  This has happened
to other promoters and Coolworld was silent.  Don;t make them out to be
some great philanthropists.  They could only hope to aspire to such
greatness.


>    So before anyone starts to put them down, just remember that they are
>not just doing this to recoup a $300,000 loss

wrong.

, but to make a point that We
>are not to be Fucked around with, cause We fight back, and are Not
>pushovers.

wrong, to prove *they* are not pushovers.

>This is the main issue in this suite...

Money is the main issue, it was the first thing they brought up after they
were turned down.

>not the Money...
>remember money is just a tool... it has no REAL intrinsic value, and is not
>the end product.

So when is the next FREE Coolworld massive w/ world renown DJ's being thrown?

>  Unless your a drug dealer, lawyer, politician, or a used
>car salesman.

Or a rave promoter, or someone who works, or someone who has to feed your
kids, or someone who has to eat.  In any case I wonder what it must be like
to go to school, the only worry being soem scholarship or grades, with no
job other than school.  Now *that's* good living! Anyway learning is cool,
work is work.  If your parents didn;t work, and didn;t value that money,
you could have very well been one of the multitude of street urchins with
little or no hope.

Money isn;t the root of all evil, people are.

>
>Keep It Real
>
>Vlad

What in the hell does that mean anyway.  Keep *what* real?

Think & Peace,
John

"The first casualty of war is truth." - Rudyard Kipling
