i guess i have to get completely cabbaged beyond hell to find raves here
at all stimulating if 70% of the crowd is sitting there "absorbing" it

i was thinking lately how now the techno scene has is seeing the split
that alternative/rock saw.  mainstreamers scowl at psychos... they scowl
at "weird" sounding stuff that doesnt "rock"  and spends effort working
on a different aspect of music... just a couple things i have notice

so many mainstrea ravers nowadays, way too many people that say "this
party is WACK" when theres some really interesting new music from a
different drummer than the lars ulrich of "progressive house"

i think we should all just plain admit it and LABEL gatherings whetther
they are about pop culture or subversive creative culture because getting
misplaced is not a fun thing for either faction.... (i hate $35 raves with
djs that play 100000 records i have heard 10000 times before) and the
poeple that love those kind of raves often hate the ones where the music
is new and different hmmmmm....

just wondering what some people feel/think because currently i feel REALLY
displacedbeing the minority even at spiraltribe parties here....

please help
-dsp

> there's nothing wrong with that.
> -------------------------------

At 7:16 PM -0700 10/23/97, dVr wrote:
>Having shut the party down at the LAST MINUTE, it's only fair that they
>should cover the damages.  There is no dollar amount that could describe
>the kind of work that goes into such a large event.
>
>DJ Dave Alga
>Cool World Productions

Well that is obviously not true since you have placed a dollar amount on
such work.

The stuff you guys do may seem to you to be priceless, but let's face
facts.  After *all* of this passes (if it does), there will be no
monuments, no great human gains...after all it is just a party, like the
millions before it, it too will fade in time.  A lasting legacy?  Doubtful,
humans love to play and watch.  Whether it be the glory of Rome in
Coliseums, or the glory of butts moving at a party.  It's all the same.
Now when you guys start having gladiator fights, and lions, call me, I'll
pay $500 to attend such an event.

My cynicism at all things CW is well warranted.  I will now watch and see
if you guys attempt to rally the troops behind this cause (remeber, to
collect some 4.5 mil).  I can only wonder if you do succeed in doing so
will you pay the troops for thier valiance?  Or will there be, perhaps, a
FREE Massive by CW (and I mean free, no donations to some sundry cause, no
cans of food, I mean free, including guilt free)?

I'll just sit on the sidelines and coach from here.

Drama....gotta love it.  Lawyers and ravers, the devolution continues.

(On the other side, these guys have *BALLS* of steel doing this.  I admire
them for one reason, at least thier fighting for what they beleive in, and
doing it by any means necessary.  I have always said people need to get in
the game.  From where I stand, I just wish it was someone else who was
doing it.  But who other than CW is so well organized and well funded to
pull this off.  My hats off to them for their courage!)

Late,
John

I hate the duality of human nature. To wit I am often it's most vocal victim.

"The first casualty of war is truth." - Rudyard Kipling

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

It is just my personal opinion of course, but i feel like raves are
ideally safe spaces (places that people can feel like they can be
themselves
and not be harrassed, ridiculed, or harmed at least MOST of the time).
I think that anything one might want to do there as long as it isn't
stepping
on someone else's rights should be okay and also subject to the same
respect.

Ya know, maybe that person isn't the same as you.  Maybe they haven't
figured
out the intense joy dancing can bring yet.  Maybe they are insecure. 
Maybe a rave
is not a safe enough space to them yet.  Maybe they need some time to
check it out.
Maybe they just need a few more positive experiences before they can
"cut loose" and
dance without worrying about whatever.

People who criticize a lot tend to at least sometimes be very insecure.
I am not saying that it increases the vibe for the party for people to
be like that,
but maybe they can't contribute yet.  I bet ya a dollar if they keep
going and
keep feeling warmth from those around them that those walls would come
down.

Just my thoughts.

your friend jen

i just think, from a poor college student standpoint, that $30 for a 
rave is waaaaayyyyy too much......Sure i like big events, but I'm also 
down with small parties too..... i just wish that raves would become 
more accessible to those who cant spend 20-30 bucks every weekend just 
to dance and listen to music.. if thats what its coming too....i might 
as well chill at home and start producing my own jungle sounds.. and 
dance with my self in the mirror :)
my 2 cents.. please dont get angry...
-=*hugs*=- and good vibes for all.. either way, we'll be partying, 
whether in body or in mind or in spirit.. :)
peace
Philip

I was tring to aviod jumping on the singularity thread but I decided 
that I must put in my 2 cents in. 

One thing that I liked about raves (most of them mind you , not all, I 
have been to meat market raves, which usually sucked) is that it was an 
environment where you could talk to people w/o having that same club 
type expectation of automagicly thinking that anybody who talked to you 
was tring to pick up on you, or any body you talk to thinks that you are 
tring to pick up on them!!! I did meet my girlfriend of the past year at 
a rave but the whole relationship was based on a friendly non-pick-up 
additude. I think this whole idea of a singles party is a bad idea 
because I feel that it would make people have a similar additude I have 
seen in the club environment which seems to brew the questions below:

.................plz cut upon the dotted line................
>1) what if no one likes me?
>2) what if someone I'm not attracted to hits on me? 
>3) what if someone I think I might be attracted to isn't attracted to 
me?
>4) is everyone going to expect to hook up with someone?
>5) I would feel really bad seeing people getting together with someone 
and
>then myself not finding anyone
>6) Can I talk to anyone without them thinking I'm hitting on them?
>
..................manufactures coupon / no cash value.............

Ivan Weiss
"Software is like sex; 
it's better when it's free."
- Linus Torvalds 
idw@hotmail.com

NooOOooO sheet :)
staying home and inviting over friends and their ideas and record crates
has been a much cheaper and much more interesting music wise way to spend
weekends thren shelling out $100000s of dollars for prodigy concerts.

you also learn a lot more about people and how they respond to music and
what they like in their music when they spin for only a few friends rather
than a bunch of angry raversa wanting to get their $300000 worth out of
the "party"

has begun to digest itself hence giving me the nutrition i have been
lacking today

Man, that sounds hella cool.  That would just make any party perfect,
regardless if it's a good party or not.  The way you described it would
have to happen to me 'cause I'm kinda shy.  Only if it seems totally,
completely right would I have it in me to go talk to her.  Either that or
if she talked to me.  You see, I can never really start a conversation
but once someone comes and starts talking to me, I'm a totally cool
person to talk to.  It's kinda weird.  Just need a catalyst.

My ideal situation would be something like this.  Let's say I'm at that
party Wonder coming up.  I'm sitting there DJing my first party in the
room with open decks.  While DJing, I make eye contact with a girl and I
can just tell there's something there.  Eventually she walks over to me
but doesn't really say anything to me.  The whole time DJing, we just
kinda non-chalantly glance at each other but underneath it all we are
just totally attracted to each other.  At the end of the set, she comes
over to me and sincereley says that she really enjoyed the music that I
played (which sometimes seems like it wouldn't happen since ambient isn't
the most popular music in the world).  We introduce each other, I go put
my rekkids back, and we spend the rest of the party dancing to Macadio
'till we're tired and finally spend the whee hours just chillin' and
talking in the chill room while holding each other or something.  Then to
top it off, we kiss each other good-bye and exchange numbers (another
plus, she lives fairly close to me).  Epilogue:  We eventually fall madly
in love and are happy forever or something like that.  Yeah, that'd be
pretty KEWL.

Funky Desert Breaks -

It has *some* breakbeat but I wouldn't call it an example of the genre...

I would try a comp like "Hardhop and Trypno" or that one Omar Santana did 
of all those Tricked Out records... those are better examples of the 
genre on a track-by-track kind of basis

If there is anything I miss about raves it's that it seems like there 
used to be so many diffrent types of people from other scenes that made 
up the crowd. It seems today that only certain types of people are 
pre-disposed to even checking out the rave scene. OUR scene was built on 
all thease diffrent types of people and on all our diffrent beliefs 
being united by music. 
Just something I remember and thought y'all should think about-

Raf

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: BSP: www.spareroomstudio.com (electronic music makers site)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Sorry to spam the entire list but there are enough of us music makers on
this list to let you all know about a website my room-mate Paul has put
together.

www.spareroomstudio.com

It's new and smallish but growing quickly and contains lots of
real-audio tracks from music makers from all over. ambient, dub, house,
techno, etc.

It's aimed at people like us making music in low budget home based
studios.

It all started when he got his hands on a copy of Rebirth and created a
few tracks. We then hooked up with Crisp Records here in SF and added
some tracks created by DJ Rasoul and DJ Don Crisp. The Crisp record
tracks should be available soon on vinyl.

Anyway... if anyone else out there is creating music and needs a web
place to put a track or two (or even a link to your own site) check it
out.

Thanks,

Martin

jen wrote:

> It is just my personal opinion of course, but i feel like raves are
> ideally safe spaces <snip>

I met this guy at Sweet last weekend, and he's easily in his late 40s
[sorry if i'm overshooting this, tom]...  He told me about the three
things that attract people to amusement parks:
1. that feeling you get when you are on a roller coaster, about to go
down the big hill
2. that you know you are safe
3. that there's a wonder and awe to the experience....

A good party, good vibe, people....  *this* is the feeling, and it's the
safety, I think, that makes it easier to let go and trust - this isn't
easy for a lot of us.

> <snip>  Maybe they are insecure. Maybe a rave is not a safe enough
> space to them yet.

OK, another personal note:  I was a dancer for fifteen years, and didn't
go to any event where there would be dancing for a long time because I
literally turned my back on my body [just dropped 25lbs i've been
carrying for ten years].  It wasn't until just a few months ago [my
first Goa party], that i said, fuckit!  I don't care what these people
look like, and if they really care what I look like, then it doesn't
matter if i'm dancing or not.

Raves are about music. Not everyone dances to show how much they
appreciate it.  When was the lsat time you saw Sho or BrianB or Rocky M
or MysterE or JohnS at the front of the crowd dancing? [assuming that
they are only there when i am not totally tranced out] I usually see
these guys watching the art of their piers - the *making* of the music.

my .02
katiez

> (On the other side, these guys have *BALLS* of steel doing this.  I admire
> them for one reason, at least thier fighting for what they beleive in, and
> doing it by any means necessary.  I have always said people need to get in
> the game.  From where I stand, I just wish it was someone else who was
> doing it.  But who other than CW is so well organized and well funded to
> pull this off.  My hats off to them for their courage!)

I think this should be the point, and not any dissing of cool world (if
you don't like em, don't go).... the point is that if a party like the
Exotic Erotic ball got nuked at the last minute (after everybody bought
tix, promoters set it up, got permits, performers flew in from out of
town, etc etc etc) there'd be hell to pay on the part of the city-wanks
that pulled the permits at the last moment. I don't think there should
be any difference if the breach of contract (which is what the suit
appears to be fundamentally) is for a rave, for a black and white ball,
or for exotic erotic, or whatever.

The difference is that the exotic erotic and/or black/white ball has
socialites and money and power on it's side, so that would never
happen.  Even if the "morals" of a party like the Exotic Erotic Ball
don't play well by the community standards of the greater bay area
either.... It's time for ravers to claim their power as well,
politically, monetarily, by whatever means necessary. I'm sure Sasson P
ain't poor, so I guess this means he's got the power as well.

Kudos to CW for this lawsuit.

 =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==>>                    Niels Mayer (mayer@netcom.com)                   <<==

"you gotta fight for your right..."  - except...

if the law suit was about making things right by say, making the
governing bodies responsible for the cancellation finance a coolworld
event as retribution, i would agree that cw would be fighting the good
fight. but with these kinds of stakes, i can't see a whole lot of good
coming out of it. my biggest nightmare here is that:

1) coolworld refuses to settle for an amount comparable to what was
"lost" and demands their day on court

&

2) the government is forced to battle the case in and out of the courts,
mostly likely by throwing up a smokescreen and putting cw & ravers on
trial and in the headlines. we don't need anymore slanted 48hr or 20/20
reports misinforming the rest of the world about how we spend our time.

John,
I've always respected you on most every post you have made in my 2 years on this
list.  but this time I have to tell you that you are completely wrong about what
you know and what you think you know about CW.   Try a little open minded
approach to the entire situation, and evaluate ALL the possibilities of this
suite, not just the narrow view of the $$.  Its truly not all about that, There
are a lot of principles involved in this suit, and if it is won... everyone
wins.  Maybe you can try to see this... hopefully you can get past your
animosities and understand the bigger picture.  This is a time when credibility
can be established for this "Youth-Dance Culture"  A president can be established
with this suit, that would make legal and political agencies think twice about
discriminating against this scene.   I could go through your entire reply and
comment about all your misconceptions, but why bother.  We all have our visions,
and our limitations.

Keep It Real (A Vague statement of Integrity asserting Values)

Vlad

John S. Lee wrote:

> At 2:48 PM -0800 11/23/98, Ray Vonie wrote:
> >Break Dancer wrote:
> >
> >> this IS a very touchy subject.. in some sense i think they have a right
> >> to do that, but in another sense, it just adds to the useless " i'm
> >> gonna sue you" mentality.. they got shut down, they should elave it at
> >> that...unless they plan on throwing a big free party, or donating the
> >> won money, instead of putting it in their already fat pockets if ya know
> >> what i mean...
> >
> >       Actually CWP is standing up for everyone in the entire dance
> >community by filing this suite.
>
> No they are not.  If I read correctly this is not "The Rave Community vs
> The City of Alameda"  it's Coolworld, a for profit company vs the City of
> Alameda.  They do not speak for me, nor anyone else I know.  They do
> however speak for themselves.  Something they have always done.  Quite well
> in fact.
>
> >Don't get distracted by the $4.5 mill, its
> >just a statement.
>
> No it's just money, TAXPAYER money.  Distracted?  How can you do that if
> you just follow the money.  For Collworld the whole object is money,
> nothing to be distracted by, that is what they are about.  They are a for
> profit company, dressed up in ravewear for marketing, and they sell a
> product.  No, I'm afraid the money is much more than a statement, it is a
> reason.  Their entire reson for existence.
>
> >   If there will be any settlement it will be a small
> >percentage of the initial complaint... that's the way our fucked up system
> >works.
>
> No, that is the way our legal system works.  It is not so fucked up that I
> would *dare* throw it out and try to do something *better* (I think the
> founders were great thinkers, far better than the scum who have invaded
> that space over the past couple of centuries...slavery notwithstanding,
> they did a good job).
>
> To me, there is no better system of jurisprudence.
>
> >  You have to ask for 100 times more than what you want in order to
> >get what you expect.
>
> Judging by teh Coolworld foldouts, you have to multiply your original
> number by 10 fold.
>
> >     But all that aside....  CWP is making a stand on
> >behalf of the entire community....
>
> No they are not, they ar representing themselves.  And I am not so sure I
> want them to win.  I never elected them, attended any of thier parties
> (that is a lie, I went to one and left some 30 minutes later.  I got in on
> guest as did my crew, and we bailed.  The party and vibe left plenty to be
> desired.  I never attended another event.  That was 1994.
>
> > They are saying that youth culture should
> >not be discriminated against, and they are trying to set a president to make
> >sure something like this NEVER happens again to ANY promoter.
>
> Nope, just to them.  I think they should have bene wiser than to even try
> to do a partin in a military installation.  How dumb.  Anyway they are
> making sure this never happens to them, and in the course of this ditch
> effort, they will scare anyone they approach in the future.  I think that
> if they win they will have a heck of a time finding other municipalities to
> give them permits.  On the other hand, who cares.  If they pocket 4.5, or
> 2.1, they won;t have to throw another party again, and will probably go
> away or break up and do smaller things that will eventually become
> large...oh the drama.
>
> >  Not just in
> >this area, but anywhere in this country.  Don't forget, it was CWP that
> >opened up the city of Oakland for permits after they fought long and hard
> >for 2 years with the city council to allow after-hours event to happen in
> >Oakland... And Now they are still leading the fight to eliminate
> >discrimination and unfair treatment of OUR Youth Culture.
>
> No, that is not true.  There were vents in Oakland before Coolworld that
> went on all hours...Flohouse anyone?  Anyway untrue.  Also as for fighting
> for *OUR Youth Culture*, I do not consider it such.  I consider it dance
> culture, since many of the players, movers, and shakers, are far removed
> from being youth.  Just ask some of them (30 something so and so's ;) ).
> They are fighting against discrimination against them.  This has happened
> to other promoters and Coolworld was silent.  Don;t make them out to be
> some great philanthropists.  They could only hope to aspire to such
> greatness.
>
> >    So before anyone starts to put them down, just remember that they are
> >not just doing this to recoup a $300,000 loss
>
> wrong.
>
> , but to make a point that We
> >are not to be Fucked around with, cause We fight back, and are Not
> >pushovers.
>
> wrong, to prove *they* are not pushovers.
>
> >This is the main issue in this suite...
>
> Money is the main issue, it was the first thing they brought up after they
> were turned down.
>
> >not the Money...
> >remember money is just a tool... it has no REAL intrinsic value, and is not
> >the end product.

> >car salesman.

> kids, or someone who has to eat.  In any case I wonder what it must be like
> to go to school, the only worry being soem scholarship or grades, with no
> job other than school.  Now *that's* good living! Anyway learning is cool,
> work is work.  If your parents didn;t work, and didn;t value that money,

> little or no hope.

just jer wrote:

> well... if it's not about the money and only for the scene.
>
> CoolWorld Productions, will you throw a *FREE* mega-massive with all
> your name brand DJ's and super-galactic lazers and exotic space-hoochie
> dancers and cyber-moon-castles... if you win the suit?

I do not have the authority to speak for CWP, but I would be very surprised
if this did not happen.  Lets assume hypothetically that in 2-3 years, after
this suite is settled, there will be some sort of event to celebrate the
landmark decision that sets a president to all who would consider
discriminating against independent organizers, and the freedom of youth to
assemble and dance.   That's what this thing is all about.  Fairness, and
equal representation under the letter of the law.  Not about the $$$.  A
suite like this is not worth fighting if its just about the money, there are
a lot better ways to spend a few years of your life.  But if it does happen,
I wouldn't be surprised if CWP through a free party.  But then again this is
all speculation, and who knows what is going to happen in real life.  But if
it was me... I would do it... BIG TIME... And make the Alameda Naval Air
Station  host the event, just to throw it in their faces!!!!

Keep it Real

Vlad

<< ---Digital Devil <raf_one@hotmail.com> wrote:
 >
 > If there is anything I miss about raves it's that it seems like there 
 > used to be so many diffrent types of people from other scenes that
 made 
 > up the crowd. It seems today that only certain types of people are 
 > pre-disposed to even checking out the rave scene. OUR scene was
 built on 
 > all thease diffrent types of people and on all our diffrent beliefs 
 > being united by music. 
 > Just something I remember and thought y'all should think about-
 > 
 > Raf
 > 
 > 
 > 
 >  >>
    
     It's not that the people are no longer there it's that the scene has
been devide in to groups. You have your Goa Trance parties, House parties,
Jungle parties, Breakbeat parties, etc. Before you also had clubs that only
played top 40 or hip hop not alot of clubs had (so called) rave music. Now
just about every club out there plays house or techno so most of the crowd
that is 21 and over goes to the clubs. Parties before used to have House,
Techno, Trance, Breakbeat, Ambient, Jungle and so on. The music used to be
diverse now you have your little so called clicks that just stick to there
own style of music and don't make it interesting for everybody. Don't get me
wrong there are a few people (Few!!!!!) that throw parties and have a little
variety of different styles of music.

Thats just my opinion

Jazz-e 
We are the trend setters

i believe that cw has to do what's right for them as people - sorry (and
i hope you - whoever that is - agree), but screw the business end, $
comes and goes... your humanity is the only constant.  what's right for
them maybe to sue. with the limited info i have heard, i believe they
*were* wronged and shouldn't just blow it off.

however...

it isn't easy to predict the out come of cases like these, and on how
many different levels a community will react. cw may win their suit or
not, but a whole lot can happen in between. there's a vietnamese
(possibly chinese first, but vietnam lived it) proverb that basically
says "when two great bulls do battle it's the ground that suffers." 

either way, ironically enough, it looks like we'll all have to sit back
and watch ...

> John,

I imagine that John, like myself has seen and talked to to enough folks to
have at least a reasonable idea of what CW is about. And hey, John is one
up on me, he actually went to one, if for but 30 min... So, because these
folks are your friends/associates/business partners/whatever, John is
wrong in his opinion and experiences? Sorry, I don't follow the logic.

> Try a little open minded approach to the entire situation, and evaluate
> ALL the possibilities of this suite, not just the narrow view of the $$.
> Its truly not all about that, 

The lawsuit says otherwise. 


> There are a lot of principles involved in this suit, and if it is won...
> everyone wins.  

Really? What is my take of the 4.5mil? Does everyone win? Hell no. As
someone pointed out, if CW wins the taxpayers lose. I'm a taxpayer. I
LOSE.

That said, I still think CW is justified in their suit, and I hope they do
get a *FAIR* (read not 4.5mil) settlement. 

> This is a time when credibility can be established for this "Youth-Dance
> Culture"  A president can be established with this suit, that would make
> legal and political agencies think twice about discriminating against
> this scene.   

Your assertation that this action was taken in an attempt to discriminate
against "the scene" is dubious. This action was, according to base
officials taken because of the possibility and their *PRIOR EXPERIENCE*
with noise complaints with late night activities on the base. I didn't see
any mention of particulars other than NOISE.

> I could go through your entire reply and comment about all your
> misconceptions, but why bother.  We all have our visions, and our
> limitations.

You could, and John would eat you for lunch(hi John.) 

Vlad, I have said this before and I will continue to say this:

I have no problem with CW, you, or anyone else making a small amount, or
amassing a fortune from events. What I *do* have a problem with is when
people are not direct and honest about their motives in conducting
themselves and their "business." 

CW are not martyrs. They do not represent me. They do not represent
the "dance culture" in the Bay Area, which has been around much longer 
than, is much bigger than, and will be around after CW is long forgotten.
CW represents *itself* and it's attendees. 
They are not doing me any favors by their lawsuit. The are, and have been
about *money* Because you will not admit, and further, flatly deny this, I
find anything you say suspect. Do yourself a favor and save the 
self-righteous Christ-on-the-Cross martyrdom speech for people that will
buy it. 

					Black Adder

At 11:28 PM 10/23/97 -0700, you wrote:
>internet. Why go if you just do what you would do at your house? Or at
>least go sit down somewhere? I hope I haven't made any enemies already....
*****
Why go?  It's *not* your house. The music is a million times louder, and
there isn't a bunch of people dancing to it, or walking around with
glowsticks [don't know about you, but I've never found a rave at my house
in the evening when i get home from work].  Somehow going to a rave is a
bit different, and kinda more fun than listening to my same old music at
home, playing it pretty quiet so my crack dealing neighbors don't know i
have a system worth stealing [bad neighborhood].  Sitting down is sometimes
necessary, and may be what I choose to do.  I could just as easily tell you
*that* was the right thing to do.  [on a harsher note:] who are you to tell
me I'm not doing the right thing?

>>if you arent going to do anything to contribute, dont take up space?!?!?!
****
not contributing if you... what...? aren't dancing?  well, cant those
wallflowers with a smile on their face, wiggling thier hands, or
marianettes, or hugging on a friend while they peak to the music... isn't
that contributing good vibe?  they are enjoying themselves...  aren't you?
or have been you been spending your night giving off negative vibe
concerning yourself over the wallflowers, thinking how they aren't a
positive addition. maybe you are the one who is spreading "you shouldn't be
here" negativity.  those people don't have a problem with  you... why don't
you lay off them and enjoy yourself dancing, or whatever is your thing.  if
putting people down for enjoying themselves is your thing, maybe you should
go sit at home untill you have learned to play well with others.

>>DO your own thing, yes :) but if "not doing anything" is "your own thing"
>>go sit on the haight all night and do your own thing. 
****
they probably *are* doing their own thing.  Sitting and enjoying
themselves.  you got a problem with that?  thanks for spreading the
negativity.  Are you sure you understand PLUR?  you don't respect them for
doing their own thing, enjoying themselves.. you don't seem to want to let
them have their peace.  an ultimatum where they either do what *you* think
is right, or leave to go sit in the cold, is a rather selfish look at
unity.  try and tell me you love them while you're telling them to go sit
on the haight.

They have every bit as much right to be there as you.  they paid their
money, for whatever reason, and it's not for you to say if they are having
a good time, or that they are doing the wrong thing by enjoying themselves
on the wall.  raves may be about dancing  to you, but everyone doesn't
share your opinion.  

i love to dance at parties, i rarely leave the floor, i am not opposed to
dancing by my self in the middle of a barren dancefloor.  if the music is
dancable to me, and i'm up for it mEntally and physically, i'm there
dancing.  

just try and keep in mind, those wallflowers arent' trying to bring down
*your* vibe, but you're trying to bring down theirs, giving them the "you
don't belong" or "your doing the wrong thing" or "you should leave"
negativity.

-SolR


From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Oct 24 21:03:41 1997

At 12:35 PM -0800 11/24/96, Ray Vonie wrote:
>John,
>I've always respected you on most every post you have made in my 2 years
>on this
>list.  but this time I have to tell you that you are completely wrong
>about what
>you know and what you think you know about CW.

Ray,

All I can say is I am seeing the reality, at least mine, of the situation.
Logic bears my thoughts out completely.  I am as open-minded as the next
person.  I just don't see how you can foist all of these goals and ideals
on a comapny who you are not authorized to represent.  I challenged those
assertions, then gave them props for their courage.

I can only read numbers, & listen to the street.  This little lawsuit is in
the noise of people's lives (except the CW people).  Just another lawsuit.
There is *NO* rallying cry from rave promoters to support CW (after all it
is in a promoters best interest for other parties NOT to succeed), nor from
the rave community in general.  Nor from anyone else I know other than you
and thier DJ's, who paint the most glowing picture of their philosophies.

>Try a little open minded
>approach to the entire situation, and evaluate ALL the possibilities of this
>suite, not just the narrow view of the $$.

Ray, I did evaluate and gave them props, that's all they'll get from me.
This isn't Rodney King, or Judy Barry, or Critical Mass, it's a party,
entertainment.  The $$$'s are what COolworld is about (please state how I
am incorrect).  There is nothing wrong with that, I am also about $$$'s.
Love it.  Lots of it, and I want more of it.  I work, doing my thang to
make $$$'s and it works.  I love money and nothing is wrong with that.  CWP
loves money too, lots of it.  They work hard for it, they do everything
they can to get it.  If that means putting out a massive 4 color flyer that
ends up in the wastebasket, as much as advertisements do, then go for it.
I don't frequent thier parties because I am not down with *anything* they
do.  That's how I voice my protest.  As a amtter of fact I've stayed out of
most CW discussions, but I couldn't help but butt-in when I saw you putting
a spin on this whole thing as some type of *movement for dance culture*,
yikes.

Here are the possibilities:
-CW Wins:
 + They will get some $$'s (taxpayer $$'s mind you) who knows how much.
 + They will secure permits and throw another party charging people to get
in (obvious).
 + They will secure permits and throw a FREE party(not so obvious).
 + The rave community is shown that if they stick up for thier rights
vigorously they too can get things done.
-CW Loses:
 + They may try another angle and sue again.
 + They will secure permits and throw another party charging people to get in.
 + The rave community is shown that if they stick up for thier rights
vigorously they too can get things done.

That's pretty much it.  Authorities will not be frightened by them or any
other late night party.  So although it may embolden some promoters, I can
easily see municipalities withdrawing all support for all night events due
to the litiginous nature of ravers.  Bitten once you know.

The narrow view of dollars is a self-fulfilling edifice of CWP.  If they
were *really* about dance culture they would have helped others with
getting legal assistance, they would do free parties in the park, etc.
There are tons of things people with money and capital can do, that CWP has
YET to do. (Now of course this is up to some promoters as well, I doubt
*anyone* has asked CWP to help them out due the the innate animosity of
for-profit/lifestyle promoters toward one another).

Let's get JSLick:
I am a promoter of a large successful party.  As a amtter of fact, I'm
incorporated, me and my partners.  We've made stax of cash and now it's
time for our benefit party.  We ask, for the children, that you bring in a
can of food for admission, we'll drop $5 off the price to $20.  The food
will go to the  Food For Homeless Children Fund.  After the pary, I'm
counting my cash, and my cans.  I add up the value of the cans, write it
down, and take that as a charitable *tax deductible* donation from my
company.  Allowing me to effectively pocket more money.  Now that's USFingA
Philanthropy, but someone's gotta do it.

Better yet I'll do a free party and ask for cans.  Of course writing off
everything as an expense w/ a tax write-off to boot.

JSLwakeup.....

Now I am in no way insisting that CW or any other promoter has engaged in
such, er, acts.  I am however looking past the $$'s as instructed.  And you
know what I see?, more $$$.

This whole idea about philanthropic parties has been irritating me for
years.  The one plausible and easy way to give back the the dance community
is to have a free event.  After all the dance community is affording you a
certain lifestyle, you should give back.  Short of that I could care less.

>Its truly not all about that, There
>are a lot of principles involved in this suit, and if it is won... everyone
>wins.

I am curious as to how that is so?  What?, do you think parties will
finally be out of the grasps of officials?  You think that if the lawsuit
is won that the cops will get the message?  The local authorities will get
the message?

real world check:
There was a FEDERAL injunction against the cops shutting down parties in SF
around 95.  Do you know what happened?  The cops still shut down parties,
even permitted ones like 1015 Folsom.

Did you know that after Civil Rights legilastion was passed int he 60's,
people were still killed and lynched.  Even governeors wouldn't obey the
laws.  What in g-ds green earth gives you the notion that a party is going
to change anything other than a record?  Looking at history, I suggest that
things will be staus quo, that CWP will  not do a freebie, and that they'll
be back at the grind of making more $$$ oops I mean parties in a short
while.  Please tell me how wrong I am, I do want to be wrong and will admit
to such if so.

Lesson:  short of a national guard you may be up shits creek with laws as oars.

So far though we're BOTH speculating.  I do not know the outcome nor do I
know *anything* about CWP motives, ambitions.  I am making well educated
guesses by what they've done in the past.  But I could be very wrong and
end up with egg on my mug when CWP announces a huge free party, rides and
all, dancers and all, GRATIS, with a bug FU to the non-believers.  I hope
you will accept same egg on face when it happens in the converse and they
give a rats ass about a freebie.

>Maybe you can try to see this... hopefully you can get past your
>animosities and understand the bigger picture.

G-d I hate this type of holier than thou attitude.  I do not hate CWP, I
don;t go to their parties, nor do I admire them.  You made assertions I
challenged them. That does not make me hateful of CWP or you, I challenged
your ideas and adressed them.  And I did not call you clueless, naive, or
any other characterization.  Too bad the same courtesy was not extended to
me.  Another courtesy you forget is the decency of an explanation.  I have
explained thoroughyl my thoughts and how I think about it.  You wouldn't
even do that as a corrtesy saying:"I could go through your entire reply and
comment about all your misconceptions, but why bother.  We all have our
visions,
and our limitations."  Also the characterizations of:
close mindedness, and animosity.  Without any proff or backup.

Well if you're not going to backup what you say then that is your issue.
Don't be suprised at people checking your assertions.  Nothing goes
unchallenged here on SFR.

>This is a time when credibility
>can be established for this "Youth-Dance Culture"  A president can be
>established
>with this suit, that would make legal and political agencies think twice about
>discriminating against this scene.

With human history as my teacher, I say that this is not true at all.

>   I could go through your entire reply and
>comment about all your misconceptions, but why bother.  We all have our
>visions,
>and our limitations.

As for misconceptions I did read a tone of them in your previous posts
standing up for your CWP crew.  I mean if they were half of the things you
said I would say nothing in reply.  They are not, so I did.  I do want to
be wrong and await proof of their philanthropy.

The only limitation I've found within myself how long I can dance these
days.  I can go about 1 hour, then I need to kiss my lady for a little bit.
Oh yeah, I don't like the tank/top bra look, that's another one of my
limitations.  I am limited to seeing that as a totally non-sexy outfit,
even when done correctly.  Ladies (and gents who may dress this way too),
tuck in the bra strap, it's tacky.

>
>Keep It Real (A Vague statement of Integrity asserting Values)
>
>Vlad

Peace,
John


"The first casualty of war is truth." - Rudyard Kipling

n i c o wrote:

> >       Actually CWP is standing up for everyone in the entire dance
> >community by filing this suite.
>
>     What if everyone in the dance community doesn't want CWP
> to represent them?

That is a interesting question???  I do not have an answer to that, no
one can answer that except you.   Maybe you weren't around in early 94
when CWP stood up for the rave community and was able to get the Mayors
office to grant them the VERY FIRST OFFICIAL after-hours extension given
by the city since the Vietnam War.  Since that president was set, every
promoter can now go and also apply for that same kind of permit.  and
the city can not turn them away if they meet all the necessary
qualifications on the basis of discrimination.  Well i'm sure since then
you may have enjoyed the efforts of CWP anytime you have gone to many of
the parties that take place in oakland... Even though you may have not
given it any thought.   We the situation id the same here.  and unless
it is fought, then maybe the city of oakland will decide that they can
get away with jerking permits after they have given them out, just like
Alameda and the Navy did, and all of a sudden ... oops no more raves in
Oakland... and everyone's is asking "why are the police discriminating
like this??"  ...  get my drift...  think about it, and then ask your
question again.

Keep it Real

Vlad

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 8pm-10pm - "Soundz of Resistance" w/DJ Poohbear.
       Underground electronic music, mainly jungle/drum and bass, dub and
       hard techno along with guest DJs, interviews and not-so-random
       amples of life. KZSC 88.1 (Santa Cruz)
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. The
       best in beats to satiate your inner child. Electronic dance,
       noise, spoken word, world music and more. Also available in
       RealAudio. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 5pm-9pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of jungle, dub,
       breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon and guests -
       Beats, Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford). Also broadcast via
       RealAudio.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Saturday night - "House Nation" w/"Anthems Mix", Top 10s from
       guest DJs and "London Connection w/DJ Doubt". 2am-4am, WILD 94.9
       SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
   For a _search_ interface to the calendar, see the Late Train club
   section (http://www.latetrain.com/clubs/).
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.org with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.org with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.org

>n i c o wrote:
>
>> >       Actually CWP is standing up for everyone in the entire dance
>> >community by filing this suite.
>>
>>     What if everyone in the dance community doesn't want CWP
>> to represent them?
>
>That is a interesting question???  I do not have an answer to that, no
>one can answer that except you.   Maybe you weren't around in early 94
>when CWP stood up for the rave community and was able to get the Mayors
>office to grant them the VERY FIRST OFFICIAL after-hours extension given
>by the city since the Vietnam War.
[snip]
>oops no more raves in
>Oakland... and everyone's is asking "why are the police discriminating
>like this??"  ...  get my drift...  think about it, and then ask your
>question again.
>


    I didn't mean to imply that I didn't want CWP standing up for my rights
as a raver, all I wanted to do was to bring to your attention to the fact
that no one really knows CWP's motives are EXCEPT CWP.  So how are we
supposed to join a group of promoters' cause if we don't fully understand
what's going on?  Lots of people have negative views on what CWP is
thinking, and to tell you the truth, so do I.  4.5 million dollars ... I
dunno ... maybe it's a statement.  People's eyebrows raise when they see
that kind of figure so it could be CWP's way of getting the public's
attention.  But of course, I'm not here to decipher what CWP wants, nor do I
really care to.
    You're right on one thing and that's the judicial precedent.  No body of
legislature would touch a matter like this if a court had previously struck
it down.  And even if something did pass through, it would be tied up in the
courts, much like prop 187 and the recently deceased CDA.  However, I have
given a lot of thought about this.  If you want to make a statement, YOU DO
NOT USE MONEY AS A TOOL.  Civil disobedience never involved suing the bus
company because they made you sit in the back of the bus.  Men and women
with nobility sat down and faced arrest for a cause they believed in.  If
this is something that Coolworld Productions believes in, then it would
organize more than just a group of lawyers.
    You know what though? I might have even been swayed to follow your
persuasive arguement but there's something that has bothered me to no end.
THERE IS NO UNITY ON THIS MATTER.  Many of the more vocal list members have
demonstrated their displeasure with CWP.  So it leads me to believe an
analogy my father taught me.  A country should not fight a war unless the
people are behind its cause.  Thus a father should not do something his
family does not support.
    Now I ask you again, what if the community doesn't want CWP representing
them?
    I think you're a really intelligent individual, Vlad, and I respect ALL
of your opinions, I just happen to disagree with you on this matter.

    : ) : ) : )  LOVE ALWAYS  : ) : ) : )

    Nico


P.S.  And personally I don't see how a 32 year old promoter (like the one
mentioned in the CWP article in Mercury News) could accurately represent a
broke ass college student/raver like myself.

ya know, i've never been to a super huge massive, and i was looking
forward to the alemada party.  so, what i'm curious about, being
fairly new to the bay area, is why everyone disses coolworld so hard. 
don't get me wrong, there may be perfectly legit reasons for doing so,
i just don't know 'em.  i mean, what's the big difference between the
coolworld party, which got harshed on constantly before it happened on
this list, and the massive that ftt is throwing on halloween?  i
haven't heard anyone blasting them for throwing a massive, but it
seems like the almeda gig had a lot of the same talent plus a few
other choice dj's to boot, in an interesting location, with rides, for
the same price.  granted, funky techno tribe throws exellent free
parties in golden gate park...

it seems to me that making some quick cash throwing huge parties has
always been intergal part of the rave scene (a part, mind you, not the
whole of it), starting in britain with the huge illegal countryside
parties (you can bet some people made a LOT of dough on those parties).

finally, i'd like to point out that almost every party i've been to
(or tried to go to) recently has gotten busted.  i support anyone
doing anything to help rectify the situation.  and if they make a few
million in the process, well, so be it.  the point of huge settlements
like that is to make it hurt for the people who lose - i mean, the us
navy or town of alemeda probably wouldn't blink at losing $300,000 in
a court case.  besides, legal battles are long, expensive, and
unpleasant.  if coolworld loses, they'll just be that much more in the
hole...

-messiah

Subject: COOLWORLD lawsuit.. My Final Reply :)
References: <19971023202327.5663.qmail@hotmail.com>
	 <v03102807b0755ae8c1cf@[205.162.25.58]> <v03102800b076533ebd91@[205.162.25.58]>

    WOW...OK...HMMMMM.....alright... John and everyone else on the list... It is my
believe that we all have our own beliefs on this issue. :)  And I am not going to
try to impose my perspective on anyone , and if I have I apologize for it.  However
that will not stop me from expressing my perspective to anyone that cares to read
it.
    I feel that if CWP wins this case, then everyone in the dance community wins,
because....  There will be less discrimination and more options for future dance
promoters to pursue.  Many promoters, including myself have benefited from previous
CWP activities.  Much more than CWP has benefited from other promoters activities.
Sure CWP is in it for the money, they are a business, but they are in the business
of providing entertainment to people, and that is also what they are about... and
4.5 million... that's just a joke...  after settlement hearings and evaluations,
and attorney, court, deposition, and investigative costs... shit they would be
lucky to receive a settlement for just the physical cost of the event...  How's
that for absurd...  if they really wanted to make money of this, then they should
have sued for 20 million.
    Any ways, my whole point in standing up for cool world is that I feel that they
got very wronged, and if they, or someone, does not do something about it, then it
will keep happening.  This goes deeper than anything that has been written in the
papers, there is a lot of conspiring going on within the political bodies of the
city of Alameda, Oakland and the Navy that caused the cancellation of this event,
and if CWP did not sue them, then Oakland would follow and they would be the next
city to follow Alamedas example.   There is a lot more going on here than the
obvious, so lets all hope and pray that this lawsuit will plug the leak in the dam,
or else the future looks bleak for permits in Oakland.  Because this suit was
filed, everything is going to be ok for permits and parties will still happen.  But
if it was not filed, then we would start seeing situations develop in early 98 that
would make it extremely difficult and expensive for promoters to obtain permits for
all nighters.  There are a lot of players that would rather not see this raving
develop, or that would rather develop it themselves, then there are (legal, voting)
supporters of raving.  It is a total uphill battle, all the time, with very few
shortcuts.
    Many of you on this list have very little understanding of what it takes to
obtain permits and all the politics involved.... and that's ok...  it shouldn't be
your concern, nor is it anyone's (but the promoters) responsibility.  But I do
know, and What I know is that CWP isn't starting a fight, they are fighting back.
And they are fighting for all of us at the same time, so that the situation does
not escalate, and we are all getting a free ride.   The magnitude of what's
happening right now, will not be realized for some time to come, and at that point
people will have a higher opinion for organizations like CWP, that fought the
necessary fights to keep politicians, organized entertainment, and conservative
lobbies from stepping all over anyone whose perspectives they don't agree with.
    That is why I am standing up for CWP, because I realize what's really going
on.  And as time goes on, and details surface, many of you will probably be jumping
onto the bandwagon.  Or everyone will forget about it until the next CWP event,
when it will all go around in circles all over again.  :)
    This is unfortunately my last public response to this issue.  If anyone is
seriously compelled to ask more, then please do it privately.  As much as I love
this list and addressing issues on it, I am much to busy and am limited in the
amount of time I can dedicate to it.  So I will reply to private posts you as I
find the time.  Thank you for your understanding. And as always:

Keep it Real

Yours in PLUR, Vlad aka Ray Vonie




John S. Lee wrote:

> At 12:35 PM -0800 11/24/96, Ray Vonie wrote:
> >John,
> >I've always respected you on most every post you have made in my 2 years
> >on this
> >list.  but this time I have to tell you that you are completely wrong
> >about what
> >you know and what you think you know about CW.
>
> Ray,
>
> All I can say is I am seeing the reality, at least mine, of the situation.
> Logic bears my thoughts out completely.  I am as open-minded as the next
> person.  I just don't see how you can foist all of these goals and ideals
> on a comapny who you are not authorized to represent.  I challenged those
> assertions, then gave them props for their courage.
>
> I can only read numbers, & listen to the street.  This little lawsuit is in
> the noise of people's lives (except the CW people).  Just another lawsuit.
> There is *NO* rallying cry from rave promoters to support CW (after all it
> is in a promoters best interest for other parties NOT to succeed), nor from
> the rave community in general.  Nor from anyone else I know other than you
> and thier DJ's, who paint the most glowing picture of their philosophies.
>
> >Try a little open minded
> >approach to the entire situation, and evaluate ALL the possibilities of this
> >suite, not just the narrow view of the $$.
>
> Ray, I did evaluate and gave them props, that's all they'll get from me.
> This isn't Rodney King, or Judy Barry, or Critical Mass, it's a party,
> entertainment.  The $$$'s are what COolworld is about (please state how I
> am incorrect).  There is nothing wrong with that, I am also about $$$'s.
> Love it.  Lots of it, and I want more of it.  I work, doing my thang to
> make $$$'s and it works.  I love money and nothing is wrong with that.  CWP
> loves money too, lots of it.  They work hard for it, they do everything
> they can to get it.  If that means putting out a massive 4 color flyer that
> ends up in the wastebasket, as much as advertisements do, then go for it.
> I don't frequent thier parties because I am not down with *anything* they
> do.  That's how I voice my protest.  As a amtter of fact I've stayed out of
> most CW discussions, but I couldn't help but butt-in when I saw you putting
> a spin on this whole thing as some type of *movement for dance culture*,
> yikes.
>
> Here are the possibilities:
> -CW Wins:
>  + They will get some $$'s (taxpayer $$'s mind you) who knows how much.
>  + They will secure permits and throw another party charging people to get
> in (obvious).
>  + They will secure permits and throw a FREE party(not so obvious).
>  + The rave community is shown that if they stick up for thier rights
> vigorously they too can get things done.
> -CW Loses:
>  + They may try another angle and sue again.
>  + They will secure permits and throw another party charging people to get in.
>  + The rave community is shown that if they stick up for thier rights
> vigorously they too can get things done.
>
> That's pretty much it.  Authorities will not be frightened by them or any
> other late night party.  So although it may embolden some promoters, I can
> easily see municipalities withdrawing all support for all night events due
> to the litiginous nature of ravers.  Bitten once you know.
>
> The narrow view of dollars is a self-fulfilling edifice of CWP.  If they
> were *really* about dance culture they would have helped others with
> getting legal assistance, they would do free parties in the park, etc.
> There are tons of things people with money and capital can do, that CWP has
> YET to do. (Now of course this is up to some promoters as well, I doubt
> *anyone* has asked CWP to help them out due the the innate animosity of
> for-profit/lifestyle promoters toward one another).
>
> Let's get JSLick:
> I am a promoter of a large successful party.  As a amtter of fact, I'm
> incorporated, me and my partners.  We've made stax of cash and now it's
> time for our benefit party.  We ask, for the children, that you bring in a
> can of food for admission, we'll drop $5 off the price to $20.  The food
> will go to the  Food For Homeless Children Fund.  After the pary, I'm
> counting my cash, and my cans.  I add up the value of the cans, write it
> down, and take that as a charitable *tax deductible* donation from my
> company.  Allowing me to effectively pocket more money.  Now that's USFingA
> Philanthropy, but someone's gotta do it.
>
> Better yet I'll do a free party and ask for cans.  Of course writing off
> everything as an expense w/ a tax write-off to boot.
>
> JSLwakeup.....
>
> Now I am in no way insisting that CW or any other promoter has engaged in
> such, er, acts.  I am however looking past the $$'s as instructed.  And you
> know what I see?, more $$$.
>
> This whole idea about philanthropic parties has been irritating me for
> years.  The one plausible and easy way to give back the the dance community
> is to have a free event.  After all the dance community is affording you a
> certain lifestyle, you should give back.  Short of that I could care less.
>
> >Its truly not all about that, There
> >are a lot of principles involved in this suit, and if it is won... everyone
> >wins.
>
> I am curious as to how that is so?  What?, do you think parties will
> finally be out of the grasps of officials?  You think that if the lawsuit
> is won that the cops will get the message?  The local authorities will get
> the message?
>
> real world check:
> There was a FEDERAL injunction against the cops shutting down parties in SF
> around 95.  Do you know what happened?  The cops still shut down parties,
> even permitted ones like 1015 Folsom.
>
> Did you know that after Civil Rights legilastion was passed int he 60's,
> people were still killed and lynched.  Even governeors wouldn't obey the
> laws.  What in g-ds green earth gives you the notion that a party is going
> to change anything other than a record?  Looking at history, I suggest that
> things will be staus quo, that CWP will  not do a freebie, and that they'll
> be back at the grind of making more $$$ oops I mean parties in a short
> while.  Please tell me how wrong I am, I do want to be wrong and will admit
> to such if so.
>
> Lesson:  short of a national guard you may be up shits creek with laws as oars.
>
> So far though we're BOTH speculating.  I do not know the outcome nor do I
> know *anything* about CWP motives, ambitions.  I am making well educated
> guesses by what they've done in the past.  But I could be very wrong and
> end up with egg on my mug when CWP announces a huge free party, rides and
> all, dancers and all, GRATIS, with a bug FU to the non-believers.  I hope
> you will accept same egg on face when it happens in the converse and they
> give a rats ass about a freebie.
>
> >Maybe you can try to see this... hopefully you can get past your
> >animosities and understand the bigger picture.
>
> G-d I hate this type of holier than thou attitude.  I do not hate CWP, I
> don;t go to their parties, nor do I admire them.  You made assertions I
> challenged them. That does not make me hateful of CWP or you, I challenged

A couple of thoughts:

in regards to whether cw represent "us" or not..."we" are rather
diverse and anarchic so I dont see how Anyone can really represent
"Us"

burning man, Food not bombs, critical mass,and many
others...none of these represent me..yet i support
their fights for freedom.

they have all suffered the same harassment that CW and raves
in general have suffered. Even though none of these groups
represent me i still feel that the harasment they got/get
has to stop. In politics there are coalitions that even
tho they have different agendas they often come together
to support each other on common issues...even tho they
disagree with each other.

A second thought.... $4.5 mil is pocket change in the world
of high finance and government.

ps...i am not defending cw as a group... i dont know them and
they may be the slimy sleaze some of you say they are.
I am not qualified to make that judgement... i just know
the got treated illegally and unfairly and i dont like that.

 I say its time for a tEa party...now what kind of tea should
we have =)

Jazz-E's recent post on the musical diversity of the dance scene got me
wonderin'.  Are there any DJ's that spin house, jungle, techno, trance all
in one set or combination thereof?  As each tunes into a different
frequency in my movement, I'd love to tune into all my frequencies, if ya
get my drift.  WHy do DJ's stick to one style?  I'm sure there's ways
around the different bpms.  Actually, I can hear a couple already.

Anyways, the day a dj can take me on a musical journey of epic proportions
spanning the gamut of dance music I will stop...  My book of matches will
explode and ignite spontaneously in a moment of shear exstacy and my
existence will be snuffed out.  That's a like water for chocolate
reference, if any of you caught that.

Peace, have a great and safe weekend, I'm off to Tahoe to interview for
snow bum jobs, so take care in the bay.

George

aaahh..  i hate boredom as well teresa.  sometimes i couldn't stand it
 so mentally i jump myself off bridges.  enough madness from me. 

one way i discover as a boredom killer on the internet is to download
this program called ICQ from site http://www.mirabilis.com/ and have
close friends around doing the same thing.  it will inform you of when
participants are online to send back and forth quick messages, and my
favorite, open a live chat session sans long distance charge. 
everyone too, try it out when you get a chance.  

there are a lot of cool parties next halloween friday guys and gals
but we can only be at one place  :[.  here are clues and reasons to
which one i'll be at:  it's no MysterE that i like Mars.  i'm such a
Happy Kidz.  DJ Lyra is a cool senorita ...  see some of U's there
beautiful people.

While the folks over at Hormel (The makers of SPAM) have my 
sympathy, I say SPAM Stays!

	There are just too many similarities between the canned variety and 
it's email cousin to name it anything else. 
For example...
Both can be highly offensive to the senses.
Both can give you a terrible stomach ache just by looking at them.
Both  are dispised by normal human beings (yes, vegitarians dispise 
it too).
Both seem to continue to exist dispite their lack of popularity.
Both should be thrown in the trash before you open them....

Yep... No matter how much we try and fight it... destroy it... 
discourage it...  or ignore it...  Spam stays.

-Faro

(Of course, most of us knew all along that all that stuff we find in 
Spam was just a big Scam. :-}

later, still attending these things, seeing what it's all about,

Date: Mon, 21 Apr 1997 19:02:26 -0700

At 02:27 AM 4/21/97 -0700, you wrote:
>Why?


Because comets fall on jupiter.
Because icechunks fall from glacial bodies.
Because my cigarettes fall apart in the rain.

Because I have no answers.
Because sometimes our lives feel empty.
Because only Now is eternal.

Because my posters are falling off the walls.

Because we are dying, one breath at a time.
Because we only have one chance to get it right.
Because this is life.
Because of how we were designed.

Because sometimes life falls apart like this.

Because there is tomorrow.
Because nothing is constant.
Because we are warriors.

Because songs fall from the mouths of angels.

Because we are ravers.
Because

love 
holds 
us 

together.


love,

b))merang

Not so long ago,ID W made the lovely statement:
<< it was an  environment where you could talk to people w/o having that same
club  type expectation of automagicly thinking that anybody who talked to you

 was tring to pick up on you, or any body you talk to thinks that you are
 tring to pick up on them!!! >>

I'd have to say Yes, you are correct.  :o)  Since I began raving, I've always
been asked what it is (as I'm sure we all have over and over. . .) and what I
tell people is to take the pretty lasers and lights and decorations of a
club, some of the big BASSy music (I know, it's not the same, but to people
that have never heard it, club music is the closest they can get to
understanding me) and then fill the place with all your best freinds in the
world and you have a rave (yea, it's an ideal perfect vibe rave, but, hell,
it's happened, no reason it can't keep happening).  The attitude is one that
defies the idea of a nasty ole' meat market or catwalk (again, I'm focusing
on the good raves, not the $$$-raves).  Instead, people can just walk up to
one another and give hugs without feeling awkward or have ideas about hitting
on each other.  Point of fact, my first rave, as soon as I stepped into the
circle (Plasti/< '95) some girl I'd never met walked up to me and my friend
Janis and gave us each a big, happy, glittery, plurry hug.  I just stood
there and couldn't help but fall in love with the idea of hugging random
people.  Now, I wish I could do that everywhere, but it usually only works
best at raves or amongst good company.  :o)

Anyhow, that's my  for t'day.

LuV -N- BiG HuGZ,
~^V^~PhoeniX~^V^~

P.S. if anyone wants some free hugs, find me at Happy Kidz on Friday.  Just
look for the laminates hangin from me  :o)
P.P.S. For more info on what people think raving is, check out my far from
finished website on raving.  Gimme suggestions (esp. for things to put on the
Vibe page, I'm kinda stuck as to what exactly to say, I think I've been too
long without a bunch of good events)
http://members.aol.com/phoenixjpl/begin.html
(Meet to PhoeniX for the rave info, Meet Jason for a soooooper small page on
lil ole me)

At 8:53 AM -0700 10/24/97, Digital Devil wrote:
>If there is anything I miss about raves it's that it seems like there
>used to be so many diffrent types of people from other scenes that made
>up the crowd. It seems today that only certain types of people are
>pre-disposed to even checking out the rave scene. OUR scene was built on
>all thease diffrent types of people and on all our diffrent beliefs
>being united by music.
>Just something I remember and thought y'all should think about-
>
>Raf

G-d, I do love these threads sometimes.  I think you're right Devil (esp.
if you're going back years which is what I'm going to do):

Anybody remember the numerous parties in the Flop House (for those who
don;t know this was an all night event far before CWP was a thought), like
Piggly Wiggly?  How about Felix which is now FTT?  How about WAX, Vortex,
Toon Town, Five Foot Tongue, Don't Sit On The Furniture, Eklypz, Rave
Called Sharon, there are soo many, like the X-Men...literally hundreds of
parties, what about the old sacto parties thrown by Miguel, Scott, & Gina ,
what about....

Oh, those were the days.

Well, prepared to get snuffed, 'cuz on Thursday nights at the Kitchen Sink,
you can hear almost anything you can think of in one night. From House, to
Techno, to Drum N Bass in the place, all the way to Reggae, Downtempo, Jazz
and more. It taked place at Blake's on Telegraph Ave. in Berkeley. Residents
are Joe Rice, Stareyes, and myself(Monty). Check it out!

fraction of the rave community: the hippies who only go to raves, because

went to Dead shows.

The fish 
had a wish
for a new scam
to replace spam

But proponents of spam
said we do not like your scam

we would not like it in a box
nor would we like it with a fox

we would not like it with a vase
we would not like it at homebase

we dont want it with tea
or even with E

we dont want it at 420 
for we have had plenty

this is sfrave
so behave

get back on topic
or we will beat you with a glowstick

you should talk about plur
and things with fuzzy fur

your plan is dumb
and you are a scum
so take your scam
and scram...

they said.
so with bowed head

and a tear in his eye
the fish said goodbye

Until another day
i will swim in the bay

But i will be back 
with another trick in my sack

MarQ,

awsome, and you will meet a lot of people from sfraves.  True, it is a massive,
but the vibe is going to be phat.  Hallowen Tribal massive was my very first rav
e last year, I have been out and about ever since.  :):):):):):):)

live back around '82 or so. By the time 924 Gilman opened up in about '86 I
was into NewRo, Techno Pop, and other precursors to rave music. There are
quite a few former punx in the rave scene though, but I'm not gonna out any
of them.

>The fish 
>had a wish
>for a new scam
>to replace spam

"Ah" said the crowd
they said it rather loud
and a small child said
with an idea in his head
If you call it scam
or even the dreaded spam
it will be the same
it all fits in the game
we will call it spam
and you are welcome to use scam
you have the right to be your own
not some silly clone

Ivan Weiss
"I SAID TO INVEST IN SNAPPLE NOT APPLE!!!"
-Bill gates :^)

WEll.. so a little pre-halloween cheer.  With everyone home saving money for
next weekend we had a nice small crowd.  A.K.A. LESS HOMIE G's.  Lotsa housy
funky stuff, with a different set-up for the T room.   They used the back
room as the entrance and let me just tell you, it feels a lot more spaced out
and natural that way.  OR it could have been that there was hardly anyone
there and lots of space to move around.  when we got in Melanie (??) was
spinning and she is so cute bouncing around to her little housy toons.  Other
DJs followed and I pretty much lost track, but I remembered enjoying
Essence's set.  
THe room down the ramp had some sound system trouble.  At first the music was
too loud and then the whole thing just shut down.  Needless to say, the only
time I went down there was to use the porta potties.  
Mostly it was just a kick-back evening to see everyone and dance.  I was
actually awake for once, but had to go on a quest with Victoria to find
energizers.  Very peaceful.  NOt an intense vibe, but no where near a bad
one.  Too much money for this party, tho..  Hi to Matt, Steve, Steve,
Victoria, Paul (I FINALLY PARTIED WITH YOU) Joey, Dale, Lisa and Kelly From
area 51, Rob, Jive, Autumn, people people and more people =)  See you all
next weekend!

              hugs n'stuff,
             'trice the tekno diva               <<<RAVEON>>>>

	id rma020699; Sun Oct 26 16:10:08 1997
Message-ID: <329B696C.E7F245F6@ix.netcom.com>
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 1996 14:04:28 -0800
From: Ray Vonie <rayvonie@ix.netcom.com>
Organization: Feel Good Entertainmnet
X-Mailer: Mozilla 4.02 [en] (Win95; I)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: Exotic Erotic review & A Reality Check
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

    Last night Jeannie and I went to the Exotic Erotic Ball.  Well, All
I Can say was that most of you on this list who complain about how much
stuff is at the parties (admission, water, parking, security,
location...etc)  You all really need to attend an event like this for a
good reality check.
    Admission was like $60 a ticket, and they sold it out.. with a line
of 4000 people still trying to get in.   It was packed, crammed, loud,
and the entertainment SUCKED.  The band Downstairs were ... Interesting,
and the dj upstairs sounded like he was playing a tape.  I noticed that
many of the people were having a good time, and everyone seemed like
they were enjoying themselves.. probably cause they didn't  know any
better...no points of better reference.
    Water was $3 a bottle, parking across the street was $15 a car (and
yes it was filled up).
The security could not have been any ruder if they tried, and there were
more cops inside than I've seen at a policeman's ball, and I mean real
cops, not just the people in costumes :)
    As far as the costumes go... there wasn't much that I have not seen
at most raves that I have been to.   And to top it off,  the Fire
marshal shut the party down at 11:30 because there were too many people
inside, and the event got closed down at midnight.  We had VIP passes
(HELL YES, I would never pay good money for this shit, Its the only
reason i went) and couldn't even get back in after going out to the car
to drop of our costumes Because the AC inside was not on and it was way
hot and crowded.  So we bolted and went to the Sound factory for the
after party... Well I guess the sound factory was ahead of the game,
cause they Cut of the guest list (which made it extremely difficult for
us to get in) and were charging $30 admission.. YES THIRTY BUCKS... and
this was at 1 am... oh and did I mention that there was a line around
the corner to get in, like 1000 people long!!!! and not much parking
within a 2 mile radius :)  And once we finally got inside, after dealing
with the HELLA rude doorman (shit this place has changed a lot since the
good old days when I was working with there) it was a mad house... nasty
people every where.. all trying to get ugly with you around every
corner, and the bathrooms... DAMM ... I've seen cleaner port-o-poties
after a massive.  It took 15 minuets to get through one hallway... I
thought that the place was going to spontaneously combust from all the
heat and pressure.  Well we bailed that place real quick, and headed
home, for some rest.
    Any ways... my point is that many of you complain about parties and
massive with incredible productions and entertainment costing like $20..
or whatever.  Well I think that those of you that have any sort of
complaints with what raves and massive cost in relation to what you
get... well you all need a reality check by going to a non rave event
like this to readjust your understanding of how good you really have it,
and how fortunate you really are.  Cause from what i've seen in clubs,
and other special event s like the last night... gives me even more
reason to love our scene, and APPRECIATE every party I can get to...
Cause its a mad world out there.

Keep it Real

Vlad aka Ray Vonie

Subject: Bjork: Homogenic

Hey there kids...
Just thought I'd wrap up the weekend with a little suggestion for anyone
who has ever liked Bjork - even the teensiest bit.
Got her new CD (Homogenic) today and I am truly impressed.  Girl got her
sound together and has really turned out a nice one.  Lots of groovy
rhythms and, of course, those Bjorky vocals.  Who could live without her
mousy little self?  She seems to have grown up a bit and her sound is much
more polished.  Even the art work is impressive.  All around a very nice
production.  Definately worth checking out.  And if you hurry, you can get
it on sale at Tower for $12.99.  Don't ya just love a bargain!?!
Night now,
Megan

Precedence: bulk

so, i was wondering if anyone would care to help me on a little project of
mine.  just answer a couple of questions about your sex life if you dare.
this is for the betterment of society, whatever that may be.  actually it
is for my term paper for my gay and lesbian culture and society class.  i
will be questioning kids at parties as well, but i believe  i wil get a
different reply from people on the computer and probably not high.  so,
what do you think?  put in the subject line eeneR. here goes....
1.  what is your self identified gender? (do you think you are a boy or a girl?)
2.  is it the same as your sex?  ( do you have a penis or a vagina?)
3.  if you were to fit in one of western culture's sexual identities, what
would you be labeled as?  (are you straight{their word} or gay?)
4.  How would you label yourself?
5.  do you feel free to express your sexual identity in the  mainstream culture?
6.  do you feel the rave culture is accepting of your sexual identity?
7.  do you feel accepted by mainstream society?
8.  how does the rave culture &/or mainstream society  influence your
persona or decisions?  (but does this really matter?  no, i personally do
not feel that either one of these aspects of my life make me, but it is
human to be influenced by our surroundings.  did nature make nurture or
nurture make nature? anyway)
9.  does the sex of the individual you are having sex with matter to you?
10.  if it did not matter who you had sex with or how you did it, do you
think that sex would be better?
11.  commentary

thank you all so much.  i will process all the info i get and put it
online.  and you will all get my thanks when i win the nobel peace prize
for joining the whole planet together in complete harmony;-)  peace.
love,
'eeneR

Its silly
says ms bea

It could not be...
But i think you will see
that it could
and it should.

It might happen in the rain
with djs on the train

It might happen in the sun
which would really be fun

It might happen with faces of glitter
as we pick up market streets litter.

We will have our silly dance
if you just give us a chance

You may even like it
and contribute a bit

___________________
the following is stolen from apples new adds:

To the crazy ones.
Heres to the crazy ones, the misfits, the rebels, the troublemakers.
the round pegs in the square hole. the ones who see things 
differently.

they are not fond of rules. ANd have no respect for the status
quo. 

You can praise them or disagree with them, quote them,
disbelieve them, glorify them or vilify them.
About the only thing you cant do is ignore them.

Because they change things. They invent. They imagine. They
heal. They create. They inspire. They push the human race forward
They do not accept that because it has failed before
that it will always fail. 

Maybe they have to be crazy, How else can you stare at an empty
canvas and see a work of art? Or sit in silence and hear a song
that has never been written? Or gaze at a red planet and see
a laboratory on wheels.

We make tools for these kind of people, because while some
see them as crazy ones, we see them as genius.

And its the people who are crazy enough to think 
they can change the world, who actually do.

this add is filled with pictures of people like 
einstein, picasso, ghandi and neil armstrong
standing on the moon

think different

		><{{{">  <"}}}><

			foolish fish
