Hi,

I'd like to introduce myself: I'm a 24 year old partyperson back here in
Amsterdam, the Netherlands, Europe. I've been on this list for a while now,
lurking, because I'm applying for a visa to live in the US permanently. And,
I just received news that it is working out! It's really going to happen!
(still can't believe it myself..). So that means I'm moving to San Francisco
in january. Now, here in Amsterdam we have a lot of good partying (although
apparently kind of hard to get into if you're an overseas visitor), and of
course I've been on this list to figure out what the scene is about out
there. So if I ask dumb questions on this list, please consider I'm an
ignorant european.. Oh: and I'm still in the market for a job as a web
developer, any help is appreciated!

later,
Wessel

From: dsp <dsp@raven.dartmouth.edu>

Subject: rave review
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.93.971027063133.7622C-100000@raven.dartmouth.edu>

i have to say i attended my 2nd and LAST "rave-you-have-to-pay-for" in
oakland this weekend.  

i saw many things that were thorougghly embarassing for techno enthusiasts
and honest ravers that i refuse to show support for ever again.

lets just say the incident that infuriated me the most was the blatant
mysogeny taking place at what seemed to be an event set up to show that
there were some slick women dj's out there too.  

I guess it wouldnt have been so bad if the white fat soul-free fuck that
played right before heather heart went on for hours on
end with his white soul-free trash pop funk free 'techno' or should i
say electronica breaks and  ate up all of heather's
set, then turned the decks over to his homee with the squeaky voice who
not until getting screamed at by some angry militant ravers for his
blatent show of hatred towards women, gave the decks over to the guest.

i believe that showing of mysogeny was solely because "the boys" couldnt
get over the fact that the women
dj's there were of much higher caliber than they could ever be,, even
after their many many many years of "representing" the san francisco
scene.

in the words of one of the dj's that was among the many many distressing
over the fact that one of her idols was getting dicked over by some dumb
boy behavior "It looks like the boys have taken over"

Im terribly disappointed.  

i am in shock from this scene of massive disrespect to women, to djs from
other towns, djs who present
music with soul, people who project themselves...

:(

(on top of all this the doorman threw out my $8 of sealed water
bottles for me and my
friends, (hence i had to spend another $8 on the exact same water
bottles INSIDE) and the sound
sucked... ie: people talking was louder than the music in the main room.)
man, ive seen better sound at $1 and a can of food parties.

see you next summer ive had enough of this crap for a while

please dont let "the boys" take over techno...

for the many of you who have not heard of the spiraltribe  or know less
than 1k of info about them, i highly highly recommend reading the section
in "Altered State" about the nomadic techno tribes (ie spiraltribe) its
like 3 chapters of wicked engaging material :) it also gives a good
background as to why "ravers" in the states are refered to as lightweights
;)

the rest of the book is good historically but talks about clubbing and
stuff way too much, although it definitely clears up the picture about how
techno started off

rage on
-dsp

Date: Sat, 25 Oct 1997 14:58:54 +0100
From: bworthe@muse.sfusd.k12.ca.us (Bea Worthen)
Subject: Re: jus choking

MICHAEL MICHAEL MICHAEL,if these jokes are thats offensive to you then ur
taking urself too damn seriusly (remember rule 62)I know a buch of really

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 25 Oct 1997 18:00:34 -0400 (EDT)
From: LAKSMI <Laksmi@cris.com>
Subject: Re: jus choking

On Sat, 25 Oct 1997, Michael Standish wrote:

> I find these "jokes" very insulting. These jokes describe a very small
> fraction of the rave community: the hippies who only go to raves, because
> Jerry is dead, and they need a new place to take drugs, and pretend to have
> PLUR. God, I miss the old days when ravers went to raves, and deadheads
> went to Dead shows.

then laksmi wrote:
You know... I know some pretty awesome people who are much more than their
identities as raver/deadheads who have been going to "raves" well before
the "good ole days".  Generalizing can get a bit silly.

(my response:)
have you ever asked a 'hippie' why (s)he's at a rave? the above statement
from mr standish seems to me to be really 'un-PLURalistic'... i'm not fond
of all this advertising your plur anyway (if you are 'plurry', then why
feel the need to plaster it all over the place?), but god. to tell one type
of person that they have no bsns being at a rave is a bit exclusive. my
first rave: 1990. my first dead show: c.1983. what does that make me?
instead of looking at the difference, why don't you look at the
similarities? have you ever really listened to mickey hart? his drums would
put most d&b djs to shame.

anyway, i'd hate to think that there are little ravers running around
saying that i have no bsns being at a rave because i happen to like the
dead as well. especially when i was going to raves when some were still in
elementary school. there really are quite a few similarities btwn the two -
i suspect that you haven't been to a show otherwise you wouldn't be saying
such things. no dead head ever told me to leave because i dressed in black
- i was welcomed with open arms, the same way i entered raving. if you
close the world out because it's different, it might just do the same to
you. probably will.

off to work - if you've got something to say to me, reply personally 'coz i
just might delete the digest tonight.

cheers - e. :)

At 7:31 AM -0800 10/27/97, e.menon wrote:
>have you ever asked a 'hippie' why (s)he's at a rave? the above statement
>from mr standish seems to me to be really 'un-PLURalistic'...

And ganging up on the odd man out is PLURy? Look at this thread a little
more closely, and you will find very little PLUR from anyone except Moshe
and Larry. Yeah I was mean in a private reply to a private email, but I am
by no means the only person wha has behaved meanly in this thread.

>feel the need to plaster it all over the place?), but god. to tell one type
>of person that they have no bsns being at a rave is a bit exclusive.

I never said that. I took offense to the generalizations in the converted
deadhead jokes. Many people who have jumped in to attack me seem to think
that those generalizations are OK, but that some that I may have made are
not. Even if I had said that, how would it be any different from the many
posts over the years where people say that "gangstas" don't belong?

>first rave: 1990. my first dead show: c.1983. what does that make me?

Nothing, you are who you are; unless you choose to define yourself that way.

>instead of looking at the difference, why don't you look at the
>similarities?

12 step much?

>have you ever really listened to mickey hart? his drums would

Hart is damn good. So what? That doesn't make deadheads any more pleasant
to be around.

> there really are quite a few similarities btwn the two -

Yeah, pot, acid, E, booze, crank, junk, and fake PLUR.

>i suspect that you haven't been to a show otherwise you wouldn't be saying
>such things. no dead head ever told me to leave because i dressed in black
>- i was welcomed with open arms, the same way i entered raving.

That was not my experience. I went to a show once, looking like the
Mettalica fan that I was, and I got hella bad vibes. One guy said "Wow man
unmellow, like this isn't a metal show." No my friends I am not kidding, he
really said that.

>close the world out because it's different, it might just do the same to
>you. probably will.

I hope hippies do close me out. I have nothing to say to them.


Ulrich

hey hey hey,

I completely feel ya there but please don't assume all massives are like this
and that it was all directed at the fact that heather heart is a girl DJ.

First of all.  If you do choose to go to a massive please choose very 
carefully.  I for one do not attend massives thrown by half of the crews
in this area.  mainly to avoid a night like the one you had. but there are
lots of other reasons as well.  Charging for water, Headliner DJ's not showing
up or if they do they usually don't get to spin their full set.  I could go 
on and on.

Second is that think that the DJ's in questions would act that way to any
DJ that they deemed unworthy of their "respect", male or female. 
The scene has definatly lost its sense of comraderie and belonging to
a special family of sorts.  It has just gotten too big.  With this comes 
competition which eats away at what makes a family feel like a family
It is also a sad
fact that the egos of DJ's, especially in this area, seem to be growing
exponentially. With this they lose something, like their heart, and their 
sight and focus of what is really important in their life and in the scene. 
It happens to all of us.  If we aren't careful we are destined to become what 
we at one time despised and fought against.  I don't think a lot of 
DJ's, when they first started out, thought that they would need an agent/manager
but as their popularity increased they felt it necessary. 

It does however fall back upon us.  How can we support a truly good DJ without
him/her becoming what we fear the most.  Granted a lot of the desire relies in 
the DJ whether or not to become a supastar, but we are the critics, fans, and
supporters. A lot of people need constant reminders so they don't lose sight and
focus and that is our responsiblity.

If you don't like a certain DJ or crew for whatever reason don't go to that 
party. Don't support them and get your friends to not support them either.

Anyways if you really think about it though.  We are all just people trying to
make a mark / or leave a mark in this weird thing we call society so can you
really blame them for trying ?

I dont' know, but all I really know is that I don't know.

don't keep it real .. just be true to yourself and what you believe in.

Herb
= )

ok, so friday night i *thought* was going out to dinner with my 
roomates and a couple of other selected people in honor of my 
birthday (which was thurs) and lo and behold, i'm walking in to the 
restaurant and there's like all 12 of my friends sitting there.  a 
conspiracy!  but a pleasant one.  i really wasn't expecting much, no 
one really does when they turn 20, because it's like "*sigh* another 
year ...." but this has been one of my best birthdays ever.  and it 
is because i reflected on my life and realized that i am one of the 
luckiest people because i have so many rad friends.  true friends.  
friends who are there to listen to me bitch, whine, tell jokes, cry, 
laugh, etc.   i love you molly and yuko, thank you for making my 
birthday... no, my LIFE that much better and brighter.  :-)

_-^-_doreen_-^-_

     Greetings Vlad,
     
     Welp, 99% of the time I agree with your comments about the "scene" and 
     the price issue that comes to our list every now and then. However, 
     when you insist that some of us need a reality check, I disagree.
     
     Now, I understand that for a "massive" to take place, it take moolah 
     up front, alot of moolah. You need a return on your investment. Most 
     of the time, you can barley break even. Understood. There is a need 
     for high entrance prices. Big name talent, cool location, security. 
     
     Where I disagree: In your note(No offense please, just my opinion), it 
     sounds like you feel that we as partygoers should feel lucky that we 
     have it so good... I will not feel lucky that I have to pay 30 dollars 
     to enter a party. Especially when I pay the high fee, and in order to 
     save me money, bring my own water, which I must discard when I 
     approach the gate. That's not lucky! It's something we have to deal 
     with in order to enjoy the party. I believe it's unfortunate. I don't 
     think the 3 dollars I spent at 7-11 rather the party, will kill a 
     margin you are trying to hit. I've been to many UG's where they had 
     plenty of free stuff! Free Water, Free Fruit... Free afterparties!!
     
     I do feel lucky that these parties are available to the masses, 
     however I believe YOU SHOULD FEEL LUCKY that you have a market out 
     there, that is willing to pay the 30 bucks.
     
     I do agree with your remarks about the exotic erotic, and the club 
     scene. However I choose not to compare our scene to the club scene. 
     That's why I rave... Clubs are a JOKE! 
     
     The "you should feel lucky" remark rubbed me the wrong way first thing 
     Monday morning... But hey, nothin but love for ya babay!
     
     Keep the Peace! <JCO>

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Exotic Erotic review & A Reality Check
Author:  Ray Vonie <rayvonie@ix.netcom.com> at Internet_mail
Date:    11/26/96 2:04 PM


    Last night Jeannie and I went to the Exotic Erotic Ball.  Well, All
I Can say was that most of you on this list who complain about how much 
stuff is at the parties (admission, water, parking, security, 
location...etc)  You all really need to attend an event like this for a 
good reality check.
    Admission was like $60 a ticket, and they sold it out.. with a line
of 4000 people still trying to get in.   It was packed, crammed, loud, 
and the entertainment SUCKED.  The band Downstairs were ... Interesting, 
and the dj upstairs sounded like he was playing a tape.  I noticed that 
many of the people were having a good time, and everyone seemed like they 
were enjoying themselves.. probably cause they didn't  know any 
better...no points of better reference.
    Water was $3 a bottle, parking across the street was $15 a car (and
yes it was filled up).
The security could not have been any ruder if they tried, and there were 
more cops inside than I've seen at a policeman's ball, and I mean real 
cops, not just the people in costumes :)
    As far as the costumes go... there wasn't much that I have not seen
at most raves that I have been to.   And to top it off,  the Fire 
marshal shut the party down at 11:30 because there were too many people 
inside, and the event got closed down at midnight.  We had VIP passes 
(HELL YES, I would never pay good money for this shit, Its the only 
reason i went) and couldn't even get back in after going out to the car 
to drop of our costumes Because the AC inside was not on and it was way 
hot and crowded.  So we bolted and went to the Sound factory for the 
after party... Well I guess the sound factory was ahead of the game, 
cause they Cut of the guest list (which made it extremely difficult for 
us to get in) and were charging $30 admission.. YES THIRTY BUCKS... and 
this was at 1 am... oh and did I mention that there was a line around 
the corner to get in, like 1000 people long!!!! and not much parking 
within a 2 mile radius :)  And once we finally got inside, after dealing 
with the HELLA rude doorman (shit this place has changed a lot since the 
good old days when I was working with there) it was a mad house... nasty 
people every where.. all trying to get ugly with you around every 
corner, and the bathrooms... DAMM ... I've seen cleaner port-o-poties 
after a massive.  It took 15 minuets to get through one hallway... I 
thought that the place was going to spontaneously combust from all the 
heat and pressure.  Well we bailed that place real quick, and headed 
home, for some rest.
    Any ways... my point is that many of you complain about parties and
massive with incredible productions and entertainment costing like $20.. 
or whatever.  Well I think that those of you that have any sort of 
complaints with what raves and massive cost in relation to what you 
get... well you all need a reality check by going to a non rave event 
like this to readjust your understanding of how good you really have it, 
and how fortunate you really are.  Cause from what i've seen in clubs, 
and other special event s like the last night... gives me even more 
reason to love our scene, and APPRECIATE every party I can get to... 
Cause its a mad world out there.
     
Keep it Real
     
Vlad aka Ray Vonie

	 Mon, 27 Oct 1997 12:33:31 -0800
Message-Id: <3.0.1.32.19971027124105.006a98d4@medialive.com>
X-Sender: megan@medialive.com (Unverified)
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 3.0.1 (32)
Date: Mon, 27 Oct 1997 12:41:05 -0800
To: Ray Vonie <rayvonie@ix.netcom.com>, sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: Megan Hug <megan@medialive.com>
Subject: Re: Exotic Erotic review & A Reality Check
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

i went last year...
i had just moved into the sf area from the east coast... and let me tell
you- i was SHOCKED! never seen anything like it before! all the nudity,
leather, exotic outfits... things i'd only seen in lingerie magazines! 
i actually kind of liked it... it was nice to see people so free and
comfortable with their bodies... after all it was an EXOTIC EROTIC ball-
what else is to be expected?
(it's funny how after only a year in the city... i've already become
accustom to this sort of thing... i even found the folsom street fair a bit
tame!)
what i didn't like (at the Exotic Erotic ball) were the people/tourists
that were there in normal clothing taking videos and pictures of every
exposed butt, breast, and penis... and NOT participating... it was as if
they were invading this scene for the pornographic value and not the other
natural side of the human body... but i guess there are two sides to
everything and who am i to judge?  just because i chose to see it one way
doesn't necessarily mean that the other way is wrong... but i have to
admit, as a participant, i did at times feel uncomfortable around some of
the voyeurs... almost exploited.  and it was a bit unsettling being in the
company of completely nude people with only face masks on, sitting in the
corner, (for lack of a more polite term) literally masturbating in public! 
at a function like this... celebrating sexuality... is there any limit or
standard to what is and isn't acceptable?
well, i chose not go this year...

I've been pretty busy lately so it's rare that I share anything with the
list anymore (save for my BSPs, sorry) but I had to share this bit of
weirdness...
So Garth was DJing down at the Shack last Saturday and if you haven't
seen him lately he's sans dreads, in fact he had some straw hat on. 
Anyway, the place was electric, the guy was dropping hard breakbeat
(seriously) and everything else under the sun and smilin' and bobbin' up
and down the whole time! And for the first time in a a long while I just
smiled and thought, "Yep, this is how it's sposed to be." (note: not how
it used to be) Even stranger... Pauly Shore (sp?) right in front of
Garth w/ his hands in the air just screaming and smiling and just behind
him Morris Day gettin' down a la James Brown.  Weird huh? Anyway,
Garth's still got it, that's for sure.

-SUNNY 
P.S.S. 
11/1: Jeno & Taj

Jody_Orsburn_at_KaoFremont@kaoinfo.com wrote:

>       Where I disagree: In your note(No offense please, just my opinion), it
>      sounds like you feel that we as partygoers should feel lucky that we
>      have it so good... I will not feel lucky that I have to pay 30 dollars
>      to enter a party. Especially when I pay the high fee, and in order to
>      save me money, bring my own water, which I must discard when I
>      approach the gate. That's not lucky! It's something we have to deal
>      with in order to enjoy the party.

I see what you mean, and I understand where you are coming from.  It sounds like
your saying... "I don't have to feel lucky about anything, cause I'm paying for what
I'm getting"  Which in my opinion sounds like a very valid statement.  Cause it's
the truth!!  My whole thing, was that I hear people say that 20 bucks is too much to
pay for.... Blah... Blah... Blah... etc.  My point is that I was astonished at how
much people were paying for what little they were receiving back at the exotic
ball.  In my opinion (form a price vs. entertainment evaluation)  it was a total
rip-off.  a $50 advance / $60 door cover charge people should have gotten a lot more
than they did.  AND the parody of it all is that they were all happy... like they
didn't know they were getting gouged.    They were getting screwed and they were
loving it.  That's the reality check i'm talking about.   And on top if it all,
there were less people in costume then there were perverts with cameras.   I guess
the bottom line was that I was left flabbergasted after seeing how badly people were
taken for their cash.  I guess I just have high standards of what is fun and what is
a wrong.  Because from a production value standpoint, what you get at a rave; with
visuals, lighting, lasers, sound and dj's and.... for only like $20 , and not to
mention that it runs for 10 hours, comes out to like $2/hour of fun.   And at the 5
hour exotic erotic with 2 small stages and very little production value, at
$10/hr... and that's before you add in the party favors, and accessories... it just
feels all wrong.

I think that we are ALL very lucky that even the most commercial of massive still
gives back 10 times more than a mainstream special event at a fraction of the cost.

Keep It Real

Vlad, aka Ray Vonie

New Rane DJ Mixer info!

(only a geek could get stoked about this).

I don't know how much hype there has been about this, but it looks like
fun from here.  I'd wanted to buy a Rane for a while, but I always wanted
that seperate EQ per channel of the MP-22, and the 3-4 deck capability
(no, I'm not all that yet, maybe someday though...) of the MP-24 (plus all
four channels will take phono), and the VCA/active crossfader (read:
doesn't get scratchy) available on some ESOs and the new Intimidation
Apex.

Except for the fact that this mixer is UGLY as sin (well, at least it
matches my crossover now, which is also UGLY...), I think this will be a
welcome sight to plug your headphones into in the next coming months.

Peace,
AndyW

Rane Release Info is below...

taken from...

http://www.rane.com/mm8x.htm

MM 8x
                                 Mojo DJ Mixer
                                                                          
General Description

Combining the success of the Mojo Series with the MP 22 and MP 24 Mixers,
Rane proudly presents the MM 8x Mojo Mixer, the DJ's centerpiece. 

The MM 8x features eight stereo Inputs. Each of the four assignable buses
contains its own three band EQ, allowing separate equalization of
different sources. The four faders are grouped in two pairs, allowing a
custom mix of two input sources on each side of the crossfader.

The MM 8x incorporates new Active Crossfader technology that combines
state of the art voltage controlled amplifier design with a professional
studio quality, dual-rail crossfader control.  Combining Active Crossfader
technology with a removable crossfader, sets new standards for
performance, reliability and serviceability. Virtually all crossfader
noise is eliminated. Channel to channel crosstalk is greatly reduced and
the OFF isolation of the faded channel is greatly increased. Active
Crossfader technology dramatically increases the service life of the
crossfader. In the unlikely event of crossfader failure, there is no loss
of signal. If a crossfader should become rough or noisy, it is possible to
'hot swap' the control during a performance with no interruption of the
audio signal. Simply use the input faders to set the audio levels while
the crossfader is out of service.

Each of the four Phono (RIAA) Inputs switch to Line Level via rear panel
switches. 

Both the Main and Aux Mic Inputs route through Bass and Treble controls. 
The Main Mic input has an Effects Loop. The main program signal includes a
stereo Master Loop for equalization or processing.

The Tape Output can be switched to exclude the Master Loop signal and
record the unprocessed program signal. 

The MM 8x doesnt scrimp on its powerful Headphone Cueing system in which
one or more channels may be cued at one time.  The metering can be
switched to monitor stereo main output or mono cue on one side and mono
program on the other.

The MM 8xs recessed top mounted jacks provide room for cabling in tight DJ
coffins or racks without sacrificing its compact 4"  depth.

   Yeah, I successfully quit/resigned/gave up/hated/and left City 
Espresso  :)  Some advice to people who aren't enjoying their places of 
employment 
1)quit,  
2)do not think things will get any better especially if they haven't 
improved for the last six months 
3)Quit with a hot sword up your butt (don't just quit, make it 
interesting, you only live once)-very unethical, but everyone does 
it-bandwagon you know?  :P 
4)don't beleive anything that the Big Boss Man tells you, cuz they know 
that you can't stand to look at them.  
5)don't clean the toilet in which your mgr. recuperates on because that 
shit stinks and so do they, they should clean it. 
6)don't ask for a raise because you, and only you know you'll be leaving 
in a week anyways.  
7)Keep in touch with everyone that you helped out while you worked, for 
me it was the ravers and without that job, Ida never met anyofyou. 8)get 
a great job that you enjoy and use the 90 day probationary period to 
your advantage.  
    Well, there is my tangent of employment.  I'll still see everyone 
around, just not every single day of my life, i know that is the breaks 
but I got to clean the new mgr's. toilet now.  Take care everybody and 
we'll see you all goolish-like at Happy Kidz

I do like the cabling setup on RANE mixers, but aside from that I've had 
really bad luck with them.  Every one I've used had a short in the 
headphone jack :/  Also, the cues are all of the push-button variety 
(Yeah, I've grown kinda used to teh good old rotary style like on the 
Geminis or the "second crossfader" on the older Numarks)

I look forward to playing with the new RANE sometime, but I don't 
know...  I think I'll prolly stick with my Scratchmaster for a while 
longer :D :D :D :D  Talk about a booty mixer!  Oh well, at least it's not 
RadioShack... :D

At 6:50 AM +0000 10/27/97, bABy HueY wrote:
>And hippies kick butt.  When you think about it, ravers go to raves for
>the same reasons that "dead heads"  went to Dead shows.

Now who's generalizing? How dare you presume to say why I go to raves.
There are many reasons to rave. People rave for different combinations of
those reasons. Some times, as you say those reasons are similar to why
people go to dead shows, but not always. Nobody, at least for the last 20
to 25 years has gone to a dead show for the new fashions, or the new styles
of music. Do you mean to say that these reasons, which are paramount to me,
are unimportant?

>Heaven forbid
>the two collide.

Fortunately for me they ussually colide at trance parties. And, as I am not
fond of trance, I miss most of the collision.

one. this doesn't constitute a 'ganging up' - only a difference of opinion.
and once again, i can only hope that my expression of such might open a few
eyes.

>12 step much?

oooh - was that obvious??? ;) i knew i was spending too much time in those
smokey rooms!

>
>>have you ever really listened to mickey hart? his drums would
>
>Hart is damn good. So what? That doesn't make deadheads any more pleasant
>to be around.

okay, so i guess i confused your calling people deadheads with the music -
you like the music, you just don't like the people who like it? well, i
don't care for some ravers, either. but this doesn't mean that i don't care
for _all_ of them.... as in any group, there will be assholes and there
will be really beautiful people. it's up to you to seek out those who will
compliment your life. you could be missing out by prejudging a person by
the way they're dressed.....

>> there really are quite a few similarities btwn the two -
>
>Yeah, pot, acid, E, booze, crank, junk, and fake PLUR.

not all of it is fake. yes, quite a bit of it. but i've met some really
wonderful people within both scenes - and that respect, for yourself as you
are, and for others as they are, is a lot of what brings them together. and
you know, they're both a *circus*, full of hedonistic freaks! how can you
not enjoy that??
>
>>i suspect that you haven't been to a show otherwise you wouldn't be saying
>>such things. no dead head ever told me to leave because i dressed in black
>>- i was welcomed with open arms, the same way i entered raving.
>
>That was not my experience. I went to a show once, looking like the
>Mettalica fan that I was, and I got hella bad vibes. One guy said "Wow man
>unmellow, like this isn't a metal show." No my friends I am not kidding, he
>really said that.

once. yeah, i had a shitty experience at one show - meadowlands. :( but in
a way, the bad things that happened brought some ppl together.

and i read shakespeare once in 7th grade. at that point, i decided i hated
shakespeare.

>>close the world out because it's different, it might just do the same to
>>you. probably will.
>
>I hope hippies do close me out. I have nothing to say to them.

i still don't see how you can generalize this way about an entire group of
ppl.... but then it'll be your loss.

cheers - e. :)

Quoth e.menon
>oh, and i wasn't going to get drawn into this again. oooops... i guess
>changing to the digest format doesn't really change that much! *anyway*, i
>must apologise. i caught this thread at this particular point and missed

>'gang up' - this, as i understand, requires more than one person. i'm just
>one. this doesn't constitute a 'ganging up' - only a difference of opinion.
>and once again, i can only hope that my expression of such might open a few
>eyes.

I didn't mean just you. There have been hella people acting all high and
mighty, and ripping on me at the same time. In so doing they were being
self righteous, and hypocritical, two things which I find all too common
among hippies.

>>Hart is damn good. So what? That doesn't make deadheads any more pleasant
>>to be around.
>
>okay, so i guess i confused your calling people deadheads with the music -
>you like the music,

Gawd no I can't stand GD music. I said Mickey is damn good; I didn't say
anything about his music. Perhaps I should have said 'Mickey is damn
talented.'

>you just don't like the people who like it? well, i
>don't care for some ravers, either. but this doesn't mean that i don't care
>for _all_ of them.... as in any group, there will be assholes and there
>will be really beautiful people. it's up to you to seek out those who will
>compliment your life. you could be missing out by prejudging a person by
>the way they're dressed.....

Given that I have a finite amount of time with which to seek out people who
I can connect with, I would have take time away from people with whom I
share similar tastes and interests, in order to spend time with hippies.
And, as a result I would be reducing the odds of my finding someone I
really click with.

>not all of it is fake. yes, quite a bit of it. but i've met some really
>wonderful people within both scenes - and that respect, for yourself as you
>are, and for others as they are,

I have had enough experience to be sure that deadheads are very judgmental
of others. I guess were just going to have to agree to disagree on this one.

>you know, they're both a *circus*, full of hedonistic freaks!

So is a punk show, goth club, heavy metal concert, leather bar, Ren.
Faire..... Some are my cuppa and some aren't.

>how can you
>not enjoy that??

The stench of PU-chewly comes to mind.

>once. yeah, i had a shitty experience at one show - meadowlands. :( but in
>a way, the bad things that happened brought some ppl together.
>
>and i read shakespeare once in 7th grade. at that point, i decided i hated
>shakespeare.

Believe me I've had enough contact with deadheads to get a statistically
significant sample.

>i still don't see how you can generalize this way about an entire group of
>ppl.... but then it'll be your loss.

No, it will be my gain, because I'll be spending time with people I have
stuff in common with.

At 11:29 PM -0800 10/28/97, Derek J Fieldsoe wrote:
>the other?  Do you people like the mixers with samplers in them or not?
>
>I need some pros and cons since I've never used either method before.

Well, I can't imagine why you would want a sampler, but...

All the best mixers do not come with a sampler, so you would have to get a
less desirable mixer if you want a built in sampler.

When you go to play out, you will be using the mixer that the sound people
set up for everyone. If you buy a stand alone sampler, and show up before
the rave to hook it up, they'll let you plug it in. On the other hand if
you role up and want to unplug the Rane or Intimidation to plug in your
Numark or whatever sampling mixer, you're gonna get hella grief.

Sir Ulrich Knight of the Turntables

Morning all you peoples out there,

I am not sure if you all know this but the bovine crew won RSA's 56-Bit 
encryption key contest and have moved onto the 64-Bit key.  You can help
out by donating all of your spare CPU cycles. It took them almost a year with
over 30,000 computers working together to find it so they are going to need
more help with the 64-Bit key.  You should check them out.  There is a prize
attached RSA gives the winner $10,000.  $1,000 goes to the bovine crew, $8,000
goes to these people who are publishing books on the web (well that is who got
it the last time I am not sure who will get it this time) and $1,000 goes to the
lucky person who actually found the key.  Its kinda like a bonus you know?

Anyways its very cool and it doesn't even require you to have a permanent 
connection to the net. It does however require your computer to run all of the
time.

Please check out www.distributed.net/rc5 for more info.  Then even have a cool
status page so you can see how you are doing versus the rest of the world.

enjoy your tuesday,

Herb

ok, first let me say i think danny is a sweetheart .... but a career
counselor for 10 years, i just have to spout some advice here...

truth is, the secret to being happy in your work is attitude.... and that
includes finding a job that you have fun doing, and finding a boss who you
like (and don't buy into this "the boss is out to get you" mentality cuz it
ain't usually that way)...

and especially that "quit with a hot sword up your butt" is scary, yikes!

it's way better not to burn the bridges if you can help it... everybody
wins that way and you still get the phat reference... and a sense of pride
in how well you handled yourself even when it wasn't easy....

and i should know, cuz i've done it both ways



leslie

In-Reply-To: <19971028.233056.2678.6.drek1@juno.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.971028100711.5537B-100000@kzsu.Stanford.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Well, my very first mixer was a gemini with a hobbled little 
integrated sampler. It was really convenient, though, for just taking 
something quickly from the cue and being able to do sample "hits" with it.

The downsides of integrated mixer/samplers:

- trimming samples is either not supported or very difficult
- so-so sound quality (usually)
- limited sampling time (depending on what you want to do, this may not 
be an issue
- no storage (so all those wonderful samples die when you turn off the power)

The upside:
- cheap (this is the big one)
- unless the sampler is integrated, it's very tricky to be able to sample 
the "cue" channel. Most dj-oriented external samplers either sit between 
your mixer and your amplifier, or in the effects loop of your mixer (if 
your mixer's got one). As a result, unless you have a really fancy mixer 
(ie., the Vestax PMC-56 @ $1800, or use another multi-bus mixer like a 
Mackie 16*4 @ $1000), you will only be able to sample from your live mix (or 
record the samples before you start your live set). 

This is less than ideal: the crowd has to hear everything that you 
sample as you're sampling it!

So unless you are _very_ ambitious and have a lot of money to spare, and 
you're more interested in splicing in shorter samples (as opposed to doing 
sample loops, MIDI, or full-on production), I'd recommend an integrated 
sampler.

-radon

ps. if anyone is curious about setting up an external sampler with a 
multibus mixer, email me.

23 five invites you to a benefit spectacular...
                                       =


Bay Area subterraneous notables converge
for an evening of indulgence in sound, sight,
sushi, and support to benefit 23five Incorporated.

When: Saturday, Nov. 8, 1997, 9 p.m.
Where: The Lab, 2948 16th St. (at Capp)
How much: $10 to $15 sliding scale

23five =97 a nonprofit dedicated to the development and increased
awareness of sound works in the public arena and to the education of
artists working with sound =97 has recently acquired a facility in Potrer=
o
Hill. But, like sushi, it's raw. We have the equipment necessary to
operate a recording studio, but we gotta build it. And that takes $$$.

The new studio will give artists access to professional audio recording
equipment, facilitate the archiving of sound art recordings, serve as a
site for seminars and workshops, and produce recordings by young people.

 =

YES... :) (I love this subject..)

The reason I love music so much is because it touches my soul and makes me
feel really good. The reason I love playing music for others is because
it's a great way to share this *magic*. I don't play what others want to hear,
I play what sounds good to me, and others who have similiar tastes will
enjoy my telegrams of love and emotion... this is what makes a true DJ
(in my opinion)... someone who plays what *he* wants others to hear.. not
what he thinks *they* want to hear... 

I don't think you can ever be true to yourself, the music or the listener 
if all you do is play what you think people want to hear... you have to
go deeeper than that, play what touches your heart and tickles your
soul... this is when the true connection is made between the musician, DJ and
 listener...

This is all you should think about when you think to yourself, "there are
so many DJs... ".. and you feel disenchanted to put the energy into
becoming a DJ. If you think this way (thinking that it's hopeless), you're
probably not in it for the right reason..... just play what you love and
be true to yourself... everything is possible if you put your mind,
body and soul to it...... because believe it or not, there are tons of
poeple out there dieing to hear what you want to play....  

Byroni
(DJ Byroni!) ;)

What kind of music will you be spinning?  Are the samples gunna be a big
part of your music or are you just going to add the samples to make your
sound better?  If you are going to use samples often then you should get a
sampler separate from the mixer (since the good samplers out there in the
market are those that don't come with the mixer).

Hope this helps.

AnthonE

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
           AnthonE @ SFRaves
	     rave@vibe.org
      anthony@gomez.sc.intel.com
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Hi Everyone,
I'm need recommendations for cool but not too expensive places 
in the Bay Area, Sacramento, Tahoe or surrounding areas to have 
a weekend retreat.  The dates of my class retreat are 11/21/97
to 11/23/97.

We expect to play loud music sometimes during the day and 
outside on the Saturday night (a mini rave).  Hopefully, that 
won't bother neighbors or the local authorities.  There are 
17 people in my class so there needs to be enough sleeping 
space (i.e., floor space for sleeping bags) and a room large 
enough for all of us to sit on the floor in a circle.  Cooking 
facilities are a plus.

I really appreciate your thoughts and suggestions.

Bradley

Huh.  I play what I want to hear, yeah.  I started because of things I 
was hearing at parties, etc.  It was almost there, but it wasn't quite 
what I wanted to hear, close but not quite.
So I figured the only way to really hear what I wanted to hear was to 
play it.

I love to look up from the decks and see someone just lost in the music.  
It's that look that makes it worth all the money, the work, etc.  

It's fun, I like the instant gratification you get when it works, I'm 
much better at spinning than I am at actually making music (a 
realization that took me many years of making bad music), and it 
inspires me to make more music (bad or good, we'll have to see).

And I love when someone tells me that they liked something I played, 
just gives me a big ole warm fuzzy inside.

   mike
---64k---

Date: Tue, 28 Oct 1997 12:13:41 -0800
Subject: Re: To all the Djs out there....(This actually has text!)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


After being exposed to my first rave back in '92, I started to get into the
whole music side of things.  It wasn't until two years ago that I made the
investment and bought some decks and a mixer.  As somebody who studied
classic piano music for the past 20 years, I found an immediate connection
to the music of the underground.  I really don't know how to explain this
connection; it's very personnal and close to my soul.

Though I don't get too many opportunities to get out and spin, I really
enjoy those moments when you connect with people through the music.  The
most fun I usually have at parties is when I connect with others around me
through the music.  It's somehow spiritual, seeing others around you being
affected in the same manner as yourself.

Anyway, those are my few comments.  I could go one and one about this
topic, but I'll save the bandwith.

-Todd



From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Oct 28 20:18:21 1997

	Tue, 28 Oct 1997 12:18:22 PST
X-Originating-IP: [157.22.229.127]
From: "peter sandifer" <boomerangflip@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: To all the Djs out there....
Content-Type: text/plain
Date: Tue, 28 Oct 1997 12:18:22 PST
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

I want to be a healer.

Vertigo and I were talking about this last night.  I mentioned to him
that (for me personally) there is a superficial desire to be liked and 
admired.  Sometimes I find that I boast about the fact that I am a DJ.

But that isn't what makes me happy.  That just the shallow,
soulless part of me that hasn't fully healed yet.

This music is an incredible gift that has been dropped into the
master program.  I think that locked inside our DNA is a lot of 
really important information about where we've come from, and where
we're going.  The history of the Universe from start to finish.

I think that techno music is a key that opens door to all that
information.  Not the ONLY key, but one of many.    Vertigo said
he thinks it's sound that are souls hear when they're in transit.
Like when you bust a whippit and hear techno music, even when 
none is playing.

Being a DJ is like being the Keeper of the Gates between Here
and There.   "Come one in everybody, I have some secrets I want 
to share with you!"

I also think there is an incredible responsibility for the DJ.  To
carry the audience through the night smoothly  ( I say audience because
I'm an ambient DJ).  
One time,  this kid in LA sent me an email; he said, "I remember you! 
You're the guy who played Arlo Guthrie and sent my friend into a bad 
trip!"
It was weird to think about being responsible for someone's bad
trip.

As Vertigo pointed out last night, we have enormous potential to heal
ourselves with this music. That's the reward to being a DJ, for me.

for a little pre-shin dig. It is a room where as much noise can be made and complaints
are very rare. Essentially in the middle of an industrial area in a nice, safe section

before hand, let me know and I'll send you directions.

> > > ....time is a cruel thing.
> > >
> > > You might be an Xer if:
> > >
> > > You wore anything Izod, especially those windbreakers that folded
> > > up into a
> > > pouch you could wear around your waist.
> > >
> > > You remember when Jordache jeans were cool.
> > >
> > > In your fifth grade class picture, you're wearing an Izod shirt
> > > with the
> > > collar up
> > >
> > > You know, by heart, the words to any "Weird" Al Yankovic song
> > >
> > > The Brady Bunch movie brought back cool memories
> > >
> > > You ever rang someone's doorbell and said "Landshark".
> > >
> > > Three words: "Atari"  "IntelliVision" and "Coleco".   Sound
> > > familiar?
> > >
> > > You remember the days when "safe sex" meant "my parents are gone
> > > for the
> > > weekend"
> > >
> > > You remember "Friday Night Videos" before the days of MTV
> > >
> > > A predominant color in your childhood photos is "plaid"
> > >
> > > While in high school, you and all your friends discussed elaborate
> > > plans to
> > > get together again at the end of the century and play "1999" by
> > > Prince over
> > > and over again
> > >
> > > You remember when music that was labeled "alternative" really was
> > >
> > > You took family trips BEFORE the invention of the mini-van. You
> > > rode in the
> > > back of the station wagon and you faced the cars behind you.
> > >
> > > You've ever conversationally used the phrase "Jane, you ignorant
> > > slut."
> > >
> > > You watched HR Puffenstuff as a child, but now that you're older,
> > > you really
> > > understand that it would have been much better had you known about
> > > drugs at
> > > the time.
> > >
> > > You've recently horrified yourself by using any one of the
> > > following phases:
> > >  - "When I was younger"
> > >  - "When I was your age"
> > >  - "You know, back when..."
> > >
> > > Schoolhouse Rock played a HUGE part in how you actually learned
> > > the English
> > > language
> > >
> > > You're starting to view getting carded to buy alcohol as a GOOD
> > > thing,
> > >
> > > You ever dressed to emulate a person you saw in either a Duran
> > > Duran,
> > > Madonna,or Cyndi Lauper video
> > >
> > > The first time you ever kissed someone at a dance came during
> > > "Crazy for
> > > You" by Madonna
> > >
> > > You remember with pain the sad day when the Green Machine hit the
> > > streets
> > > and made your old Big Wheel quite obsolete.
> > >
> > > The phrase "Where's the beef?" still doubles you over with
> > > laughter.
> > >
> > > Honestly remember when film critics raved that no movie could ever
> > > possibly
> > > get better special effects than those in the movie TRON.
> > >
> > > (girls) you thought Sean Cassidy was "dreamy", lusted after "Ted,
> > > your
> > > ship's photographer" on the Love Boat
> > >
> > > You freaked out when you found that you now fall into the "26 -
> > > 50" age
> > > category on most questionnaires
> > >
> > > Your hair, at some point in time in the 80's, became something
> > > which can
> > > only be described by the phrase "I was experimenting"
> > >
> > > This timeline appropriately describes actual events in your life:
> > > Star Wars
> > > opens, you are still in single digit ages, and you think the
> > > creatures are
> > > WAY cool.  Empire Strikes Back opens, you are now in
> > > early double digit ages, and you are convinced that the special
> > > effects are
> > > much better, the characters are cool, and you want one of every
> > > collectible
> > > out there.  Return of the Jedi hits the theaters...you are now a
> > > teenager,

> > > Solo's butt.

> > >
> > > year-round wouldn't be such a bad

> > >

> > >

> > >

> > > the first

> > > decided it was
> > > pointless since Quincy got all the babes, anyway.

Message-Id: <199710282144.NAA17283@mom.hooked.net>
From: "Mr nStuff" <stuff@hooked.net>
To: <SFRaves@hyperreal.org>, <drek1@juno.com>
Subject: Re: Which do DJ's prefer?
Date: Tue, 28 Oct 1997 13:47:55 -0800
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal

Precedence: bulk

Just catch the break mang..

 You don't need be worrying about any sampling going on..
Although. I have thought of recording people live at the ravEs (back in the
day) and then playing selected samples during a set. "Hey, that was me. Did
you guys hear that? Your trippin"
 But... You should worry more about your mixers quality, rather than some
sampler built in strictly for commercial advantages. I love my
Numark1800x..Even though the x-fader goes out really fast. It seems to
bring out that THUMP, THUMP like at the ravEs nStuff.. Whenever I hear a
new mix tape.. It's almost like I can tell when there using a Numark or
not. But I am still only guessing.

 Hey, I was wondering.. I seem to have adapted a pretty special way of
cuing the records.. You know.. Even if the tempo's are dead on with one
another.. If the cue is slitely off, whatever record is trailing behind
will actually sound SLOWER than the other. I have noticed that this makes
novice spinners actually mess with there tempo, even though it is already
set right.
 But, I seem to have this ability to just touch one record or the other
and. Blam! The cue is istantly streightened out, and the mix goes on
forever untell one record runs out..blah blah blah..
 Now, I know you can't go hitting the record to much when your in the mix
but. This works really great when I am matching my tempo's in the
headphones. No more constant speeding up or slowing down of the tempo,
squeezing the turn stile (thumb blisters).. I just hit the record not
currently playing outside of the head phone, over & over while adjusting
the tempo. And when I don't have to adjust the tempo anymore. The beat is
perfectly matched (sometimes?) .... It's really cool. I find myself able to
match the beats within 5 to 10 second of throwing a new record on I have
not heard before.
 I just basically FORCE the beats to match everytime they go off, hit the
tempo alittle, if it goes off again, force the beats to match again, adjust
the tempo..And so on and so forth.. It really makes it more possible to
catch your breaks on time.


Gotta goto work though.
Anyone else use this forced beat match method?
Peaz.
Jeff

Well for me I personally like the Money, The chicks I
get, and Fame that I have received. heheheeh Now if
you believe that I have a bridge to sell ya!!

Well I enjoy it cause I love making people feel the
way the music makes me feel. I like to "Try" and take
you on a Mental Journey sometimes I feel like I am
taking people there other times I feel like I am not.
It is all about spreading the feeling of the music to
people. To have people come up and say hey you rocked
my world you played some great music. That is the
best payment to me!! My duty is to make people Smile
and Dance. I do see us as shamiens of Music. He do
hold the Keys as Boomer had metioned. 
Now for a few DJ facts:
1.) You rarely get chicks (Except some DJ's)
2.) UG DJ's rarely get paid or at least it is small
amounts that does not even cover rekkid costs at
least for me that is.
3.) It takes so F**king long to get even some what
known. I have been spinning for a long time and I am
know Barely getting known.

So I hope this little guide helps some wanabee DJ's
for the future.

Macadio (Mack-Audio)

I studied piano and voice for years as well. Since my
voice just isn't what it used to be, I find spinning
rekkids a great way to create. Besides, it beats the
hell out of watching TV at night, I come home from work
take a drag off the blunt and spin for a couple hours.

---Todd_Manley@notes.hds.eds.com wrote:
>
> 
> After being exposed to my first rave back in '92, I
started to get into the
> whole music side of things.  It wasn't until two
years ago that I made the
> investment and bought some decks and a mixer.  As
somebody who studied
> classic piano music for the past 20 years, I found
an immediate connection
> to the music of the underground.  I really don't
know how to explain this
> connection; it's very personnal and close to my soul.
> 
> Though I don't get too many opportunities to get
out and spin, I really
> enjoy those moments when you connect with people
through the music.  The
> most fun I usually have at parties is when I
connect with others around me
> through the music.  It's somehow spiritual, seeing
others around you being
> affected in the same manner as yourself.
> 
> Anyway, those are my few comments.  I could go one
and one about this
> topic, but I'll save the bandwith.

> -Todd

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


I've got an outboard sampler and I think it's a much better idea.  Most 
samplers that are built into mixers (I'm not saying all, but it might be 
all) do not have MIDI or extra output lines.  Why is this important?  
Well, the one day you decide to make some tracks and you want to use 
your sampler, you're screwed!  Of course, buying an outboard sampler may 
cost you a little bit more, but in the long term I think it's well worth 
it.

:)

From: Noah Apodaca <unclenoa@netcom.com>
Subject: Re: To all the Djs out there....
To: "Ravers 'Round the Bay" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9710281636.A28810-0100000@netcom9>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


I spin because I've always loved music in general.  I was trained in 
music theory and I learned how to play a bunch of instruments through 
private lessons and school.  But I always had this almost guilty love for 
electronic music (ever since I was a little Uncle Noah!).  
One of my goals when I went to college was to get a radio show so I could 
share music with folks.  Well, soon, I started realizing that I now had a 
perfect opportunity to get really deep into electronic music and that 
lead me into the rave scene.

I liked some psy-trance and some house, but that boom boom boom boom 
really got to me after a while.  Jungle seemed cool, but it was a little 
too frantic for me, so I started spinning breakbeat.  :)  It made me 
remember the old days of Adidas and cardboard and ghettoblasters on 
street corners.  I liked remembering that stuff.  Nowadays when I spin 
rekkids I'll see some kid breakin'.  That makes me happy.  

The thing about DJing for me is I'd be doing it no matter what.  I've 
always picked through the vinyl and found some stuff I thought was cool 
and then put it on for my friends.  The whole rave DJing thing is a way 
for me to share the tracks I've found with a larger group of people.  

And I have to agree with Macadio, it ain't about gettin ravergurlies and 
it sure as hell ain't about gettin $$!!! :D  If you want sex and money 
you better forget spinning records and go do something else! :D

Last night at ULTRA, Dara spun an amazing set, he got me groovin' for the
long haul.  Lots of breaks, different textures, thump-thumpety
syncopation.  I like when DJ's mix/sample in one tune interspersed
throughout their set, gives the set an mental aural image after its over.
He's spinning at Phunkatech on Wednesday and Eklektic on Thursday, check
it out if you get a chance.

This whole DJ thread is great.  Collectively, all you djs out there are
responsible for 100's of my hours for good times, soothing times,
visionary times, angsty times, the whole emotional gamut, ya know?  Well,
anyways, i enjoy hearing the dj perspectives, I hope you all will post
more about your dj experiences.  What about stories of powerful
connections between dj and dancer?  Anyways, here's a big thank you to the
masters of vinyl.

right round,
GEorgie

ooooohhhhhhhh....well I love to spin because when I do I get so into the
music that it is just like entering another world that I have created
myself....Everything around me doesn't exist for the time being and it is
like being in a trance....especially when the speakers and you can feel the
base going through your whole body. It brings peace to my mind and when I am
all done I take the tape that I just recorded and listen to it in my car as
my base thumps....and I get to experience the whole thing all over
again.....ahhhhhh the exitement of spinning....


                ***** Melissa or mushy   ********

a guy came up to me last week after my set and said ( almost verbatim , i

had that before. thanks."

>i want to make people dance. not cause they they like the songs i'm

the other day glittergirl@value.net wrote
>
>Bea, where is your trust in that which is silly and beautiful?  I have 
been
>properly chagrined on asking for a reason to dance, I do not need a 
reason
>to dance- anywhere, in line at Safeway, at work, on the bus.  Foolish

we

dance.

And My reply is:

Funny thing happened on monday, I woke up and decided it was time to do 
some laundry, so I put together a load of laundry and pop it in the 
washer, so I go about my day-off stuff and I decide to go check on the 
laundry.... just a moment... the point is coming up ..... Sure enough 
the load was a tad bit big so I start shifting the clothes a little to 
help and the washer starts giving off this combination bass and squeak
groove, So I listen to it for a few minutes and the next thing I know 
I'm dancing the the rhythm of the washing machine,which went on for 
several minutes. The moral of the story............. he he :^)...... If 
you've got the need to dance you can find a good beat anywhere, anytime!


Ivan Weiss
"I SAID TO INVEST IN SNAPPLE NOT APPLE!!!"

idw@hotmail.com

p.s. I really must get out more often! *B^)

From: DJBookings@aol.com
Message-ID: <971029120920_1202111895@emout07.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: MOBY 411
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

<< Moby has a new single out in October/November. It's a cover of the classic
 "James Bond Theme"; there are remixes by Danny Tenaglia, Grooverider, CJ
 Bolland, Dub Pistols, LSG, Oliver Lieb and Moby himself. It's out...
 
 in most of Europe: now.
 in the UK and Germany: November 3.
 in America: 12" out now, CD soon (ask your local record store).
 
 The video for the single  features Moby as an action hero leaping off
 buildings, dodging trains and fighting attackers, as well as clips from the
 new Bond movie, "Tomorrow Never Dies". It's picking up plays on MTV in
 America and Europe and has been playlisted on MTV UK. It's also being
 played on The Box in the UK and Europe - if you want to see more of it you
 can help by ringing the voting number and requesting it (watch The Box for
 details).
 
 Moby also has a new album, "I Like To Score". It's released in most of
 Europe and America now, and will be released in the UK and Germany on
 November 10. Tracklisting is:
 
 1       Novio
 2       James Bond Theme (Moby's re-version)
 3       Go
 4       Ah-Ah
 5       I Like To Score
 6       Oil 1
 7       New Dawn Fades
 8       God Moving Over The Face Of The Waters
 9       First Cool Hive
 10    Nash
 11     Love Theme
 12     Grace
 
 The album is a collection of Moby music from films such as Heat, Scream,
 Tomorrow Never Dies (the forthcoming Bond movie), The Saint, Cool World,
 Joe's Apartment, Space Water Onion (an indie film made by one of Moby's
 friends) and from his first ever full film score, Double Tap. Double Tap
 was made for America's HBO TV channel but it might get a cinema release in
 some countries.
 
 NEWS
 ** Moby has recently recorded a track - "Tiny Rubberband" - with the
 Butthole Surfers for the Spawn soundtrack, out now. He's got another song,
 "Shining", on the soundtrack to the forthcoming movie "The Jackal", and
 several more of his tracks are due for inclusion on soundtracks soon. More
 info as we get it. He's also recorded a version of The Clash's "Straight To
 Hell" with Heather Nova; that's included on a Clash soundtrack album (not
 sure if it's out yet - sorry!)
 
 ** He may help on a couple of tracks for the new Guns 'n' Roses album, but
 unfortunately doesn't have the time to produce the whole thing, And, as he
 recently said, "Working with Guns 'n' Roses every day for nine or ten
 months might well drive me insane. I like them and we get along well, but
 it's bad enough spending all that time with myself..."
 
 ** He recently met Bono from U2, who told him that reading the sleevenotes
 to Moby's "Animal Rights" album meant more to him than seeing The Clash in
 1977...
 
 ** Moby is currently working on his next album proper, due for release in
 late1998. The first single from that album will hopefully be released in
 the spring.
 
 ** Moby will be touring America in November and December. Unfortunately we
 don't have the dates yet, so if you live in the US check out your local
 press/radio. As & when we get the dates we will forward them to you.
 
 EUROPE
 Moby performed the "James Bond Theme" on France's Nulle Part Ailleurs on
 October 28, and will be doing a live DJ mix of his own records on Fun Radio
 (Paris) at about 1700 on Wednesday 29. He's doing an interview for a French
 internet magazine - it should soon be up at
 http://www.club-internet.fr/rencontres/ (no doubt in French). He will also
 perform live on Ireland's Late Late Show this Friday (31st Oct)and DJ on
 Radio Ireland at 1am on Friday night/Saturday morning.
 
 MERCHANDISE
 We have lots of official Moby merchandise available, including some new I
 LIKE TO SCORE t-shirts. Please e-mail us if you would like a list (e-mail)
 or catalogue (snail mail). However, bear in mind that we're based in the UK
 and only accept payments in UK pounds - UK cheque or postal order,
 Eurocheque, international money order or cash (by registered post). No
 credit card orders - sorry. If you live in the US you can write to MCT
 Productions Inc, 333 West 532nd St, Suite 1003, New York NY 10012 for a
 catalogue of US merchandise. You can also check out
 http://www.rise.co.uk/underworld/ - they have some t-shirts which can be
 ordered by credit card. Keep checking the site as it's due to be updated
 soon.
 
 BACKCATALOGUE
 All of Moby's releases on Mute Records (and some posters) can be obtained
 from MuteBank:
 http://www.mutelibtech.com/mute/
 E-mail mutebank@mutelibtech.com
 Mail: send SAE or IRC to Mute Bank Mail Order, 429 Harrow Road, London W10
 4RE, UK
 Tel: +44 (0) 181 964 0029
 Fax: +44 (0) 181 964 3722
 
 You'll probably find MuteBank to be the cheapest and most reliable source
 of old Moby records, although they only have their own UK releases. They're
 more modern than us & do take credit card orders.
 
 
 Finally, apologies to those of you outside Europe; we're based in the UK
 and it's very hard for us to keep track of what's going on in America and
 beyond. Your best bet for keeping up-to-date with Moby news is to subscribe
 to the unofficial Moby discussion list, Mobility. To subscribe, send a
 message to:
 
 majordomo@xmission.com
 
 with the following text as the message body:
 
 subscribe mobility
 
 Leave the subject blank.
 
 
 You can also check out the following web site:
 
 http://www.moby.org/
 
 
 Bye for now
 
 DEF
 
 
 -------------------------
 "Is that Selma? Ring-a-ding-ding!"

Subj:	 Moby Update - October 1997

Moby has a new single out in October/November. It's a cover of the classic
"James Bond Theme"; there are remixes by Danny Tenaglia, Grooverider, CJ
Bolland, Dub Pistols, LSG, Oliver Lieb and Moby himself. It's out...

in most of Europe: now.
in the UK and Germany: November 3.
in America: 12" out now, CD soon (ask your local record store).

The video for the single  features Moby as an action hero leaping off
buildings, dodging trains and fighting attackers, as well as clips from the
new Bond movie, "Tomorrow Never Dies". It's picking up plays on MTV in
America and Europe and has been playlisted on MTV UK. It's also being
played on The Box in the UK and Europe - if you want to see more of it you
can help by ringing the voting number and requesting it (watch The Box for
details).

Moby also has a new album, "I Like To Score". It's released in most of
Europe and America now, and will be released in the UK and Germany on
November 10. Tracklisting is:

1       Novio
2       James Bond Theme (Moby's re-version)
3       Go
4       Ah-Ah
5       I Like To Score
6       Oil 1
7       New Dawn Fades
8       God Moving Over The Face Of The Waters
9       First Cool Hive
10    Nash
11     Love Theme
12     Grace

The album is a collection of Moby music from films such as Heat, Scream,
Tomorrow Never Dies (the forthcoming Bond movie), The Saint, Cool World,
Joe's Apartment, Space Water Onion (an indie film made by one of Moby's
friends) and from his first ever full film score, Double Tap. Double Tap
was made for America's HBO TV channel but it might get a cinema release in
some countries.

Butthole Surfers for the Spawn soundtrack, out now. He's got another song,
"Shining", on the soundtrack to the forthcoming movie "The Jackal", and
several more of his tracks are due for inclusion on soundtracks soon. More

Hell" with Heather Nova; that's included on a Clash soundtrack album (not
sure if it's out yet - sorry!)

** He may help on a couple of tracks for the new Guns 'n' Roses album, but
unfortunately doesn't have the time to produce the whole thing, And, as he
recently said, "Working with Guns 'n' Roses every day for nine or ten
months might well drive me insane. I like them and we get along well, but
it's bad enough spending all that time with myself..."

** He recently met Bono from U2, who told him that reading the sleevenotes
to Moby's "Animal Rights" album meant more to him than seeing The Clash in
1977...

late1998. The first single from that album will hopefully be released in

credit card orders - sorry. If you live in the US you can write to MCT
Productions Inc, 333 West 532nd St, Suite 1003, New York NY 10012 for a
catalogue of US merchandise. You can also check out
http://www.rise.co.uk/underworld/ - they have some t-shirts which can be
ordered by credit card. Keep checking the site as it's due to be updated
soon.

BACKCATALOGUE
All of Moby's releases on Mute Records (and some posters) can be obtained
from MuteBank:
http://www.mutelibtech.com/mute/
E-mail mutebank@mutelibtech.com
Mail: send SAE or IRC to Mute Bank Mail Order, 429 Harrow Road, London W10
4RE, UK
Tel: +44 (0) 181 964 0029
Fax: +44 (0) 181 964 3722

You'll probably find MuteBank to be the cheapest and most reliable source
of old Moby records, although they only have their own UK releases. They're
more modern than us & do take credit card orders.>>

From: "Digital Devil" <raf_one@hotmail.com>

Subject: Re: To all the Djs out there....
Content-Type: text/plain
Date: Wed, 29 Oct 1997 10:45:07 PST

The feeling when  that build up just drops and takes over everything 
including yourself. IS  why I love to DJ. The first time someone breaks 
in a record and just floors the party. or when you're at the record 
store and you find that piece of vinyl you've been chasing forever or 
discover that jem you've never heard anyone play out before. Or that 
mixtaqpe that puts you in the right mood. Even tho Djing can be a VERY 
EXPENSIVE, time consuming, habit. You got to have your priorites 
straight and love it for what it is. Getting to play out is a mix of who 
you know, having the skills, promotion and preserverance. There is so 
much competion-even doing it yourself (throwing your own parties) is as 
expensive and risky as ever (PROPS to thos e that continue) In the end 
you have what  you started with-The Music..this is the bottom line (at 
least on my screen).--(DJ) Raf  (One)

On Wed, 29 Oct 1997, Mike Robinson wrote:
> 
> As an extension of this thread, whats the best/worst/strangest comment 
> you've ever gotten after/while playing?
> 

Best Comment for Chill/Ambient/Trip Hop:	

Ethan Miller after my chill set at 4x4 "So er... what do you call that?"
He then went out of his way to indicate that he meant that in the best
possible way... I think I might have overdone the "art factor" on that
set...

Any time people spontaneously start making out or stop talking, or several
people suddenly open their eyes, look at each other, smile, and go back
into their heads to wander around some more in their spaces comfortable
and confident.

Best Comment for Dance Sets:

Eyes rolling into back of sockets and going into the "I don't know if it's
the drugs or the music or what but I am elevated and very happy dance"

The stomp dance, where they have given up on thinking about dancing, and
are now going into tribal mode... doing what feels best as opposed to a
cohesive dance that might look better.  Actually, I think most dance DJs
go off when they see people just go apeshit.

Like... I love it when people can't talk after a set, and they try anyway,
and they finally give up, blab something that sounds like "Thank You" and
proceed to give a very good hug.  Suddenly, your records cost nothing,
they spin themselves and you ask yourself what you could have possibly
done to deserve it.  That's the one that keeps me beaming for about two or
three weeks afterwards.

Worst Comment:

I guess there are multiple ties...

1. Someone came up during a set and said "why are you doing this to me?" 

2. Someone asked me if I had any Happy Hardcore during an ambient set. 

3. Someone asked me if I thought whale sounds should qualify as music, or
if was just trying to be "trippy" (the track playing at the time was FSOL
Lifeforms band 2, a track that I would consider gorgeous by any
standards).

Secret Fear:

Deck Divers

Peace,
AndyW

>>whats the best/worst/strangest comment you've ever gotten after/while 
playing?

> and turn off the damn fog machine, i can hardly breathe!!!"


yes, these are always the best!  usually made by newbies. Kind of cute
and innocent.  It's like the dj is 
that Mary Poppins guy, spinning records with his hands while running the 
rest of
the show with his feet.

  can you dim the lights a little?  
  it's too hot in here!
  can  I go out to my car for just a second???
  
At a Ghostribe party:
Nice sound system! where did you get it?

And the absolute best comment;  from this happy goofball who was
psyched to be at his first rave ( i think Love Affair), leaned over 
the mixer and said

  o  What are you doing?
  o  Playin records.  
  o  Oh.  Can I flick this this switch on and off?

I DJ BECAUSE  I DONT DO DRUGS AND SPINNING GIVES ME A HIGH LIKE NOTHING
ELSE WHEN IM AT PARTY AND IM PLAYING AND I SEE PEOPLE DANCING TO THIE MUSIC
I PUT ON AND GOING ON THE TRIP I SELECT FOR THEM IT FEELS GREAT. I LOVE
EVRYTHING ABOUT IT , I LOVE THE FEELINF OF GOING TO THE RECORD STORE AND
SPENDING WAY TOO  MUCH MONEY AND THEN GOING STRAINGHT HOME AND MIXING THEM
ALL TOGETHER OVER AND OVER. I LOVE SHOWING OFF AT A PARTY AND  SCRATCHING.
I LOVE WHEN SOMEONE CHEERS AND I REALIZE ITS FOR ME . AND MOST OF ALL I
LOVE THE MUSIC  BECAUSE I WAS A DANCER/RAVER B4 I STARTED DJING  AND MY
LOVE OF MUSIC ,DANCE ANDALL DAT GOOD STUFF HASNT GONE NEWHERE OK?
RESPECT AND LOVE, MOSHE(PS HI REGAN)

It occurs to me to actually answer my own question...

Best comment (for trip hop/chill/ambient/noise...)
 - Was that the music, or me?
 - I think it was the music...

Looking up from the decks to see a bunch of sleeping people smiling.


Worst (maybe best, I dunno...)
 - That was really scary, I'm glad I'm sober...

The same morning as the best sleeping thing...
Looking up again to see someone's eyes open, and the MOST frightened 
look I have ever seen lock onto their face.

comment 
>> you've ever gotten after/while playing?
>> 
>1. Someone came up during a set and said "why are you doing this to 
me?" 

Ouch.

mike

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Mon, 27 Oct 1997 16:27:12 +1000 (EST)
From: Kath Williamson <bigk@it.uq.edu.au>
To: taz@mystical.org
Subject: TAZ: Coroner's Inquest - Ecstasy (MDMA) & Ritonavir (Norvir) Interaction 


---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: PRIDE <pride@geko.net.au>
Reply-To: ausgblf@queer.org.au

A Year ago, my boyfriend - Philip Kay, died from an overdose of MDMA.  I
knew that he had only taken 2 1/2 tablets of E at  most, yet plasma
levels showed the equivalent to 22 tablets.  I suspected an interaction
with Ritonavir and with the help of the Terrence Higgins Trust, had the
original Coroner's Inquest adjourned whilst this was investigated.
After two hearings, on 15th October 1997, after examining the evidence
presented, and following conversations with Abbott Laboratories UK, the
Coroner found the following:
Interaction
That Philip had taken only 2 1/2 tablets, and that there had been a
ten-fold increase in MDMA levels in Phil's blood, and that this had been
caused by an interaction between the MDMA and Ritonavir - the Ritonavir
having effected the way in which his body metabolised the MDMA;
Window Of Danger
That there exists a Window-Of-Danger, a period of particular danger
immediately following Ritonavir's dosing-up-schedule, when the CYP2D6
pathway in the liver which is responsible for metabolising both
Ritonavir and ecstasy was almost completely blocked as it metabolised
the Ritonavir.  During this period, other substances using the pathway
are left in the blood and could build up to potentially dangerous or
fatal levels;
Warning
That patients deserved to be warned of the interaction and that Abbott
Laboratories plea that to warn of the interaction would be tantamount to
condoning illegal drug use was unacceptable;
That the Court could see no reason why a clear and specific warning
could not be put on the packaging.
Further Action
On this point, using her powers under Rule 43 of the Coroner's Rules,
the Coroner is sending the case up to the Committee on Safety of
Medicines for further action.  Dr, John Henry (UK's Leading Expert on
Ecstasy)to investigate further and write case up in British Medical
Journal.
I have a longer version of the above giving details of the background,
the evidence, the verdict and my thanks.  To obtain a copy, please mail
me on jim-phil@dircon.co.uk.  
Best wishes 
Jim Lumb

So my 2nd cousin from LA calls me up and asks me to pick up an exchange
student from Africa and have her stay with me for a night or two. I tell
her no problem but that I plan to go out on Fri night (to either Happy
Kids and/or FTT.) She wonders if I would want to bring her with me. This
girl is 15 ("going on 20" my cousin says) and is sort of a 'chosen
delegate' for a world youth conference in S.F. Thats about all I know.

Should I take this girl with me to a party? My thinking right now is
probably not. But I thought I'd throw it out here to you guys. What do
you think? I like the idea of showing her the awsome expierence that a
rave can be. But the drug element worries me. Not that I think she'll
take anything. But what would she think? This "world youth conference
delegate"?

-=Pengo=-

I'd personally take her.

Four years ago while a sr. in h.s., we'd take this Romanian guy who was 
on the basketball team.

It was a really neat experience for him because he had gone to parties 
like ours back in his native homeland.

The usual thing would be for him to climb a tree b4 he went in.

Pretty strange guy!

As graduation took place, I could remember him say:

"Now I can tell my friends back home I went to a rave in San Francisco, 
Berkeley, and Richmond!"

Much love and increase the serene environment.. Mr. E

Foreign exchange students often come to different countries  to see how 
it is, Youth delegates, of all people, or whatever, would be more 
interested in finding out what goes on with students/people/thingies in 
other countries, I would think.  By taking this person to a rave, She 
would have a bit more knowledge as to what we do out here and what  
other people do in other countries...a learning experience.  You totally 
should inform her about the drug scene.  Tell her everything that you 
know about raves, and The United States Of America.  If President 
Clinton inhaled, I would take him to a party too, but he didn't.  :(
bAByHueY

Just in case that Happy Kidz doesn't get a location, I think that 
instead of lagging, and being lost souls we should all plan something.  
What should happen, I do not know.  Well, that isn't all that true.  In 
Santa Cruz, My dad says "that it is like a normle day down there but all 
the normal people stay home"-fun,  Castro is always fun.  I can't afford 
the Tribal Massive though...just thought that it might be fun to do 
something, other than raving on Halloween (if happy kids...)
Camping with lots of blankets in my foresty backyard, being plurilistic 
and throw pumpkins at adults, or we can steal candy from 
trick-o-tweekers so we can give it all out at our next party.  :P
Any more ideas?
Peace,
bAByHuey

P.S.
Last year when I went trick or treatin'  I would say to all the peeps
"Trick-or Slinky?" then they would proceed to kick me in the knees and 
o    say "You're too old to trick or treat," 
 o   
  o o0 o0  And I would reply hastily, "No, I'm not!..."
   0  O  o then I would leave, and be really mad for the rest of the 
          O
day.  I'd also look at my calendar and realize that I was 
trick-or-treating a week early.  I just don't understand 
holidays...hmmm?  :P

On Wed, 29 Oct 1997, Mike Robinson wrote:

> As an extension of this thread, whats the best/worst/strangest comment 
> you've ever gotten after/while playing?
> 

I once had a bloke come up to me and in a thick thick English accent he 
said, "I'm here visiting from England and I go home in the morning and I 
was wondering if you could play some four-beat for me?"

I said, "I'm sorry, I'm a breakbeat DJ... this is all I've got."
:D

rarely do i find a compliation cd that i appreciate as much as the vinyl
itself, but if you love deep trance, you've got to check out "northern
exposure 2" put together by sasha and john digweed.  it's the stuff dreams
are made of.  pretty pricey, coming all the way from the island...but what
is money when you can have this musik to live by.   :)

btw...i'm, of course, not affiliated with said label, just thought i'd
share this find, if anyone is interested.

Hey!
I know exactly what you mean!
College kinda kicks your ass though! Especially taking Organic Chemistry
and Calculus 1b (or BC for highschool calc, but it's different) together
with another class, trying to work at least twenty
hours a week (which ends up being my weekends usually) and trying to do
homework! Then my mom gets mad because I never come visit her and my
friends think I don't want to hang out with them because I need to do
homework.
UGGGG! Boy do i know!

So how do I manage my time. Just go witht he flow and don't trip on the
shit I need to do cause then I would go crazy- literally. So just think of
the now and what needs to be now. Yes procrastination is what I am doing
now while I should be sleeping for my midterm tomorrow but just get out of
the house and into a cafe or library. You will get so much mroe done. I
swear!
Well that's about it, hope it helps!


 Shira

10 years ago. All they played on the radio was house
and early techno.

careful on the northern exposure cd. i was only mostly-dead coming back
from burningman and my friend passed this disk forward. it was fucking
purr-fekt so of course i asked what it was - sasha n digweed's
nexposure. fine. next week when i finally wake up i buy it. but it's not
the same fucking cd. i take my gripe to my friend; you told me to get
the wrong disk and what's more i don't like most of it... too house.
turns out that the *import* is a double disk set, and the second disk,
unavailable in our watered down domestic market is the one I WANTED...
arrrggh!
